fields.headline: Cuba's Edith Piaf
fields.standfirst:
Omara Portuondo
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Omara Portuondo
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Anyone who has seen the Wim Wenders film Buena Vista Social Club will remember its only female star, Omara Portuondo, as a dry-witted counterpoint to the dreamlike scenes of Havana street life. Unlike the other Buena Vista musicians, who had been forgotten or undiscovered until the film, she had been famous all along, dubbed Cuba's Edith Piaf for her torchy renditions of Cuban standards.

Despite making numerous albums since the 50s and representing Cuba at a communist version of Eurovision in 1967, it took Buena Vista and its 3m-selling album to get her to the Festival Hall for her first London solo show. And yet her music should be performed in a club, preferably after midnight, when the London audience is far enough gone to have acquired a sense of rhythm. Here, attempts to bossa nova merely produced a self-conscious lateral sway. Presumably Portuondo, simultaneously glamourous and motherly in twinkling black and orange, is used to the gracelessness of northerly countries, because she beamed tolerantly. But I'd have given a lot to know what she said to the Spanish-speaking segment of the crowd that made them laugh so heartily.

The evening was weighted in favour of up-tempo mambos, boleros and "filin", or feeling, the jazzed-up style she has made her own. With typical Latin floridness, she has been christened the Fiancée of Filin, which becomes self-explanatory on the likes of El Hombre Que Yo Ame, otherwise known as the Gershwins' The Man I Love. Her still-resonant voice was bittersweet and stoic, the dandyish brass section rippled sympathetically and the place was united in dreamy rapture.

fields.headline: ICI faces 'pollution' protest
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Environmental protesters donned protective clothing and brandished sparkling "time bombs" outside ICI's annual meeting yesterday. The campaigners, from Friends of the Earth, told shareholders that the chemicals company's record on pollution was "appalling".
fields.body:
Environmental protesters donned protective clothing and brandished sparkling "time bombs" outside ICI's annual meeting yesterday. The campaigners, from Friends of the Earth, told shareholders that the chemicals company's record on pollution was "appalling".

They cited a recent toxic leak from an ICI site near Runcorn, in Cheshire, in which dozens of people had to leave their homes.

The protest's organiser, Mike Childs, called for a comprehensive report disclosing the location and contents of all ICI's dumps. Inside the meeting, he questioned ICI's chairman, Charles Miller Smith.

Friends of the Earth said: "ICI tend to spend an awful lot of time defending their old chemicals. They should use the money developing new ones which are more environmentally friendly."

An ICI spokesman said that the company had been at the forefront of environmental reporting since the early 1990s. She said: "There were about a dozen protesters and they were extremely orderly. I hope all that gear kept them dry because it wasn't a very nice morning."

ICI announced an 84% rise in first-quarter pre-tax profits to £90m but its shares fell 41.25p to 550p.

fields.headline: Protect yourself from the cyber-pirates
fields.trailText: Online finance gives you enormous freedom - you can deal when and where you like. But how do you know whether your personal details are being kept safely?
fields.body:
Online finance gives you enormous freedom - you can deal when and where you like. But how do you know whether your personal details are being kept safely?

Stories of 15-year-olds hacking into accounts are becoming all too common and their effects are all too real. Your fortune could evaporate into cyberspace.

When you sign up with an online dealer they should tell you, under the Data Protection Act, whether they intend to pass your details on to a third party, and give you the option to deny their request to do so. They may or may not give you the option of being removed from mailing lists for information about their products and services.

Some investment sites send out daily bulletins telling you the day's news and features. You can ask to "unsubscribe" from this. When signing up, check for boxes that allow you to opt out of any other mailing service.

Once signed up, you will be sent a confirmation of your username, the first bit of information you give when you log in. You also need to remember your password.

When you go to a site and log in to a secure area the location address at the top of the site should change.

The beginning of the address, which usually reads "http://" should change to "https://" to indicate you have switched into a protected zone.

If you are using Microsoft Internet Explorer or Netscape Navigator on a PC or Mac, a small padlock icon should appear in the bottom righthand corner of your screen.

You have to use whatever internet defences there are, and and ask companies about their compensation policy if thieves worm their way into secure areas.

Paul Lubbock, at DLJdirect, the online broker, advises:

 Change your password frequently. This is a difficult habit to get into but it is a good security measure.

 Log out when you have finished your session. Don't leave your computer terminal unattended while you are still logged on.

 Try not to let people look over your shoulder when you are conducting a transaction.

 Treat e-commerce as you would credit-card transactions - don't hand out personal information and be sure you know who you are dealing with.

 Keep a record of transactions. Most sites give you confirmation of this on screen and you can print out the details. Others send you confirmation in the post.

John Hughes, acting chief technical officer of Entegrity Solutions, said hackers can spoof a website to make it look like it belongs to a well-known company. "Consumers should check carefully before they make an online transaction. Make sure you know who you are dealing with and that you have visited the site before," he says.

"Beware of spelling mistakes when inputting the address of the website. Hackers can register common misspellings of well-known companies as domain names."

fields.headline: Every net must have holes
fields.trailText: The web's image as a surefire money-saver is looking a little tarnished. Despite promised benefits, not everything is cheaper and better online.
fields.body:
The internet revolution has foundered a little in recent weeks - and not just for lastminute.com shareholders and tech investors.

The web's image as a surefire money-saver is looking a little tarnished. Take credit cards and personal loans. Despite promised benefits, not everything is cheaper and better online: loan and credit cards provided by traditional means can be better value than those exclusively on the net.

Last year the Consumers' Association estimated that heavy credit card users could each save up to £300 a year by switching to better-value cards. Indeed, it calculated that if everyone with a credit card switched to the handful that topped its best-buy tables, they would save a total of £4m a day in interest and annual fees. A staggering sum.

Last year saw the heavily advertised launch of Britain's first full service internet-only bank, Smile. An offshoot of the Co-operative Bank, Smile features in best-buy charts for both credit cards and loans. Even at the bank's standard rate of 12.9%, it is competitive.

The Marbles credit card, issued by HFC Bank, is another good internet deal with a standard rate of 14.9% and a tempting introductory teaser of 5.9%.

But both are edged out by Egg, whose Visa card offers a rate of 10.9% APR; a deal only available over the net.

But it's not the best, according to Moneyfacts. That accolade goes to Northern Rock with a standard credit-card rate of 10.5% APR. It is not a web-exclusive card.

Teaser rates that tempt you to transfer balances to other cards will be attractive to those seeking to give their finances a long-promised fresh start. The introductory rates offered by Marbles, Smile and Egg - which charges 4.9% APR on balance transfers for the first six months - are beaten by Capital One Bank's premier Visa which offers a rate of 3.9% for the first six months. Capital One's card can be run over the phone.

When it comes to loans the net also fails to turn up the best deals. If you are looking to borrow more than £5,000, Smile will charge you 9.9% APR for a three-year loan, if you take insurance.

Lloyds TSB, which also offers loans over the net, charges 12.8% APR for the same size loan - whether you take out repayment insurance or not. As insurance can be expensive, the Lloyds deal is cheaper.

Neither can match an offer from a bricks and mortar lender. Northern Rock charges 8.8% APR on a £5,000 loan and doesn't ask you to take out insurance.

Your monthly repayments would be £157.75 without insurance or £180.41 with. Northern Rock's is a rate that is available to telephone customers, too.

Banks offering customers cards and/or loans over the net include Lloyds TSB (www.loan-direct.co.uk); Marbles (www.marbles.com); Egg (www.egg.com); Smile (www.smile.co.uk); and Royal Bank of Scotland (www.rbs.co.uk).

The best of the rest include Northern Rock (0845 605 0808) and Capital One Bank (0800 952 5355).

fields.headline: Take account of high interest
fields.standfirst: Jill Papworth says it pays to switch to internet banking while it's still client-hungry
fields.trailText: Jill Papworth says it pays to switch to internet banking while it's still client-hungry.
fields.body:
Savers with less than £5,000 have little reason to look at high street banks and building societies. The top rates on £1 plus in a straightforward instant access account, with no restrictions on the number and size of withdrawals you make each year, come from internet banks.

Egg, set up by the Prudential, is paying a flat 6.3% gross on all balances to a maximum £250,000. Dublin-based first-e, which is outside Britain's bank consumer protection scheme, is paying 6.31%.

These rates compare with an average instant access gross rate on the high street of around 1.51%, according to Moneyfacts - and many of these require higher minimum deposits or impose withdrawal restrictions.

So should we all be switching to internet banking? The answer has to be a qualified yes. It's cheaper for banks to run internet-based savings accounts - estimated to be around a 10th of the cost of running a branch network and a quarter that of running a call centre-based operation. So banks can afford to pass on savings.

This means savers can expect very competitive and, in many instances, chart-topping rates from internet-only savings accounts.

But it does not mean that over the long term you can expect bank rate-busting interest levels like those on offer from Egg and first-e. These rates are loss leaders to attract customers to new internet banks. And once a big enough customer base has been built, they will fall to a more realistic level.

"At the moment, our internet-only savings account rate is positioned to acquire customers," says an Egg spokesperson.

Egg has built up some 600,000 savings customers. Its rival, first-e, has as yet a smaller customer base. Its declared aim is to get 200,000 customers across Europe by the end of the year. It is still very much in the growth stage, so it is not likely to drop its loss leader rate just yet.

But the choice of high-interest internet-only savings accounts is still surprisingly limited, though more are expected to come on stream over the next few months.

Virtually all high-street banks and building societies now have their own internet websites, and many of the larger institutions, including Lloyds TSB, NatWest, Barclays, Halifax and Nationwide, now offer online banking to their customers. But very few offer separate internet-only accounts.

The notable exception is the Co-op Bank's Smile, offering a full range of internet-only banking products, including the only internet-exclusive cash Isa, which pays 6.75%. Smile pays 4.5% gross on its savings account, plus a 1% bonus, bringing the current rate up to 5.5% if you are also a Smile current account holder.

Aside from these three existing internet banks, just five other institutions - the Royal Bank of Scotland, and four building societies, Norwich & Peterborough, Skipton, Lambeth and Market Harborough - currently offer an internet-only savings product.

There are high-interest alternatives, although these come with restrictions. Northern Rock's base rate tracker account, paying 6.5% gross on £1 plus, is the only one to beat Egg's and first-e's rates on smaller balances, but holders are allowed no more than six withdrawals a year and minimum transactions of £250.

For those with a deposit of £5,000 or more, Bristol & West's postal and telephone account Call One, paying a flat 6.55% gross on £5,000, does offer a better deal, though this rate includes a 1% bonus only guaranteed until June 1.

fields.headline: Cruising without mysteries
fields.standfirst: Jenne Mannion reports on the websites that help investors navigate in murky waters
fields.trailText: The growth of the internet has revolutionised private investment by pushing down dealing costs through online execution and delivering to consumers a smorgasbord of financial tools and information previously the domain of professionals.
fields.body:
The growth of the internet has revolutionised private investment by pushing down dealing costs through online execution and delivering to consumers a smorgasbord of financial tools and information previously the domain of professionals.

An endless range of financial websites means the private investor can now construct a portfolio online, receive share price alerts, obtain real-time price quotes, use bulletin boards to initiate or contribute to discussion on the market, and monitor company news.

Even the more specialised components of this information, such as the real-time price quotes, are free if the user knows where to look. The sheer volume of these services, however, means that sifting through the numerous sites to obtain the best information and tools has become a major challenge in itself.

If looking for bulletin boards, where investors share thoughts or ask questions, leading sites are Interactive Investor International (www.iii.co.uk), Motley Fool (www.fool.co.uk), Hemscott (www.hemscott.co.uk) and Market Eye (www.market-eye.co.uk). Motley Fool and Interactive Investor tend to attract the newer investor, while Market Eye and Hemscott appeal to the more sophisticated trader - although none are proof against users "ramping" stocks by giving unwarranted recommendations, or the unscrupulous individuals who "pump" worthless shares and "dump" them on novices.

Interactive Investor's discussion boards are easy to use in that they are linked to the individual's portfolio. Therefore if the investor holds a particular share, for example Marks & Spencer, they can directly access discussion on this stock.

Interactive Investor is also considered the leader in terms of offering online portfolios, which enable users to monitor a list of their investments. Michael Scott, author of the UK Guide to Online Investing, says: "Most sites offer a portfolio facility for equities, but Interactive Investor has invested in a computer program which can also provide current performance of unit trusts, investment trusts and individual savings accounts. Most other sites offer a portfolio service which tracks only equities. So that can be quite restrictive."

Most sites offering the portfolio service offer links to a range of online brokers as well as other financial product providers, where the investor can purchase Isas, pensions, unit trusts, investment trusts, insurance and mortgages online. A common feature of many sites is the fantasy or virtual portfolio, so aspiring investors can dabble in the share market without committing money.

Free stock price alerts is a relatively new and attractive feature among sites including Interactive Investor and Digital Look (www.digitallook.co.uk). Alerts are linked to the user's portfolio and an instruction is issued to send an email if a stock increases or falls by a certain level.

Price or stock quote information is generally offered with a 15-minute delay. Interactive Investor recently introduced a £5 a month service accessing real-time information. There is little need to pay this small sum, as UK Invest and Freequotes (www.freequotes.co.uk) offer this free of charge.

UK Invest offers a unique function. The private investor can use Java charts which enable the setting of a time period for monitoring performance. Investors can monitor a price from the day they bought the shares.

Many sites offer news, but the leaders are Bloomberg (www.bloomberg.co.uk), Market Eye and Freequotes. A final useful site for working around all this information is Investment Gateway (www.investment-gateway.com), enabling users to direct themselves into their area of interest.

webTitle: Internet bank gets Egg on its face again

fields.headline: Internet bank gets Egg on its face again
fields.standfirst: A good interest rate was offered - but £20 becoming £303,000 in a matter of weeks was too good to be true, reports Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: A good interest rate was offered - but £20 becoming £303,000 in a matter of weeks was too good to be true, reports Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
Egg, the internet bank, has apologised to a saver after his account was wrongly credited with more than £300,000 of phantom cash. Simon Bunn, 32, opened his account just over a month ago. He was keen to save £20 a month into it and filled in a direct debit form so that this amount would be regularly transferred from his main bank account.

On April 12, when he logged on to check the £20 had gone in, he was "flabbergasted" to see just over £303,000 sitting in his account.

Mr Bunn sat there trying to work out what on earth had happened. Then it dawned on him that the figure paid in was the same as his main bank account number. What seemed to have happened was that the person processing his direct debit form had mistakenly keyed his account number into the value field instead of inputting "£20".

"In the end I realised it was not 'real money' - it didn't come from someone's account. It was just a silly mistake really. But it was annoying. I was up until the early hours fretting over it, thinking 'What am I going to do?' All kinds of things were going through my mind.

"I sent them an email to say 'What's happening?' "

Egg took the money out of his account on April 13. As the £303,000 had sat there for four days, Mr Bunn argued he should receive four days' worth of interest on this amount - about £200 - as a reward for his promptness in reporting the mistake. Instead, Egg offered him £20, which he accepted.

"They did apologise. They said they were glad I'd realised," says Mr Bunn, of Worthing, West Sussex, who works in the finance depart ment of a marketing company. "However, if they are going to make a silly mistake with an amount that large, they should face some kind of penalty charge." webTitle: Friends fail to close doors on carpetbaggers

fields.headline: Friends fail to close doors on carpetbaggers
fields.trailText: Friends Provident, the third largest mutual life office after Standard Life and Equitable Life, is the next target for internet-based carpetbaggers seeking windfalls of up to £5,000 - and it has not yet closed its doors to new members.
fields.body:
Friends Provident, the third largest mutual life office after Standard Life and Equitable Life, is the next target for internet-based carpetbaggers seeking windfalls of up to £5,000 - and it has not yet closed its doors to new members.

This week a website (www.fpvote.co.uk) opened to collect the 100 signatures needed to force Friends Provident to ballot its 750,000 members on converting to a stockmarket company. Analysts pencil in a floatation value of around £4bn, which dished out between its members, would result in average payouts of around £5,000.

While Standard Life and Scottish Provident, also under siege, have closed their doors to new membership accounts, Friends Provident has not. You can buy a new Friends Provident regular savings plan for just £35 per month, or a lump-sum investment bond for £3,000, according to finanical advisers Chartwell Investment Management of Bath. Both products are invested in the with-profits fund, which means that the saver is almost guaranteed a pay out if the mutual converts.

But is it worth it? The headline figures of huge pay outs will be reserved for investors who have been putting £100 a month into a personal pension for the last 20 years. So those who jump on the bandwagon this week may see only a payout of a few hundred pounds - and they may have to wait two years before they see the cash.

Which is why carpetbagging resolutions, such as the one at Friends Provident, tend to include a clause demanding that the life office sets a minimum payout figure of £1,000. If the carpetbaggers are successful on this front, then the £35-per-month policy held for two years (a total investment of £840) does indeed produce a very healthy return.

The Financial Services Authority has issued stern warnings against advisers who select your pension provider on the basis of a possible windfall, as the potential payout is insignificant compared to the impact of investment performance, charges and commission.

And the tide does not always run in favour of carpetbaggers. Skipton and Chelsea building societies both saw off the windfall hunters in ballots this week.

webTitle: Standard must fight for its life

fields.headline: Standard must fight for its life
fields.standfirst: As the carpetbaggers set their sights on the biggest of the mutuals, Rupert Jones looks at the confused background to the whole affair
fields.trailText: As the carpetbaggers set their sights on the biggest of the mutuals, Rupert Jones looks at the confused background to the whole affair.
fields.body:
Carpetbaggers this week scored a significant first-round victory in their battle to force the biggest mutual of them all, Standard Life, to convert to a plc and dish out windfalls.

A group of rebel members led by Fred Woollard, a Monaco-based investor, persuaded the insurance giant to give its millions of policyholders a say on the issue. A special meeting to vote on demutualisation will be held within the next three months.

Standard Life will write to members in the next few days to give more details, and says it will be vigorously putting the case for mutuality. "We see our future as a strong mutual group run purely for our members," says chairman John Trott.

Will the policyholders see it that way, with the carrot of windfalls of perhaps £5,000-£6,000 dangling before them? Bradford & Bingley building society was the last big mutual to allow members to vote on demutualisation while opposing such a move, and we all know what happened to them: a majority of members voted to take the money, and the society is now converting.

Speculation that Standard Life could face an uphill battle in fending off the carpetbaggers was fuelled by the disclosure that a poll by the insurer two months ago found that more policyholders favoured conversion to a plc than supported it staying member-owned (25.5% and 23.3% respectively).

However, half the 1,500 policyholders quizzed were undecided, giving both sides in the battle everything to play for in the weeks ahead of the vote.

At this week's annual meeting in Edinburgh, some policyholders criticised the company for allowing Mr Woollard to "set the agenda". Mark Bolland at financial advisers Chamberlain de Broe probably summed up the feelings of many when he said: "Having a gun put to their heads is an unsavoury way of doing business."

Here we answer some of the questions policyholders may have.

Remind me of the background. And who is this Woollard character?

The Standard Life Members' Action Group run by Mr Woollard submitted a conversion resolution two months ago but the insurer rejected this an invalid. On February 9, in a bid to foil the carpetbaggers, the company put in place a number of measures which mean people buying new policies after this date, and possibly some other policyholders too, will not receive any windfall resulting from a demutualisation within the next three years . The action group this week submitted five new resolutions which the company said appeared to be valid. Mr Woollard is an Australian national and a former fund manager who started buying up second-hand Standard Life endowment policies two years ago.

The $64,000 dollar question: how much might I get?

According to Mr Woollard, flotation could see the company valued at up to £15bn and potentially deliver average windfalls of £5,000-£6,300 to each qualifying policyholder. He proposes everyone should get a fixed handout of shares worth £500, plus a variable handout worth around 40%-50% of the surrender value of their policy. So someone with a policy with a surrender value of £10,000 could be looking at a payout of £500 plus £4,000-£5,000 which is equal to £4,500-£5,500.

Standard Life says it is impossible to say what any windfalls might be worth because it has not decided how any distribution would be made, and no one knows what the state of the stock market will be if and when it floats.

So who would benefit?

While it is thought that one in five UK adults holds a Standard Life policy of some sort, only the 2.3m people with qualifying "with-profits" policies would get a payout. They are people who own products such as endowment policies, personal pensions and with-profits savings plans. Standard Life unit trust investors and those with Standard Life Bank products will not qualify.

However, those whose policies are not with-profits may be comforted by the fact that Norwich Union and Scottish Widows both gave payouts to holders of certain non-with-profits life policies.

What happens now?

A special meeting to vote on demutualisation will be held, probably in June or July. For demutualisation to get the go-ahead two resolutions must be approved. The first proposes a change in the company's rules which would give policyholders more power to direct the board on particular issues, and requires a 75% majority of members voting in favour to succeed. Only if this goes through can the demutualisation proposal, which calls on the board "to take steps to demutualise the company and convert to a plc," be effective.

This second resolution requires a 50%-plus majority voting in favour. If both are passed, the company will have to draw up a full demutualisation plan which would then have to be put to another vote of members.

My policy matures next week/next month/later this year. Will I qualify for a windfall?

With a demutualisation likely to take up to two years, quite a few people are worried they will lose out on a windfall because their policy is nearing maturity.

Philip Crozier, 45, of Abertillery, near Newport, south Wales, has two Standard Life endowment policies; one matures this September and the other in March 2001. He is concerned that if flotation is after these dates, as seems likely, he will miss out on what could be quite a large windfall. "I don't think I deserve to lose out after being a loyal customer for 15 years," he says.

Unfortunately for Mr Crozier and others like him, Standard Life has not yet decided what to do about this issue. "It's one of the things yet to be resolved," says a spokesman. There is a glimmer of hope, however. Insurance giant Sun Life of Canada, which converted to a plc last month, announced that if an eligible policy matured after January 1998, the owner was still entitled to a handout. Standard Life may adopt a similar strategy.

I've bought a second-hand Standard Life endowment policy (known as a traded endowment or "Tep"). Will I get a windfall?

Hmm, this is a bit of a thorny one. Earlier this year the company prompted an outcry when it indicated it might refuse to pay windfalls to owners of second-hand endowment policies if it is forced to demutualise.

This week it attempted to clarify the position but has left many people confused and angry. It says that when someone buys one of its policies second-hand, getting membership rights is not automatic you have to apply for them. It seems that if you applied for membership rights before the February 9 cut-off date you probably will get a windfall, but if you applied after that date, you won't receive any windfall resulting from a demutualisation within the next three years. However, it is thought some people who bought second-hand policies before the cut-off date didn't apply for membership rights because they assumed - perhaps understandably - that these would automatically be transferred over to them.

One of Mr Woollard's five resolutions attempts to clarify the situation by proposing that anyone who bought a Tep before the cut-off date should have the same membership rights as the original policyholder.

I sold my Standard Life endowment policy. Would I be entitled to any windfall?

"This is one of the things we are not sure about and that is going to have to be clarified," says a spokesman.

I've heard that if I want to increase the amount I'm paying into my policy, I'll have to sign away my right to a windfall. Is this true?

This is an issue the company admits has been causing a lot of concern. The facts are these: if you want to pay more into a policy (a personal pension, for example), you will be able to do this, and it won't jeopardise any windfall you might receive. But you will have to sign a form which means you won't be entitled to a handout on any extra that you invest.

In other words, by signing the form, you don't sign away all your rights to a payout.

fields.headline: Classics with an edge
fields.standfirst:
Roy Hargrove/Tim Whitehead
Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham
****
fields.trailText:
Roy Hargrove/Tim Whitehead
Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham
****
fields.body:
The young American trumpeter Roy Hargrove brought his sizzling, hard-bop quintet to the opening night of this year's Cheltenham Jazz Festival. But it was an appropriate symbol of that shrewdly programmed event that a less expert European group delivered music at least as absorbing and in some respects more unpredictably distinctive.

Playing opposite Hargrove was British saxophonist Tim Whitehead, joined by the quartet with whom he made his excellent Personal Standards CD last year. The repertoire is exactly what the CD title says: there's a breathy version of John Lennon's Imagine, the Titanic theme is given a ghostly, Jan Garbarek-like timbre, while Dancing in the Streets is played as a flat-out rocker with free-sax diversions. In Liam Noble the band has a brilliant pianist of occasionally Jarrett-like persuasion who hardly plays a solo without at least one turn of phrase that brings you to the edge of your seat.

Roy Hargrove's band approached matters quite differently, going straight as arrows for the hard-bop and hard-swing traditions. They looked and sounded about as much like an American band as was possible: square-set men in suits, hitting the music between the eyes with a fierce, hustling energy, yet delivering it with hypnotic impassivity.

Unlike many of the respectful, Marsalis-inspired neo-classicists, Hargrove is a performer of fiery urgency and restless charm, and his solos bristle with high-note chatters, surging runs and Dizzy Gillespie-like drama. But he's also a superb manipulator of tone and timbre in more restrained music, as he demonstrated on Blame It on My Youth. This Hargrove quintet has been a regular ensemble for some years, and in the rhythm section's delectably effortless echoing of the classic Wynton Kelly/Phill Joe Jones sound of Miles Davis's 50s band, it certainly sounds like it. Classic jazz with an edge.

The Cheltenham Jazz Festival continues tonight with Arthur Blythe; tomorrow with Bobo Stenson, Jools Holland and Bobby Watson; Monday with Wayne Krantz and George Shearing. Details: 01242 227979

fields.headline: Standard Life sets vote date
fields.standfirst:
Insurer begins battle to stay a mutual
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Standard Life kicked off a high profile-campaign against demutualisation yesterday, disputing the size of potential windfalls and setting June 27 as the date for a crucial vote forced by carpetbaggers.
fields.body:
Standard Life kicked off a high profile-campaign against demutualisation yesterday, disputing the size of potential windfalls and setting June 27 as the date for a crucial vote forced by carpetbaggers.

Scott Bell, managing director of the 175-year-old insurance group, said claims that the average payout would be £6,000 were too high. Only one in five of the 2.3m policyholders stood a chance of getting such a windfall, he said.

The payout claims were made by Fred Woollard, the Monaco-based fund manager who has led the campaign for the vote. Mr Woollard, who founded the Standard Life Members' Action Group, forced Barclays, which has inadvertently been dragged in to the battle, into clarifying the independence of three endowment funds which are backing the rebel group.

Matt Barrett, the Barclays chief executive, yesterday wrote to Mr Bell to express his "regret that our name has been used to give the false appearance that Barclays plc has backed the campaign by Mr Woollard. Personally I find this an unacceptable distortion of the facts".

Barclays Global Investors, the fund management arm which advised the endowment funds, also plans to ask the funds to remove the Barclays name from their titles.

Standard Life, which faces a hefty bill for promoting mutuality, said the long-term interests of the company and its policyholders "are under threat from opportunists only interested in a quick profit". But analysts said it could face an uphill battle persuading policyholders to reject the lure of a four-figure windfall in favour of the less tangible benefits of mutuality, even with the 75% majority vote required. Independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet said: "I think Standard Life is going to find a great deal of difficulty in mustering significant numbers of people to turn down money."

Mr Bell said it was the board's unanimous view that staying member-owned was in the best interests of the company, and that demutualisation would "damage" it. "As a mutual, Standard Life has delivered significantly better payouts overall than plc competitors," he added.

For the first time, the company has hit back at the carpetbaggers' estimates of potential windfalls with figures of its own. But it did not explicitly state that policyholders would be financially worse-off as a result of any demutualisation, claiming instead that policyholders benefited from "excellent performance and customer service" because as a mutual, it was free from the shareholders demands to generate profit.

Over the coming weeks the insurer is likely to be haunted by a remark made by finance director Iain Lumsden 10 months ago, which appeared to suggest policyholders would gain more from a flotation than they would lose by having to share some of the profits with shareholders.

Only one in five of the 2.3m policyholders stood a chance of getting such a windfall, he said. The payout claims were made by Fred Woollard, the Monaco-based fund manager who has led the campaign for the vote. Mr Woollard, who founded the Standard Life Members' Action Group, forced Barclays, which has inadvertently been dragged in to the battle, into clarifying the independence of three endowment funds which are backing the rebel group. Matt Barrett, the Barclays chief executive, yesterday wrote to Mr Bell to express his "regret that our name has been used to give the false appearance that Barclays plc has backed the campaign by Mr Woollard. Personally I find this an unacceptable distortion of the facts". Barclays Global Investors, the fund management arm which advised the endowment funds, also plans to ask the funds to remove the Barclays name from their titles. Standard Life, which faces a hefty bill for promoting mutuality, said the long-term interests of the company and its policyholders "are under threat from opportunists only interested in a quick profit". But analysts said it could face an uphill battle persuading policyholders to reject the lure of a four-figure windfall in favour of the less tangible benefits of mutuality, even with the 75% majority vote required. Independent life insurance analyst Ned Cazalet said: "I think Standard Life is going to find a great deal of difficulty in mustering significant numbers of people to turn down money." Mr Bell said it was the board's unanimous view that staying member-owned was in the best interests of the company, and that demutualisation would "damage" it. "As a mutual, Standard Life has delivered significantly better payouts overall than plc competitors," he added. For the first time, the company has hit back at the carpetbaggers' estimates of potential windfalls with figures of its own. But it did not explicitly state that policyholders would be financially worse-off as a result of any demutualisation, claiming instead that policyholders benefited from "excellent performance and customer service" because as a mutual, it was free from the shareholders demands to generate profit. Over the coming weeks the insurer is likely to be haunted by a remark made by finance director Iain Lumsden 10 months ago, which appeared to suggest policyholders would gain more from a flotation than they would lose by having to share some of the profits with shareholders.

webTitle: Getting that loan is a steep learning curve

fields.headline: Getting that loan is a steep learning curve
fields.standfirst: Maggie Greatorex advises would-be students on the best debt strategy to avoid delay and reduce overdrafts
fields.trailText: There is only one piece of advice on loans for would-be students: start applying to your local authority to be means-tested now and get the completed loan application form returned the minute it drops through the door with your UCAS form and offer of a university place in August or September.
fields.body:
There is only one piece of advice on loans for would-be students: start applying to your local authority to be means-tested now and get the completed loan application form returned the minute it drops through the door with your UCAS form and offer of a university place in August or September.

For, according to the National Union of Students, in the current academic year (1999-2000) - the first for loans without any element of maintenance grant and the second in which students have been liable for tuition fees - the operations of the Student Loan Company were "a mess". The NUS delivered this verdict to the House of Commons select committee on education and employment earlier this month.

Anecdotal evidence from around the country bears out this view, with students - even those who applied on time with all the right evidence of family income, including parental tax returns in order - finding themselves without loans when they arrived at university.

A significant number were still without money at Christmas and in the worst cases did not get cheques until February, halfway through the academic year and well beyond the time of biggest expense in the first term, when most books are bought.

Students who had taken gap years were often those who waited longest, since they had been abroad at application time and councils were not sufficiently organised to handle applications before the gap-year travellers took to the air.

Universities' hardship funds provided help where loans were late.

The confusion was worse because local authorities did not always complete means-testing in time and the government told the Student Loans Company to make payments on the basis that students were entitled to full loans. Some cheques were issued on that basis, but cancelled before the students presented them to their banks when the SLC received the LEA means test decision. A quarter of the loan is means-tested.

Students were being told by the SLC to fill in applications for full loans and within a week were told their loan would be delayed because they had improperly applied for the full amount.

Student self-help gossip groups came to the conclusion that the only way to get cheques, sometimes, was to get an irate parent to telephone the headquarters in Glasgow, ignoring the official helpline, demanding to speak to the chief executive, Colin Ward.

The complications of the system, with the local authorities assessing students for both tuition fees and loans, but the SLC making the payments of the loans, and the variety of sliding scales for loans and fees, does not make the job of the applicants or the SLC easy.

But the Glasgow-based company, set up in 1990 when a loan element was first introduced, appears to have added baroque complications. Mr Ward, who was questioned by the Commons select committee last summer, has promised that hiccups are being ironed out.

There are three different rates for full loans. If the student lives with parents or an earning spouse, the loan is £2,875. For those living away from home in London it is £4,480, or for those living away from home outside London it is £3,635.

Tuition fees from last September were £1,025, are means-tested and rise each year with inflation. They can be paid in three chunks. About a third of students pay the full whack, a third pay on a sliding scale and a third pay nothing. If parental or spousal or the student's own income is more than £28,000, the full amount is paid. Between £17,370 and £27,999, students contribute on a sliding scale, and between 0 and £17,365, they do not pay fees.

The levels for the discretionary 25% of the loan are similar, but there are complications about other financial commitments.

Most councils have already started means-testing. Next year's first-years have to approach the council. Students moving into later years should get forms automatically. If they have not arrived by May Day, the wise will ask where they are.

Four out of five of all students apply for loans which are then paid into student bank accounts, set up on the understanding that the loans will go into them. Banks offer all kinds of incentives, from Walkmans to cash, and also provide £1,000 interest-free overdrafts and credit cards. Most of this year's students took their full entitlement with 40% still needing to work to have enough to live on.

What happens after graduation is worth checking. Most banks now say the £1,000 free overdraft will continue for a year after the student leaves. Until last year, graduates had to repay loans at a flat rate within five years once their income was more than £15,000. Repayment now starts at £10,000 but is geared to the level of income and can be spread over 20 years. For the incautious, this could entail being asked to fund a student child before having paid off their own student debt.

Last year's graduates had an average debt of £4,497 and the estimate is that with the new system it could be up to £12,000 for those graduating in 2002. Research shows that 58% of students have an overdraft and 30% have debts on their credit cards. This institutionalised debt is one of the Commons select committee's main concerns.

webTitle: Pick of the perks for this year's intake

fields.headline: Pick of the perks for this year's intake
fields.trailText: If you're a cash-strapped student, it might not seem the banks are on your side. But many of today's students will be tomorrow's big earners, so banks are keen to woo them. Which is best? Here, Jobs & Money sets out the offerings from the top six banks - but look out for new perks this summer.
fields.body:
If you're a cash-strapped student, it might not seem the banks are on your side. But many of today's students will be tomorrow's big earners, so banks are keen to woo them. Which is best? Here, Jobs & Money sets out the offerings from the top six banks - but look out for new perks this summer.

Barclays offers the highest maximum overdraft of £3,000, interest-free for the first £1,250 and 8.9% thereafter. Unauthorised borrowing is charged at 29.8%. Graduates can borrow up to £10,000, including student debt, at rates of 8.9% a year, repayable within seven years. Account openers get £20 worth of books, CDs and video vouchers plus 15% off books, CDs and videos. It has 22 campus branches.

NatWest offers an interest free overdraft up to £2,000, with unauthorised overdrafts charged at a relatively low 9.38%. Graduates can borrow up to £10,000 at 7.5% but must repay it within seven years. New customers are offered £35 cash or a Panasonic CD player. It has the most campus branches, 46.

Lloyds TSB offers interest-free overdrafts up to £2,000. Unauthorised borrowing is charged at 26.8%. Graduates can borrow up to £10,000 at 7.8%, repayable within five years. The student freebies are £30 cash and Virgin vouchers worth £10. It has 21 campus branches.

HSBC offers a maximum interest-free overdraft of £1,500. Unauthorised borrowing costs 29.5%. HSBC's freebies are the most attractive; choose between £50 cash or a free four-year Young Person's Railcard. Graduates can also access 100% mortgages of up to four-times their salary.

Halifax limits overdrafts to £1,000. They are interest-free under £1,000 then cost 8%. Once a graduate, only £100 is interest-free, and above that rates of 14.3% are charged. Rates of 24.9% are levied on unauthorised borrowing. It has 31 campus branches.

Abbey National does not offer any special student deals.

webTitle: Time to take stock of tech holdings

fields.headline: Time to take stock of tech holdings
fields.trailText: Against the backdrop of plunging technology shares, it is certainly time to take stock of your dot.com investments. But your last-minute Isa investment in tech funds will only be a mistake if you lose your nerve and sell when prices are going down.
fields.body:
Against the backdrop of plunging technology shares, it is certainly time to take stock of your dot.com investments. But your last-minute Isa investment in tech funds will only be a mistake if you lose your nerve and sell when prices are going down.

Before the end of the Isa season, many investors in tech stocks were feeling good about their purchases, even if some didn't know a great deal about the companies. But technology investors have learned some hard lessons from the past month's stock market volatility.

According to financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown, three quarters of all 1999-2000's last-minute Isa money went into tech funds. Yet most of these investors will have seen up to a third wiped off the value of their funds in recent weeks.

The rollercoaster ride is a timely reminder that investment is a long-term game. "No one should put money in such a specialist area if they aren't prepared to face some short-term storms along the way," says John Pullar-Strecker, head of the global technology desk at Aberdeen Asset Management.

"You should be looking to hold your investments for at least five years, which should ride out dramatic falls and rises."

Advisers will not be surprised it there are further falls in the next few weeks. But unless you really believe that the technological revolution ended when Lastminute.com shares slumped, then it will remain a good long-term bet to have some of these stocks in your portfolio.

That said, you should be asking some searching questions of your fund manager. This shake-out is proving that there are good and bad tech stocks, just as in every other industry. You should satisfy yourself that your fund manager has the skill and freedom to choose the winners.

webTitle: Stakeholder plan looks increasingly  shaky for lower earners

fields.headline: Stakeholder plan looks increasingly  shaky for lower earners
fields.trailText: The government is to spend £5m of taxpayers' cash to publicise stakeholder pensions amid growing fears that the new retirement pay scheme - due to start in April 2001 - will prove an embarrassing flop.
fields.body:
The government is to spend £5m of taxpayers' cash to publicise stakeholder pensions amid growing fears that the new retirement pay scheme - due to start in April 2001 - will prove an embarrassing flop.

Pensions experts claim the chances of the target market buying into stakeholder is remote - no matter how much is spent on advertising. Stakeholder pensions are aimed at those earning £9,000 to £18,000 a year - a band that ranges from below half national average earnings to typical salaries.

But the reality is that many will do better spending the money at the pub or bookies than handing it over to a pensions firm, as any pension may be reduced pound-for-pound by the withdrawal of welfare benefits.

There are positives about the new scheme. Its lower charges will increase retirement earnings for those who are on above average salaries and for the self-employed because costs are to be driven down.

And at the very top, ultra-rich company directors will take advantage of loopholes in the rules to buy tax-benefit boosted pension provision above the current maximum £91,800 earnings cap.

Stakeholder pensions are a government initiative to increase the attractions of personal pensions. Firms with five or more employees must offer a scheme.

They will feature:

 Overall charges limited to 1% a year with no upfront fees;

 A minimum £20 contribution;

 No penalties for irregular amounts or missed months;

 Anyone can have one, irrespective of earnings.

But product sellers will be allowed to charge for advice, although the government believes few will buy into this. Instead, the Financial Services Authority intends publishing a "decision tree"by the end of May.

It should explain whether a stakeholder is right or not for individuals. This "tree" is currently under wraps. So it is still unclear whether branches will include the interaction between stakeholder payouts and social security.

Andy Cox at actuaries Bacon & Woodrow is "not really optimistic that stakeholder will change much for its intended market. And if it does not take off in a big way, there is a lot of political capital to be lost." He says stakeholder will be a waste of time if income support is offset pound for pound by pension cash.

Scottish Life pensions guru Steve Bee is also concerned about suitability. He says: "Stakeholder will not bite without benefit reform. You would need to exempt these pensions benefits from the means test. Building up a decent pension is beyond anyone on less than average earnings."

Someone now aged 55 and earning £15,000 a year and retiring in 10 years time would end up with a £19 a week flat rate pension for the rest of their lives assuming they pay 5% of their earnings into a stakeholder each year. This is based on a 7% growth rate and 1% annual fees and current annuity rates.

If the only other earning is the state basic pension, the holder would do better with the pensioners' minimum income guarantee.

A potential pension buyer on the same salary but with 30 years to go before retirement would end up with £165 a week. Again, part of this would be offset by social security payment losses but it could be worthwhile if this pension purchaser expects to see future salary increases.

Someone contributing 5% of a £10,000 salary - less likely because a low earner may not be able to save £500 a year - would retire with a pension of £10 a week after 10 years, £40 a week after 20 years and just over £100 a week after 30 years.

"These are simply not worthwhile under the present benefits system," says Bee. "But it becomes ludicrous if you take the occasional payer putting in the minimum £20 amount. We calculate that someone of 20 paying in £20 a quarter would only have £7 a week after 40 years and less than £2 a week after 20 years."

One solution is compulsion, but that would be politically difficult as it would be seen as a tax, impacting mainly on the poor. Forcing people to save with a private company without a state alternative could also be problematic.

Cox says stakeholder could do better if the proposed second tier state pension was generous. This is a flat rate boost to the ba sic pension. "It will be compulsory like national insurance and will not be earnings related. But it could take years before it is up and running." But where stakeholder will score is with the better off.

Many currently paying into a personal pension will save by switching into a stakeholder with its lower charges. Some existing personal pensions may be better value than stakeholders. They could also be a good deal for additional contributions to a company pension, but only if the government clears up the confusion on "concurrency" - being allowed to hold a company and a stakeholder pension at the same time.

And for someone running up against the earnings cap, paying the maximum £3,600 a year into plans for a non-working spouse, children and other relations could be an attractive way of saving in a tax-free environment.

Advisers suggest that these payments will also be seen as a legitimate form of inheritance tax planning, more than doubling the present £3,000 a year that can be given away.

webTitle: Has early retirement been pensioned off?

fields.headline: Has early retirement been pensioned off?
fields.standfirst: One of the few consolations of getting older is the prospect of taking it a bit easier while you've still got your health. But, reports Tony Levene, even that small solace may be denied to many of us
fields.trailText: If you're thinking of combining your 50th birthday party with a retirement bash, be warned: what is often dubbed the longest holiday of your life may be postponed by at least five years under government proposals announced this week.
fields.body:
If you're thinking of combining your 50th birthday party with a retirement bash, be warned: what is often dubbed the longest holiday of your life may be postponed by at least five years under government proposals announced this week.

Heading for the pavilion after your half century could be put off until your score reaches at least 55. But don't panic if you're in your 40s; any change will be gradual with those currently aged 40 or over unlikely to be adversely affected.

The public relations spin on ending retirement at 50 is that "the government wants to help people remain active as they grow older and for society to value their continuing contribution".

But behind these upbeat concepts lies a depressing reality: if we do not work longer and therefore spend less time drawing our retirement pay, much of the financial structure that backs state, occupational and personal pensions could shatter.

A report, Winning the Generation Game, produced by the prime minister's performance and innovation unit, says one in three people aged between 50 and the state pension age (60 for women rising to 65 for those born in 1955 or after, and 65 for men) do not work. This totals 2.8m - and some 2m of these were forced into early retirement.

The government reckons early retirement costs £16bn a year. This includes up to £5bn in benefit payments and lost taxes - equal to around 2p on basic-rate income tax. No wonder social security secretary Alastair Darling wants healthy men aged 60 to 65 to look for work again. It is also proposed that this group should be forced to sign on regularly to prove they are actively seeking employment.

The law will not be able to prevent those who can afford it quitting work early. The government plans to enforce its minimum pension age by banning the tax-free lump sum and other Inland Revenue benefits on pension plans which are cashed in before holders reach 55. So you can retire early; it just won't be so beneficial tax-wise.

In the same way as the increase in the state pension age for women from 60 to 65 is being phased in over a number of years, the end of retirement at 50 is likely to be introduced over 10 years, with those aged 50 in 2010 the most likely to feel the impact of new rules first.

It is unclear what will happen to existing personal pension and other contracts which promise pensions at 50. However, it seems certain that once the legislation is changed, future policies will reflect retirement at 55.

The political drive to push up retirement ages contrasts strongly with the situation in the mid-80s when mass unemployment was more of an issue. Only a decade and a half ago the then Conservative government proposed retirement at 50 as part of its plan to popularise the personal pensions it introduced in 1988. Until then the precursor to personal pensions (retirement annuity policies) had banned drawing a retirement income until 60. Most occupational pensions were based on 65 for a man, 60 for a woman.

Generous workplace pension schemes have been the main driver behind early retirement. Someone leaving work aged 55 or 50 may be little worse off than if they had carried on in employment once national insurance, tax and expenses of employment such as travel and clothes plus state and other benefits are balanced against earnings loss. Even where companies do not allow retirement before 60 or 65, employees can leave by switching their accumulated company benefits into a personal pension - a transfer that some financial advisers push as a controversial way of paying off credit card debts.

Early retirement may also be a corporate euphemism for redundancy. It can be cheaper for companies to use surpluses in the pension fund to slash its older workforce than to pay younger employees redundancy.

There is also a need for everyone to carry on earning and making pension contributions if retirement pensions are going to provide a half decent return.

Research from investment bank Barclays Capital shows that by 2010, when the government hopes people will defer retirement by at least five years and preferably more, there could be a pensions asset crunch. The ageing population will see us all saving madly in pension schemes which buy shares, then all selling them madly when we retire. The result? A huge sell-off on the stock market.

Tim Bond of Barclays says: "As saving turns to spending, asset prices will fall because those selling the equities do not have enough purchasers from the next generation to soak up the supply. If that happens, prices slump and pension pots are worth less. At the same time, a big surge of people cashing in on their pensions will bring a new wave of demand for government stocks which are now rarely issued and so suffer from low supply. This will force annuity rates downwards on sums which are themselves less than they might otherwise be."

Two things could help avoid this. One is a decrease in the dependency ratio - the number of retired people compared with those in work - by increasing retirement ages and making it more attractive to stay at work.

A second would be growth in the economy. "If the government is serious about winning the generation game," says Mr Bond, "then there are unexploited opportunities. It should be spending on infrastructure such as transport which may not have immediate bottom line benefit but would help iron out the north-south divide, even out house prices and drive inflation down. If we do nothing, we could face a bubble and burst economy."

If your heart is set on early retirement, there are a few escape channels. Saving outside the rigidity of a pension fund - via an individual savings account - gives freedom. Taking on a portfolio of work - a number of one or two day jobs a week or setting up as a consultant - gives the flexibility to move gradually out of the jobs market.

The other way, if you're young and fit enough, is to take up a job which depends on body rather than brain. Special Inland Revenue rules allow you to take pension tax benefits on retirement at under 50 in a number of jobs.

Downhill skiers can quit at 30. Professional athletes, boxers, cyclists, dancers, ice hockey players, models, rugby players and wrestlers are among those who can draw a pension at 35.

Cricketers, divers, golfers, snooker players and trapeze artists must wait until 40 while flat race jockeys and members of the reserve forces have to stay until they are 45. These regulations will not be affected by a general move to a 55 minimum age.

webTitle: Guilt edge is so easy to avoid

fields.headline: Guilt edge is so easy to avoid
fields.standfirst: Simon Birch sets you on the internet's path to making money without sacrificing morality
fields.trailText: The internet is proving to be an invaluable source of information for the would-be ethical investor. Possibly the best starting place is the UK Social Investment Forum (www.uksif.org) the body responsible for the promotion of all aspects of ethical investment in the country.
fields.body:
The internet is proving to be an invaluable source of information for the would-be ethical investor. Possibly the best starting place is the UK Social Investment Forum (www.uksif.org) the body responsible for the promotion of all aspects of ethical investment in the country.

The UKSIF site provides a comprehensive who's who and what's what of the UK ethical investment scene. Ethically minded investors can now also take advantage of a number of specialist websites that give information about the ethical record of companies that might appear in their portfolio of investments and pensions.

With a database consisting of the majority of the UK's and the world's biggest companies, www.corporate-register.com is able to tell you whether or not a company has an ethical or environmental policy.

Corporate Critic on the other hand (www.ethicalconsumer.org/corporat.htm) is the only online database giving details of a company's ethical and environmental record. With changes in the pension law in July requiring occupational pension funds to state their policy on socially responsible investment, occupational pension holders might like to visit www.ethicsforuss.org.uk which indicates how pension holders can challenge trustees to adopt a socially responsible investment policy.

A similar approach to corporate responsibility is advocated by the Shareholder Action Service (www.thesasuk.com) which lobbies companies on behalf of concerned shareholders.

But compared with the US, British shareholder activism and the ethical investment movement in general are in their infancy.

With billions of dollars under ethical management, the US is home to specialist funds such as the Pride Fund (www.pridefund.com) which invests only in companies with progressive gay and lesbian policies, and the Women's Equity Mutual Fund (www.womens-equity.com) which limits investment to public companies which have an affirmative women's policy.

Worth noting is Calvert Fund (www.calvertgroup.com) whose "Shareholder Resolution Tool" has much to teach ethical investors here.

You can find ethical independent financial advisers on the UKSIF's list or the Ethical Investors Association site (www.ethicalinvestment.org.uk). One of the most ambitious online ethical IFAs is Fleetwood Money Advice Consultants - and yes, they call themselves Fleetwood MAC. John Fleetwood says in future "clients wouldn't necessarily even have to talk to their financial adviser".

Despite these claims, many advisers still see value in doing business over a low-tech cuppa. "The net can't take the place of meeting clients face-to-face or talking to them over the phone," says Brigid Benson of Gaeia Associates (www.gaeia.co.uk) one of the first ethical IFAs on the net.

While you'll find a wealth of brochure-style information from ethical IFA websites, there's not much information about individual financial products. This can be remedied by visiting the websites of leading providers such as NPI Global Care (www.npi.co.uk/globalcare), Standard Life Ethical Fund (www.standardlifeinvestments.co.uk) and Friends Provident Stewardship Fund (www.friendsprovident.co.uk/stewardship).

Managing your money ethically isn't just restricted to the one-off buying of specific financial products. Your day-to-day financial affairs can also be managed in a more ethical manner.

Currently reaping the financial rewards of being the leading ethical bank, the Co-op (www.co-operativebank.co.uk) is the obvious choice for those who want to avoid banks with a questionable ethical track record.

webTitle: Want to a be a www.wheelerdealer?

fields.headline: Want to a be a www.wheelerdealer?
fields.trailText: Share dealing is for the first time topping the charts as the most popular financial activity on the net - a boom fuelled by the explosion in demand for technology shares among private investors.
fields.body:
Share dealing is for the first time topping the charts as the most popular financial activity on the net - a boom fuelled by the explosion in demand for technology shares among private investors.

An army of cheap online brokers has sprung up to cater for this market, charging just a few pounds for an execution-only service - where shares are bought and sold without advice.

So where should wannabe internet stock market wheeler-dealers begin? Alan Stevens, head of digital services for the Consumers' Association, says it is important not to rush in without testing the water.

"Run a fantasy portfolio," he says. "Financial websites such as Interactive Investor and Motley Fool offer the facility to play with stocks and shares seeing how they perform without losing any money. Try it for at least a month before going further."

He adds: "The great thing about the web is you can get some very valuable background information on firms - look at past records not only through the online brokers but general financial websites, when running your portfolio. But make sure you treat chatroom comments with a pinch of salt. In some cases the people making comments are merely trying to ramp up share prices."

While you are gearing up to invest, should be able to register with the online traders and use their facilities without trading a bean. When you do start trading, prices among brokers will vary widely but they will slap 0.5% stamp duty on all purchases.

Charles Schwab, the biggest online broker, charges 1% for deals under £2,500, with a minimum £15 charge. There is also a £4 annual charge for each stock held.

Barclays Stockbrokers has a 1% dealing cost and a £12 minimum; NatWest Stockbrokers charges the same flat rate, with a £15 minimum for the first £4,000. Halifax ShareExpress charges £12.50 for deals up to £2,500, while financial adviser Hargreaves Lansdown only wants £9.95 for each transaction but has a £50 annual management charge so it is only worthwhile for frequent dealings.

E*Trade charges £14.95 for deals less than £1,500, with a £50 annual management fee, and Fastrade charges 0.5% for each transaction but with a £15 minimum.

Jane Drew at Charles Schwab warns: "Picking the cheapest trader is not necessarily the right thing to do. People get very excited about online brokers but they must realise it is just another channel for dealing in shares - so you can lose as well as win. What the internet does do is demystify the process. But if you want to trade you should find an online broker who can give you information about shares."

webTitle: How to get your home loan without going outside

fields.headline: How to get your home loan without going outside
fields.standfirst: Dozens of internet mortgage services have been launched this year, reports Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Dozens of internet mortgage services have been launched this year, reports Rupert Jones
fields.body:
Taking the advice of a mortgage broker traditionally meant making an appointment and sitting in their office while they talked through your circumstances. They told you about the deal they thought suited your needs and you sat there nodding sagely. It sometimes felt as though they were holding all the cards.

The internet is changing that - now it's the borrower who is in the driving seat. Homebuyers and those looking to remortgage can browse through details of hundreds of home loans from dozens of lenders, ranging from high-street giants to tiny local building societies.

The last few months have seen the launch of a plethora of online mortgage services. Some are new entrants to the home loans market, such as Emfinance, the mortgage broking arm of online information company Exchange Holdings. Others, such as Charcolonline and NetMortgage, have been set up by established brokers.

The online mortgage market is small but growing rapidly. Already, home loans are the most commonly researched financial product on the net, and a survey has found that more than two in five people looking to change their mortgage will consider going online to find the right deal.

So why might you want to turn to an online mortgage broking service? Probably the most obvious reason is the convenience factor. Instead of trudging down the high street collecting bumph or logging on to 101 different bank and building society websites, you may be able to find all the information you need on one site.

Charcolonline (www.charcolonline.co.uk) boasts that it carries details of "400-plus mortgages from 45-plus top lenders, all without leaving your chair". E-Loan (www.eloan.com/uk) the online service launched by the US mortgage giant of the same name, also features products from more than 40 lenders, but curiously Britain's two biggest, Halifax and Abbey National, are not among them.

NetMortgage (www.netmortgage.co.uk) which went live on April 1, claims to go one better, carrying details of mortgages from 128 lenders.

Many of the sites allow you to search for the deals that meet your particular requirements, compare products from different lenders and see what the monthly payments would be.

Borrowers typically enter their details and the search engine selects a shortlist of products that may be suitable. You can then apply online by completing an application form and emailing this to the broker.

The internet services claim they can dramatically speed up the traditional process of obtaining a mortgage.

For example, Charcolonline offers a "rapid remortgage service" which promises to give a formal mortgage offer online in just 24 hours.

But while a lot can be done electronically, you will have to sign a paper copy of the application form and post it back. There is still a legal requirement for forms to have a handwritten signature, though companies are lobbying for "electronic" signatures to be allowed.

If you arrange your mortgage through a service such as Charcolonline, NetMortgage or E-Loan, you will not have to pay a fee to them - they make their money by receiving a payment from the lender. If you were to use an "offline" mortgage broker, the fee you would pay might be around £250.

But remember that with many of the net services you are not getting any advice - at the end of the day you will have to make up your own mind about which product is best for you.

Research carried out by E-Loan found that 15% of people were drawn to the privacy they felt the net gave them. Using an online mortgage broker might appeal to those people who feel uncomfortable sitting down in a financial adviser's office and talking about their debt problems in the past, for example.

Some sites also allow the customer to track online the whole process of their mortgage, from application to completion, 24 hours a day, simply by inputting a password.

With the net services competing hard for people's custom, some are offering perks and exclusive deals to tempt homebuyers into signing up with them. Emfinance (www.emfinance.com) offers all borrowers three months' free buildings and contents insurance, and six months' free accident, sickness and unemployment insurance.

But the site is somewhat limited by the fact that it currently only offers 12 mortgage deals from six different lenders, including the Woolwich and West Bromwich building society.

For many people, particularly those who have a good idea what sort of home loan they want, the online mortgage services can represent a fast and low-cost way of financing their house purchase.

But if you are not at all sure what sort of deal you want, or your circumstances are not so clear-cut, you may feel happier sitting down and talking to an expert.

webTitle: Be there as market opens up

fields.headline: Be there as market opens up
fields.standfirst: Buying unit trusts on the web is getting easier, says Joanne Gill
fields.trailText: The computer no longer crashes every time you connect to the internet and you're ready to invest. But is the internet ready for you?
fields.body:
The computer no longer crashes every time you connect to the internet and you're ready to invest.

But is the internet ready for you? Since April last year a handful of companies have allowed you to take out Isas online. Still more have allowed you to access existing investments, look at valuations and order literature. But a resistance to dealing with finances on the internet has made companies reluctant to invest in online services, according to Lewis McNaught at Gartmore Fund Management.

This is all about to change. "Widespread use of the internet is becoming a reality and now we've computed the benefits we're just about in a position as an industry to deliver the benefits," Mr McNaught says.

He says investment firms are working on an initiative that will enable people to buy and sell their investments on the web at a "massively" reduced cost.

"From the middle of this year I think we will see a proliferation of sites which can transact business. There will be a common set of standards for messaging which will enable people to conduct business on a common screen."

Mercury is currently test-marketing a low-cost direct investment scheme among its existing clients. But until such schemes are launched the net's scope remains limited.

Anne McMeehan at the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds says there is no monetary benefit for the consumer from investing online at the moment, but things will change as the market grows. Jo Roddan at Fidelity agrees, saying that despite taking 20% of last year's Isa business online the firm offers no "price initiative at the moment".

But some companies are rewarding customers who choose a paperless transaction. Johnson Fry is offering online Isa subscribers a 2% discount. It is also looking at offering savings to online investors in its unit trust range, although these will not be available until the end of the year.

Henrietta Tye at Johnson Fry says the delay in launching unit trusts online is down to the problems of checking client identity, to prevent money laundering. "We are looking into lots of different things, like links into the electoral roll, to make sure people are who they say they are," she says.

Perpetual offers Isa projections and fund price information, allows customers to download or request literature, and provides easy-to-understand product information. The Aberdeen Asset Management site offers much of the same, but allows online Isa investment. It is also offering 0.5% discount on lump-sum investments over the net until June 5.

Schroder's site gives daily market movements together with fund prices, so you can do your own valuations. And Henderson lets you print off application forms.

But for the moment, the best place to get good deals on investments on the internet is through the discount brokers. Most of these brokers offer 3% or more off the initial charge of the investment, sometimes wiping it out completely. They also allow you to print application forms.
