There will be a common set of standards for messaging which will enable people to conduct business on a common screen." Mercury is currently test-marketing a low-cost direct investment scheme among its existing clients. But until such schemes are launched the net's scope remains limited. Anne McMeehan at the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds says there is no monetary benefit for the consumer from investing online at the moment, but things will change as the market grows. Jo Roddan at Fidelity agrees, saying that despite taking 20% of last year's Isa business online the firm offers no "price initiative at the moment". But some companies are rewarding customers who choose a paperless transaction. Johnson Fry is offering online Isa subscribers a 2% discount. It is also looking at offering savings to online investors in its unit trust range, although these will not be available until the end of the year. Henrietta Tye at Johnson Fry says the delay in launching unit trusts online is down to the problems of checking client identity, to prevent money laundering. "We are looking into lots of different things, like links into the electoral roll, to make sure people are who they say they are," she says. Perpetual offers Isa projections and fund price information, allows customers to download or request literature, and provides easy-to-understand product information. The Aberdeen Asset Management site offers much of the same, but allows online Isa investment. It is also offering 0.5% discount on lump-sum investments over the net until June 5. Schroder's site gives daily market movements together with fund prices, so you can do your own valuations. And Henderson lets you print off application forms. But for the moment, the best place to get good deals on investments on the internet is through the discount brokers. Most of these brokers offer 3% or more off the initial charge of the investment, sometimes wiping it out completely. They also allow you to print application forms.

webTitle: A friendly banker in the living room corner

fields.headline: A friendly banker in the living room corner
fields.trailText: Watching a lot of television - the nation's favourite activity - is generally a cause for embarrassment. But a group of banks, led by HSBC, is planning to capitalise on this habit to bring branch operations to living rooms.
fields.body:
Watching a lot of television - the nation's favourite activity - is generally a cause for embarrassment. But a group of banks, led by HSBC, is planning to capitalise on this habit to bring branch operations to living rooms.

The idea is to convert millions of customers into conducting routine banking business through Open, an interactive service designed for digital transmission. The plans rest on the assumption that Britons wary of new technology will trust the telly.

HSBC has become the first bank to open a branch on your television screen. It is digital TV's ease of use that it thinks customers will like. There are no backslashes or https to worry about.

This month HSBC became the first bank to make its digital television service fully interactive.

More than 75,000 customers have signed up for the service since last autumn. Those with an HSBC personal account will be able to check their balances, transactions and credit card dealings on their television sets 24 hours a day.

Open, owned by HSBC, BSkyB, BT and Matsushita, is available to SkyDigital's near-2m subscribers and offers a range of services from companies such as Argos, Dixons and ticket agency First Call.

Using the television to access your bank account could not be easier: just pick up the remote control, key in your pass number and you're away.

You can check out the state of your account, get a quote for a personal loan, or a mortgage quote in less than 10 minutes. True, you cannot pay bills or buy car insurance on Open but as time goes by the range of services offered is likely to expand.

Moreover, digital television is likely to provide a rapidly expanding customer base because the government intends to turn off analogue broadcasts by 2006 at the earliest and 2010 at the latest.

For technology-literate bank customers, the web-based banks are an attractive proposition as they offer keen pricing deals to woo customers online.

While it offers email connections, the rest of Open is closed; TV users have access only to those retailers or service providers who have paid Open for the privilege.

So far only two other high-street financial institutions are keen to launch TV banking operations through the Open digital platform, Abbey National and the Woolwich. For these TV banking services , you need to subscribe to BSkyB.

For this you will need digital TV equipment including a set-top box and dish. There is a £40 connection fee and the monthly Sky subscription, ranging from £7 to £32 a month.

HSBC has worked out that 1.2m of its 8m British customers have access to Sky, and they might well be inclined to try digital interactive television.

webTitle: Click around to save on insurance

fields.headline: Click around to save on insurance
fields.trailText: With its range of sites and comparative information, the internet is unbeatable when it comes to finding the best price for a general insurance policy.
fields.body:
With its range of sites and comparative information, the internet is unbeatable when it comes to finding the best price for a general insurance policy.

When the product is easy to understand, as with a motor or home insurance policy, it makes good sense to buy online - especially since insurers often offer cheaper deals over the internet than through a branch or over the phone.

Churchill, Norwich Union and Eagle Star all give a 10% discount for buying online.

But as Suzanne Moore at the Association of British Insurers says: "There are some very good deals on the internet, although you shouldn't assume the prices are automatically going to be cheaper. We recommend you visit a variety of insurers' and brokers' websites and be very clear about what you are getting for your money. It is the power to compare prices that counts."

Internet prices are likely to get even cheaper as new market entrants like Halifax's online brand Esure put pressure on companies that do not offer online reductions.

Esure, backed by Direct Line founder Peter Wood, will launch early next year and plans to offer 15% discounts on motor and home insurance - although it is not yet clear which policies will be cut by this percentage.

Because online insurance is in its infancy, service can vary widely. Some sites, such as Eagle Star and Churchill, give you a quote and allow you to buy the cover online.

The cover begins straight away, although you generally have to wait three days for your paper contract to arrive in the post. Other insurers have less sophisticated websites and redirect you to a call centre to buy the policy.

The amount of information the insurers require to give you a quote can also vary, but you will need to complete an online questionnaire which will typically take between five and 15 minutes.

If you don't want to visit the insurers' sites individually you can use an intermediary site instead. Although each one is slightly different, they all take your details and provide you with the most suitable policy from their panel of insurers.

This is not always better. The intermediary can often get a discount but they are limited to a handful of insurers. Screentrade, which claims to be the first internet insurance "supermarket", gets around this by guaranteeing that anyone visiting its website will receive the cheapest motor, home and travel insurance or it will refund the difference.

Screentrade is one of the larger intermediaries, offering 52 policies from 22 com panies, including Norwich Union, Royal & Sun Alliance, AXA and Zurich.

But don't forget that traditional insurance brokers can also harness the net's power and use it on your behalf.

This can be especially useful if you are "non-standard". This can embrace anything that scares insurers - from having more than one kitchen in your home to driving a souped-up car.

fields.headline: US demands Microsoft break-up
fields.standfirst:
The future of Microsoft: special report
E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
Microsoft
fields.trailText: Microsoft, the world's largest software company, will be broken up into two separate businesses under proposals put forward by the US government last night.
fields.body:
Microsoft, the world's largest software company, will be broken up into two separate businesses under proposals put forward by the US government last night.

If agreed by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson later this year, the proposals would create an operating systems company with the rights to Windows and an applications company responsible for products such as MS Office and the internet business.

Last night's filing by the department of justice to the courts was also expected to ask for other restrictions on Microsoft.

These could include interim measures seeking to change Microsoft's business practices before any appeal is heard as well as permanent limits on the way it collaborates with other companies.

Microsoft has pledged to fight a break-up and intends to appeal against Judge Jackson's earlier ruling that it was guilty of anti-competitive conduct. This is likely to delay any remedy for at least a year.

The department of justice and 19 US states are pushing for a break-up after agreeing that trying to change the company's behaviour would have been too difficult to police.

Joel Klein, the assistant attorney general, has previously said: "The department is committed to finding a remedy that protects consumers, innovation and competition by putting an end to Microsoft's widespread and persistent abuse of monopoly power."

Even if Judge Jackson backs the government and orders a break-up, the case is expected to go to the US Supreme Court.

Steve Ballmer, Microsoft's chief executive, has called the break-up proposals "extreme and unprecedented". In an email to employees this week, he wrote: "Absolutely nothing in the current case justifies breaking us up."

Judge Jackson ruled that the company had broken US laws by abusing its stranglehold on the world's computer systems earlier this month. The company believes that a former appeals court ruling contradicts Judge Jackson's decision.

Legal experts have hailed the long-running case as a landmark for US anti-monopoly laws. Bill Kovacic, law professor at George Washington uni versity, said: "This is the first time that we will have any experience of breaking up an enterprise that basically sells ideas."

Among the restrictions that the government could call for would be a ban on co-operation by the two companies and a time limit for any future partnerships.

At lunchtime yesterday, shares in Microsoft were trading down 2% at $687/16, a sharp fall from the year's high of almost $120 in January. Some Wall Street analysts were trying to calm investors yesterday by saying that the likelihood of the company actually being broken up was still very low. Analysts believe that any sub sequent appeal would also be helped by a Republican victory in the autumn's presidential election and some yesterday accused the justice department and US states attorney generals of political posturing.

George W Bush, the Republican presidential contender, has also stepped up his support for Microsoft.

webTitle: That'll do nicely to the tune of £12bn

fields.headline: That'll do nicely to the tune of £12bn
fields.standfirst:
Spending on credit and debit cards climbs to record levels

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Credit and debit card spending rose to record levels in March. The total reached £12.6bn compared with £10.2bn in the same month last year, according to new figures from the Credit Card Research Group.
fields.body:
Credit and debit card spending rose to record levels in March. The total reached £12.6bn compared with £10.2bn in the same month last year, according to new figures from the Credit Card Research Group.

Spending on credit cards rose 23.2% to £6.5bn from £5.3bn, while expenditure using debit cards increased even more rapidly to £6.1bn from £4.9bn, a gain of 25.7%.

Separate figures from the British Bankers' Association reveal that the total debt outstanding on credit cards jumped to £29bn in March from £24.5bn a year ago, equal to around £675 per card.

"This does suggest some overheating in the economy," warned CCRG researcher Amy Brown. Some of the increase in volumes comes from the greater use of cards at smaller businesses, but even in mature markets such as high street shops and petrol stations, spending "on plastic" is rising rapidly.

"Considering clothing is a mature market for cards, with most shops already accepting plastic, a gain of 25% is surprising," said Ms Brown.

The March spending figures are the highest on record apart from the £14.5bn last December - Christmas is traditionally the biggest spending month of the year.

A spokesman for Barclaycard said: "What you are seeing is a surge in the number of people transferring their spending patterns away from cash and cheques and onto plastic."

The figures will add to fears about growing indebtedness among UK consumers. The Financial Services Authority chairman, Howard Davies, recently called on mortgage providers to restrain lending, partly because the burden of credit cards and personal loans is expanding so rapidly.

The number of cards in consumers' wallets and purses has also continued to surge, with the total reaching nearly 90m cards. This is the equivalent of almost two cards for every man, woman and child in the UK. The figure compares with 82m a year ago.

Spending on services showed the greatest gain dur ing March, rising 74% to £1.7bn from £976m. The CCRG says the leap is largely the result of small businesses such as plumbers and dry cleaners using swipe machines for the first time.

Food and drink showed the smallest gain, up 6% to £2.6bn. Clothing, household and motoring spending rose between 20-30%.

Monthly card spending figures are notoriously erratic, but the six-month moving averages reveal a marked upswing.

In early 1999 spending growth on credit cards was running at an average of 12-13% compared to 18% over the past six months, while debit card growth has increased to 25% from 15%.

fields.headline: Barbed farewell for SmithKline chief
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's best paid chief executive, Jan Leschly, retired at yesterday's annual meeting of SmithKline Beecham, attracting a barbed farewell from the drug company's shareholders.
fields.body:
Britain's best paid chief executive, Jan Leschly, retired at yesterday's annual meeting of SmithKline Beecham, attracting a barbed farewell from the drug company's shareholders.

Mr Leschly, 59, stood down to make way for the Frenchman, Jean-Pierre Garnier, saying: "Good luck, buddy. I just want to tell you, you've got some job to do over the next four or five years."

In his final presentation to investors, Mr Leschly pointed out that SmithKline's market value had increased from £12.2bn to £49bn in his six years at the helm. A planned merger with Glaxo Wellcome will turn it into the world's biggest drugs company.

However, investors remained critical of his notoriously generous pay package - at one stage last year Mr Leschly's renumeration, options and shares were worth more than £91m. One shareholder said: "I would like to wish him a long life, because he needs it to spend some of the money he managed so skilfully to extract out of us."

Another asked why Mr Leschly was being paid until his 60th birthday in September - despite his departure from the company yesterday: "Why do you not change this vulgar story which is rolling on and on and on?"

SmithKline's chairman, Sir Peter Walters, said Mr Leschly's contract entitled him to be paid until retirement age. He was leaving early because it was more convenient to hand over at the beginning of the financial year.

Sir Peter defended the group's pay policy, saying: "Top people are in desperately short supply." He blamed start-up biotech companies and dot.com ventures for offering executives the opportunity to make even more money.

fields.headline: How to avoid an audience
fields.standfirst:
Papa M
Brudenell Social Club, Leeds
**
fields.trailText:
Papa M
Brudenell Social Club, Leeds
**
fields.body:
The perfect setting for these cult American post-rockers' eerie guitar soundscapes would be the closing sequence of Apocalypse Now. Sadly, the Doors got there 20 years ago. Still, the sheer surrealism of the venue, a former working men's club, makes it equally suitable for avant garde music. The vibe is somewhere between a debauched bingo hall and a bombed-out air raid shelter. A shame then, that former Slint/Tortoise man David Pajo's band resolutely refuse to rise to the full house.

The warning signs are on the stage, where there are no microphones, so there are no "hellos" or "goodbyes". Instead, Pajo and bandmates shuffle on and stare intently at each other's playing. A few people are awestruck, others chatter uneasily. God help us if somebody coughs.

The fragile, painstaking nature of Papa M's instrumentals demand a level of interaction between musicians far beyond that of a regular rock band, but surely that makes it all the more important to involve the crowd. With his Bruce Lee/assassin's good looks, Pajo would make a fine anti-hero rock star. But there's no movement, no drama, no acknowledgement that an audience exists. Instead, we're left to make sense of studious but often directionless music that scarcely approaches the more magical moments of their Live From a Shark Cage album. As a military drum explosion briefly threatens to interrupt the monotony, I find myself wondering whether the album's more intricate Fripp & Eno-type constructions are impossible to perform. The answer arrives as the band slope off, leaving their superior recordings to waft into the darkness. Appropriately, it's the highlight of the night.

fields.headline: Ministers plan more stable pensions
fields.standfirst:
New inflation index sought to avoid big changes each year

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Labour is considering linking the basic state pension with a new more stable index of inflation in an attempt to stop big annual variations in the scale of the increase.
fields.body:
Labour is considering linking the basic state pension with a new more stable index of inflation in an attempt to stop big annual variations in the scale of the increase.

But the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, again ruled out increasing the pension in line with earnings, saying the measures introduced over the parliament meant the government had spent an extra £6.5bn on pensioners, £2.5bn more than if the pension had been increased in line with earnings, the staple demand of many pensioner lobby groups.

The Liberal Democrats, however, claimed the government was reneging on its manifesto commitment to ensure pensioners would receive a fair share of the increase in national income. Steve Webb, the party's pensions spokes man, said: "Every year of this parliament the proportion of national income going to pensioners will be lower than in the last year of the Conservative government. The problem is the economy is growing strongly, but the government does not have the mechanisms or the political will to divert it to pensioners."

The government admits it is on the rack over pensions after the record low inflation level last September of 1.1% meant the average state pension rose by 75p this year. Higher inflation, largely due to higher mortgage costs, means the rise from next April will be £2 for a single person and £3 for couples.

The Department of Social Security is considering switching to the index used by the Bank of England to calculate inflation. This strips out mortgage costs. There is also a separate pensions inflation index, but this tends to produce lower increases and is unlikely to be used by the government.

Ministers remain adamantly opposed to the earnings link on the grounds that it will divert excessive sums to richer, mainly younger pensioners, many of whom have occupational pensions.

Ministerial sources said the government's top priorty remained older pensions targetted through the minimum income guarantee and costing £2.2bn in this parliament. The government also remains committed to the winter fuel payment for every pensioner household.

Mr Webb said he would welcome greater stability in pensions, but urged the government to give more money direct to older pensioners. His party supports a £5 a week increase for pensionsers over 80 and £3 increase for over 75s.

Hilary Carter, spokeswoman for Help the Aged, said: "The government needs to learn that it ignores the 10.8m pensioner vote at its peril. The older population is united in its anger over the loss of a decent state pension and will have no hesitation in voting against Labour to register its fury.

"If Gordon Brown wants to retain the 'silver vote', he needs to break for all time this insidious link with inflation."

Meanwhile, it emerged yesterday that up to £79m each week in means-tested benefits may be going unclaimed. The Child Poverty Action Group said it feared up to £4bn a year was not being paid out.

This was in addition to the 40% of people who do not claim non-means tested benefits such as disability living allowance or attendance allowance, the charity said.

It believed the amount of unclaimed social security benefits could exceed the amount estimated to be lost through benefit fraud, which varies between £3bn and £7bn a year.

But the social security secretary, Alistair Darling, again ruled out increasing the pension in line with earnings, saying the measures introduced over the parliament meant the government had spent an extra £6.5bn on pensioners, £2.5bn more than if the pension had been increased in line with earnings, the staple demand of many pensioner lobby groups. The Liberal Democrats, however, claimed the government was reneging on its manifesto commitment to ensure pensioners would receive a fair share of the increase in national income. Steve Webb, the party's pensions spokes man, said: "Every year of this parliament the proportion of national income going to pensioners will be lower than in the last year of the Conservative government. The problem is the economy is growing strongly, but the government does not have the mechanisms or the political will to divert it to pensioners." The government admits it is on the rack over pensions after the record low inflation level last September of 1.1% meant the average state pension rose by 75p this year. Higher inflation, largely due to higher mortgage costs, means the rise from next April will be £2 for a single person and £3 for couples. The Department of Social Security is considering switching to the index used by the Bank of England to calculate inflation. This strips out mortgage costs. There is also a separate pensions inflation index, but this tends to produce lower increases and is unlikely to be used by the government. Ministers remain adamantly opposed to the earnings link on the grounds that it will divert excessive sums to richer, mainly younger pensioners, many of whom have occupational pensions. Ministerial sources said the government's top priorty remained older pensions targetted through the minimum income guarantee and costing £2.2bn in this parliament. The government also remains committed to the winter fuel payment for every pensioner household. Mr Webb said he would welcome greater stability in pensions, but urged the government to give more money direct to older pensioners. His party supports a £5 a week increase for pensionsers over 80 and £3 increase for over 75s. Hilary Carter, spokeswoman for Help the Aged, said: "The government needs to learn that it ignores the 10.8m pensioner vote at its peril. The older population is united in its anger over the loss of a decent state pension and will have no hesitation in voting against Labour to register its fury. "If Gordon Brown wants to retain the 'silver vote', he needs to break for all time this insidious link with inflation." Meanwhile, it emerged yesterday that up to £79m each week in means-tested benefits may be going unclaimed. The Child Poverty Action Group said it feared up to £4bn a year was not being paid out. This was in addition to the 40% of people who do not claim non-means tested benefits such as disability living allowance or attendance allowance, the charity said. It believed the amount of unclaimed social security benefits could exceed the amount estimated to be lost through benefit fraud, which varies between £3bn and £7bn a year.

fields.headline: Doing Elvis proud
fields.standfirst:
The King
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.trailText:
The King
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.body:
When Peter Schaufuss's Elvis Presley ballet ran into copyright difficulties two weeks ago, the Danish choreographer was not only forced to drop 18 of the songs in his original score, he was also forced to drop his hero. In the hastily rejigged version of The King the new protagonist is a British Elvis impersonator called Johnny. Events in Johnny's life run parallel to Presley's - his career disrupted by a spell in the army, and ultimately trashed by drink and drugs - yet, as the hero's triumphs at Las Vegas are relocated to Blackpool, the tale acquires a low rent comedy.

It is hard to criticise the ballet given the speed with which it has been rewritten and the extra energy expended by its dancers. But with the Presley legend at one remove the story loses its tragi-tacky resonance. What's left is a series of disparate dance numbers and a revised set of Presley hits.

The Danish company boasts some very fine performers. An extravagantly supple dancer, Juan Rodriguez as Presley-Johnny has the frisson of the singer's big sexy voice and an undeniable charisma. Also impressive is Quang Van as the hero's friend. A dancer of louche power, he invests the choreography with a subtle blend of thuggery and sex.

But Schaufuss lacks a vernacular instinct. Even though he is right to avoid diluted rock'n'roll, too many of his steps look pale and polite against the drastic rhythms of their music. The dancers aren't given sufficiently individualised moves for us to get intimate with them. It is hard to justify the use of Wagner's Liebestod for the apotheosis of this particular Elvis impersonator. Still, members of an Elvis tribute band who attended felt their hero had been honoured. "From what I saw here tonight," said one, "Elvis would have been proud."

Until May 6. Box office: 020-7863 8000

webTitle: Lewis and board go to war

fields.headline: Lewis and board go to war
fields.standfirst: The former England all-rounder hits back at MacLaurin
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey on the rift between Chris Lewis and the ECB which erupted yesterday into open hostility.
fields.body:
The rift between Chris Lewis and the England and Wales Cricket Board erupted yesterday into open hostility.

Lewis accused the board of "reinventing events" after it dismissed his claims that it had procrastinated and covered up information, passed on by him last summer, that three high-profile England cricketers were linked to possible match-rigging and had been paid "thousands" in backhanders.

The Leicestershire and former England all-rounder was responding to strong criticism from the chairman of the ECB Lord MacLaurin, made in a letter to the county chairmen, in which he described Lewis's assertion as "unbelievable".

Lewis claimed in a recent newspaper article that he had offered the identities of the three players to the ECB last August when he told it of an approach allegedly made to him by Ashim Kheterpal, an Asian businessman, to act as middleman in a scam to rig a test match between England and New Zealand. Kheterpal has denied the allegation.

The board, he said, had dismissed his information concerning the three players as "hearsay" and had leaked the story of his meeting with Kheterpal to the News of the World, which had used it as the basis for an article about him that appeared last summer.

After a lengthy meeting of its management board yesterday the ECB unequivocally denied the sequence of events that Lewis alleges took place. "I am satisfied that there is no foundation whatsoever in the idea that those involved at the board were not interested in the information that was made available by Chris Lewis when he first reported the matter on August 3 1999," MacLaurin wrote in his letter.

"To suggest that the board did not seek to establish immediately from him the names of England players allegedly involved as soon as this information was divulged is unbelievable."

But Lewis's agent Gareth James insists that his client stands by his version of events. "I am absolutely stunned by this letter," he said last night. "It is a complete reinvention of events and it is not over.

"At no stage did the ECB ask for the names of the three England players. Either Lord MacLaurin has been misled or... I hate to think of the other option."

James called for notes taken during the meeting between his client and the board to be made public.

MacLaurin's response, coming after the chairman of the board's discipline standing committee, Gerard Elias QC, had officially cleared all England players past or present of any involvement in match-rigging or bribery, indicated just how much the establishment had been stung by suggestions that it was inept and unwieldy. "I owe it to everyone associated with the game to answer the criticisms that have been levelled at the board," he said.

MacLaurin was also scathing over suggestions that the board had leaked information, which it had distributed to a limited number of board members only on a need-to-know basis. "For the board to have leaked details of this case," he said, "would only have served to undermine the very investigation which it had instigated. The allegations are utterly refuted and I hope this will lay to rest any suspicion that the board has acted improperly."

MacLaurin has quite rightly ignored calls for Lewis to be hauled up on a disrepute charge and the ferocity of his attack was tempered with a plea for cricketers and public alike to allow the player to continue his career in peace. "We have no reason to take action against him," said the ECB chairman.

"He came to us and it showed a lot of guts to come forward. We do not wish to discourage anybody from coming to us with information that may be important.

"We also have no reason to be embarrassed. We dealt with the situation entirely properly and if we had our time over again we would deal with it in exactly the same fashion.

"It is very sad for sportsmen like Chris to put up with jeers from the fans. He should be allowed to continue his career."

webTitle: Jones the mudlark bogs down Surrey

fields.headline: Jones the mudlark bogs down Surrey
fields.standfirst: Surrey 185 Somerset 4-0
fields.trailText: Steffan Jones, the only player in the land to have combined professional careers in cricket and rugby, yesterday tormented the champions with line and length.
fields.body:
As the only player in the land to have combined professional careers in cricket and rugby, there have doubtless been times over the past two years when Steffan Jones has turned up unsure whether to unleash a yorker or an up-and-under.

Urged by Somerset to be more single-minded, the former Wales Under-21 full-back has now given up muddied oafing, not that you could tell yesterday as he demolished the champions with his left leg smeared in west country soil.

Jones completed the job begun by Andy Caddick and Matthew Bulbeck by taking five of the last six wickets to glean his best figures for Somerset, five for 41, as Surrey crashed in 45 overs. Alistair Brown and Adam Hollioake had plundered a dozen runs from the Llanelli lad's opening over, so resilience is clearly an asset.

When the umpires decreed that play in this First Division fixture could start at 3pm, 157 overs having been lost, Surrey were even then reluctant, fearing that the run-ups would be treacherous. This may have influenced Jamie Cox's decision to put them in but in the event his bowlers were not inconvenienced.

Caddick, inevitably, proved a sizeable handful in what will probably be one of his few Taunton shows of the summer. In his first over he had Ian Ward held at short-leg via an inside edge; in his second he opened up Graham Thorpe with a snorter which took the edge for Rob Turner to take the first of two splendid catches that belied the crass decision not to select the leading Englishman in last season's batting averages for a winter tour of any kind.

Noticeably brisker these days, Bulbeck persuaded Mark Butcher to shoulder arms to reduce Surrey to 11 for three, then ended a streaky cameo from Alec Stewart with another leg-before verdict. The mood then altered abruptly as Brown and Hollioake added 74 in 16 overs with such brio that, in two overs either side of tea, Caddick went for 21.

Replacing Caddick, Jones took that early punishment on the chin and spat back. Brown nicked a near yorker, pace and lift did for Hollioake and Martin Bicknell, and when Cox recalled Caddick, guess who clung on at long-leg when the impressive Ben Hollioake mis-hooked.

fields.headline: Double duck debut for Ganguly
fields.standfirst: Lancashire 95-3 v Kent
fields.trailText: It could be a long season for Sourav Ganguly. The Indian captain added a duck on his championship debut, this one first ball, to the one he made on his Lancashire debut in the Benson & Hedges Cup.
fields.body:
It may be a long season for Sourav Ganguly. After sitting around for the best part of a day and a half the Indian captain added a duck on his championship debut, this one first ball, to the one he made on his Lancashire debut in the Benson & Hedges Cup.

After the previous day's washout, only 27 overs were possible yesterday in the First Division game here, but it was an eventful passage of play none the less.

For a while it looked as if Matthew Fleming's decision to ask Lancashire to bat might backfire as Mark Chilton and particularly Mike Atherton began with assurance.

Having survived a raucous shout for leg-before to the day's fourth ball, from Mark Ealham at around 2.30pm, Atherton proceeded to accumulate efficiently off his legs and drive confidently through the covers.

Chilton, like Atherton a product of Manchester Grammar School, took more time to open his broad shoulders; meanwhile Atherton's fallibility outside off stump gave both Ealham and Martin Saggers some encouragement.

But it was Martin McCague who made the breakthrough, his extra pace catching Atherton flat-footed with his snick to third slip well held by James Hockley.

Joe Scuderi, the Australian with an Italian passport, was another making his championship debut but a brief cameo was all he could manage before a ball of full length from Ealham landed on his toe and Lancashire were 38 for two.

Ganguly entered with the understated swagger to which a batsman with a test average of 50 is entitled. But Ealham by now was on a roll and when Ganguly offered no stroke to his very first ball it was asking for trouble.

A slimline Andy Flintoff survived the hat-trick, but only just, and with Chilton he set about repairing the damage. They added 50 in 57 balls, Flintoff getting off the mark with a sumptuous back-foot drive for four and finding his range on several further occasions, and Chilton grew steadily in composure before the rain returned at tea.

Meanwhile, Ganguly cut a forlorn and isolated figure on the Lancashire players' balcony. By all accounts he is finding it hard to settle. A little sunshine would not go amiss, he probably thinks.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Chris Lewis made an impact on the pitch at Derby yesterday when the Leicestershire all-rounder took the key wicket of Derbyshire's Australian batsman Michael di Venuto.
fields.body:
Chris Lewis made an impact on the pitch at Derby yesterday when the Leicestershire all-rounder took the key wicket of Derbyshire's Australian batsman Michael di Venuto.

Di Venuto had raced to his first championship 50 for Derbyshire from only 57 balls, striking 11 fours in his 70, when he played on to Lewis. Derbyshire, once struggling at 129 for four, recovered to reach 227 for six at stumps.

Di Venuto and Rob Bailey, 64 not out, became the first players to score half- centuries on Derbyshire debuts in the same innings.

fields.headline: Keegan pencils in fragile Fowler
fields.trailText: Despite the fact that he has barely been unable to put one foot in front of the other for much of the season, Kevin Keegan admits that he is 'waiting on Robbie Fowler'.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan yesterday dropped a broad and perhaps surprising hint that Robbie Fowler can stroll back into the Euro 2000 squad, even though he has barely been able to put one foot in front of the other for much of the season.

When Fowler came on as a substitute for Liverpool at Everton last Friday it was his first action for almost four months. Having also suffered a 2-month lay-off earlier in the season, he has been restricted to only 11 Premiership matches and three goals.

But the England coach, who says that he has eight contenders for the last four places in his 22-man squad, said: "I am waiting on Robbie Fowler. He is a terrific player who is good to have around the squad. And he is left-footed, which is an advantage because we don't have many of those."

So long as Fowler manages to play in a couple of Liverpool's final games it seems he will take one of the five forward places. That will mean misery for either Sunderland's Kevin Phillips or Manchester United's Andy Cole, since the captain Alan Shearer and Fowler's Liverpool team-mates Emile Heskey and Michael Owen are certainties.

Keegan said: "They have all been scoring regularly but I think Fowler would have been scoring too if he'd been playing. The striking position is definitely the most competitive in my squad."

Steve McManaman's performances for Real Madrid against Manchester United may also earn him a spot. Keegan said: "If you had asked me three or four months ago I would have said that I hadn't seen him play enough good games for Real Madrid. But I have picked him before and everyone knows that I rate him as a player."

Keegan spent Wednesday watching Portugal lose 2-0 to Italy. But he said: "Despite their defeat they looked a very good side and they have an inventive midfield led by [Luis] Figo and Rui Costa.

"Everyone is going on about our match against Germany but I will be telling my players that the biggest game without doubt is Portugal. If you win your first game you can see a way through, and Portugal are a good side who will take points off the other two teams."

Keegan admits that, given the defeats of Chelsea, Manchester United and Leeds in European competition, it would have been possible for England to have had a warm-up game this week. But he doubts whether it would have meant much in preparation for Euro 2000. No team, he says, are laying all their cards on the table yet.

The England coach Derek Fazackerley watched Germany struggle to a 1-1 draw against Switzerland which led their former captain and coach Franz Beckenbauer to declare that "our football is at rock bottom". Keegan is unlikely to fall for that one but insists there is no outstanding side in this summer's tournament.

"I think we are all much of a muchness. I've come under pressure after some of our performances, and so have most of the other leading managers. Only the Czech Republic manager seems to have been free of that, though the other day someone said they are not happy with him."

 In a poll of 3,000 fans by onefootball.com, Germans gave the thumbs-down to their national team in the build-up to Euro 2000, though fans of every other European country believed the holders could retain the trophy. Half the Germans polled added that their team played the most boring football in Europe, and 36% tipped Holland for the title.

fields.headline: England opt out of Turkey
fields.trailText: The Football Association has withdrawn England's Under-18 team from a tournament in Turkey, fearing for the safety of fans and players alike.
fields.body:
The Football Association has withdrawn England's Under-18 team from a tournament in Turkey, fearing for the safety of fans and players alike.

The team were due to contest the eight-nation Ataturk Cup from May 20-28, an invitation-only event, but the FA said that emotions were running too high after the fatal stabbings of two Leeds fans on the eve of the Uefa Cup semi-final at Galatasaray this month.

"It is a disappointment but now is not the time for England to be competing in this tournament in Turkey," said the FA's executive director David Davies. "It is not a decision which has been taken lightly but there were clearly security issues to be considered, particularly with the tournament being played at a number of venues.

"The squad hadn't been selected but it was almost inevitable that there would have been Leeds United players in it. The judgment was that we would be putting an unnecessary burden on the organisers of that tour."

The decision is unlikely to endear the FA to Turkey's Uefa delegate Senes Erzik, who has a vote on the venue for the 2006 World Cup, but as the Ataturk Cup is not a Uefa-sanctioned tournament the FA is hoping the no-show will not discredit England's 2006 bid in the eyes of Fifa, the world game's governing body.

Davies added that the FA had discussed the withdrawal with Turkish officials and intended to meet them again after the season. "We are looking at how to put our relationship back on a firm footing. We are taking the matter of bridge-building very seriously and that will be stepped up."

Doubtless the initiative will be regarded as urgent because England may meet Turkey in a Euro 2000 quarter-final in the Low Counties in June if both teams get past the group stage.

 Two Leeds fans were yesterday banned from domestic and international matches for 12 months and 15 months and fined £75 and £150 for, respectively, being drunk and committing public order offences at the Uefa Cup semi-final second leg with Galatasaray, when 23 arrests were made.
fields.bodyText: The Football Association has withdrawn England's Under-18 team from a tournament in Turkey, fearing for the safety of fans and players alike. The team were due to contest the eight-nation Ataturk Cup from May 20-28, an invitation-only event, but the FA said that emotions were running too high after the fatal stabbings of two Leeds fans on the eve of the Uefa Cup semi-final at Galatasaray this month. "It is a disappointment but now is not the time for England to be competing in this tournament in Turkey," said the FA's executive director David Davies. "It is not a decision which has been taken lightly but there were clearly security issues to be considered, particularly with the tournament being played at a number of venues. "The squad hadn't been selected but it was almost inevitable that there would have been Leeds United players in it. The judgment was that we would be putting an unnecessary burden on the organisers of that tour." The decision is unlikely to endear the FA to Turkey's Uefa delegate Senes Erzik, who has a vote on the venue for the 2006 World Cup, but as the Ataturk Cup is not a Uefa-sanctioned tournament the FA is hoping the no-show will not discredit England's 2006 bid in the eyes of Fifa, the world game's governing body. Davies added that the FA had discussed the withdrawal with Turkish officials and intended to meet them again after the season. "We are looking at how to put our relationship back on a firm footing. fields.headline: Clubs charged for pitch trouble
fields.trailText: Bristol Rovers and Darlington charged by the FA, Tottenham lodge an appeal, and Riedle's short reign comes to an end at Fulham.
fields.body:
Bristol Rovers and Darlington have been charged by the Football Association with failing to control their fans, after incidents in which pitch invaders allegedly attacked an opposition player.

Rovers' charge arises from their game with Stoke at the Memorial stadium on April 1. Stoke's goalkeeper Gavin Ward fended off two fans before stewards and police intervened.

Darlington supporters ran on to the field celebrating an injury-time equaliser in a 2-2 draw at Feethams on April 5 and Shrewsbury's keeper Paul Edwards was assaulted.

The FA spokesman Adrian Bevington said: "Both cases have been treated as very serious matters, taking into account that a player was assaulted by a fan following pitch invasions."

There may be further charges after trouble between rival fans during Stoke's visit to Wigan on February 26.

Tottenham are appealing against the FA's decision to find them guilty of "failing to control their players" in the February match at Leeds in which there was an 18-man brawl. Each club was fined a record £150,000 after the incident.

Karlheinz Riedle's reign as Fulham's caretaker manager has ended after less than a month because of the lung injuries he sustained on Monday while playing against Nottingham Forest.

The German striker, who took control when Paul Bracewell was sacked, went home yesterday after three nights in hospital with a bruised and partly collapsed lung. He will not be fit for the rest of the season so team control will be left to Roy Evans and Alan Smith until Jean Tigana takes over.

The South American World Cup qualifier in La Paz between Bolivia and Colombia was halted for 10 minutes after a linesman was hit by a plastic bottle, one of several that rained down on him after he disallowed a goal for the home team. Bolivia's Erwin Sanchez, who had scored their goal, was sent off for butting the referee in the confusion that followed, then Colombia's Mario Yepes was dismissed for a wild tackle. The game finished 1-1.

 Barcelona have been expelled from this and next season's Copa del Rey and also fined 2m pesetas (£7,000) for refusing to play in last Monday's semi-final second-leg tie against Atletico Madrid.

fields.headline: Schoolboy passes his first exam
fields.standfirst: Hampshire 131 Zimbabweans 19-1
fields.trailText: Tatenda Taibu, Zimbabwe's 16-year-old deputy wicketkeeper takes three catches against Hampshire.
fields.body:
It could hardly be considered a bad half-day's work for the diffident tourists as they limbered up in sweatered preparation for their two-test series against England.

Political distractions or not, they bowled out Hampshire by the 54th over, a modest enough triumph of accurate medium-pace against tentative batting. The psychological lift was timely, though the collective threat remains deceptive. Zimbabwe need to restore confidence and go some way towards shedding an unexceptional reputation by the highest international standards.

Their busy demeanour is as attractive as ever; a team without airs and graces. But they have lost ground after high points in the World Cup and too many of their players are fighting personal battles to rediscover form.

But this should not be said of Pommie Mbangwa and Neil Johnson, although there is nothing remotely ferocious about their pace. They peg away with a minimum of waywardness, relying on the caprices of England's early summer for a little swing and seam.

Mbangwa has a controlled, good-looking action which yesterday brought him four for 19 off 16 overs. Johnson, more privy to our conditions from his county days with Leicestershire, had four for 28 off fewer than nine overs.

Nor were these the only encouraging performances. Their captain Andy Flower had left himself out so that his 16-year-old wicketkeeping deputy Tatenda Taibu could get some immediate experience.

Still at school and not much taller than the stumps, Taibu performed with an unshowy neatness and efficiency that earned him plaudits from the crowd as well as his team-mates. He held three catches and one felt he should have been popping the ball into his satchel.

The sun had peeped through with its usual reluctance for play to start after lunch. Hampshire were sent in and for much of the time sparred with April-style weariness, succumbing too readily to slips, wicketkeeper and gully.

Zimbabwe have always proved themselves nimble ground fielders but are generally less reliable when it comes to holding their close catches. Mbangwa was the bowler who suffered. He had quickly taken over from Bryan Strang when in his second over he had Jason Laney caught at second slip. In his next over, Giles White pushed forward to be taken at the wicket.

The sequence should have continued but Will Kendall survived as Trevor Gripper, at third slip, put the catch down. The worrying trend was sustained when Robin Smith was dropped by Johnson off the gently nagging left-arm persistence of Strang.

Of the Hampshire batsmen, Kendall faced 62 balls to reinforce his stubborn qualities which look like being needed again this summer. Derek Kenway, from whom much is expected, offered the greatest stability before being yorked two short of his half-century.

Zimbabwe themselves finished on 19 for one off 11 overs after losing Grant Flower to a catch at the wicket by Kenway, due to stand in for the injured Adrian Aynes for at least some of the early fixtures.

There was some disappointment that Hampshire included neither Shane Warne nor Alan Mullally. But there could still be plenty to enjoy and to speculate on - if the rain stays away.

webTitle: United pull plug on Van Nistelrooy transfer

fields.headline: United pull plug on Van Nistelrooy transfer
fields.standfirst: Striker refuses request for keyhole surgery on his injured right knee
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy's £18.5m transfer to Manchester United collapsed dramatically last night when the Old Trafford club unexpectedly informed PSV Eindhoven that they were withdrawing their British-record bid for the Dutch international striker.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy's £18.5m transfer to Manchester United collapsed dramatically last night when the Old Trafford club unexpectedly informed PSV Eindhoven that they were withdrawing their British-record bid for the Dutch international striker.

The move came only 24 hours after Van Nistelrooy had been told that he had three weeks to prove his fitness and resurrect the deal. But his ambition of signing for the Premiership champions perished after he refused United's request that he undergo keyhole surgery to ascertain the full extent of the ligament damage caused to his right knee in early March.

He decided that if he was forced into even minor surgery, the operation would adversely affect his recovery programme and his chances of playing for Holland in the European championship this summer.

"Ruud cannot agree to the additional conditions which United have requested for the completion of the transfer," said the PSV spokesman, Pedro Salazar Hewitt. "To agree would be to put in danger his rehabilitation. We have reached an impasse."

United last night confirmed that they were unable to proceed with the deal, the implication being that unless Van Nistelrooy agreed to the surgical examination the transfer was dead in the water.

In a statement they said: "We are very disappointed that the transfer cannot proceed at the present time. Manchester United wish Ruud every success with his rehabilitation programme and will continue to monitor the situation very closely in order to achieve our desire to make him a Manchester United player."

The PSV chairman Harry van Raay said he believed there was now a "less than 50% chance" that Van Nistelrooy would be playing for United at the start of next season.

"The situation is very clear; it is down to a difference of opinion between the medical people at PSV and the medical advisers to United," he said. "I won't be specific but the difference relates to tests to be done, and our club doctor has advised the player not to follow United's procedure. In my opinion the tests which have been suggested are just not possible.

"He has recovered very well, better than even our doctor expected, but even when he is recovering well and the knee is stable he does not seem able to do what the doctors of Manchester United feel is necessary to fulfil their medical tests."

Van Nistelrooy is adamant that he is fast approaching full fitness and insists that he plans to play at least some part in PSV's final league game of the season against NEC Nijmegen on May 14. "I am not upset with the medical people, or with Alex Ferguson, but it is distressing that this has happened and that the move is now in great doubt," he said. "It is a matter of principle."

He injured the medial ligament in his right knee during a friendly game against the Danish club Silkeborg on March 6 and is believed to be at least five weeks away from returning to full fitness.

On Tuesday, United's planned unveiling of their new player was abandoned when it became clear that he was unable to negotiate a mandatory medical examination.

Van Nistelrooy spent much of the following day undergoing further tests at a private hospital in Cheadle, Cheshire, then flew back to the Netherlands in the evening having been told that he should return to Manchester in the middle of next month for another medical.

However, it would seem that United's insurers were so concerned about the player's long-term fitness that they insisted on him entering hospital immediately for exploratory surgery. Van Nistelrooy turned down United's request and, in so doing, scuppered a deal which would have netted him about £42,000 a week over the next five years.

Meanwhile, the Dutch footballing authorities have told him that he must be fully recovered from injury and in a position to resume playing senior football within three weeks if he is to be considered for Euro 2000.

Meanwhile, the Dutch footballing authorities have told him that he must be fully recovered from injury and in a position to resume playing senior football within three weeks if he is to be considered for Euro 2000.

webTitle: Players swapped, loaned, sold... and mortgaged

fields.headline: Players swapped, loaned, sold... and mortgaged
fields.trailText: Imagine the excitement in the Chester City boardroom that day in 1980 when Liverpool paid them £300,000 for Ian Rush. Now the Grimsbys, Yorks and Rochdales can no longer be guaranteed a big payday from a decent transfer every season. A group of football agents have come up with a novel solution.
fields.body:
There was a time when the minnows of professional football were happy to be eaten alive by the sharks of the game. Selling their best players to the big clubs was the game's simple rule of economics long before plcs replaced FCs.

Imagine the excitement in the Chester City boardroom that day in 1980 when Liverpool paid them £300,000 for Ian Rush. Forget the fact that Liverpool made untold riches from the deal and appreciate the glee when the Chester secretary hand-delivered a fat cheque to an exasperated bank manager.

It still goes on, of course - Crewe, for instance, received £3m from Derby for Seth Johnson - but it's now a trickle rather than a constant stream, as a result of cheaper foreign imports and the impact of post-Bosman player power.

The Grimsbys, Yorks and Rochdales can no longer be guaranteed a big payday from a decent transfer every season or so, and that's why the balance sheets of a vast majority of the lower-division clubs are causing apoplexy to all concerned. The numbers don't stack up, banks' patience is being severely tested, and lemming-like capitulation is not far away.

You wonder why they bother, but I suppose Michael Knighton of Carlisle summed it up when he suggested that dreams were "the thread that draws this whole industry together, from parks football to Carlisle to Milan. We all aspire to The Dream."

Against this rather disturbing financial landscape, you can fully understand why boardrooms up and down the country are allowing themselves a few collective chuckles at Manchester United's difficulties in their attempts to spend £18.5m on a Dutchman with an injured knee and a silly name.

Deloitte & Touche has been warning of football's armageddon for years, but it is not a firm of accountants which has come up with a rescue plan. No, it's a firm of Fifa-registered football agents called Premier Management Holdings plc, which recently became the first soccer agency to float on the stock market.

The PMH directors, the lawyer-cum-agent Barry Gold, the former West Ham forward Billy Jennings and the City banker Stuart Lucas, have devised a way of "levelling the playing field a little".

Say, for instance, Colchester want to buy a player from Bristol Rovers and can afford only £100,000. The west country club want £200,000 so the deal would, under normal circumstances, collapse. PMH, with Football Association backing, will assess the quality of the player and, if satisfied, invest the difference by taking a stake in the future transfer value of the player. As a result, clubs can buy a better player than they would otherwise be able to afford.

Alternatively a club with a good player, by giving up a percentage of a future fee, can hold on to their prize asset for a little longer and hope to receive a higher transfer fee at a later date. As Gold put it: "We will share in the current pain but also, hopefully, a future gain."

It must also be better for a young player to continue to develop with regular first-team football in a lower division than collecting splinters in his backside in a Premiership dug-out.

The transfer market today is totally dominated by the Bosman ruling, with players often allowing their contracts to run out. But Premier Management argues that this can cause a breakdown in the relationship between the club and the player.

Clubs are in a no-win dilemma: if they allow the player's contract to expire they get no transfer fee, and if they sell him in the months approaching that deadline they receive an inferior fee. PMH believes that if it takes a stake in that player's future value the club will be able to offer the player a new contract, pay him what he wants and receive a bigger transfer fee later (as, of course, will PMH).

In its way the PMH idea will make a difference, and its initiative is sure to prompt rivals to follow suit, but it can never be seen as the complete answer to football's financial prayers.

But for as long as there are Premiership owners prepared to invest millions in footballers, there will be chairmen of struggling Football League clubs prepared to invest hours of worry in the pursuit of The Dream. God bless 'em.

fields.headline: LS Lowry
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the industrial artist on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the industrial artist on the net
fields.body:
1. According to one song sung by schoolchildren and on the 70s hit single by Brian and Michael, LS Lowry painted "matchstick men and matchstick cats and dogs".

2. But with the opening of the new Lowry centre in Salford, Greater Manchester, today we can appreciate the painter for the pioneer he truly was.

3. The centre's dockside location and industrial aesthetic signal the way in which the northern artist led the way in urban living.

4. Yes, long before it was fashionable to at least pretend that you spent your days in a inner-city factory or warehouse Lowry painted people who were doing it for real - way back in the 20th century.

5. The only downer was that many of them worked long hours for little pay in dull, tedious jobs.

6. Thanks to the Pennine coal fields and Atlantic port of Liverpool, the northern cities in Lowry's native Lancashire were among the most heavily industrialised parts of Britain and provided the subject for the bulk of his pictures.

7. Like a modern-day advertising executive or fashion designer he was obsessed with the immense industrial buildings at the heart of the industrial towns. So much so that the human characters often become part of a featureless foreground as the aforementioned matchstick men and matchstick cats and dogs.

8. During his lifetime his art received a mixed reception. Now it appears the world has caught up with him and - to almost universal acclaim - the new Tate Modern gallery opens next month in a former power station in Southwark, south London.

9. Lowry was a private person: he never drank or smoked and once said that he got all the pleasure he needed from his work. He was devoted to his mother and, after her death, recalled that "she did not understand my painting, but she understood me and that was enough".

10. His most expensive painting, Going to the Match was sold to the Professional Footballers Association for £1,926,500 in December - a record price at auction for any modern British painting. It shows a crowd of fans on their way to Bolton Wanderers' home ground and, said PFA chief executive Gordon Taylor, represents "the heart and soul of the game".

webTitle: Odeon opens doors to art-house crowd

fields.headline: Odeon opens doors to art-house crowd
fields.trailText: Once the bastion of all things mainstream, the Odeon chain of cinemas is dipping a toe in the art-house waters in a deal with the BFI. From today, the BFI at Odeon scheme will commandeer one screen at eight Multiplexes across the UK to showcase films that normally struggle to reach a wider audience.
fields.body:
Once the bastion of all things mainstream, the Odeon chain of cinemas is dipping a toe in the art-house waters in a deal with the BFI. From today, the BFI at Odeon scheme will commandeer one screen at eight Multiplexes across the UK to showcase films that normally struggle to reach a wider audience.

The scheme will concentrate on independently produced British and American pictures, foreign-language film and re-released classics from the past. The first interlopers onto Odeon territory include the Oscar-winning Boys Don't Cry, Jane Campion's Holy Smoke and the reissued A Matter of Life and Death.

The BFI at Odeon scheme will be in place for at least the next twelve months. In addition to daily or weekly screenings, the scheme is also planning wider seasons, festivals and retrospectives of the work of such luminaries as Alfred Hitchcock and Humphrey Bogart. fields.body:
Now in its fourth year, the annual onedotzero season (from today - April 28 - to May 7 at London's ICA) provides a showcase for the cutting edge of cinematic techniques. The season runs the gamut between digital film, interactive movies and live performance art and kicks off with the acclaimed Japanese art-pic Pornostar. Of course, such experimental stylings may be too art-house for some tastes, the news that George Lucas is planning to film the next Star Wars picture with digital cameras make it all seem terribly current.

Once the white-hot edge of film-making, the assorted treats of onedotzero are in danger of becoming this year's movie mainstream.

For full details of onedotzero screenings, visit the ICA website

fields.headline: Belles sing out
fields.standfirst: Martin Wainwright gets the lowdown on the first-ever women's FA Cup final tune
fields.trailText: The musically primitive world of the football chant discovered descants, harmonies and counterpoint this week with the launch of Britain's first women's Cup Final song.
fields.body:
The musically primitive world of the football chant discovered descants, harmonies and counterpoint this week with the launch of Britain's first women's Cup Final song.

Violins, organ and choir accompany 25 sopranos and contraltos in the specially-commissioned anthem in D Minor for Doncaster Belles, who take on Croydon Ladies for the FA Women's trophy on Monday.

Two 'subtle and delicate' duets alternate with a chorus of the club's first team and reserve players, which composer Mark Morris described as 'very powerful when they all pile in.' The song, Northern Pride, also includes a prolonged rap section, working through the names of the players and their various achievements.

'We've a bit of a reputation for pioneering,' said Mick Abrahams, commercial manager of the Belles, who are the only women football club not affiliated to a professional men's team. 'We wanted something a bit different, and maybe a bit more sophisticated, than great FA Cup anthems we have known and maybe wished we could forget.'

Famous for sticking in the mind as relentlessly as TV jingles, the genre includes Chelsea's Blue Is The Colour and Spurs' Nice One, Cyril, both of which reached the record charts. Less hyped equivalents have followed a pattern of simple settings and libretto, as in Oldham Athletic's 'Meat pies, sausage roll/Come on Oldham, give us a goal' or Luton Town's 'Hatters, Hatters, what a great team/We'll show the others that we are the cream.'

The Belles are aiming for something more complex, according to Mr Morris, a Doncaster club singer who decided that women's voices were football anthems' missing ingredient. He said: 'The girls do a lot of singing - they always have a karaoke session after the match. There are some excellent voices in there, clear and strong.'

Belles and England women's captain Gillian Coulthard said that her voice was best confined to the shower room but 'some of the other girls certainly fancy themselves as karaoke queens.' The song, published on CD yesterday, was composed by Mr Morris, 42, in a period of triumphant inspiration after the Belles eliminated Arsenal women's team in the semi-final. He said: 'Using D Minor gave it a bit of a mood, I felt, and the Belles supply the rest.'

fields.headline: Timeline of anti-capitalism
fields.standfirst: How the disparate groups came together
fields.trailText: 1 May 1992: Avon, Somerset and Gloucestershire police prevent the Avon Free Festival from taking place. The plan backfires as convoys of travellers' vehicles are forced over the border into Worcestershire in the jurisdiction of West Mercia Police. A four-day party takes place on Castlemorton Common. Among the many sound systems are the Spiral Tribe, a newly formed, highly politicised group. At the end of the four days Spiral Tribe refuse to stop. They are arrested, charged with conspiracy to cause a public nuisance and have their equipment seized.
fields.body:
1 May 1992: Avon, Somerset and Gloucestershire police prevent the Avon Free Festival from taking place. The plan backfires as convoys of travellers' vehicles are forced over the border into Worcestershire in the jurisdiction of West Mercia Police. A four-day party takes place on Castlemorton Common. Among the many sound systems are the Spiral Tribe, a newly formed, highly politicised group. At the end of the four days Spiral Tribe refuse to stop. They are arrested, charged with conspiracy to cause a public nuisance and have their equipment seized.

4 June 1992: Spiral Tribe hold an ad hoc street party in Canada Square, next to Canary Wharf (then a half-empty office block) in London. 1,000 people manage to dance for a little over an hour before 300 police seal off roads and move in to make arrests. Nonetheless, many see the event a success and proof that urban areas can be reclaimed temporarily.

December 1993: The Criminal Justice And Public Order Bill is passed in Britain, outlawing unlicensed all-night raves. Spiral Tribe emigrate to Europe.

1 January 1994: With a battle cry of "Ya Basta" (enough is enough), People's Global Action (PGA) is formed in Southern Mexico to coincide with the formation of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The group makes early use of the internet as a communication and resistance tool. Today, PGA is the largest umbrella organisation in the anti-capitalism movement.

April 1994: Born out of the London Cycling Campaign, Critical Mass holds its first demonstration in London, when 90 people cycle around the Bullring and Millbank roundabouts. The demonstration is repeated on a monthly basis and similar organisation are formed in cities around the world. The critical mass web wheel - a circuit of interlinked international sites - is set up.

May 1996: Nearly 10,000 demonstrators occupy a stretch of the M41 in west London. The event is organised by a new group calling itself Reclaim the Street (RTS). An estimated 10,000 people take part in the Demonstration, which quickly turns into an impromptu rave. Several arrests are made, but the day is free of violence.

February 1998: The first Reclaim the Streets demonstration is held in Sydney, where 3,000 people manage to blockade the busy Enmore Road in the city centre. After the road is taken, Sydney police cooperate with the protesters and RTS negotiates regular closures of the road with the city council.

May 1998: First RTS "global party". Illegal street parties are held simultaneously in 17 cities across the globe. The internet is used as the main means of communication for the first time. All parties pass relatively peacefully.

July 1998: RTS activists shut down the eastbound Central Line on the London underground by climbing on the roof of a tube train at Bank station. The action is in support of striking tube workers.

18 June 1999: Thousands mass in the City of London for the inaugural "carnival against capitalism" or J18. Demonstrators occupy Southwark Bridge, which is swiftly converted into another street party. Violence erupts in the centre of the City, where a minority of protesters try to storm the London International Financial Futures Exchange. Dozens are arrested and 150 injured. Similar demonstrations are held around the world. Most pass relatively peacefully, though 18 arrests are made in New York.

16 October 1999: Groups calling for a review of immigration and asylum laws in Europe hold simultaneous demonstration in nine countries across the continent. The action is timed to coincide with European Council Summit in Tampere, Finland. Activists in Frankfurt shut down the airport for six hours by attaching foil-covered balloons filled with helium to fences, thereby interfering with radar. Demonstrators set up a media centre in Tampere to galvanise the groups and distribute digital pictures and eyewitness accounts over the internet.

30 November 1999: The infamous "Battle for Seattle". Tens of thousands of demonstrators from nearly 1,200 non-governmental organisations in 87 countries call for wholesale reform of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) which is meeting in Seattle. Protesters manage to delay the summit for six hours. Police use tear gas to break-up the demonstrations and there are hundreds of arrests. In London crowds congregate around Euston Station. Police surround the protesters and make many arrests.

18 April 2000: Protesters attempt to block a meeting of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank in Washington DC. Police react much more quickly than in Seattle, moving in with tear gas, billy clubs and motor cycles. Demonstrators fail to prevent or delay the meeting and eventually compromise by agreeing to the voluntary mass arrest of 600 of them. Both sides claim victory as the meeting goes ahead but demonstrators grab the headlines.

fields.headline: Keegan's bluff
fields.standfirst: If Kevin Keegan wants to include Robbie Fowler in the England squad for Euro 2000 he must bring six strikers argues Sean Ingle
fields.trailText: If Kevin Keegan wants to include Robbie Fowler in the England squad foor Euro 2000 he must bring six strikers argues Sean Ingle
fields.body:
Once again Kevin Keegan is in danger of letting his heart rule his head. Yesterday the England coach all-but admitted that Robbie Fowler will make the Euro 2000 squad - providing he can struggle through Liverpool's remaining games without picking up yet another injury.

"I am waiting on Robbie Fowler," Keegan said. "He is a terrific player who is good to have around the squad. And he is left-footed, which is an advantage because we don't have many of those."

Damn right Kevin - if you are talking about a fully-fit Robbie Fowler.

Because in this creatine-laden world of modern football - where the prevailing wisdom is that you must possess a sprinter's pace, a boxer's physique or a long-distance runner's stamina to succeed - Robbie Fowler is different. His sharpness of mind, rather than any overwhelming physical attributes, enables him to steal space in even the most crowded of penalty boxes and snatch goals from seemingly impossible situations.

In his prime he is the best natural finisher in England. But come Euro 2000 - which starts in just six weeks remember - Robbie Fowler almost certainly won't be in prime condition. And if that's the case why should Keegan choose him ahead of Kevin Phillips or Andy Cole?

At the moment the decision is really is that simple, because Keegan has insisted he will only pick five strikers in his 22 man squad. Alan Shearer, Emile Heskey and Michael Owen are certainties. Therefore if Fowler goes, Phillips or Cole won't.

But Fowler's fitness and his form at the moment are both open to question.

First off, he's been injured most of the past year. When he came on as a substitute for Liverpool at Everton last Friday it was his first game for almost four months, and he also suffered a two-month lay-off earlier in the season. With a record like that, what happens if the ankle goes again during Euro 2000 and England are restricted to only four front-line strikers - or perhaps even three if Michael Owen suffers more hamstring problems.

Furthermore, what about Fowler's form? So far he has been restricted to only 11 Premiership matches and three goals this season - during which, by his own admission, he hasn't been at his best (except for a stellar performance against Arsenal). For the most part he looked like he was struggling to get over an injury he suffered at the back-end of last season. Why should his recovery period be any shorter this time round?

If Keegan wants to risk bringing Fowler then he must stop boxing himself in, and pick six strikers instead of five. My six would be Alan Shearer, Michael Owen, Kevin Phillips, Emile Heskey, Robbie Fowler and Andy Cole.

Alan Shearer picks himself although, as even he seems to realise, he is a forlorn shadow of his former greatness. He shouldn't be a certain starter (but he will be). Michael Owen, who has added closer control to his bewildering pace and accuracy, should be in the first eleven (but isn't certain to be).

Emile Heskey is one of Keegan's favourites, and deserves to be in the squad despite being as raw as French steak and possessing the worrying tendency (for a striker especially) to fear the six-yard box as much as an impressionable child frets over the boogieman.

I would place Sunderland's Kevin Phillips ahead of Heskey, but despite his phenomenal goal record in the Premiership Keegan doesn't rate him that highly. Fortunately for Phillips, Keegan doesn't trust Cole either, although with his pace and all-round game he should make the squad. And despite my earlier reservations about Fowler's injury and form, I would bring him along too.

That makes six strikers, one more than Keegan wants to bring. But the policy makes a lot of sense - Fowler, Phillips and Cole are all much more likely to play a part than Richard Wright or Keegan's eighth choice defender, and there's also the back-up if Fowler or Owen get injured. Finally, if you're still unconvinced, ask yourself this: if England are trailing Holland in the Euro 2000 semi-final who would you want Keegan to bring on - Robbie Fowler or Phillip Neville?
