fields.headline: Oxfam fury at education summit
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Initial optimism that UN bodies, non-government groups and ministers would back an international action plan with extra money to bring basic education to more than 125m children were dashed last night in favour of vague commitments from the world community.
fields.body:
Initial optimism that UN bodies, non-government groups and ministers would back an international action plan with extra money to bring basic education to more than 125m children were dashed last night in favour of vague commitments from the world community.

Non-governmental groups were last night meeting in emergency session to decide whether to walk out of the world education summit. "We are bitterly disappointed", said Kevin Watkins of Oxfam, one of four NGOs on the committee drafting the final communication which will be presented later today. "All references to a global plan of action have been replaced and all decisions on the core issue of how the world community responds to the accepted crisis in education are being postponed."

Earlier, Kofi Annan, the World Bank, the heads of the several UN agencies and representatives of hundreds of non-government groups had urged immediate international political commitment and an end to the rhetoric that has bedevilled the conference so far.

But the principle of an international plan has not been popular with all countries. Development secretary Clare Short and the Department for International Development argued yesterday that sufficient funds were already available to bring education to everyone and that education should not be separated from poverty or other development priorities.

In a speech to the conference yesterday, she said: "I do not support a call for new separate funds for education, new conditionality or a new set of education objectives. Progress on education must go together with progress on other essential development objectives."

Later she said that the £2.5bn a year that the non-governmental groups from 180 countries were calling for to bring primary education to everyone, was "tokenistic". "£32bn in overseas development assistance is available already. The problem is not money. To say you need £2.5bn is tokenism; it won't change anything."

Ms Short has argued that the international community should back countries prepared to reform their educational policies to include the poorest and that many governments are corrupt or do not have the right policies in place to deliver effectively. Britain prefers to work on a country by country basis and has increased education by more than £300m a year with good results. However, most of the money goes to 12 preferred countries.

Too much money, she said, was siphoned off by elites in developing countries or was wasted on bad quality programmes. "You cannot pour money into budgets going down the tubes. If you get behind reformers, you can have massive achievements. You cannot build a quality education system in rotten corrupt dictatorships. Even the Archangel Gabriel can't do that."

Britain also objected to parts of the World Bank plan mooted earlier this week to "fast-track" a few countries who could show that they wanted to bring primary education to all in a very few years. "We should fast-track any country ready to move'" Ms Short said. "But you can't just fast-track education alone."

Yesterday James Wolfensohn, head of the World Bank, said that Britain preferred "country-led activities rather than generalities" but that there was no fundamental disagreement with Ms Short. "Our objectives are simple - to take countries with a plan who want to move ahead and then bring the international community together behind them to come up with examples of real progress." Mr Wolfensohn said that the World Bank, already the world's largest international provider of education, would make extra money available for primary education. "We are prepared to stretch [beyond the £1.2bn already given each year] if programmes are viable."

But he agreed with Ms Short, saying that money would probably not be the issue. "I'm most concerned that management of the education budget in the countries is used effectively. But, yes, we are prepared to put more in."

webTitle: Van Nistelrooy out for a year after new injury

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy out for a year after new injury
fields.trailText: Ruud van Nistelrooy could be out for as long as a year after he ruptured his anterior cruciate ligament in a training incident earlier today.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy could be out for as long as a year after he ruptured his anterior cruciate ligament in a training incident earlier today.

The Dutch striker fell awkwardly after going for a header in training, buckling the same right knee he hurt six weeks ago while attempting a bicycle kick. He was able to walk off the pitch but was taken to St Amna Hospital in the nearby town of Geldrop to assess the damage.

This afternoon PSV club doctor Cees Rein van der Hoogenband carried out an exploratory operation on the Dutch international and found a further knee problem.

PSV spokesman Pedro Salazar-Hewitt said the club had still to decide on an operation but admitted the star striker could be out for between eight and twelve months.

Earlier he had explained how the injury on the training ground came about. "Van Nistelrooy was about three-quarters way through his training programme when it went wrong. He jumped for a header and when he landed he hurt his right knee.

"He was in great pain, but after two minutes the pain lessened and he stood up himself and walked to the dressing room. About two minutes later he was on his way to the hospital."

United were waiting to see how well the 23-year-old would recover from his medial ligament injury and this new injury has set the deal back even further.

However Salazar-Hewitt claimed that was no longer the most important issue. "We've been in contact with Manchester, but the transfer is not the question any more," said Salazar-Hewitt. "We're using all our energies at PSV to help and support Ruud at this difficult moment.

"We understand also the disappointment of Manchester, and Mr Alex Ferguson and Mr Martin Edwards and we hope everything we be all right. He's a young man and a strong guy and we'll wait and see what happens when he comes back in a year's time."

On Tuesday United had wanted Van Nistelrooy to undergo key-hole sugery to make sure his medial ligament injury would cause no lasting damage. But the Dutch international feared the minor surgery would jeopardise his chances of being fit to play in Euro 2000.

PSV and van Nistelrooy insisted that the injury had cleared up and that he would be able to play in the European Championships. But United were not convinced as a medial ligament injury can lead to a more serious cruciate ligament damage and stopped the proposed £18.5m deal - a move that has proven remarkably prescient.

webTitle: Cutting edge Dobson wins online campaign

fields.headline: Cutting edge Dobson wins online campaign
fields.standfirst:
Labour's candidate for London mayor may be struggling according to the opinion polls, but he has won the vote of technophiles by becoming the first British politician to advertise online.
View the Dobbo banner
fields.trailText: Labour's candidate for London mayor may be struggling according to the opinion polls, but he has won the vote of technophiles by becoming the first British politician to advertise online.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson's campaign team is to boost his hopes of becoming London's mayor by making him the first British politician to branch into the world of online advertising.

With adverts on sites such as thisislondon.com [the Evening Standard online] and capitalfm.com [Capital Radio], Labour's candidate follows the likes of John McCain and George W Bush in the USA, who recently used targeted political ads to great effect in the Republican primaries.

Mr Dobson has hired the San Francisco-based political internet consultancy Aristotle.com - which worked for both Republican candidates - to manage this phase of his online strategy.

Aristotle created banner ads that successfully targeted Virginians to "put McCain on the ballot" by clicking and registering. Meanwhile, key voters in Iowa and New Hampshire received an "interactive tax calculator" where voters could work out how much less tax they would pay by voting Bush.

Mr Dobson's ads are far simpler. They carry only the familiar Frank logo, his "Beware the cost of Livingstone" slogan, and allow users to click through to his website. But by UK standards, Aristotle's spokesman considers that "Frank is cutting edge".

He may be languishing in the polls, but the virtual Frank's presence is far more dynamic. Even before Mr Dobson's paid ads appear on other sites, frank-dobson.org.uk has long been tempting the public with the offer of free, easy-to-use banners to enhance their own websites.

Kate McCarthy, manager of frank-dobson.org, claims about 100 people have now downloaded them. "Whether they've put them up I don't know - but all the London constituency parties and London MPs with websites have them."

The online campaign team also boasts a rapid-email-response unit and the first secure credit card donation service. Electronic contributions to date are, McCarthy admits, "not a lot".

However, she reports a spectacular response to the opportunity to watch the campaign video online. With more than 600 downloads since its appearance last Friday, Frank: the Movie appears to have been the surprise hit of the bank holiday weekend.

webTitle: Drugs turf war is linked to Telford hangings

fields.headline: Drugs turf war is linked to Telford hangings
fields.standfirst:
Drugs in Britain: special report
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Errol McGowan, one of two black men found hanged in mysterious circumstances in Telford, Shropshire, may have been unwittingly caught up in a turf war between rival drug gangs shortly before he died.
fields.body:
Errol McGowan, one of two black men found hanged in mysterious circumstances in Telford, Shropshire, may have been unwittingly caught up in a turf war between rival drug gangs shortly before he died.

Detectives investigating his death initially concentrated on the theory that the 34-year-old might have been the target of racists who had subjected him to two years of abuse, including death threats.

They now believe the circumstances surrounding his death on July 2 last year were far more complicated and are investigating whether there is a link between his death and a turf war between white and Asian gangs vying for control of the council estates in the Wellington area of the town.

Mr McGowan, a father of three, was known to be fiercely anti-drugs and there is no suggestion that he was personally involved in drug dealing.

There is also no doubt that he had suffered severe racial abuse, including death threats, in the months before he died and that the initial police investigation last year was at fault for presuming that he had committed suicide.

But Det Supt Mel Shore, who is leading the inquiry, has been forced to widen the scope of the investigation because of revelations about the depth of the drugs problem in the area.

The Guardian has learned that one of Mr McGowan's friends was a well-known drug dealer involved in a battle between Asian and white gangs around Regent Street, Urban Gardens and Victoria Avenue.

Sources described how Mr McGowan was increasingly unhappy about the involvement of his associates in the drugs scene - it made him a target for both sides - and had even talked about exposing their activities.

His discomfort was heightened when a teenager approached him and pleaded for help. The boy was a dealer who thought he was in over his head. Mr McGowan lent him money to leave Telford.

A source said: "The police would be wrong to assume that the abuse Errol was getting was purely down to race. This was not a race issue on its own. He was targeted because some of his associates were involved in drugs."

Mr McGowan, a nightclub doorman, was found hanging from a doorknob by the flex of an iron. There were no marks on his body or signs that he had been drugged. The police originally dismissed the case as suicide.

However, his family were convinced of foul play. Mr McGowan was hanging just 35 inches from the floor. The iron which the flex was cut from was hidden. Neighbours heard a loud banging noise in the street in the hours before his body was discovered, and saw two men entering the house. Neither has come forward.

In the days before he died, Mr McGowan had spoken to his brother, Clifton, about his wedding to Sharon Buttery, which was due to be held in Jamaica. A reception was planned on their return.

Errol McGowan's nephew Jason, 20, was found hanging by his belt from iron railings on New Year's Day, near a pub where earlier he had been celebrating with his wife, Sinead. Jason had been investigating the circumstances of his uncle's death and had also received death threats.

Clifton McGowan told the Guardian that Jason "was getting very close" to finding the people responsible for Errol's death when he died.

Clifton remembered a call on his mobile phone last December. The voice said: "If you lot don't back off this Errol thing, one of you will pay."

West Mercia was forced to launch a joint investigation into the deaths in February after pressure from the family. The new inquiry is being overseen by John Grieve, the head of Scotland Yard's racial and violent crimes task force.

The police have questioned and released several men allegedly behind the racist abuse levelled at Errol. One of them, a forklift truck driver called Rob Boyle, told reporters last month that he had not murdered Errol or Jason McGowan.

A spokesman for West Mercia said: "We are aware of drug issues locally and have taken steps to address them. It is not possible to say what part drug issues may have played in the deaths of either Errol or Jason McGowan."

fields.headline: Martin launches appeal over 'jury nobbling'
fields.trailText: Lawyers representing farmer Tony Martin today launched an appeal against his conviction for the murder of a teenage burglar.
fields.body:
Lawyers representing farmer Tony Martin today launched an appeal against his conviction for the murder of a teenage burglar.

They have also said they may seek an injunction against Norwich crown court after receiving reports that court staff were deterring trial witnesses and jurors from contacting the farmer's defence team.

Martin's solicitor Nick Makin said that one of the grounds of appeal would be the intimidation of witnesses and members of the jury.

"We have heard from some people that the local court in Norwich has been discouraging people from contacting us in connection with witnesses or jurors being intimidated," said Mr Makin. "We are taking this up with the court officials. If it turns out to be correct, we will probably go for an injunction against the local court. We are told some witnesses have telephoned the court and been told by the court that they should not contact the defence solicitors."

Asked about the allegations that court staff were deterring callers from contacting Martin's defence team, Norwich crown court official Mike Haw said: "If Mr Makin has written to me I haven't received his letter yet and I don't know why he should be saying that."

Martin, 55, of Emneth Hungate in Norfolk, was found guilty of murdering Fred Barras, 16, at Norwich crown court last week, following an eight-day trial. He was sentenced to life imprisonment after being convicted of murder by a 10-2 majority.

Martin was also convicted of wounding a second burglar, Brendan Fearon, with intent to cause grievous bodily harm. The farmer was cleared of attempting to murder Fearon and of possessing a pump-action shotgun with intent to endanger life.

Jurors heard that the burglars had been shot after breaking into Martin's isolated home late at night in August. It was alleged that Martin, who had suffered a number of other burglaries, hated criminals and gypsies and had shot the burglars "like rats in a trap". The farmer said he fired in self-defence.

Documents sent to the court of appeal, and which have not been publicly disclosed at the request of the court, set out six main grounds of appeal, said Mr Makin.

The grounds, according to Martin's defence team, are firstly that the judge failed to tell the jury what constitutes self-defence and that they should look at the question of self-defence "from the viewpoint of the victim of crime at the time that the crime was being committed". He also did not inform the jury that a victim of crime can take action to protect both himself and his property.

Secondly, a fair trial was "not possible in an atmosphere of intimidation of both witnesses and jury".

Thirdly, the judge wrongly allowed evidence about Martin's opinion on burglars and travellers - opinions which Martin denied he held.

Fourthly, in his summing up, the judge failed to tell the jury that the defence and prosecution agreed on the most likely sequence of events in Bleak House on the night Fred Barras died. "Mr Martin fired below a torch being shone at him by (another burglar, Brendon) Fearon and as a result of avoiding firing at Fearon holding the torch, Mr Barras was hit," said Mr Makin. The judge also did not mention that Mr Barras could not be seen by Martin as he fired the weapon, said Mr Makin.

Fifthly, the prosecution "changed their tack in the middle of the trial" and suggested Martin had "shot burglars like rats in a trap". Mr Makin said: "The prosecution should have mentioned this earlier - it had at no time been part of their case until the trial was well under way that Mr Martin was alleged to have set a trap. Furthermore, there was no evidence to support this prosecution allegation."

Finally, the jury's verdict "could not be rational" as it found Martin did not intend to endanger life with his shotgun yet they found he had murdered Mr Barras with it.

Concerns about intimidation were expressed by lawyers after a woman claiming to be a juror called a Norwich-based local radio phone-in the day after Martin was convicted.

She alleged in a call to Broadland 102 FM that jurors had been intimidated by people staring at them from the courtroom's public gallery. Broadland insisted the woman caller had not spoken of being "intimidated, pressured or nobbled".

On Wednesday Norwich-based BBC Radio Norfolk said it had also been in touch with a juror and been told that members of the panel felt uneasy.

Martin's lawyers have mounted their own investigation and have appealed for jurors to contact them. "Mr Martin hopes that the court of appeal will deal with this as quickly as possible and that he can get out of prison," said Mr Makin.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  big stitches
fields.trailText: Fashion is returning to its roots: needle and thread are what it's all about, lest we forget. Which is presumably why fat stitches have started appearing on the outside of clothes this season. Are designers simply bored of the perfect finish? On the spring/summer catwalks, Paul Smith had hessian stitches, while Givenchy had big, child-like ones; Sonia Rykiel roughly sewed cherries and flowers on to bags and tops, and Stella McCartney at Chloe went craft crazy, stitching multicoloured tigers, eagles and faces on to frayed white skirts and - gasp! - leaving the threads hanging loose. For high street offerings, meanwhile, try Top Shop and Karen Millen.

fields.headline: A brush with fame
fields.standfirst: Almost every week sees the launch of a glossy new cosmetic range. But are they any good?  Jess Cartner-Morley meets legendary make-up artist Bobbi Brown to find out
fields.trailText: Almost every week sees the launch of a glossy new cosmetic range. But are they any good? Jess Cartner-Morley meets legendary make-up artist Bobbi Brown to find out
fields.body:
Bobbi Brown, premier league make-up artist and global beauty entrepreneur, has a seductive way with words. Expressing her disdain for ugly, clumpy, long-lasting lipsticks, she says she prefers "lipstick that slowly fades away, so it looks like you've eaten a cherry". Sitting next to Brown, a tiny woman with a husky voice and clever, twinkIy eyes, you can't help wanting to look like you've eaten a cherry, too. She is persuasive like that. Poetic imagery aside, she has a disarming habit of talking sense - disarming because, in a world in which moisturisers promise eternal youth and perfumes everlasting love, Brown's beauty philosophy has never wavered from her statement that "women just want to look like themselves, but prettier".

Hardly rocket science, really, but it's got Bobbi Brown a long way. She was one of the first make-up artists to create her own cosmetics range - a move that has been followed by everyone from Francois Nars to Trish McEvoy, from Laura Mercier to Jeannine Lobell. But when it launched in 1991, Brown's range, Bobbi Brown Essentials, was truly an original idea. Strange as it may seem now, hers was the first range based on neutral, skin-toned shades. Foundations and concealers were yellow-based, a truer reflection of most women's complexions than the pink-toned shades that then dominated the counters. There were 10 lipsticks, numbered one to 10, all variations on nude. The range was an instant success and Brown became a familiar figure on television and in magazines. Now the company, which was acquired by Estée Lauder in 1996, is in a phase of expansion, with a new range imminent and other projects, such as a teenage how-to book of make-up, in the pipeline.

But if the 90s was the decade in which make-up artists made their names, this year has seen a burst of cosmetic activity from another source: designers. Calvin Klein's range, which arrived in Britain in March, was the first to make a major splash but American designers Anna Sui and Vera Wang have both put their names to ranges, with persistent though unconfirmed rumours of plans from Prada. Designers, of course, have a ready-made aspirational image with which to bait women into shelling out for a new blusher. The sleek transparent and silver packaging of Calvin Klein's make-up reflects the sleek, minimal, I-work-in-a-Manhattan-art-gallery image of his clothes, while Anna Sui's swirly boho packaging is a direct cull from her laidback, downtown boutique persona.

Brown loves the Calvin Klein packaging but is otherwise unimpressed by designers inching on to her territory. "I think it's a trend that will be over in a couple of years. All the make-up artists have launched, now the designers are launching. Who's next? Models? Photographers? Editors? Everyone thinks it's easy and it's not that easy. Actually I think I'd have better luck launching clothes. Which I'm not going to do."

Ranges Brown does like include the professional French range Make Up For Ever, which she adores for its dense pigment. She loves how Chanel make-up is presented ("They have the best packaging") and "could find some good blushers at Clinique". But generally, she is less than blown away by the make-up on offer today. "There are plenty of colours out there, but a lot of them make you look silly. No one wants to look silly. And everyone does neutrals now, but most people's neutrals wash out the colour of your face. Mine don't. It's not about taking away colour, it's about the right colour."

Despite her relationship with research giants Lauder, Brown is uninterested in new technologies: waterproof mascara has got gentler, but there have been few other advances that interest her. "It's all marketing buzz. What I do is not about that. I stick to what I know," says Brown, who has made-up armies of catwalk models in her time.

"Fashion does affect beauty because clothes and make-up need to tie in - velvety fabrics need stronger textured make-up. But the ladylike thing won't work," she declares firmly. "Women don't want to groom any more. No one's going to set their hair."

One unmissable development that Brown sees as positive is our obsession with celebrity style. "I think it's healthy because for years there were only models. Models to me are quirks of nature. There are a lot more people who can't see or who can't hear than who look like supermodels. Yes, you have to be attractive to be a celebrity, but at least they're real women."

Brown's strength is that she has a grown-up, womanly approach to what she does, unmoved by passing fads. It is an attitude not dissimilar to that of Catherine Zeta Jones, who told InStyle magazine recently that one thing she won't do is kooky "little barrettes in my hair ... something I've never been, never will be, is hip".

Brown, similarly, knows instinctively that for most women a choice between being hip and being beautiful is not a difficult one to make. Still, she has a healthy attitude to the limitations of the beauty industry. "There are no miracles. The only way you have good skin is if you're born with it. Sorry, but that's how it is."

A car outside the Madrid hotel is waiting to take Brown, her husband and their sons to start a short holiday in Barcelona. Having completed a make-up demonstration to a group of European journalists, she is now clearly itching to get off. "I don't think you should spend too much time on this stuff," she says. "You know when you go to a party and everyone's in the bathroom doing their faces? I don't even look. To me, you do the best you can at home, then you go out and have fun. You look better if it's not so ... important."

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Sanderson cocktails
fields.trailText: It's fair to assume that Ian Schrager knows a thing or two about going out of an evening: this, after all, is the man who counts the nightclub Studio 54 among his first business ventures. Now Schrager has cornered the market in chic hotels and declared that disco decadence is out and Lobby Socialising in.
fields.body:
It's fair to assume that Ian Schrager knows a thing or two about going out of an evening: this, after all, is the man who counts the nightclub Studio 54 among his first business ventures. Now Schrager has cornered the market in chic hotels and declared that disco decadence is out and Lobby Socialising in.

Not the most promising of names, Lobby Socialising, sounding as it does like making conversation as you wait for the lift, but the hotel lobby bar is the place for sip-and-be-spotted cocktails. Happy hour in a Holiday Inn piano bar won't cut it, I'm afraid: it's got to be the Long Bar or the Purple Bar at Schrager's second London hotel, Sanderson, at 50 Berners Street. In a listed 1950s building in the allegedly-fashionable-although-nobody-actually-goes-there Noho (as in north of Soho), Sanderson's whimsical Philippe Starck design has every credential to be the new spiritual home of the beau monde.

In the softly lit Purple Bar, cute undersized violet armchairs cradle the teensiest of bottoms, while the white stools in the Long Bar feature a heavily mascara'd eye which, seeing as the 80-foot, rectangular bar is eyeing-up heaven, could not be more appropriate.

fields.headline: Fake London
fields.trailText: Would you rate the Whitechapel Ladies Bridge Club as fashionable? It may seem unlikely but designer Desiree Mejer has the unique ability to make even the most mundane of things cool. Her spring/summer 2000 collection for Fake London has thrust into the forefront of style not only the Bridge Club but also the Wolverhampton Pier Racing Ladies and the Ambulance Pit Bulls. Not so much chic as cheap, so it's surprising to hear that their immortalisation comes beaded and embroidered on to very expensive jumpers. Cashmere, actually - a fabric most assume is reserved for more upmarket causes. But Mejer doesn't care - after all, she has been known to decorate it with Biro and red wine. This girl's got balls.

Would you rate the Whitechapel Ladies Bridge Club as fashionable? It may seem unlikely but designer Desiree Mejer has the unique ability to make even the most mundane of things cool. Her spring/summer 2000 collection for Fake London has thrust into the forefront of style not only the Bridge Club but also the Wolverhampton Pier Racing Ladies and the Ambulance Pit Bulls. Not so much chic as cheap, so it's surprising to hear that their immortalisation comes beaded and embroidered on to very expensive jumpers. Cashmere, actually - a fabric most assume is reserved for more upmarket causes. But Mejer doesn't care - after all, she has been known to decorate it with Biro and red wine. This girl's got balls.

Founded by Mejer in 1992, Fake London is a fashion label known for its idiosyncratic style and patriotism - as well as the name, every season the Union Jack is reinvented in the collection (this spring in sequins). The designs, which draw inspiration from all corners of the globe, have stormed to success internationally over the past eight years and are now sold in such style meccas as Browns and Jones in London, and Neiman Marcus and Barneys in the US.

Fake's collections aren't only coolly Brit to the core, though: they also make you feel good about yourself, as the clothes are predominantly recycled. Old sweaters in jersey, corduroy and even the beloved cashmere are cut up and stitched together to make new designs, so they are as good for the environment as they are for your street cred. For spring/summer look out for pompom, knitted flower and sequin bull's-eye tops, as well as rag-like Gypsy dresses. Love it.

fields.headline: Back to the future
fields.standfirst: It hit the news stands in 1965 and if ever a women's magazine caught the mood of the moment, Nova did. It had the lot, from freewheeling fashion and sex tips to politics. Within a decade, it had folded ... but now it's back. Fashion editor  Laura Craik reports
fields.trailText: It hit the news stands in 1965 and if ever a women's magazine caught the mood of the moment, Nova did. It had the lot, from freewheeling fashion and sex tips to politics. Within a decade, it had folded ... but now it's back. Fashion editor Laura Craik reports
fields.body:
Laydeez. What do you buy to read on the train? Vogue? Elle? Cosmo? Marie Claire? "I'm just not interested in any of them," my flatmate says. "They all ... annoy me." And it's true: night after night, I bring home all my mags and she doesn't even glance at them. Weirdo.

Soon she is going to have not one, not two, but three new women's magazines clamouring for her attention, not to mention Eve Pollard's recently launched Aura. There is Frank (probably - it might yet change its name) which first launched in 1997, failed, and will now be resurrected by publishers Emap. There's Pop, a trashy-trendy fashion mag to be launched off the back of The Face. And there's Nova, publisher IPC's first foray into the high fashion market. Of the three, Nova is the only monthly; the others will be bi-annual. Nova will be on sale next Thursday.

If you are a woman of a certain age, you might remember Nova. It first came out in 1965, smack in the middle of the opulent, affluent 60s when women started shagging around in Mary Quant minis, stoned and listening to the Stones. Nova caught the wave of this freewheeling new optimism: its fashion stories (models who actually smiled and jumped around), features (in-depth politics, shocking sex tips, gritty realism) and covers (Mary Bell, Twiggy, George Best) created a magazine so risqué as to be unprecedented in publishing history. The only thing disappointing about Nova was that all this ferocious feminism was presided over by a man. A succession of men, in fact, until Gillian Cooke, who took over as editor in December 1970 and remained at the helm until the magazine folded in October 1975.

There will be no man at the helm of new Nova: publishing has moved on and women are now judged the more suitable gender to edit a women's magazine. Deborah Bee - 35, married, model looks, proud mother of four sons - is the editor charged with bringing to a new generation Nova's original spirit. "The Nova reader is a feisty young woman who's into lipstick as much as politics," Bee says. "She's ageless because it's not about age any more, it's about attitude."

Publishers and advertisers might love hearing this type of mission statement (superficially, it convinces them that their product will succeed), but it grates on the rest of us. What definition could Bee give that wouldn't grate, though? For what is the essence of modern woman? Having her cake, eating it and then feeling guilty? This would be a more honest definition, perhaps, though not one likely to endear Bee to that particular brand of feminist who refuses to acknowledge that most women are as man-mad and weight-obsessed as they ever were. They just hold down careers at the same time.

The new Nova looks like a good read. Bee and her team have given thought-provoking topics to thought- provoking writers (including Guardian women's editor Libby Brooks): 100 successful women are canvassed on various big issues; there's a piece on why women have two brains, plus some solid, fluff-free health advice.

All this is wrapped in stylish, edgy fashion coverage. IPC has been savvy enough to get the big guns on board: Nova's fashion director is Venetia Scott, partner of top photographer Juergen Teller, who for the first issue documents Tracey Emin attending an Alexander McQueen show. Big ticks in the cred box all round. There's Chloe Sevigny modelling, Vanessa Paradis musing on life with Johnny Depp and a couture story illustrated by the talented James Jarvis.

"The triangle we had as our working model was the style press, which is incredibly cool, the fashion mags, which deal with the catwalk very well, and newspapers, which have the best writing. Our woman is right in the middle of that triangle and wants something from all of those," Bee says. "We are the magazine that encapsulates those three things."

What Nova does encapsulate more than any other women's magazine is stylish art direction. The cover, featuring model du jour Ana Claudia in a stripy Marc Jacobs sweater, manages to look retro and modern at the same time. Inside, the magazine looks slick and well-designed. But will many women respond to this? More worryingly for circulation figures, will they be intimidated? The women's mags with the biggest readerships project a "join our gang" mentality: too great a degree of aspiration can be a commercially dangerous thing, as Frank and indeed Mirabella found to their cost. Their edginess edged them straight out of the market.

"Nova is much more commercial than it will perhaps look," says IPC's publishing director, Rita Lewis. "It's the kind of mag you need to sit with and read. It's not a mag that screams for your attention with salacious coverlines. But once you read it, it's terribly engaging, very funny, very now."

When asked who Nova would be if she were a real woman, Lewis is more cautious. "In some respects, Jade Jagger. In terms of her heritage, her qualities. Kate Moss, too, but she's an overused person."

Lewis is supremely confident that there are enough Nova readers out there to make the magazine a success. "Young women who understand the internet, are completely aware of globalisation and are absolutely in love with labels," she says. "You just have to go out on the street and you see them everywhere."

Nobody is doubting that this confident, intelligent global-babe exists, but in sufficient numbers to make three new women's fashion titles a success? Vogue, Elle and Marie Claire all have incredibly loyal followings, but perhaps this is missing the point. Women might not need or want another fashion mag, but publishers do. The British economy is booming: demand for luxury labels is high and that means design houses have more money to spend on advertising. And while publishers would all adore healthy circulation figures of 200,000-plus, a tidy sum can still be made through advertising revenue alone. Create a buzz about a magazine and those glossy fashion ads will come rolling in. Get the right stylists and photographers on your masthead - ideally the same ones who work on the big ad campaigns and fashion shows - and it's a fait accompli. In the world of the fash mag, an editor is only as powerful as her team of stylists and photographers.

"Fashion advertising in women's glossy magazines has doubled in the past five years. It's a massive market. Publishers would be remiss not to address it," Lewis says. Is she worried about the competition? "No. There is always competition. It's time for a new brand, time for more than one new brand. Obviously we're going to see who's going to win. But with the credentials of the team we've got on Nova, it's going to work."

webTitle: Sometime hero, never leader, once a traitor

fields.headline: Sometime hero, never leader, once a traitor
fields.standfirst:
David McKie on the stormy political life of a maverick MP

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The political landscape is littered with the remains of men who might have been, even should have been, prime minister but who, for any number of reasons - ill luck, ill health, miscalculation, the loss of a parliamentary seat at a crucial moment - never made it.
fields.body:
The political landscape is littered with the remains of men who might have been, even should have been, prime minister but who, for any number of reasons - ill luck, ill health, miscalculation, the loss of a parliamentary seat at a crucial moment - never made it.

Michael Heseltine, who yesterday announced his intention to give up his Commons seat at the next election, is one of the most conspicuous and extravagantly gifted members of this fraternity.

He never made prime minister; he never made party leader; the reference books will record that he reached at peak the status of deputy premier in a government which was decaying and a party which would take many years to resuscitate.

Yet despite this defeat - and defeat it certainly was, for since his university days he had set his sights on the very top of the tree - Heseltine will be better and more vividly remembered than some who got where he couldn't: John Major, for instance, who beat him to the job he most coveted but did that job with so much less swagger and style and sense of occasion; and so much less vision.

Some politicians are stronger on style than content; others are the other way round. Michael Heseltine always had bagfuls of both. His annual conference speech - his annual conference rant, as his critics (who at all times were many) preferred to call it - was one of the guaranteed treats of the political season. Many who came to scoff ended up mesmerised. It was always so good to watch: that recalcitrant lock of hair, gradually escaping from his coiffure, swishing impertinently into his eyes, then swept back into place with a fine imperial gesture. Later, as he grew older, the lock of hair was replaced by another teasingly eye-catching device: the pair of half-glasses, seeping steadily down his nose as he grew more and more excited, until they seemed certain to slip to the floor - when at the very last moment he would haul them back into obedience.

Learned - but entertaining - excursions into Victorian history or the wars of old Europe, for instance, put there not just for their colour and spice but because they chimed in with essential Heseltine themes, of which the most prominent always were industry (where he promised - to the rapturous cheers of a party which so often denounced all government meddling - to intervene before breakfast, before lunch, tea and dinner); the state of our inner cities; and Europe.

(He had once been an officer in the Welsh Guards, though only on national service.) It happened in the course of a cabinet meeting: he gathered his papers and swept (Margaret Thatcher said "flounced") out of the room. The principle on which he resigned - the conduct of government - was certainly crucial: but so too was his personal commitment to Europe; his sense of himself; his ambition.

He was out of the party hierarchy for more than four years, at the end of which he emerged, even more dramatically, as Margaret Thatcher's assassin. Not without skilled accomplices: Geoffrey Howe, whose decision to take no more of her punishment opened the final act; Thatcher herself, for her stubbornness over Europe and over the poll tax. It was Heseltine, though, who by pledging himself to stand against her precipitated the contest which finished her.

After that, he was, for a swathe of his party, "that traitor": the outcast, the man who had slain the queen. He bided his time, serving John Major faithfully (though without disguising his hope that he might yet land the top job himself) and helped shore him up when vicious critics were out for his blood. And for all the venom against him, he came tantalisingly close to winning the leadership. When Major resigned after Labour's victory, Heseltine was the obvious choice - far more formidable a figure than than Hague or Redwood and, though still a staunch European, more flexible on Europe than Clarke. And a way of postponing the really decisive contest until Michael Portillo and Chris Patten, both general election casualties, were back in the House.

What did for him then was ill-health. Not death in Venice, but a kind of finality there, even so. The television pictures which showed him being borne home, haggard and ashen, made it clear that the game might be up. There were always suspicions that when his wife announced that his hopes of leading the party must now be abandoned, she spoke for herself more than she did for him. But he had had his warning. Even those who most wanted to see him succeed remembered the fate of John Smith.

And now he is going, leaving a local party in Oxfordshire which has shown signs of restlessness with him as he went on banging the Euro-drum in a party increasingly hostile to the whole European involvement. He announced his decision not to them (though he warned some local officials), not to William Hague, but on one of the battlegrounds he had most enjoyed: the studios of the BBC Today programme.

Wherever he goes after this (the Lords is a clear possibility, even though many Tories would not wish to see him there) he will have the time and the freedom - given good luck with his health - to bring his crusading passion to a cause which clearly has desperate need of it.

Rt Hon Michael Ray Dibdin Heseltine, CH

Born:
March 21 1933

Educated:
Shrewsbury School, Pembroke College, Oxford (BA, Politics, Philosophy, Economics)

Political progress:
MP for Tavistock, 1966-74

MP for Henley, Feb 1974-

Opposition transport spokesman, 1969

Parliamentary secretary, Ministry of Transport, 1970

Parliamentary under-secretary, Department of the Environment, 1970-72

Minister for aerospace and shipping in the Department of Trade and Industry, 1972-74

Opposition industry spokesman, 1974-76

Opposition environment spokesman, 1976-79

Environment secretary, 1979-83

Defence secretary, 1983-86 (resigned during Westland affair)

Environment secretary, 1990-92

Trade and industry secretary, 1992-95

Deputy prime minister, 1995-97

fields.headline: Keeping the lid on CJD
fields.trailText: Confusion, doubt and fear still shrouds the topic of BSE. Guardian correspondent James Miekle reports.
fields.body:
The lack of evidence of nascent traces of the human form of BSE in a survey of tonsil and appendix samples dating back to the 1980s is at best only partly reassuring.

Trawling through a few thousand results of operations undergone by a population of 50m to try and establish the likely threat from what is technically called variant CJD was always going to be a long shot, given that even now only 55 people in Britain are thought to have died from the fatal condition since March 1995, with another 12 likely victims still living.

Specialists in both the clinical disease and statistical prediction of the size of the epidemic disagree wildly about the future. Some believe we still may get away with fewer than 100 cases, although that estimate is looking less likely as the death toll mounts, while others think it still may run into hundreds of thousands of even millions. The problem is that there are still so many unknowns.

There is no conclusive proof yet that the disease came from cattle, although the analysis of the "signature'' of the disease in the brain reveals many similarities with BSE. The likelihood is that it came from eating infected beef, although other sources including vaccines and cosmetics with bovine material are possible.

The scientific establishment believes the behaviour of an abnormal prion protein is a key factor in the disease but just when does it first show itself? The incubation period of the disease may be anything from just over 4 to nearer 40 years.

It was the chance discovery of an abnormal prion in the appendix of a variant CJD victim , removed eight months before he showed the first obvious outward signs of the disease and three years before he died, that provoked the screening programme whose first results were published today. It has also accelerated changes in the use of medical instruments, with more disposable equipment being used in several types of operation and medical treatment.

There have been some important developments recently in being able to diagnose pretty conclusively the existence of the disease before death, through tonsil tests on those already showing outward signs. There is now hope, too, of being able to develop ways of "modulating'' the disease, as happened with HIV and Aids.

However, we are still a long way from developing tests for the condition before clinical signs become evident, or drugs to block it. Even before those arrive, there is a huge debate to be had on the ethics of telling victims of a disease that is incurable.

But the longer deaths from the appalling symptoms - including dementia, aggression and loss of bodily control - remain on a relatively small scale, the more ministers and their advisers are having to balance the cost of prevention. This includes expensive precautions on spreading vCJD through blood donations and potentially infected food, against the as-yet-unquantified risk of a doomsday-sized epidemic. The government once rubbished anyone who suggested that people might die from eating BSE-infected cattle. Now it is ready to err on the side of caution.

webTitle: Sheep to be tested for 'hidden' BSE

fields.headline: Sheep to be tested for 'hidden' BSE
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The government is to increase significantly research into whether sheep are harbouring "hidden" BSE and posing a new food risk to humans.
fields.body:
The government is to increase significantly research into whether sheep are harbouring "hidden" BSE and posing a new food risk to humans.

A programme was announced yesterday to find new tests for live animals, comparisons of sheep BSE with cattle BSE, and ways of determining whether scrapie, a similar disease long endemic in British flocks, is helping to mask a potentially more devastating threat to people's health.

It follows concern among scientific advisers that there are still gaps in knowledge about how BSE and similar conditions may be affecting livestock.

Researchers around the world are being invited to compete for a share of an extra £5m worth of work next year. Since 1986 £90m has already been spent on research into the issue.

As few as one in eight sheep farmers might be obeying the law by reporting suspect cases of scrapie, government vets warned earlier this month, and ministers have announced plans to tag or tattoo 40m sheep in an effort to improve the tracking-down of diseases and the recording of animals' provenance.

Much of the work will involve sheep purchased from New Zealand farms, where there is no scrapie, to act as controls for the experiments. There is no evidence that scrapie is a danger to humans, and BSE has only been transmitted from infected cattle to sheep via the laboratory.

One theory on the cause of BSE is that the remains of scrapie-infected sheep were eaten in the meat and bone meal which used to be commonly fed to cattle and sheep, and the infective agent then began working in a totally different way in cows. Even if that is not the case, it is possible that BSE was spread from the remains of infected cattle to sheep before the 1988 ban on the use of such feed.

Although all sheep fed contaminated materials would probably now have died naturally, scientists see no reason why BSE , if it exists in sheep, should not have become endemic like scrapie. Animals may simply have become carriers of the disease without displaying outward signs. In the laboratory, sheep BSE already appears to behave differently from BSE in cattle.

There is no test for identifying scrapie in live sheep, BSE in live cattle, or, until it is clinically apparent, variant CJD (the human form of BSE) in people while still alive. There are promising signs for a scrapie test using blood that is being developed by the US department of agriculture.

The government believes successive measures introduced to protect humans by banning parts of cattle and sheep from food are sufficient at present, but needs to know more about how both BSE and scrapie work and their minimum infective "doses".

Baroness Hayman, the agriculture minister, said: "Although our scientific knowledge in this field has increased and evolved significantly, there are still identifiable areas where more work needs to be done."

fields.headline: Egg-splosion
fields.standfirst: Courthouse cracker, kidnapped canines, a reptile rumpus and a shop's leftovers
fields.trailText:
Sweet surprise
There have been some egg-splosive goings on at Epsom court house, where bomb-disposal experts were called in to destroy a suspicious package which turned out to be a gift-wrapped box of Cadbury's Creme Eggs.
fields.body:
Sweet surprise
There have been some egg-splosive goings on at Epsom court house, where bomb-disposal experts were called in to destroy a suspicious package which turned out to be a gift-wrapped box of Cadbury's Creme Eggs.

The eggs had been left by an anonymous benefactor on the steps of the court house outside the bailiff's office.

"We tend to get more threats than chocolates," explained one employee. "So when we saw the box our immediate thought was that someone was trying to blow us up."

The court house was evacuated and the area cordoned off. Bomb-disposal experts from RAF Northolt arrived and after three hours of examination, decided it would be best to destroy the box in a controlled explosion.

Only after the smoke had cleared to reveal a coating of chocolate and cream spattered across the front of the court house did the true nature of the package emerge.

"You can never be too careful," said one court worker. "And anyway, chocolate eggs are full of cholesterol, so it's probably the best thing that could have happened."
East Grinstead Observer

Disappearing dogs
A pall of fear is hanging over Dewsbury - a town in the grip of a serial dog thief.

The Dewsbury dog-napper first struck last year, removing a red-haired fox-terrier named Bobby from the garden of 70-year-old Frank Marshall.

"I contacted the police, the RSPCA, kennels, everywhere - but nothing," said Mr Marshall. "I was devastated."

It looked like a one-off incident. But since then there have been further canine kidnappings, including two poodles, one datschund, four labradors and a pug named Gwendoline. Police believe the dogs' disappearances are connected.

"We would appear to be dealing with a single individual here," said a police spokesman. "Or possibly a dog-napping ring. We would urge all dog-owners to be extra-vigilant."

But not everyone in Dewsbury is concerned about the thefts. "This town is ankle-deep in dog-dirt," fumed one man. "As far as I'm concerned, the more of them that disappear the better. And I wouldn't mind if they took the pigeons too."
Dewsbury Reporter

March of the bullfrogs
More animal traumas in leafy Surrey, which is being invaded by North American Bullfrogs. The frogs, the size of a dinner plate and weighing up to 2lbs, were banned from being brought into Britain in 1997 because of the adverse effects they have on indigenous wildlife.

But after an anonymous tip-off, conservation officers discovered almost 7,000 of them being illegally bred on a farm near Edenbridge.

"These creatures are monstrous," said one expert. "They lay 20,000 eggs in one sitting, can leap 3ft and eat anything - even birds. They're the great white shark of the amphibian world."

English Nature has launched Operation Bullfrog to try and contain the creatures, but it is feared that they have already infiltrated local woodlands and will spread inexorably across the county, destroying all in their path.

"This man turned up on my doorstep and said there's been an outbreak of bullfrogs," said one local resident. "I hope it's not infectious, because I'm off to Corfu in a couple of weeks and don't want to be ill for my holiday."
Surrey Mirror

Bargain remains
Volunteers at an Ilkeston charity shop made a surprising discovery this week when a brass container displayed in their front window turned out to be a funerary urn containing human ashes.

The urn arrived at the British Heart Foundation branch inside a bag of donated clothes. "There were some lovely tank-tops and three pairs of jumbo corduroys," recalled one staff member. "And there at the bottom of the bag was this brass urn. It wasn't very nice looking, so I slapped a 99p price-tag on it and stuck it in the window."

There it remained for two weeks until a customer pointed out its contents. "I gave it a good shake and there were definitely ashes inside," said the volunteer. "Someone obviously left it out for collection by mistake."

The shop is trying to trace the urn's owner, so far without success. "You get all sorts of strange things donated," said one charity worker. "A few of years back we got three stuffed bisons' penises. They sold like hotcakes."
Ilkeston Advertiser

Letter of the week
While driving along Ashmeads in Chalford last Thursday, at about 5.30pm, I noticed a rather large black animal sitting in the middle of the road.

It was approximately 60m away and all I thought of at the time was that this animal had better move by the time I got to it. When I was about 20m away I began thinking that this animal was neither a cat nor a dog because of its sheer size and stature.

The animal leaped onto the steep bank in one clean move and quickly disappeared into the woods. As it made its escape, I noticed a long, curved, smooth-ended tail which convinced me that what I had seen was a big, black, wild cat!

I stopped briefly, but as I was rather scared to look some more, I drove on. I am interested to know if anyone else has spotted a big, black cat in the area opposite Oak Hill Wood. I know the wood is used frequently by people walking their dogs. Perhaps there is someone out there who will tell me they were indeed walking their huge dog at the time and it was that that I saw.

I would love to hear from anyone who can solve the mystery!
Claire Banks, This is Gloucestershire

There it remained for two weeks until a customer pointed out its contents. "I gave it a good shake and there were definitely ashes inside," said the volunteer. "Someone obviously left it out for collection by mistake." The shop is trying to trace the urn's owner, so far without success. "You get all sorts of strange things donated," said one charity worker. "A few of years back we got three stuffed bisons' penises. They sold like hotcakes." Ilkeston Advertiser Letter of the week While driving along Ashmeads in Chalford last Thursday, at about 5.30pm, I noticed a rather large black animal sitting in the middle of the road. It was approximately 60m away and all I thought of at the time was that this animal had better move by the time I got to it. When I was about 20m away I began thinking that this animal was neither a cat nor a dog because of its sheer size and stature. The animal leaped onto the steep bank in one clean move and quickly disappeared into the woods. As it made its escape, I noticed a long, curved, smooth-ended tail which convinced me that what I had seen was a big, black, wild cat! I stopped briefly, but as I was rather scared to look some more, I drove on. I am interested to know if anyone else has spotted a big, black cat in the area opposite Oak Hill Wood. I know the wood is used frequently by people walking their dogs. Perhaps there is someone out there who will tell me they were indeed walking their huge dog at the time and it was that that I saw. I would love to hear from anyone who can solve the mystery! Claire Banks, This is Gloucestershire

webTitle: LetsBuyIt to list on Neuer Markt

fields.headline: LetsBuyIt to list on Neuer Markt
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: LetsBuyIt.com, the cooperative shopping company which uses consumers' collective buying power to force down prices, is to brave a turbulent market for business-to-consumer companies by listing on the Neuer Markt on June 7.
fields.body:
LetsBuyIt.com, the cooperative shopping company which uses consumers' collective buying power to force down prices, is to brave a turbulent market for business-to-consumer companies by listing on the Neuer Markt on June 7.

It is understood that the 15-month-old, Sweden-based company was initially aiming for a market valuation of between€750m-€1bn (£423m-£575m) but waning investor enthusiasm for b2c companies and the sell-off of technology stocks in recent weeks is likely to reduce the price tag to around €400m.

Analysts say the appetite for shares in online retailers has diminished since the troubled flotation of late-bookings specialist Lastminute.com and reports from the United States that the rate at which some online retailers are spending cash threatens to put them out of business.

However, Peter Misek, senior equity research analyst at Chase H&Q, said strong retail offers can still succeed.

"The market for b2c offerings is very turbulent and the strength of every business model will be questioned," he said.

"New issues will be priced on cash flow. But companies with a strong community base like LetsBuyIt can still raise money successfully."

LetsBuyIt.com's innovative business model brings consumers together and enables them to bid for branded products as a group. The more people that bid, the lower the price of the goods they are bidding for become.

In the first quarter of this year it recorded net sales of £3.95m and a gross profit of £113,000. Of 366,000 registered members, 71,000 were buying members. It now has 450,000 members, and is attracting 25,000 new members per week.

Last month BSkyB paid £10m for a minority stake in the company.

LetsBuyIt now operates in 14 countries and chief executive Martin Coles said the proceeds of the flotation would fund an aggressive geographical expansion into Latin America and Asia, as well as marketing and advertising costs.

"The core elements of our strategy are the development of a global brand, driven by further geographic expansion as well as an ongoing extension of our range of products and services," he said.

LetsBuyIt.com claims to have business relationships with over 150 brands, including Kodak, Hewlett Packard and Psion, and to provide price savings of between 10% and 60% for members.

fields.headline: BMW may 'shut down' Rover
fields.standfirst:
BMW tries to salvage deal following Alchemy pull-out

Alchemy statement full text
fields.trailText: BMW today warned that it could shut down the Rover Car business following the collapse of talks with the venture capital group Alchemy.
fields.body:
BMW today warned that it could shut down the Rover Car business following the collapse of talks with the venture capital group Alchemy.

Announcing that the negotiations had broken down, BMW said that it would "now pursue alternative routes to bring to an end its involvement in Rover Car Operations. Those routes include the sale of Rover Car Operations or its closure." It said a decision would be taken within the next month.

Alchemy had ben negotiating to take over Rover's Longbridge plant and to concentrate on the MG marque.

The plan was unpopular with the trade unions and the worforce because it would have meant the end of volume car making at the plant and the loss of around half the workforce - plus further heavy job losses among component suppliers.

But though there was relief in some quarters that the collapse of the Alchemy deal would open the way for BMW to consider other offers - including the one table by the Phoenix Consortium, headed by former Rover boss John Towers.

BMW had earlier brushed off the Phoenix approach saying it wanted more detail about the financial backing. But it now understood to have said it will look at the Phoenix bid provided it gets more detail about the financing.

The Department of Trade and Industry said Alchemy's decision to pull out of the deal "provides a new opportunity for proposals to come forward which offer a viable future for Longbridge and which may provide more jobs than under the Alchemy proposals."

"Our efforts over the next few weeks will be directed towards achieving a successful outcome which will serve the interests of the workers at Longbridge and the wider community in the West Midlands."

The announcement will allow Alchemy an extra month in the negotiations, which will also give the Towers team more time to finalise its own bid.

BMW had previously said it wanted to complete the sale of Rover by the end of April/early May, but today's unexpected breakdown of talks with Alchemy has led to a re-think of the deadline.

The negotiations collapsed dramatically today after Alchemy and Rover's German owner BMW failed to agree on "contractual matters".

In a terse statement, Alchemy and BMW said they had "ceased negotiations as they were unable to agree upon certain contractual matters, some of which arose yesterday".

The only previous hint that something was amiss in the negotiations between Alchemy Partners and BMW was the German company's concern about Alchemy's ability to fulfil Rover's pension obligations.

Investors have long been unhappy with BMW's 1994 purchase of Rover, and shares in the German company plunged immediately after today's announcement. BMW bought Rover in 1994, attracted by its Land Rover division of four-wheel-drive cars. It thought other Rover brands would fit into the bottom of its range.

BMW has pumped nearly £3bn into the Rover group in the last five years but losses continued to increase. Productivity at the Longbridge plant near Birmingham lagged far behind rival manufacturers. A survey in 1998 showed that the plant produced 33 cars per worker, compared with 98 per worker at the Nissan factory in Sunderland.

The decision to sell Rover caused a furore, with trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers initially accused of concealing knowledge of BMW's decision to sell Rover. He was later cleared by a committee of MPs, but the Rover crisis has led to questions about the government's economic policy, particularly the high pound, which has hurt manufacturing exports. The sale could mean the loss of 16,000 jobs and possibly another 40,000 in ancillary industries.

fields.headline: Simple pleasures
fields.standfirst: Whether one likes or dislikes Istvan Szabo's latest film, it's impossible to fault its ambition. Xan Brooks meets the director of Sunshine
fields.trailText: Whether one likes or dislikes Istvan Szabo's latest film, it's impossible to fault its ambition. Xan Brooks meets the director of Sunshine
fields.body:
Whether one likes or dislikes Istvan Szabo's latest film, it's impossible to fault its ambition. Throughout a forceful three-hour flow, Sunshine offers nothing less than the complete and unabridged history of 20th century Hungary as seen through the eyes of a middle-class Jewish family (embodied by Ralph Fiennes in a trio of roles).

Szabo initially conceived of the project in terms of a mammoth mini-series for German TV before re-ordering and re-writing it for the cinema. The first draft of his script ran to a whopping 500 pages, before the film-maker (in tandem with American playwright Israel Horovitz) hacked three-fifths of the action in order to whittle it down to a more manageable length.

"It was not easy," remembers Szabo with a very European shrug. "But it is very challenging to tell a story shorter. It's like having an appointment with a very nice lady. Before meeting her you imagine all that you will say to her, and then upon arriving she tells you she has a limited time because she is meeting her mother. So you have to tell everything you wanted to say in a shorter time-span. You have to prioritise."

Analogy aside, it's hard to imagine any "very nice lady" bailing out early on a date with Szabo. The man may be pushing sixty these days, but he's a smooth, feline presence, a dash of dapper energy on a slate-grey day in London. His voice is whisper-quiet and coloured by a heavy Hungarian accent (he doesn't "think", he "sinks"). Despite a lofty international reputation (his 1981 picture Mephisto won the Best Foreign Language Oscar), he still lives in his native Budapest.

Szabo's pictures can be read as serious, modernist sagas; intimate human stories with a dark political subtext. In Mephisto an actor's rush to fame is implicitly linked with the growth of Nazism. In Colonel Redl, a gay Jewish army officer gatecrashes the aristocratic ranks of a crumbling Hapsburg empire. "Style has no interest for me," he says. "It's just a visual way to tell a story. I like to tell my stories as simply and clearly as possible and the film medium is just a means to let me do it." Ask him about his own influences and he name-checks Kurosawa and Bergman. When I remark that the opening family scenes of Sunshine reminded me of Bergman's Fanny and Alexander, he looks pleased. "I met with Bergman when he was filming Fanny and Alexander and we ate lunch around the big family table that he was using in the film. I told Bergman that it reminded me so much of my own childhood, of sitting with my own family at the table of my grandmother."

This being the case, you might see Sunshine as Szabo's most autobiographical feature to date; examining his own heritage as a Hungarian Jew whose family suffered in the Nazi Holocaust. But the director is wary of discussing this. Sunshine, he says, is merely a compilation of several true stories he heard around his grandmother's table.

He prefers to regard the film in a wider context; as a story of the changes that have taken place within Europe. "I think that everything that's happened in the last 150 years started in Middle Europe. If you just think of Sarajevo: the first world war broke out in Sarajevo and then look at what is happening there now." He takes a sip of water. "Middle Europe is the meeting point of several different languages, mentalities and cultures. Hungary itself is at the edge of two worlds, the culture of the East, represented by Slavic and Muslim cultures, and of the West, which is Protestant and Roman Catholic. So it is an enormous energy." For good and bad? Szabo shrugs again. "Ah," he says. "What is good and what is bad? On every side there are good and bad things."

The real issue, he argues, is the notion of individual roots and identity within such a climate. This is the issue that Sunshine sets out to tackle, and this, he says, is the key question of contemporary society. "It is a problem for everyone, for every country. I mean, half of Turkey is now living in Germany, and half of Algeria in France. In every American city, you will find a Chinatown or a Little Italy. So how does a Turkish person become a good German - what does that mean? And what is the identity of an African writer writing in France, or a Chinese writer who writes in the United States? The problem is to find a new identity without losing the old. What is this new identity offered by the 20th or 21st century? Do you keep yourself or lose yourself or become something new? How important is it to hold onto your roots?"

You suspect that, as far as Szabo is concerned, the last question is purely rhetorical. He has no plans to leave Budapest, or abandon his Hungarian heritage. Before filming Sunshine he filmed a documentary on the city. As soon as the round of publicity is finished, he plans to return home and stage an opera. "Projects like that are important to me, " he says. "On the one hand, they feed through and inform by film-making work, give me ideas that I can use later. But they also re-connect me with where I come from. They teach me more about my country."

webTitle: Calm for Life by Paul Wilson

fields.headline: Calm for Life by Paul Wilson
fields.standfirst:
(Penguin Books) £12.99, digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Nearly 350 pages of mindless psychobabble, patronising platitudes and incomprehensible quasi-science that is guaranteed to infuriate most readers - in a calm sort of way.
fields.body:
Breathe deeply and try to think of a perfect state of calm. It's difficult, isn't it? But with my help you're going to understand everything you need to know about being calm for life. Who could possibly know that, you might ask? A scientist? A guru? A popular author? A successful businessman? I think not. Only I am qualified to write about calm, as only I know about it.

I've been researching the topic for more than 20 years and now I am rich enough to employ several researchers to help me. That makes me feel very calm indeed.

The key to calm is choice. Tell someone they have to do the morning shift and they'll resist and resent the command. Offer them the choice between the morning and the evening shift and they'll feel happy about doing the morning shift. Apply this principle to all areas of your life. Imagine you've just been burgled. If you think someone has done this to you, you feel angry. But if you say to yourself, "I've chosen to be burgled," you feel an instant wave of calm.

Calm is not just good for your emotional state, it is also good for your physical well-being and helps you to live longer. Look at me. I am 279 years old and have shrugged off over 40 terminal illnesses. You probably find this hard to accept, but those who are familiar with the state of inner calm will not. You are unique. There is no one else quite like you. Only you know exactly what is best for you. You have the power to change your life. You, too, can make a fortune endlessly repeating trite homilies.

I don't want you to settle just for calm. I want you to reach Deep Calm. To do this you have to access your unconscious. You have to centre yourself. Try to exist in the NOW. Tell yourself you have all the time in the world. Even if you don't. Because NOW has no time attribute. Whatever that means. But it sounds good and it sounds calm.

With Calm comes Power. There is a simple formula for achieving what you want. It is M+B+F=C. M=motivation, B=belief, F=focus and C=consequence. Above all, accept the answers that your consciousness throws up when you go to the centre, as the answers can sometimes be very challenging. There. Doesn't everything feel so much simpler now? And calmer?

Remain positive at all times. Optimism and a sense of humour are essential for wellbeing. Take it from me, you're doing OK. You wouldn't have bought this book if you didn't have generous amounts of both. Love what you do and, like me, you can have a life of consequence by spreading calm wherever you go. Apply all these ideas and you, too, can reach a calm continuum where you are truly calm for life.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested:

webTitle: Veterans' leader calls for end to violence

fields.headline: Veterans' leader calls for end to violence
fields.trailText: Chenjerai Hunzvi, the leader of Zimbabwe's army veterans, today told his supporters to end violence on white-owned farms as Britain sought to cool the crisis on the land issue.
fields.body:
Chenjerai Hunzvi, the leader of Zimbabwe's army veterans, today told his supporters to end violence on white-owned farms as Britain sought to cool the crisis on the land issue.

"The last thing farmers in Zimbabwe want is to see the temperatures escalate," said the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, who rejected Tory calls for a freeze on President Robert Mugabe's assets.

"There is no legal power for us to freeze unilaterally the assets of any one individual, because we have a diplomatic difficulty with them," Mr Cook said. "For Britain to act illegally seems to me to be absolutely totally the wrong message at the present time to send to Zimbabwe, when we are trying to get it to stop acting illegally."

In Zimbabwe, Mr Hunzvi told his supporters to stop the violence that has claimed the lives of several white farmers and opposition members.

"All violence must end. However, veterans will stay on the farms but they will not interfere with any farming activities," Mr Hunzvi said after meeting the commercial farmers' union. His comments followed a second day of talks with the country's mainly white commercial farmers to end a two-month-old crisis that has seen thousands of war veterans invade hundreds of farms.

Britain and Zimbabwe yesterday failed to reach agreement on funding the transfer of white-owned land to black Zimbabweans. Mr Cook and a delegation from Zimbabwe concluded eight hours of meetings with both sides sticking to their original positions. Britain refused to provide the £36m for land reform until Mr Mugabe halts the violence that followed the occupation of white-owned farms by armed black squatters in February.

But Zimbabwe insists the farm occupations are a legitimate protest that should not be linked to the money's release. Mr Mugabe has backed the squatters, many of whom claim to be veterans of the bush war that led to Zimbabwe's independence in 1980, in a risky tactic for him to hold on to power.

The main opposition group, the Movement for Democratic Change, accuses Mr Mugabe of using the land issue to intimidate opponents in advance of elections to be held in August at the latest.

The squatters, who are occupying 1,000 farms, refuse to leave until they are assured that the colonial system - which left nearly one third of Zimbabwe's productive farmland in the hands of 4,000 white farmers - is reformed. At least seven people died in the resulting violence.

Mr Cook said that despite the deadlocked negotiations, he did not want the crisis to deepen. He said Zimbabwe's farmers had urged him to cool tensions between the two countries.
