Britain and Zimbabwe yesterday failed to reach agreement on funding the transfer of white-owned land to black Zimbabweans. Mr Cook and a delegation from Zimbabwe concluded eight hours of meetings with both sides sticking to their original positions. Britain refused to provide the £36m for land reform until Mr Mugabe halts the violence that followed the occupation of white-owned farms by armed black squatters in February. But Zimbabwe insists the farm occupations are a legitimate protest that should not be linked to the money's release. Mr Mugabe has backed the squatters, many of whom claim to be veterans of the bush war that led to Zimbabwe's independence in 1980, in a risky tactic for him to hold on to power. The main opposition group, the Movement for Democratic Change, accuses Mr Mugabe of using the land issue to intimidate opponents in advance of elections to be held in August at the latest. The squatters, who are occupying 1,000 farms, refuse to leave until they are assured that the colonial system - which left nearly one third of Zimbabwe's productive farmland in the hands of 4,000 white farmers - is reformed. At least seven people died in the resulting violence. Mr Cook said that despite the deadlocked negotiations, he did not want the crisis to deepen. He said Zimbabwe's farmers had urged him to cool tensions between the two countries.

webTitle: How Labour learned to love the grey vote

fields.headline: How Labour learned to love the grey vote
fields.standfirst: Two weeks ago the Labour hierarchy was said to regard older people as hopelessly rightwing. But they may hold the key to the party's continued dominance.
fields.trailText: Two weeks ago the Labour hierarchy was said to regard older people as hopelessly rightwing. But they may hold the key to the party's continued dominance.
fields.body:
The last few days have been a rollercoaster ride for elderly voters.

A fortnight ago, the chairman of the parliamentary Labour party, Clive Soley, was said to have written off the pensioner vote as hopelessly conservative and racist. The same Sunday Times report alleged that Peter Mandelson had accused older people of one of the gravest sins in the New Labour bible: not being aspirational. The Mandelson part of the story was later denied: the Soley part was not.

But then "grey voters" are suddenly told that the New Labour light shines on them. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, is full of remorse for giving them no more than an extra 75p a week in an otherwise generous Budget. Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, has taken on an additional role as minister for the elderly. Where two weeks ago there was bleak rejection, now there is wooing with blandishments. Whatever is going on?

Mr Soley's discontent with his elders seems to have come from two calculations. The first is contained in exit-poll analysis of the 1997 election. It showed that while all other groups were swinging to Labour in droves, pensioners did the reverse. The Conservatives won 44% of the older vote and Labour just 34%, a swing - or perhaps more of a shuffle - to the right since the 1992 election of 1.5%.

The racism charge seems to have come about because Mr Soley's postbag was swollen with letters asking why so much money was being lavished on groups such as asylum seekers when there was not enough available to pay a viable pension.

But cooler heads see no reason here for writing the elderly off as an electoral force. For a start, they are now many in number: a sixth of the electorate now is past 65, and that proportion is set to grow.

Then - thanks to the same conservatism of which Soley complains - older people cling to the notion that everyone has a duty to vote. All opinion polls show pensioners are far more likely to make it to the polling station than the much sought-after young.

One might also make this calculation: the young electorate is a "shop-around" vote, with no fixed allegiance, which makes it likely to swing in big numbers between election. The old think longer and harder before they desert old allegiances. But if the next election shows a national swing away from Labour, that reluctance to swing could become a Labour asset.

However, all this is based on looking back to how elderly voters felt in an election three years ago. Since then, some (including perhaps some of the more conservative and racist ones) will have died, while others have progressed from the 35-64 to the over-65 age group.

In that sense, they are now different people. Among that age group, according to the latest ICM poll, you find a landscape transformed. Labour is leading the Tories by 42% to 34% among over-65s.

In other words, the non-swingers seem to be swinging. Despite their reported fury at Brown's niggardly treatment of pensioners, they have swung on these figures to Labour by 9% since May 1997, when the electorate as a whole shows no swing over that period.

As for the racism: conclusions drawn from an MP's postbag are usually worthless, since those who bother to write are not representative.

The ICM evidence shows that while younger voters are more likely to detect racism in politicians' responses to the asylum issue, elderly voters are no less ready to do so than the 35-64 group.

You could not convict on such evidence. Any decent judge who tried such proceedings would be able to tell the accused that they left the court without a stain on their pension books.

webTitle: BMW's statement on the breakdown of talks with Alchemy

fields.headline: BMW's statement on the breakdown of talks with Alchemy
fields.trailText: BMW and Alchemy have terminated their negotiations. No agreement was reached on the sale of Rover Car Operations to Alchemy. The negotiating partners were finally unable to come to an understanding with respect to certain conditions of contract.
fields.body:
BMW and Alchemy have terminated their negotiations. No agreement was reached on the sale of Rover Car Operations to Alchemy. The negotiating partners were finally unable to come to an understanding with respect to certain conditions of contract.

BMW Group will now pursue alternative routes to bring to an end its involvement in Rover Car Operations. Those routes include the sale of Rover Car Operations or its closure. A decision which of those alternatives will be implemented will be taken during the course of next month.This situation does not affect the preparations for the transfer of the Land Rover brand to Ford, which are conducted with high priority and in a straightforward manner. They will be concluded according to plan by the middle of this year.

webTitle: Limited options for progress towards peace in Zimbabwe

fields.headline: Limited options for progress towards peace in Zimbabwe
fields.standfirst: Mugabe's intransigence makes it hard to envisage a quick and peaceful end to the land crisis.
fields.trailText: Mugabe's intransigence makes it hard to envisage a quick and peaceful end to the land crisis.
fields.body:
The collapse in London this week of talks to end political violence in Zimbabwe has left diplomats and analysts wondering what happens next.

Robin Cook, the British foreign secretary, says the ball is now in President Robert Mugabe's court. Britain remains ready to hand over an additional £36m in aid for land reform, says Mr Cook - but not until the farm occupations and associated killings and beatings cease.

Mr Cook claimed to have obtained verbal assurances that international monitors would be allowed to observe Zimbabwe's parliamentary elections. But no date has been set for the polls, which had been due this month. In any event, while systematic intimidation of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change continues unchecked, it is unlikely that the elections can be "free and fair" even if monitored by the EU or the Commonwealth.

The Zimbabwean government said on Friday that it would meet next week to discuss its response to the London talks. But ministers accused Britain of trying to show the world that it was "acting tough". This suggests Mr Mugabe will again seek to blame the former colonial power for Zimbabwe's problems while refusing to accept responsibility for the violence many believe he has engineered.

Calls for others to help end the impasse are likely to intensify after the failure in London. South Africa's president, Thabo Mbeki, faces criticism for apparently failing to put pressure on Mr Mugabe when he and other southern African leaders met him in Harare a week ago. South Africa is suffering economically because of the unrest, with its currency, the rand, down in international markets and fears growing about foreign investors' confidence.

South Africa controls Zimbabwe's power and fuel supplies, which it could in theory cut off. But Mr Mbeki knows that if he did that, Zimbabwe would be even less likely to pay the bills it has failed to meet in recent months. More significantly, he knows land redistribution of the kind demanded by Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party is a popular cause in South Africa, too, and while people might criticise Mr Mugabe's methods, most approve of his overall objective.

Representatives of the Commonwealth are due to discuss Zimbabwe at a meeting in London next week. British Tories demand that Zimbabwe's membership be suspended. But the Commonwealth secretary-general says there are no grounds for suspension under existing rules, and the organisation is reluctant to get involved in what is seen as an internal matter.

Much the same goes for the UN secretary general. Kofi Annan has appealed to Mr Mugabe to respect the rule of law and find a peaceful solution. But Mr Annan has not proposed any formal UN role in the crisis. Nor has mooted mediation of the crisis by the Nigerian president amounted to anything.

The World Bank and IMF, which can exert indirect pressure on a country by threatening to curtail or withhold aid and loans, are largely powerless in this case. They pulled out of Zimbabwe last year after a row over Mr Mugabe's alleged misuse of funds to pay for Zimbabwe's involvement in the Congo war and are reluctant to make new commitments. The Organisation of African Unity is (as usual) keeping away from what is a very difficult situation.

Large bilateral aid donors such as the US and the EU have recently scaled back their assistance because of policy differences with Mr Mugabe, and thus have diminished leverage.

With Britain effectively saying it can do no more at present, and with others reluctant to take responsibility, the outlook for peaceful democratic change in Zimbabwe grows bleaker. With that comes a growing prospect of worsening economic conditions in a country which is already desperately poor - and the destabilising possibility of an exodus of Zimbabweans, black and white, who feel they can no longer live with Mr Mugabe.

fields.headline: Let's abandon the one-day circus
fields.trailText: The international cricket community is facing up to a big crisis in the wake of Cronjegate. It is easy to see that betting and match-fixing have been a part of international cricket for the last decade or so and, despite the lack of concrete evidence, it is also probable that a number of players have been involved. Former Indian Test cricketer and current TV commentator Ravi Shastri put it in the right perspective when he said: "The saddest thing about all of this is that it makes me feel like a fool in doing my job as a commentator, covering matches like this." If he feels a fool, what about the cricket-crazy public that spends days on end following matches?
fields.body:
The international cricket community is facing up to a big crisis in the wake of Cronjegate. It is easy to see that betting and match-fixing have been a part of international cricket for the last decade or so and, despite the lack of concrete evidence, it is also probable that a number of players have been involved. Former Indian Test cricketer and current TV commentator Ravi Shastri put it in the right perspective when he said: "The saddest thing about all of this is that it makes me feel like a fool in doing my job as a commentator, covering matches like this." If he feels a fool, what about the cricket-crazy public that spends days on end following matches?

Cricket has radically changed from a being a gentleman's game to an industry run by people who do not have the game's best interests at heart. Their chief motivation is simply that more cricket means more money. But the popularity of instant cricket is not a yardstick of love for the game: it owes more to simple nationalistic fanaticism, especially in the sub-continent. Most of the spectators are desperate to see their national team win at any cost. This has led to crowd trouble in the recent past, something which has never happened before. It is a great mistake to consider this chauvinism to be love for cricket.

The explosion in one-day cricket has changed the whole game dramatically, especially in the wake of the Packer era. Money flows in because of the lethal combination of sponsorship, television coverage and large crowds. Seasons have even expanded to accommodate more one-day internationals. Then there is the emergence of Sharjah as a big-time cricket venue with lots of money, even though the United Arab Emirates is not a Test-playing nation. It is Sharjah that is at the centre of many betting and match-fixing allegations.

Betting and match-fixing are not isolated issues: they are symptoms of a ruined system which is being run by a mafia. The ICC is trying to globalise the game (to make more money, no doubt) but unfortunately non-cricketing interests are ruling the game now: the sport has been slowly becoming an industry since the days of Kerry Packer. The Packer Circus brought fundamental changes to the game such as white balls, day/night games and quality television coverage, but the fact is that although Packer put money into cricket, he made doubly sure he took money out of it. And there lies the basic problem.

The solution is clear: we must bring back the true spirit of cricket. There are three steps to achieving this:

1. Leave the administration of the game to bona fide 'cricketing people', (e.g. former cricketers and coaches) and eliminate non-cricketing people from influential positions in governing bodies.

2. Ban all festival matches at venues such as Sharjah, Singapore and Toronto and reduce the number of one-day internationals: three one-dayers at most should be scheduled for each tour and there should be no limited-over tournaments apart from the World Cup and the Mini-World Cup.

3. Give greater importance to Test matches and improve the quality of first-class matches. Reducing one-day international commitments will ensure that all international players can participate in domestic games.

The hectic international schedule has had an effect on the quality of first-class cricket in all countries apart from Australia and England. Administrators must learn that one-day cricket is a part of the game but it is not the game. The truest form of the game is Test cricket, the quality and challenge of which is indisputable.

Anil M. is aged 29 and from the southern Indian state of Kerala. He is a postgraduate in Mass Communication and Journalism and works in Delhi as a content developer for another website.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Tarantino teams up with NWA, Jonathan Rhys-Meyers will be in two places at the same time, Spacey pours water on Pink Panther casting rumours, and Ashley Judd announces engagement
fields.body:
Quentin Tarantino is to make a fleeting return to his directing day-job when he helms a pop promo for the reformed NWA. Tarantino, who has been Hollywood's invisible man since releasing Jackie Brown in 1997, will direct the video to the song Chin Check, which currently features on the soundtrack to the Next Friday. The promo will showcase the new-style NWA, which reunites original members Ice Cube, Dr Dre and MC Ren, and has Snoop Dogg filling in for the late Eazy E. Tarantino will pocket a reported $750,000, surely enough cash to sustain him through another three years of leisure.

The work-load of Velvet Goldmine star Jonathan Rhys-Meyers appears to be reaching back-break proportions. Next month will find the Irish actor shuttling back and forth between two film sets as he simultaneously shoots roles in a pair of independently produced features. Meyers will take a supporting role in Prozac Nation, opposite Christina Ricci, and a more high-profile slot in the thriller Conspiracy of Weeds, with Rachael Leigh Cook. Both productions roll before the camera in May and a driver will be on hand to ferry Meyers back and forth between each set.

Just two days after being tipped the classic Inspector Clouseau role in a remake of The Pink Panther (see our news story, Kevin Spacey is hedging his bets. Speaking to Reuters, the actor admitted that he had been involved in "two conversations" about the role but felt that the rumour mill was running out of hand. "I'm pouring water on it, because I'm not going to do it," Spacey insisted. He then struck a more optimistic note: "If I end up doing it, it might be six months down the line when I actually read a script and decide." So with the Panther script still unfinished, the project already looks to be descending into an entertainingly bumbling comedy of errors. Fitting somehow. Meanwhile we have a few alternative Clouseaus in mind: click here to inspect our suggestions.

With Hollywood still chewing over the Matt Damon / Winona Ryder break-up, it's heartening to learn that movie-star types can still fall in - as well as out of - love. The cause of all this joy is Double Jeopardy star Ashley Judd, who has just confirmed her engagement to boyfriend Dario Franchitti. Judd apparently first met the Scots-born, racing-driving Franchitti at a wedding reception last year, and the pair have been inseparable ever since.

fields.headline: Satire4London
fields.standfirst: Can a new play focusing on the machinations surrounding the capital's mayoral race satirise what is already beyond parody? asks Patrick Barkham.
fields.trailText: Can a new play focusing on the machinations surrounding the capital's mayoral race satirise what is already beyond parody? asks Patrick Barkham.
fields.body:
Billed as "an after-dinner entertainment", Snogging Ken is more playlet than play. Tariq Ali, Howard Brenton and Andy de la Tour's quickfire response to the shenanigans surrounding the selection of a Labour candidate for London mayor is a light, hour-long look at how Millbank might try to nobble Ken Livingstone.

The stage is made out as a swanky metropolitan restaurant. Its setting is doubly appropriate: the Almeida theatre lies mere yards from Granita, the smart Islington eaterie where political legend has it that Tony Blair persuaded Gordon Brown not to stand against him in the 1994 Labour leadership contest.

Ambitious Millbank apparatchik Pandora meets the equally ambitious Blair babe MP Lola, still smarting from a mauling at the hands of Jeremy Paxman on Newsnight, and tries to persuade her to claim that she has borne Ken's love-child - a ruse Labour hope will catapult "Dobbo the donkey" to an unlikely mayoral victory.

Meanwhile, at the neighbouring table, Thick Boy Geezer, one of Livingstone's celebrity bagman who claims to have enjoyed 15 minutes of fame at a Brit Awards rumpus two years ago, is attempting to weedle £200,000 from a reluctant businessman in aid of Ken's independent campaign.

What unfolds is a look behind the scenes at the machinations of two rival political campaigns. Although Ken and Dobbo are the focus of the scheming, in sharpest focus are the political hacks who pull the strings behind the scenes.

Sarah Coomes is perfect as Pandora, a preening, ruthless Millbank monster; the kind of posh politico who would be at the cynical heart of the political establishment in any era or ideology she was born under. Fearful of the consequences of a Livingstone victory, she articulates Millbank's biggest fear: "If Ken can be leftwing AND popular - what the fuck were we doing for 10 years ditching every leftwing policy and principle we ever had? I mean, what did we go and kill John Smith for?"

Snogging Ken's satire of New Labour scheming is perfectly serviceable. But the triumph of blind political ambition above principle in the minds of many Labour MPs and spinners who constitute the cogs of the party machine is equally well satirised by Have I Got News For You every week and Private Eye every fortnight. It is also hard to carry off satire when much of New Labour's plotting is so preposterous as to defy parody.

Where Snogging Ken is sharper, and more subtle, is in its depiction of Ken's campaign and his campaigner, Thick Boy Geezer, whose glottal protestation that "I'm a man of the people" is belied by the revelation that "Mr Geezer" is actually called Lionel. Colin Tierney, who nicely parodies the pop celebrities drawn to the cheap thrill of Ken-mania, manages to carry off his "dumb and dumber" approach to political action, while offering a qualified defence of the criticisms of Livingstone put forward by Doug, the cheque-wielding businessman.

Everyone loves Ken because of the GLC, Thick Boy claims. "Fare's fair, remember that? 10p to go where you like, firework displays every other weekend, and  and  well, that was about it really. It was just great."

Times have changed and Ken has changed. "Is he still a socialist?" Doug asks. "Oh yeah. But not as a daytime job," Thick Boy - or "Thick Lad" as Doug calls him - replies. "I mean, selling bonds to spruce up the Northern Line, that's hardly dictatorship of the proletariat."

"He doesn't want to solve problems," opines Doug. "Protest politics, that's all he wants  He wants this job because he can't deliver on anything that matters."

The deal-making and political conclusions drawn at the end of the play offer a bleak view of the political stalemate that Mayor Ken versus Number 10 will create in London. And the thin audience for a hotly contemporary political skit in the heart of political luvvieland suggests that while there is great affection for Ken, there may be less of a buzz around his campaign than the impression created by the polls and by the masterful self-publicist.

Tariq Ali, Howard Brenton and Andy de la Tour's quickfire response to the shenanigans surrounding the selection of a Labour candidate for London mayor is a light, hour-long look at how Millbank might try to nobble Ken Livingstone. The stage is made out as a swanky metropolitan restaurant. Its setting is doubly appropriate: the Almeida theatre lies mere yards from Granita, the smart Islington eaterie where political legend has it that Tony Blair persuaded Gordon Brown not to stand against him in the 1994 Labour leadership contest. fields.headline: Food on the net
fields.trailText: www.cookerybooks.com
fields.body:
www.cookerybooks.com

A good place to go in search of those restaurant cookbooks. Not as user-friendly as amazon.com, but because the site is dedicated to English language cookbooks from all over the world it can recommend some little known gems.

Pros: 20% off recommended titles, plus online reviews. More unusual is the range of food-related magazines and newspapers in stock. Sneak a preview of a recipe from your chosen book.

Cons: If you register on the site, you are supposed to be able to get prices in sterling, but it's still more likely to give it in dollars. Delivery info could be easier to find.

Delivery: Three days, if in stock.

Charges: £2.95 per order.

fields.headline: The Guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15 | Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

St Williams College, 5 College Street, York. Tel: 01904 557 233.

Set in a magnificent 15th-century building next to the Minster. Calls itself a bistro restaurant. Three-course menu (£15.75) but two (£12.95) do nicely thanks to Yorkshire portion control. Trad English and Med dishes - fresh and local. Proper cooking, too; including spiced aubergine and mushroom salad and cardamom and yogurt dressing; smoked mackerel cakes with rhubarb relish; grilled rib-eye beef with Yorks ale and mustard; Savoy cabbage parcels with haricot bean casserole; warm choc pud with white choc sauce; pear and frangipane tart. Wine is simple, service is friendly, if occasionally wobbly.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Pitcher and Piano, Coney Street, York. Tel: 01904 658 580.

Large, open, light, airy space on two floors with huge window/doors opening out on to decking over river. Friendly and efficient service. Big portions. For starters, try tomato and basil dip and humous with flat bread and olives, or deep-fried lemongrass chicken with sweet plum sauce, £4.50; "Sandwiches and Sharers" include smoked chicken, crispy bacon, tomato and lemon mayonnaise on toasted foccacia, £5.95; goats' cheese, tomato and pesto on toasted foccacia, £5.95. "Mains and salads": smoked haddock and poached eggs on toasted muffin, £6.95; fish cakes with big chips and lime mayo, 6.95; chargrilled lamb with Mediterranean vegetables, £7.50.

fields.headline: On the menu: sarsparilla
fields.trailText: Never heard of it. Oh, come on. It's always cropping up in those westerns when the tenderfoot says: "Give a shot of sarsparilla.
fields.body:
Never heard of it. Oh, come on. It's always cropping up in those westerns when the tenderfoot says: "Give a shot of sarsparilla.

So? It's on the way back

From where? Central America, originally. It's the bitter extract of the root of a creeping shrub.

Sounds gripping. The infant soft drinks industry in the US got hold of it in the second half of the 19th century. It was promoted for its health-giving properties.

And does it have any? Er, probably not, Ke-mo sah-bee.

So why should we get excited. Word has it that it's due for a fizzy drink makeover. It's going to be the Denise Van Outen of 2001.

fields.headline: Countdown to crisis
fields.standfirst: We explain how the fight for Rover has developed over the last few weeks
fields.trailText: We explain how the fight for the 'English patient' has developed over the last few weeks
fields.body:
March

15: Reports appear tipping an unknown venture capitalist firm, Alchemy Partners, as favourites to buy Rover.

16: The BMW supervisory board, meeting in Munich, agrees to break up Rover, selling Land Rover to Ford.

17: Alchemy managing partner Jon Moulton appears at a London press conference giving details of his ambitious plan to buy Rover cars and produce sports models under the MG badge. Hear Mark Milner in Munich on the deal. Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers faces Tory attacks for being "complacent" over the future of Rover. A task force is set up to help regenerate the West Midlands in the wake of expected job losses at the Longbridge factory in Birmingham.

19: Some union officials call for a boycott of BMW cars.

22: Rover dealers say they will demand compensation from BMW after heavy investment in their businesses. Birmingham businessman John Hemming says he is seeking partners to launch an alternative bid for Rover. Mr Byers travels to Munich to press BMW to help regenerate the West Midlands following the Rover sale. Chris Woodwark, former chief executive of Rolls-Royce Motors, is named by Alchemy as chief executive of its planned MG Car Company.

25: A union poll says six out of 10 British car buyers are prepared to boycott BMW.

28: Commons Trade and Industry Select Committee takes evidence close to the Longbridge plant as part of a hastily-arranged inquiry into the Rover sale. BMW's annual results show heavy losses at Rover, which had cost the German firm £2.85 billion in the six years since it bought the British carmaker.

29: BMW official Werner Samann tells the select committee that unsuccessful efforts had been made to sell Rover to Ford, General Motors, Volkswagen and Toyota.

30: Mr Byers faces Tory calls to resign.

April

1: Tens of thousands of people join a march and rally in Birmingham to support the Rover workers.

5: Mr Byers survives a two-hour grilling by select committee and receives public backing from the Prime Minister for his handling of the crisis.

6: The rival bid gathers pace, when a consortium headed by former Rover executive John Towers meets with BMW.

13: The select committee clears Mr Byers over his role in the Rover sale.

17: Alchemy announces its plans for Rover, including using Longbridge to build a family of MG sports cars.

26: The Government announces £10 million for suppliers after task force warns that Rover sale will hit thousands of jobs in the West Midlands.

27: BMW says the Towers bid is "not financially backed".

28: Alchemy issue shock statement saying negotiations with BMW have ended.

webTitle: Can Judy Garland role tempt Bening back on screen?

fields.headline: Can Judy Garland role tempt Bening back on screen?
fields.trailText: Annette Bening is rumoured to be the first choice to play tragic icon Judy Garland in a Fox Searchlight biopic which will be filmed later this year. Rainbow's End, based on the book by Steve Sanders, will trace the actress and singer through her troubled years in decline throughout the 50s and 60s. The script is by Jon Maas, and the picture will be executive-produced by Oliver Stone and Sid Luft, who is Garland's ex-husband.
fields.body:
Annette Bening is rumoured to be the first choice to play tragic icon Judy Garland in a Fox Searchlight biopic which will be filmed later this year. Rainbow's End, based on the book by Steve Sanders, will trace the actress and singer through her troubled years in decline throughout the 50s and 60s. The script is by Jon Maas, and the picture will be executive-produced by Oliver Stone and Sid Luft, who is Garland's ex-husband.

Bening is understood to be keen to take the role, but there remains a problem with the production's scheduling. The actress, Oscar-nominated for her turn in American Beauty, gave birth to her fourth child with husband Warren Beatty earlier this month, and has stated that she now plans to take an extended break from film-making in order to bring up her daughter. Whether Hollywood can tempt her back to work early remains to be seen.

webTitle: Time for a New Era's resolution

fields.headline: Time for a New Era's resolution
fields.trailText: Wednesday was to have been the big day: a new century, a new County Championship. Cricket should have knocked football from the headlines - without a wealthy businessman in sight. In the end the big day was a damp squib, and not just because of the weather.
fields.body:
Wednesday was to have been the big day: a new century, a new County Championship. Cricket should have knocked football from the headlines - without a wealthy businessman in sight. In the end the big day was a damp squib, and not just because of the weather.

This is not the way to start a cricket season. A round of championship matches was merely the next stage in an early-season sequence that began with the first University matches on April 7 and continued with the start of the Benson and Hedges Cup eight days later. At each stage the matches gained an extra degree of importance, but after almost three weeks (no less than 13 per cent of the cricket season) the drama had been sucked out of the new dawn. All we had to show for it was a few boos in the direction of Chris Lewis, and mixed fortunes for Aussies getting their first taste of 10-over thrashes.

Cricket should take a leaf out of football's book, in which the Premiership champions and FA Cup winners meet at Wembley a week before the league programme gets under way. To all intents and purposes it is just a glorified friendly, but concentrated publicity ensures everyone gets the message that the new season has started. The cricket version could be a four-day match at Lord's between the county champions and the winners of the second division. If nothing else, it would throw two in-form sides together at cricket's spiritual home. In time it would become something more than that. This is not the time for artificial select XIs, as some suggest: let's start as we mean to go on with a high-profile county cricket match. Surrey v Warwickshire at Lord's (as it technically would have been this year) with all the selectors and cricket correspondents gathered together would instantly be a focal point. At present the only focal point happens to be wherever a big-name overseas player with bleary eyes is stepping off an aeroplane.

My colleague Lawrence Booth rightly argued in last week's column for the abolition of the Benson and Hedges Cup. Without this tournament, the ECB could have taken advantage of the late Easter break and kicked off the season proper by scheduling its version of the Charity Shield for the four days starting on Good Friday. With hindsight, we know the weather would have had a say, but that is not the point. The ECB can't be blamed for rain, but it is responsible for failing to give cricket a decent fanfare, especially as it always has to compete with the climax of the football and rugby seasons.

The ECB's rush to get things going is not just confined to domestic cricket. The first Test of the summer is less than three weeks away, a fortnight ahead of its usual early-June slot. And it was no surprise when on Wednesday it was revealed that less than half of the tickets had been sold for what will be an historic match: Zimbabwe's inaugural Test in this country. Scheduling a bottom-of-the-table battle so early might help England's chances, but who wants to spend big money on a ticket when the chances are it will be cricket's second damp squib in three weeks?*

It is time to sort out the fixture list once and for all. Squeezing seven Tests and one triangular tournament in the summer requires one Test wholly in May and one mostly in September. Let's put greed aside and stick to six, which happens to fit neatly into the three warmest months of the year. Let's hold Championship matches between Wednesdays and Saturdays and play them on pitches that last: if a Shane Warne wonderspell means a match finishes on a Friday, fine; if a poor pitch is to blame, then there's something wrong. Sundays, Mondays and Tuesdays would be free for one-day cricket. Good old-fashioned daytime slogs on the Sabbath, day/night matches on the others. Regular, televised, Monday Night Cricket would be ideal, falling on a day of the week when there are fewer social occasions - weddings, barbecues, visits to gran, and so on. Then everyone will know where they are: players, officials and, most importantly, the watching public. Keep confusing the public and they just might not bother coming back, as the Lord's Test is threatening to show.

But it is the start of the season that needs rapid attention: cricket cannot keep stumbling into the spotlight, fluffing its lines. Start it with a bang, make sure it's noticed, and people will soon get the message.

* If you do fancy England v Zimbabwe at Lord's, click here to book tickets.

Matthew Hancock was editorial assistant on Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000.

fields.headline: 'Scapegoat' Hopkins in Barclays row
fields.trailText: Anthony Hopkins claimed yesterday that he has been scapegoated in the row over Barclays Bank's closure of 200 branches across England and Wales. The Oscar-winning star is currently starring in a high-profile television commercial for the bank.
fields.body:
Anthony Hopkins claimed yesterday that he has been scapegoated in the row over Barclays Bank's closure of 200 branches across England and Wales. The Oscar-winning star is currently starring in a high-profile television commercial for the bank.

In a letter sent to Labour politician Gwenda Thomas, a leading member of the Welsh National Assembly, the actor remarked that, "it seems that I have been wholly responsible for leaving thousands of people destitute".

Variety reports that Ms Thomas had approached Hopkins to solicit his support for a protest against the Barclay closures. These closures have been concentrated in rural areas and, critics claim, have bitten particularly hard in Hopkins's native South Wales. Hopkins fired back a hand-written missive. "I just have to set the record straight by saying that I do not run Barclays," it read. "I made a commercial back in June. But I suppose the press love a scapegoat, so why not have an actor." Striking a more defiant note, Hopkins reflected that "Such is life. So if I happen to be the chosen villain of the piece, so be it."

Hopkins's commercial for Barclays was filmed by Top Gun director Tony Scott. Building to its slogan "a big world needs a big bank", it features a shaven-headed Hopkins gobbling breakfast in his country mansion, then being kissed goodbye by a twentysomething girlfriend and chauffer-driven to a business meeting. "Got a big meeting with the big hitters from a big studio," he explains helpfully. The implication is that he is angling for a fee at least as "big" as the reported £750,000 he received for appearing in the commercial.

Other high-profile actors who have appeared in the current series of commercials include Tim Roth and Nick Moran. But given his Welsh roots, it is inevitably Hopkins who has drawn the flak.

The past month has become something of a PR disaster for Hopkins, who has faced criticism from his fellow Welshmen over both the Barclays controversy and his defection to the US where he now holds an American passport. The 62-year-old actor is currently preparing to reprise his malevolent Oscar-winning role in Hannibal, directed by Ridley (brother of Tony Scott). Back in his native Wales, he is becoming an off-screen villain too.

What would you do if you were in Hopkins' shoes? Debate the issue on our talkboards.

The 62-year-old actor is currently preparing to reprise his malevolent Oscar-winning role in Hannibal, directed by Ridley (brother of Tony Scott). Back in his native Wales, he is becoming an off-screen villain too. What would you do if you were in Hopkins' shoes? Debate the issue on our talkboards.

webTitle: AtomFilm and BT join forces  to distribute home entertainment

fields.headline: AtomFilm and BT join forces  to distribute home entertainment
fields.trailText: AtomFilms, the online distributor of Wallace and Gromit and Aardman animations' Angry Kid (see our news story have joined British Telecom in a ground-breaking internet deal.
fields.body:
AtomFilms, the online distributor of Wallace and Gromit and Aardman animations' Angry Kid (see our news story have joined British Telecom in a ground-breaking internet deal.

AtomFilms will give BT eight films a month to show on its new broadband service to be launched in July, which claims to allow home-based internet users the same kind of speed that can generally be obtained in the UK only on workplace computers. The home-based service will be available to anyone subscribing to the new BT internet broadband portal.

Michael Comish, head of AtomFilms Europe, said "the internet has cast potential as an entertainment medium. The only thing holding it back is the technology. Once the technology catches up, the internet will become as regular a place to watch great entertainment as sitting in front of a TV."

fields.headline: Police warrant for test veteran
fields.standfirst: Search spreads to London for Indian player allegedly linked to match-fixing
fields.trailText: A former Indian international cricketer accused of acting as a middleman between bookmakers and players in attempts to rig matches is believed to be in England.
fields.body:
A former Indian international cricketer accused of acting as a middleman between bookmakers and players in attempts to rig matches is believed to be in England.

Indian police have issued an arrest warrant for Ajay Sharma, who is thought to have left India for England on April 19, soon after the former Test cricketer was implicated in the match-fixing investigation that led to the resignation of South Africa's captain Hansie Cronje.

Sharma, who is believed to be staying somewhere in the London area, is known to be a close friend of a current India cricketer.

Indian police have records of mobile phone calls made by him to the player prior to India's matches against South Africa last month, although they insist that there is no concrete proof that these related to match-rigging.

The authorities also claim to have records of about 500 calls made by Sharma to various bookmakers during the series between India and South Africa and claim that he acted as the linchpin in an alleged match-rigging ring.

It is believed to be the first time that Indian authorities have actually named any player, current or former, in connection with match-fixing.

Sharma's alleged involvement will further increase pressure on the International Cricket Council to hold a full inquiry into match-fixing when it meets at Lord's next Tuesday.

Sharma played only one test match for India, against West Indies in Madras in 1988, but represented his country in 31 one-day matches. A stocky right-handed bat and slow left-arm bowler, he is a former captain of Delhi who owns the third highest first-class batting average of all time, 68.5.

A source said: "We would like to question him about many things, particularly his close links with some cricketers and bookmakers that we know of. We have no idea where Sharma is staying but as soon as he returns to India he will be detained and questioned."

Match-fixing investigators have voiced surprise at Sharma's affluent lifestyle. After quitting professional cricket he worked as a manager at the Central Warehousing Corporation in New Delhi and is believed to earn about 20,000 rupees (£285) a month. However, according to sources he owns two flats in an exclusive area of the Indian capital and also runs two foreign cars.

Since allegations of match-rigging surfaced this month almost all of New Delhi's major illegal bookmakers have gone into hiding and police are reported to be searching for them. Some of the country's leading cricketers have been accused by Indian media of rigging matches but no concrete evidence has been published.

Indian officials proposed to hold a full investigation into match-rigging after a meeting in New Delhi yesterday between politicians, cricket board representatives and the test cricketers Sachin Tendulkar and Mohammad Azharuddin.

"The consensus is that there there should be an investigation," said Bishen Singh Bedi, a former Indian test player who attended the meeting. The president of the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI), AC Muthiah, said: "We are prepared to cooperate wholeheartedly and give all the required documents or whatever they want to help the police in their investigations."

Earlier this month, Delhi police charged the South Africa cricketers Cronje, Pieter Strydom, Nicky Boje and Herschelle Gibbs with "cheating, fraud and criminal conspiracy" during a one-day series between India and South Africa.

webTitle: Research allays fears of CJD epidemic

fields.headline: Research allays fears of CJD epidemic
fields.trailText: A study aimed at predicting the threat to humans from BSE has found no evidence of the human form of the disease in 3,000 specimens of human tissue, the Department of Health said today.
fields.body:
A study aimed at predicting the threat to humans from BSE has found no evidence of the human form of the disease in 3,000 specimens of human tissue, the Department of Health said today.

The government's chief medical officer, Professor Liam Donaldson welcomed the news, but warned that the early results should not be taken as an indication of an "all clear". Government-funded experts analysed about 3,000 tonsil and appendix samples routinely taken from people since the 1980s. Preliminary results from the survey, which will eventually examine about 18,000 samples, found no traces of the abnormal prion protein associated with new variant CJD, the human form of mad cow disease, which has killed 52 people in the UK.

The brain disease is believed to be acquired from eating BSE-contaminated beef. Sufferers are thought to have become infected in the 1980s before the introduction of controls to prevent contaminated meat from entering the human food chain. BSE was first diagnosed in November 1986 and nv-CJD in 1995.

Some scientists have warned of a CJD epidemic affecting up to a half a million people during the next decade, but because the incubation period of the disease is unknown, it may still be too early to predict how many will succumb to nv-CJD.

Professor Donaldson said: "The fact that no positives have been found is welcome news, but these early results should not be taken as an indication of an 'all clear'. The methods of analysis used on the small sample of specimens have some limitations.

"In addition we do not know at what point in the incubation period tissues such as tonsils or appendices would turn positive, how long the incubation period would be, or even whether any individuals who were found positive would necessarily go on to develop the disease."

Nonetheless, today's results were being seen by experts as the most reliable indication so far of how many people are infected with nv-CJD.

The rogue prion proteins which cause nv-CJD are thought to accumulate in the tonsils and appendix, making them potentially useful for keeping track of the disease.

Experts from the CJD National Surveillance Unit in Edinburgh and Derriford Hospital in Plymouth carried out the study.

The research followed the death from new variant CJD in 1998 of Devon coastguard Tony Barrett. His appendix had been removed in 1995. When scientists re-examined it after his death they found the abnormal prion protein, showing that his condition could have been diagnosed before he fell ill.

Since then the two research centres have been collecting tonsil and appendix samples removed between the mid-1980s and late 1990s.

"The critical gap in our knowledge remains not having a reliable diagnostic test to detect the presence of the abnormal prion protein at the pre-clinical stage of the disease." said Professor Donaldson.

"The government is committed to spending some £26 million over the next year into research into CJD and BSE issues to address these important outstanding issues."

Commenting on today's results, a spokeswoman for the CJD Support Network said: "Obviously this is very welcome news as it may indicate that there are not going to be huge numbers of people with the disease. But we have to remember that this was a small study of only 3,000 samples and we will want to wait and see the outcome of the rest of the study.

"Meanwhile, we will have to go on supporting people and their relatives who are struck down by this devastating disease."

Like the bovine form of the disease (BSE), nv-CJD is a poorly understood condition that attacks the brain, leaving it full of holes like a bath sponge.

Victims display symptoms of dementia, becoming unsteady and confused and losing their memory. As the brain degenerates, they decline to a state where they cannot walk, talk or look after themselves. There is no known cure.

webTitle: The rise of the restaurant cookbook

fields.headline: The rise of the restaurant cookbook
fields.standfirst: The fourth River Cafe Cookbook is out next week - and it's tipped to be yet another bestseller.  Claire Phipps on the allure of the restaurant recipe book
fields.trailText: The fourth River Cafe Cookbook is out next week - and it's tipped to be yet another bestseller. Claire Phipps on the allure of the restaurant recipe book
fields.body:
It began about five years ago with the publication of a book of Italian recipes. On the face of it, there was nothing to it. The design was simple: bold colours, full-page colour pictures of no-frills rustic dishes. The recipes were, on the whole, simple; reassuringly short, pithily directed. The ingredients were, if not supermarket staples, at least reasonably easy to track down thanks to the book's list of suppliers of rocket, chicory and prosciutto. The book was the River Cafe Cookbook and it, and its sequels, have sold more than 500,000 copies.

Now, with the publication next week of the latest in the River Cafe franchise, River Cafe Green, our interest in all things Italian is set to be stoked again. Focusing on seasonality, with a typical River Cafe emphasis on vegetables, it should ensure that devotees of risotto con fiori di zucchini will be slicing their courgettes when they ought to. Once again, it is packed with illustrations - every featured vegetable is treated to a double-page picture - and big on new ingredients (expect to see sorrel, wild greens and even nettles on grocery lists in the next few months). In fact, it's big in every way, rolling in at a weighty 462 pages.

So how did the River Cafe cookbooks - Green will be the fourth - come to be a staple of British kitchen shelves? The restaurant itself opened in London W6 in 1987, eight years before the book was written. It was the book, though, which propelled it into the realms of the elite, and though a world away from Islington (by Tube, at any rate), it was to become one of the shining lights of the New Labour sun-dried tomato revolution. But it wasn't all about drooling press coverage and a mid-90s penchant for penne and Parma ham.

"What the River Cafe is very good at is inspiring," says food writer Nigella Lawson. "They use wonderful pictures and even though I don't really follow the recipes closely, I will look to see how they use a particular vegetable, for example."

Flora Woods, book buyer for Notting Hill shop Books for Cooks, says it revolutionised cookery book design. "The first River Cafe cookbook virtually obliterated everything else that was out there. It was effectively the marker for all the books that followed. The publishers began to think of the cookbook as a big new market. And they were right."

The restaurant cookbook is a rather different animal to the celebrity chef title. Jamie Oliver has just made his return on television as the Naked Chef, but is presently without a restaurant. He and his producers have deliberately given his cooking escapades a very personal flavour - buy the book, taste the trendy Vespa-riding lifestyle.

Similarly, Delia Smith has made her name through books that never stray far from the kitchen store cupboard. And both have reached massive audiences - many more than a restaurant could in a year's worth of dinner sittings - through their television shows.

So it's easy to see why the armchair chef buys a book for a recipe that has just been expertly, and provocatively, whipped up on screen. However, it's not so easy to see the appeal of a recipe book that is in essence a giant plug for a restaurant most readers have never visited and probably never will. Have half a million people really eaten at the River Cafe? Will those who bought the Momo Cookbook, published earlier this month, be rubbing shoulders with Madonna and Stella McCartney at the restaurant this evening? Can even half of those who purchased The Ivy: The Restaurant and its Recipes name its head chef?

No matter, says Lawson, who believes "most cookbooks are sold and not cooked from. It's a kind of vicarious cooking - and there's nothing wrong with that. The recipes have to work, of course, but most of all it has to be a pleasure to read." In Woods' opinion, "The Ivy was a hugely successful cookbook because it's considered to be Britain's favourite restaurant." At any rate, it's embedded in the public's mind as the place where celebrities go to eat and mere mortals wait six months for a reservation. The book was put together partly as a response to requests from regulars for the secrets of such favourites as shepherd's pie and sticky toffee pudding, but has been snapped up by those who have never got within a napkin's breadth of the maitre d'. But books such as The Ivy and its sister title, Le Caprice, are, in any case, more about the restaurant than its food says Lawson. Laden as they are with food critic AA Gill's musings on the London restaurant scene, they are more style guides with recipes than cookbooks. "You don't have to have any desire to cook to buy them," says Lawson, who sees the market moving more towards what she calls the "de-chefing of the cookbook".

But then when were restaurants ever just about food? Woods's favourite book of 1999 was the little known Cafe Paradiso Cookbook, "an absolute gem with wonderful recipes", but virtually unheard of.

Readers now tend to be more design-conscious and publishers, since the River Cafe phenomenon, certainly are. A cookbook that looks good on the shelf, or even the coffee table, will find a home in even the most under-used of kitchens. Get it wrong, and the recipes alone won't rescue it. Le Caprice ignored the rules, experimenting with pictures of neon signs, sequins and credit cards. It didn't sell well. "The design was outrageous," says Woods. "But I think it was supposed to be a reflection of what the restaurant is like."

The Momo Cookbook, a newcomer to the market, might fare better. The design is sumptuous, as is the restaurant itself, and the recipes follow suit.

The casual cook might not, for example, have a ready supply of orange blossom water. The budget, more to the point, might not stretch to a whole sea bass. Amid the restaurant specialities, though, are recipes which provide a tried and tested way into the cuisine of the moment: North African. Just as the fad for Pacific Rim fusion food boosted the fortunes of the Sugar Club Cookbook back in 1997, before the name of chef Peter Gordon warranted a book title of its own, a passion for the Maghreb might help the Momo Cookbook and next year's Moro recipe book (Nigella Lawson's tip) on their way.

To achieve River Cafe sales figures, though, the recipes have to work, and in an ordinary domestic kitchen without professional equipment and an army of sous-chefs. At Books for Cooks, chef Sylvana tests recipes from the big sellers in the in-house cafe. Her recommendations? The Mirabelle Cookbook always works, although the book itself wasn't a huge success ("people want Marco Pierre White, not the Mirabelle," says Woods). Bruno Loubet, now head chef at Isola, is also a favourite.

And the flops? The Roux Brothers, apparently, are notorious for tricky recipes which never quite work, and some of Peter Gordon's dishes turn out stodgy and heavy. "But," says Woods, "that's the beauty of a test kitchen. Maybe they forgot something when they were writing the recipe."

The legend among recipes, though, is one which only one of the Books for Cooks team has managed to master. "A complete riddle, a real chef quest," is how they describe it. The culprit? Chocolate Nemesis, a menu favourite but, well, the nemesis of the home chef. You'll find it in the River Cafe Cookbook.

The Mirabelle Cookbook always works, although the book itself wasn't a huge success ("people want Marco Pierre White, not the Mirabelle," says Woods). Bruno Loubet, now head chef at Isola, is also a favourite. And the flops? The Roux Brothers, apparently, are notorious for tricky recipes which never quite work, and some of Peter Gordon's dishes turn out stodgy and heavy. "But," says Woods, "that's the beauty of a test kitchen. Maybe they forgot something when they were writing the recipe." The legend among recipes, though, is one which only one of the Books for Cooks team has managed to master. "A complete riddle, a real chef quest," is how they describe it. The culprit? Chocolate Nemesis, a menu favourite but, well, the nemesis of the home chef. You'll find it in the River Cafe Cookbook.

fields.headline: Greer blames agency 'failure to help'
fields.trailText: Germaine Greer yesterday blamed "responsible authorities" for failing to prevent an alleged attack on her by a student on Monday.
fields.body:
Germaine Greer yesterday blamed "responsible authorities" for failing to prevent an alleged attack on her by a student on Monday.

Speaking for the first time since a 19-year-old female was charged with assault and false imprisonment, the feminist academic and broadcaster said she thought that the incident could have been avoided.

"The police have been wonderful, but everyone else in this case has behaved like a bunch of idiots," she said outside her house in Great Chesterford in Essex.

"They have not understood the gravity of this case. A lot of this could have been avoided, and I am very angry about it; I don't regard myself as a victim here. We had asked for help from people who were supposed to be responsible. But what you get is interference, not help." She declined to specify which agencies she was criticising, but indicated the social services were among them.

She had considerable sympathy with her alleged attacker's circumstances: "Students are under great stress, they are very often disorientated; now they are in debt. All of this means that many are very vulnerable... I am not angry, I am not upset, I am not hurt; I am fine. Someone else is hurt."

Ms Greer said she would not increase the security at her isolated home. "Ever since the Female Eunuch was published there has been an off-chance that some nutter would pick me off somewhere - there has always been that risk. I feel like Caesar: the brave man dies just once, the coward dies many times. I suppose I am a brave woman because I refuse to be afraid."

Police were called to her home on Monday evening after friends who had been invited for dinner heard shouting from inside. The alleged attacker has been given bail on condition she remains at least 15 miles from Ms Greer's house, and is due to appear before magistrates at Harlow in Essex on Thursday.

webTitle: US court tells relatives they cannot see Elian

fields.headline: US court tells relatives they cannot see Elian
fields.standfirst: The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: A US appeal court yesterday rejected a request by Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez to be allowed to visit the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of a custody battle.
fields.body:
A US appeal court yesterday rejected a request by Miami relatives of Elian Gonzalez to be allowed to visit the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of a custody battle.

The federal court accepted instead the US government's offer of regular reports from a psychiatrist and social worker.

The Miami relatives had cared for Elian for five months until he was seized by federal agents on Saturday to join his father. They had asked the court for "regular and reasonable access" to the boy, who is staying with his father, stepmother and half brother at a rural Maryland retreat. A request for the court to name an outside guardian to look after the boy was also turned down.

The court must now decides whether to reinstate a claim for political asylum which the relatives filed on Elian's behalf.

Meanwhile, Elian's doctor, four of his schoolmates and four of their parents have travelled from Cuba to see the youngster.

The Cuban leader, Fidel Castro, who bid farewell to the group before they flew out of Havana yesterday, complained about the US refusal to grant visas to all 31 people his country had proposed to help the young shipwreck survivor recover from trauma, catch up with schoolwork and renew relations with his friends.

webTitle: Janitors clean up in strike settlement

fields.headline: Janitors clean up in strike settlement
fields.trailText: The workers who clean the offices of corporate Los Angeles returned to work yesterday following a three-week strike that is being hailed as a major victory for the low-paid and a sign of growing union militancy in the United States. The strike, involving mainly Latino workers, has been likened to the victories achieved nearly 30 years ago by Latino farm workers.
fields.body:
The workers who clean the offices of corporate Los Angeles returned to work yesterday following a three-week strike that is being hailed as a major victory for the low-paid and a sign of growing union militancy in the United States. The strike, involving mainly Latino workers, has been likened to the victories achieved nearly 30 years ago by Latino farm workers.

The 8,500 cleaners, known as janitors in the US, went on strike earlier this month in pursuit of an increase in pay of $1 (63p) an hour for each of the next three years. They have settled for an immediate bonus of $500 plus an increase of 25% over the next three years. It is the largest such settlement for 20 years and is seen as a sign of the clout of the Services Employees International Union (SEIU) which represents them and has been increasingly active in recruiting low-paid Latino workers.

The strikers took to the streets of LA three weeks ago and brought traffic to a stand still in the city centre with their marches and demonstrations. They won vast public support for their claims that they deserved to be paid better for cleaning the toilets and offices of some of the richest businesses in the country.

The Roman Catholic archbishop Roger Mahony offered his support and took part in some of the final negotiations. He had earlier described the strikers' cause as one of "fundamental economic justice". Local councillor Jackie Goldberg was arrested with the janitors on one of their demonstrations in Bel-Air. Most of the local media gave sympathetic coverage to the strikers.

Mike Garcia, president of the SEIU Local 187, the local union branch, said: "This is the beginning of a new era for organised labour. This fight wasn't just about us. That's why we got such tremendous community and political support. We were at the right place at the right time. People were looking for an underdog to root for."

Attention now shifts northwards where 5,500 janitors in the Bay Area of San Francisco are in dispute. A march by janitors and supporters through silicon valley aimed at highlighting the disparity between rich and poor was due to take place yesterday.

The LA strike is significant in that it involves a part of the workforce that employers traditionally believed could be taken on and defeated because there is a large pool of unofficial labour in California, some of whom are prepared to work for very low wages. People have been reluctant to strike in the past for fear that they could easily be replaced with people desperate for work.

Unions representing more than 300,000 workers in Los Angeles, including teachers and public transport workers, are due to enter negotiations shortly and the victory is seen as a sign that the unions are finally taking the initiative after decades of relative passivity.

The strike comes as the British film director Ken Loach is completing a film featuring a previous janitors' strike which also campaigned under the slogan of " Si, se puede " (yes, it is possible).

fields.headline: Fear stalks Kosovo's remaining Serbs
fields.standfirst:
A diminishing minority, guilty and innocent alike, is under siege

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Milan Jankovic and his wife Todora rarely leave their second floor apartment these days. Norwegian soldiers patrolling the graffiti-disfigured estate bring them food; their closest neighbour, Maria Vlascevic, is planning to leave for Belgrade.
fields.body:
Milan Jankovic and his wife Todora rarely leave their second floor apartment these days. Norwegian soldiers patrolling the graffiti-disfigured estate bring them food; their closest neighbour, Maria Vlascevic, is planning to leave for Belgrade.

For the few Serbs who remain in Kosovo, their impoverished lives are shrinking around them. Friends have departed, jobs prove impossible to find and revenge killings by ethnic Albanians are thinning their numbers.

Of 200,000 Serbs resident in Kosovo before last year's conflict, around three-quarters are estimated to have fled since Nato and K-For troops entered the province. Most bundled up their possessions and retreated north to Serbia ahead of the occupying forces.

"Once there were 15 Serb families in this block. Now there are only three," sighs Mr Jankovic who lives in Breje, an estate on the edge of Kosovo Polje. The area remains a Serb enclave but its population, protected by multinational contingents of police and K-For soldiers, has declined sharply.

"One of my sisters has been kidnapped and no one knows where she is. We had an apartment in Pristina but that has been taken; I have the documents to show it's ours but I can't sell it. If I could, I'd be off to Montenegro immediately. We want to live somewhere where you don't have to lock the door a hundred times."

As his wife patiently mills coffee beans in a hand-grinder, he lays out his worthless papers with a disconsolate shrug. "It's not safe to visit [the capital] Pristina. These have become days of terror. We are relatively lucky here. The Albanians could come and kill us all - but we never killed any of them, didn't touch them, so I guess they respect us."

Despite the presence of tens of thousands of K-For troops, the killings have continued unabated at the rate of several a week.

Last week a salvo of mortar shells crashed into the village of Gorazdevac, 50 miles west of Pristina and one of the last all-Serb villages in the province. Former members of the Kosovo Liberation Army are suspected of carrying out the attack. No one was injured.

Across Kosovo, each Orthodox church with its distinctive onion-domed roof has an armoured K-For vehicle parked alongside. Those left unguarded have already been reduced to rubble, dynamited by Albanians in reprisal for the role they claim Orthodox priests played in stirring up ethnic and religious hatred.

There have been a few, tentative signs of reconciliation. In a rare act of solidarity, Kosovo's Serb and Albanian leaders recently issued a joint statement calling for an end to the killings. Among the signatories were Hashim Thaci, the former head of the Kosovo Liberation Army, Ibrahim Rugova, the best known ethnic Albanian politician, and, for the ethnic Serbs, Bishop Artemije and the moderate Rada Trajkovic. The statement called for a "climate of tolerance" to prepare for municipal elections planned for later this year.

Oliver Ivanovic, a Kosovo Serb leader, is also organising the first return of 1,000 fellow refugees to a valley near Istok, in an attempt to test the United Nations' commitment to restoring law and order. Dennis McNamara, the UNHCR envoy in Kosovo, has warned, however, that it is not yet safe for a large-scale return of Serbs.

The charred rows of ethnic Albanian homes in almost every town and village of Kosovo, torched by Serb forces during last year's 78-day war, are constant reminders of continuing resentments.

Even the stone tower, commemorating the battle of Blackbird Field in 1389 and used by Yugoslav president Slobodan Miliosevic 600 years later as a rallying point for his version of Serb nationalism, now bears the scars of recent conflict. Despite being protected by K-For troops, it has suffered several grenade attacks.

Back in the town of Kosovo Polje, Milan Jankovic muses over how his family's horizons have contracted to a two-roomed apartment. "Things were not like this when Tito was alive," he says. "I lived here for 50 years, had Albanian and Serb friends and no one ever bothered me. If Tito were alive you wouldn't need British and Norwegian soldiers here."

He knows who to blame: "A child could have solved these problem better than Milosevic. What did he achieve? Hate. Nothing more.

"If people who were guilty died, it wouldn't be a problem. But it's the innocent who are dying. What Milosevic did for us was a big shame. It was important to be a president for all the people, not to leave us in such a condition where we have nothing left to eat."

His neighbour, Maria Vlascevic, is packing up and preparing to head north to Belgrade. "A lot of Serbian monasteries have been destroyed," she says. "I am leaving because I have a 17-year-old daughter and she can't even go out to the coffee shop in safety. I can't say whether other presidents are better than Milosevic, but he's my president."

webTitle: Army pays soldier mother £21,000 for training ordeal

fields.headline: Army pays soldier mother £21,000 for training ordeal
fields.trailText: A woman soldier who was posted to the Balkans 10 weeks after giving birth has been paid £21,500 damages by the army after accusing it of sexual discrimination and victimisation.
fields.body:
A woman soldier who was posted to the Balkans 10 weeks after giving birth has been paid £21,500 damages by the army after accusing it of sexual discrimination and victimisation.

Lance corporal Nina Middlemass, 28, told an employment tribunal last year that she was victimised to the brink of suicide after enduring a catalogue of abuse from her superiors.

The army denied liability but agreed to make an out-of-court settlement. Ms Middlemass, from Ryton, near Gateshead, discharged herself from 2 Signals regiment earlier this month.

She brought the action against the Ministry of Defence last May, saying officers had told her to have two abortions or risk being drummed out of the service as an unmarried mother. She claimed she was put on an intensive training programme, including seven mile runs, shortly after returning from giving birth to her daughter, Kara, in 1995.

She also told the tribunal in Newcastle upon Tyne that she had never been informed of maternity leave options, although maternity rights legislation was introduced in August 1990.

"I was doing six and seven-mile runs on a regular basis after having my baby just weeks previously. I was four stone overweight and it was obvious to anyone that I was unfit.

"I was struggling. I would fall behind and then I would be left alone to complete the run by myself. Because I kept going over on my ankles I was seriously feeling the strain. After I mentioned it to my bosses I was depressed. I was told that I was using post-natal depression as an excuse to get out of work."

Ms Middlemass, who worked as a radio technician with 2 Signals based at York, was posted to Bosnia as part of a UN peacekeeping force while still breastfeeding her child.

She said yesterday: "The army have not admitted they were in the wrong, but I believe the money does that. I still feel cheated and angry that I have never been able to clear my name and that my career has been ruined."

She confirmed she had received £21,500 as payment for injury to her feelings, had been discharged from the army on medical grounds, and would also receive a pension of £3,000 a year.

A spokeswoman for the equal opportunities commission said: "This case and others like it prove that organisations have to be vigilant against discriminatory behaviour. Other cases brought by women in the services have been won after behaviour and attitudes within the forces ... have been ruled to be discriminatory."

fields.headline: Sales drive
fields.standfirst: Porsche puts prices into reverse
fields.trailText: A top-of-the-range Porsche 911 turbo, at £94,749 a throw, tells the world that its owner is loaded.
fields.body:
A top-of-the-range Porsche 911 turbo, at £94,749 a throw, tells the world that its owner is loaded.

At least, that's the picture today. But from Monday owning a Porsche will be not quite so exclusive. The German car company is to cut prices in Britain by an average of 10%.

The cost of the 911 turbo is being cut by £8,749 to £86,000, while the price of the entry level Porsche Boxster 2.7 is being clipped by £2,782 to £31,450.

Andy Goss, the managing director of Porsche Cars Great Britain, said the price cuts would remove the need for Porsche buyers to look overseas for a good bargain.

He also expected Porsche sales in Britain to rise above last year's record sales of 4,315.

Increased sales would help to offset the £21.5m cost of the price cuts, he said.

He denied the move was in response to the recent competition commission report which found that British car buyers were being overcharged.

It was "a robust response to the continued strength of the pound" and sent a clear message to customers that "the best place to buy a Porsche is in UK showrooms," he said.

"We will be selling year 2000 models at the price levels which existed in 1995."

Porsche cut British prices by 5% last August in response to the price gap that existed with the rest of Europe based on exchange rate differences.

Mr Goss said the latest 10% cut would be "permanent" - unlike other manufacturers' recent cuts, which were available for a limited time only.

There is already a six-month waiting list for new Porsches and people who have already ordered their new car will get the full benefit of the lower prices, he said.

fields.headline: Quake warning for Istanbul
fields.standfirst: More about the Taiwan earthquake
fields.trailText: For the second time in four months, scientists have warned of earthquakes in or near Istanbul.
fields.body:
For the second time in four months, scientists have warned of earthquakes in or near Istanbul.

Millions could be at risk from a powerful earthquake in Turkey within the next 30 years, according to a study published today in the US journal Science.

The geologists involved in the study claim not to be making predictions, they are simply weighing the probabilities after studying the pattern of earth tremors that killed 18,000 last year in two separate shocks along the Anatolian fault that runs under Istanbul.

"An earthquake could happen near Istanbul tomorrow, or in many years," said Tom Parsons, a geophysicist with the US Geological Survey, who worked with Turkish and Japanese colleagues on the report. webTitle: What every good spy should know

fields.headline: What every good spy should know
fields.standfirst: So Russia thinks we have the best agents in the world. KGB defector  Oleg Gordievsky explains why
fields.trailText: So Russia thinks we have the best agents in the world. KGB defector  Oleg Gordievsky explains why
fields.body:
There are few absolutes in the world of espionage, but some things never change. When I joined the KGB in the early 60s, the prevailing view was the same as that expressed yesterday by Sergei Ivanov, head of the Russian security council: British spies are some of the best in the world.

This perception was partly based on myth. Early on, Soviet intelligence became convinced that the head of the British consul in Moscow was plotting a coup d'état against Lenin and the Bolsheviks, and that he had nearly prevailed; the Russians believed they had only disrupted the conspiracy at the very last moment. From that moment on, they had an exaggerated awe for the British.

Later, though, their awe proved more justified. During the second world war, when the KGB had to cooperate with the British services, they found them highly impressive: attractive, intelligent, dedicated, imaginative. When the cold war broke out, surveillance in Moscow was so penetrating that they assumed it would be impossible for foreign agents to operate; they were amazed to discover that the British were managing. And they were even more impressed when Kim Philby told them there were fewer than 10 British agents operating in the Soviet section of head office. The Russians - who had hundreds of spies themselves - had assumed they were up against a huge directorate. They couldn't understand how so few people could achieve such a wonderful result.

Charm is a key qualification for a successful agent: a good spy, fundamentally, is somebody who knows how to persuade other humans to give him what he wants. You need to be charismatic, charming, clever, interesting and well-spoken - but that is not enough. You have to have arguments at your disposal, to be able to persuade your targets to become your contacts. Most British schools and universities - not just Oxbridge, as Philby claimed - seem to produce such people; smooth, courageous types who don't need to be told what to do.

The great drawback for the Russians was that fear of defection and betrayal led to the purging in the 30s and 40s from the agency of people with cosmopolitan attitudes - people who spoke languages, who knew Europe and the US. The KGB became much like the rest of Soviet society: free from any liberal, intelligent elements and full of bureaucrats. I remember coming back to Moscow to report my results and being told to be quiet because there were far more important things to worry about - the restructuring of a department, the filling of a middle-ranking position. Internal bureaucracy meant the Russians lost sight of the real targets - although even when they did get orders, Russian agents could often be lazy, unsystematic and disorganised. Travelling west after years in the Soviet system, they would become intoxicated by freedom and start drinking, womanising and engaging in petty corruption, and start lying to their superiors about how many contacts they had made.

The CIA is different again. It's a huge organisation with a huge budget, and simply too many people to get the job done. Departments overlap; in some smaller Latin American countries, US intelligence officers seem to be tripping over themselves. The importance of the private sector in the US means the best brains are recruited by big corporations for good money; the CIA must make do with second-rate material. Where the proportion of clever, charming officers in MI6 is nine out of 10, in the CIA it is closer to one out of 10.

But the most incompetent agents in recent history have to be the French military intelligence officers who blew up the ship Rainbow Warrior in an exercise against Greenpeace in New Zealand in 1985. One person died for nothing. The two officers, using false documents, attempted to leave New Zealand but were caught. It was a very awkward situation. Gossip with former French agents and you get the impression this is typical of the military intelligence agency there - although not of their excellent counterintelligence service, which is unjustifiably held in contempt by the military people because its staff are technically policemen.

But modern technology is changing the game. American and British spies now produce so many documents on computer that it is increasingly difficult to stop them leaking out; the KGB, meanwhile, is restricting use of modern technology - and remains very efficient in protecting its secrecy.

For the 11 years I worked for Britain, I was unable to spirit a single enciphered cable from the KGB; today David Shayler and Richard Tomlinson can get dozens of top-secret documents out of the building simply because they were stored electronically. I find it all very strange, but I don't know what to do about it. I'm told nothing can be done to stop it - but if it continues, the secret services eventually won't be secret at all.

 Oleg Gordievsky, a former KGB officer, defected to MI6 in 1985.
