webTitle: GMG Endemol takes 50% stake in Victoria Real

fields.headline: GMG Endemol takes 50% stake in Victoria Real
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: GMG Endemol Entertainment, one of Britain's largest independent television production groups, yesterday acquired a 50% stake in Victoria Real which produces interactive content for digital TV and the internet.
fields.body:
GMG Endemol Entertainment, one of Britain's largest independent television production groups, yesterday acquired a 50% stake in Victoria Real which produces interactive content for digital TV and the internet.

The acquisition builds on a collaboration between the two groups on Big Brother, which will be screened on Channel 4 and the internet this summer and claims to be the first fully interactive mass TV programme.

In the show, which has already proven a hit across Europe, 10 strangers are put in a purpose-built house, pictured left, for 70 days and cut off from any outside contact. Their actions are watched by a series of cameras and viewers vote on who stays and who goes until only one person remains and wins a cash prize.

GMG Endemol is jointly owned by Guardian Media Group and Endemol Entertainment.

webTitle: Widdecombe's lesson in cream and punishment

fields.headline: Widdecombe's lesson in cream and punishment
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, got an object lesson in cream and punishment yesterday, when she was hit in the face by a custard pie.
fields.body:
Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, got an object lesson in cream and punishment yesterday, when she was hit in the face by a custard pie.

Protesters angered by the Conservatives' hardline stance on asylum seekers staged the attack on Miss Widdecombe at a book signing in Oxford.

Police charged a man and a woman after the incident, which took place as the Tory rightwinger entered the Waterstone's bookshop in central Oxford to sign copies of her novel The Clematis Tree.

It was staged by the Biotic Baking Brigade, which targets politicians and establishment figures.

Last night Mel Jarman, 28, said that she had thrown the pie. She was charged with assault and affray after Miss Widdecombe made a witness statement. For the case to progress, the shadow home secretary may have to appear in court.

Ms Jarman told the Guardian she was only a few feet away from Miss Widdecombe. "She was walking in the shop and I was walking out.

"Obviously I got quite nervous. I heard people chanting outside about asylum seekers and realised that she had arrived. I threw a pie from a couple of feet away. I threw it very gently.

"It was all very quick. She looked very surprised, but at that point I was bundled off.

"The intention was not to harm her, but to make the point that you can't make offensive racist comments about asylum seekers and get away with it. You can't be on a pedestal."

Ms Jarman, from Oxford, said the hardening of the Tories' rhetoric on asylum seekers in the past week had prompted her to throw the pie at Miss Widdecombe.

"I don't particularly want to go to jail. But when a politician comes out with something that is racist and offensive, how does an ordinary person respond? I've written letters but nothing changes."

Ms Jarman and a 27-year-old man were bailed to appear before Oxford magistrates on May 4.

After the attack Miss Widdecombe continued with her book signing, having wiped off the custard in a store toilet.

In a statement she said: "I deplore entirely the behaviour of these protesters. This demonstration was a mindless waste of police time carried out by people who clearly have no respect for free speech."

Her aide, Adam Newton, describing the attack, said: "The pie was the size of a breakfast plate. Naturally Ann was shocked but fortunately she wasn't hurt and she quickly composed herself.

"She was ushered into a toilet where she washed the pie mixture from her face and clothing and continued upstairs signing books. It's a pity that politicians or anyone else cannot go about their legitimate business without having to put up with this kind of behaviour."

Miss Widdecombe becomes the Biotic Baking Brigade's most high-profile victim in Britain. In October 1998 it attacked Renato Ruggiero, then director general of the World Trade Organisation.

The group has members worldwide and in the United States attacked the economic guru Milton Friedman.

In February 1998 the boss and founder of Microsoft, Bill Gates, was hit by a custard pie thrown by Noel Godin, godfather of political pie throwing.

webTitle: Devon abuse inquiry may rival north Wales scandal

fields.headline: Devon abuse inquiry may rival north Wales scandal
fields.trailText: Police investigating claims of physical and sexual abuse in a Devon children's home have extended their inquiries to three more institutions in the belief that they might be dealing with abuse on a scale to rival that of the north Wales scandal.
fields.body:
Police investigating claims of physical and sexual abuse in a Devon children's home have extended their inquiries to three more institutions in the belief that they might be dealing with abuse on a scale to rival that of the north Wales scandal.

Detectives have questioned former pupils at three privately run residential special needs schools in the south of the county, where staff at a children's home in which at least 80 children were allegedly abused, used to work.

Last night, Devon and Cornwall police played down reports that up to 4,000 children might have been abused between the mid-50s and the mid-80s.

"We don't know where that figure came from," said Detective Chief Inspector Tony Carney, who refused to divulge the number of former pupils who had been contacted. But a police spokeswoman admitted there might be as many alleged victims as in the north Wales scandal, in which 650 children were allegedly abused at care homes over 16 years. "We could be looking at something at least that big," she said. "It's such an in-depth investigation that at the moment we just don't know the scale of it."

Operation Lentisk, as the inquiry has been codenamed, was set up in January 1998 after allegations of abuse at a care home in south Devon. Three people are awaiting trial. Seventy-five people are pursuing a civil action against Devon county council, eight other local authorities and the Home Office for alleged negligence.

Questionnaires have been sent to former pupils at the three private schools - Pitt House, in Torquay; Stokelake, in Chudleigh; and Ingsdon House school, in Bickington - asking them about abuse.

fields.headline: Harare talks end in failure
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Talks in London aimed at resolving the Zimbabwe crisis collapsed in failure last night, when the delegation from Harare flatly refused to give a commitment to end the violence.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, Gary Younge  in Harare and  Anthony Sampson
fields.body:
Talks in London aimed at resolving the Zimbabwe crisis collapsed in failure last night, when the delegation from Harare flatly refused to give a commitment to end the violence.

The Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, emerged empty-handed after eight hours of talks with three Zimbabwean cabinet ministers. The collapse appeared to end all dialogue at ministerial level between Britain and Zimbabwe, leaving President Robert Mugabe a free hand in the run-up to the promised elections, due next month.

Last night Mr Cook said: "I have refused to make any further progress until the essential next step is taken and that is for the occupations to come to an end."

Continuing his defiance of international opinion, Mr Mugabe tightened his grip on power by resurrecting legislation which was originally intended to suppress black political action in Rhodesia. The provision would allow police to restrict the movement of party activists and ban public gatherings that threaten law and order.

The meeting failed even to agree on a common statement. It had been convened to find a solution to the increasingly bloody takeovers of white farms. Mr Cook blamed the Zimbabwean delegation for intransigence in refusing to give a commitment to end violence.

But the Zimbabwean delegation claimed Britain was at fault in reneging on previous promises to fund land reform. A Foreign Office source described the exchanges as "frank, sometimes very frank".

The meeting, which began in the morning, had been scheduled to end at 4pm. It ran into the evening as the two sides found difficulty in agreeing a common position.

The Foreign Office source said the talks went round in circles, coming back each time to Mr Cook's call for an end to the violence.

In Harare the police commissioner, Augustine Chihuri, whose forces have been severely criticised for their failure to intervene, said that the implementation of the three sections of the Law and Order Maintenance Act was intended to halt the violence.

"In short, it is illegal to ferry supporters to meetings, public gatherings or processions unless such events are being officiated by presidents of political parties," he said.

But opposition parties said the move represented yet another attempt by the ruling Zanu-PF party to suppress opposition and claimed it would effectively outlaw all independent political activity.

All attention now focuses on the pressure that can be brought to bear on Mr Mugabe from his African neighbours. Last night the former South African president Nelson Mandela said everything was being done behind the scenes to persuade President Mugabe to "cool things down".

"The people of Zimbabwe are justified in expecting Britain to honour her pledge to finance the redistribution of land," he said, "though that does not justify their methods in taking the land. If Zimbabwe collapses we must handle the aftermath: thousands of immigrants will flow into South Africa where unemployment is already high.

"There is no danger of the violence spreading to South Africa, although the land here is largely in white hands. It will never occur in South Africa. There have been killings of white farmers, but that has mainly been the result of rough way farmers have treated black workers."

Mr Cook offered the Zimbabwean delegation a £36m economic aid package, some of it to go towards land reform, including compensation for white farmers. But, according to Foreign Office sources, the Zimbabwean delegation wanted the money without conditions attached. Mr Cook insisted that an end to violence was his bottom line.

As the day dragged on, the Foreign Office expressed frustration that the Zimbabwean delegation could not even agree to principles which it had signed up to at a conference on land reform two years ago. The Zimbabwean delegation retorted that Britain had reneged on that 1998 agreement.

The Foreign Office began to play down expectations, insisting there had never been any chance of a solution in London and that in the end the problem would have to be resolved in Harare.

The signs had been ominous before the meeting when Mr Cook appeared to lay the ground for shifting the blame for failure onto Zimbabwe.

At the same time, the Zimbabweans claimed that Britain was behaving like a colonial power and should not be interfering in internal politics.

Last month, it was hailed as a breakthrough when Mr Mugabe agreed to send a delegation after meeting Mr Cook at European Union-African summit in Cairo.

A Foreign Office source said: "Robin Cook said we were prepared to help on the 1998 agreement but only on the basis of the violence being ended."

The focus will now shift to a meeting of Commonwealth ministers in London on Tuesday.

fields.headline: Atlantic deal buys growth
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland's Atlantic Telecom yesterday transformed the size and geographical spread of its customer base by agreeing a £520m all-share takeover of First Telecom, Europe's largest reseller of telecommunications.
fields.body:
Scotland's Atlantic Telecom yesterday transformed the size and geographical spread of its customer base by agreeing a £520m all-share takeover of First Telecom, Europe's largest reseller of telecommunications.

The deal gives Atlantic access to First Telecom's valuable contracts to roll out broadband services in Europe and ends the latter's plans for a stock market flotation of its own.

Analysts speculated that First Telecom decided to call off its float after the recent turbulence in the stock market which has wiped as much as 60% off the value of some telecoms stocks. However, Atlantic chief executive Graham Duncan denied this, insisting the pair had been in talks for several months and would make "an excellent fit".

The deal furthers Atlantic's ambition of becoming a leading alternative provider of domestic telecoms and high-speed internet services.

At the same time it announced a high-speed net service which will cover all call charges and be faster - but 25% more expensive than the offer BT announced earlier.

The enlarged group's customer base will extend from the 700,000 premises Atlantic supplies in four Scottish cities, across the 11,000 business and 290,000 residential customers First Telecom has acquired in Britain, Germany and France.

webTitle: Child abandoned in pushchair for 10 days

fields.headline: Child abandoned in pushchair for 10 days
fields.trailText: A woman who tied her three-year-old son to his pushchair and abandoned him for 10 days while she visited her new boyfriend was yesterday beginning a 15 month jail sentence.
fields.body:
A woman who tied her three-year-old son to his pushchair and abandoned him for 10 days while she visited her new boyfriend was yesterday beginning a 15 month jail sentence.

The woman, who cannot be named to protect the identity of her son, made daily visits to check on the boy and feed him, Merthyr Tydfil crown court heard. But when police found him, he was dressed in a urine-soaked sweater and was shaking uncontrollably. Both his feet were red and swollen and he was unable to straighten his legs.

Doctors who examined him found he was under-nourished, dehydrated and suffering from skin conditions and from emotional and physical neglect. He weighed only 2lbs more than he had when aged 20 months.

Sue Ferrier, prosecuting, told the court that the woman, from Merthyr Tydfil, south Wales, had convinced friends and neighbours the boy was being looked after by his grandmother while she stayed with her boyfriend and paid visits to a sick friend.

Police were eventually alerted by the boy's grandmother who had not seen him for three months. They broke into the house, described in court as squalid and strewn with litter, and found the boy strapped into his chair so tightly he needed to be cut free.

In police interviews the woman, who admitted neglect and wilful abandonment, told police she "could not cope" and did not have enough money to look after her son.

Jeremy Jenkins, defending, said: "She could not hide from the fact that her son was in a deplorable state. It is clear from the evidence that the mother needs help."

Judge John Curran rejected pleas for the woman to be placed on probation or given a suspended sentence. "The offences are too serious to be dealt with by anything short of a custodial sentence," he said.

fields.headline: Outrage greets Columbine video
fields.standfirst: Special report: Gun violence in America
fields.trailText: There is blood on the carpet, and folded cards on the floor mark the place where the bodies fell. Charred books lie open on the desk and bullet holes pockmark the walls.
fields.body:
There is blood on the carpet, and folded cards on the floor mark the place where the bodies fell. Charred books lie open on the desk and bullet holes pockmark the walls.

The official scene-of-the-crime video from the Columbine high school shooting is being sold for $25 (£16), showing the place where two Colorado teenagers massacred their schoolmates a year ago.

Parents of the victims voiced outrage yesterday at the decision by a local county lawyers' office to put the gruesome video on sale - the latest in a succession of deeply debatable decisions to allow the public to have access to video and taped evidence from the worst school shooting incident in US history.

"For the first time today, I saw my daughter being dragged over to the fire engine. I don't need to see that. And nobody else needs to see that," said Beth Nimmo, whose daughter Rachel was one of the 13 people shot dead by the two teenage gunmen.

"I'm totally disgusted," said Connie Michalik, whose son Richard was shot and paralysed in the attack. "It's really painful."

Lawyers for the local Jefferson county authorities say that they had to release the video because a judge who is hearing a civil negligence suit brought against the emergency services by a group of Columbine parents has ordered it to be handed over to the plaintiffs.

The tapes were put on sale "to avoid additional lawsuits by the public or news media", lawyer Frank Hutless said, adding that the £16 is to cover Jefferson county's costs. The video, which is nearly three hours long, consists of footage taken by police and rescue services during and after the shootings, the first anniversary of which fell on April 20.

Much of the video consists of material taken from a helicopter, and shows students fleeing and emergency services responding, with scenes of personnel moving the bodies of students who were killed or wounded. But the most graphic parts come from a 25-minute section compiled by the local fire department, showing the scene inside the school after the bodies had been removed.

It shows the scene in the hallways, cafeteria and library where Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold carried out their pre-planned massacre. Evidence of the deadly rampage is all around, including pools of blood on the carpets, still shining wet.

webTitle: Expert report gives mobile phones a clean bill of health

fields.headline: Expert report gives mobile phones a clean bill of health
fields.standfirst: Mobile phone fears: special report
fields.trailText: Mobile phones are not a proven health risk to their users, according to a long-awaited report by 12 independent experts.
fields.body:
Mobile phones are not a proven health risk to their users, according to a long-awaited report by 12 independent experts.

Claims that emissions from mobile phones in effect heat the brain, causing illnesses ranging from memory loss to tumours, appear to be unfounded, the 10-month Stewart inquiry has concluded.

Evidence in the report, due to be published on May 11, suggests that mobiles heat the brain by only one tenth of a degree while the body's temperature normally varies by one degree thoughout the day.

The report will call, however, for tighter controls on emissions to match the norm in Europe. It will also urge the Department of Health and business to fund more research, especially into the non-thermal effects of phones.

The mobile phone companies, fearful of a commercially damaging report, have been kept abreast of its direction as they prepared their bids, halted at £22bn yesterday, for the new generation of licences.

Critics of the report will claim that the committee of physicists and neurologists - headed by Professor William Stewart of Tayside University hospital - has been "captured" by the national radiological protection board which has acted as the secretariat to the committee. Members of the NRPB gave evidence to the committee strongly suggesting mobiles were safe.

Prof Stewart and his colleagues are said to have been struck by the vehemence of the opposition to the siting of mobile masts and the public's sense of powerlessness in their erection.

They are set to recommend changes to make it easier to block masts - especially when they are sited near schools.

There are more than 20,000 masts in Britain and their number is expected to grow rapidly. Orange alone is planning to increase its sites from 6,500 to 10,000 by the end of next year.

Minutes of the group's meeting with the public show it "recognised there was a need to empower the public, particlarly in the area of planning".

It is expected to recommend a system of full planning control on new masts and give councils a right to take public fear of health risks into account. A full national register of masts is also likely to be proposed.

The measures follow similar recommendations from the Scottish Parliament's environment select committee.

The Department of Trade and Industry has opposed changing planning procedures, fearing it will leave the industry prey to local politics and result in a patchy phone network. The industry will also be put under new pressure to share masts.

The group is likely to reject claims that mast base stations are health risks. Even at 20 to 30 metres from towers, emission exposure levels are similar to television and radio broadcasts, the NRPB has advised the group.

The mobile phone companies, led by the Federation of the Electronics Industry, has been pressing hard for the group not to recommend the removal of 500 base stations near schools. The industry says removal would cost £100m.

Parents have claimed children are vulnerable to radiowaves since their immune systems are still not developed. The group accepted that "if there is a risk, children may be at increased risk". The NRPB will be asked to conduct regular spot checks near schools, rather than leaving them to the companies.

A Mori poll for the federation found only 2% cited mobile phones as their primary health risk. Asked what they disliked most about mobiles, 16% cited health dangers, well behind the 47% which referred to aspects of their intrusiveness.

fields.headline: Clashes in Chile
fields.standfirst:
Rival protesters fight as court begins to decide Pinochet's fate

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Security was tight around a Santiago court yesterday as lawyers seeking to lift General Augusto Pinochet's parliamentary immunity from prosecution prepared to present their opening arguments. If they are successful, the hearing would pave the way for a prosecution on human rights charges.
fields.byline: Jonathan Franklin  and agencies in Santiago
fields.body:
Security was tight around a Santiago court yesterday as lawyers seeking to lift General Augusto Pinochet's parliamentary immunity from prosecution prepared to present their opening arguments. If they are successful, the hearing would pave the way for a prosecution on human rights charges.

A day earlier proceedings had begun amid clashes in the streets between supporters and opponents of the ailing 84-year-old general. The hearing has become a test for the Chilean government's assertion that Gen Pinochet can be tried in his own country.

In the first session the Santiago court of appeals heard allegations accusing the former dictator of being the "intellectual author" of 19 assassinations.

This is the first time that Gen Pinochet has been challenged by Chilean courts, which refused attempts by his lawyers to stop the proceedings immediately on grounds of mental and physical frailty.

The court yesterday began hearing the summary of the charges against him, which are contained in a 3,500-page document.

The investigation is being headed by Judge Juan Guzman Tapia, who has interviewed hundreds of people in an attempt to establish whether Gen Pinochet was responsible for the killings which took place following the 1973 military coup.

Yesterday, outside the court, hundreds of anti-Pinochet protesters handed out leaflets with the former dictator's face placed in cross-hair rifle sights.

Viviana Diaz, president of the Association of the Detained and Disappeared, which represents the 1,100 victims of the Pinochet regime whose bodies have yet to be found, said: "Today begins the trial against the person most guilty of the crimes committed in our country."

Supporters of Gen Pinochet were outnumbered 15-1 but still managed to cause havoc by tossing coins, bottles and stones at lawyers and human rights protesters. The two groups were kept apart by riot police.

As a self-designated "senator for life" Gen Pinochet placed himself beyond the reach of the law. He is also partially protected by an amnesty law that defined the military repression as part of a civil war.

The manoeuvres were unchallenged while Gen Pinochet remained an almost mythical figure in Chile. Following his arrest in Britain in October 1998, however, legal challenges to his immunity were bolstered by public anger at the way the former dictator had terrorised his way into a quiet retirement.

The new socialist president, Ricardo Lagos, has refused to give in to military threats since taking office in March.

"The country is tranquil because the institutions [of justice] function... as we have said to the world, in this country everyone, powerful or humble, is subject to the courts," Mr Lagos said yesterday in a clear message to the military, who have previously taken to the streets to pressure the civilian government to halt investigations.

In two further signs that Gen Pinochet's grasp of power is faltering, a group of imprisoned military officials - who had previously maintained a pact of silence - has begun meetings with journalists to leak documents that implicate the former leader directly in assassinations.

On Tuesday, a website (www.elmostrador.cl) published secret military documents that directly link Gen Pinochet to an army hit squad that worked during the mid-80s.

webTitle: Scots MPs press on with repeal of 'anti-gay' law

fields.headline: Scots MPs press on with repeal of 'anti-gay' law
fields.standfirst:
Devolution in Scotland: special report
More about section 28
fields.trailText: The Scottish parliament yesterday voted to press ahead with the repeal of section 28, just a week before a privately funded referendum will ask Scots to judge the issue themselves.
fields.body:
The Scottish parliament yesterday voted to press ahead with the repeal of section 28, just a week before a privately funded referendum will ask Scots to judge the issue themselves.

After months of impassioned debate on the subject, the parliament voted by 103 votes to 16 to approve the principles of the ethical standards in public life bill which would replace section 28 with a clause stressing the value of stable family life. The bill will now go to committee stage and could become law by the summer.

The parliament's decision, however, will not lay the issue to rest. Earlier this week, the Stagecoach tycoon, Brian Souter, revealed he had found a polling society to conduct his own referendum on the topic after being turned down by the Electoral Reform Society.

Next week, 4m Scots will receive letters asking them to say whether they approve or disapprove of repealing the clause, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools.

Mr Souter, who has fronted and bankrolled the Keep the Clause campaign in Scotland, has described the clause that will replace section 28 as an insult to Scottish parents and said it offered no protection against the promotion of homosexuality. His referendum, expected to cost upwards of £1m, has been dismissed by gay rights campaigners and the Scottish executive as fundamentally flawed and undemocratic.

During yesterday's debate, the communities minister, Wendy Alexander, attacked Mr Souter's plans to survey the Scottish public in a postal ballot. "Billboard negotiations are no negotiations at all," she said. "Next out of the till is a privately funded opinion poll, promoted by those with a partisan point of view who are in effect planning to demand of fellow Scots that some of them justify their lifestyles."

Yesterday, supporters of repeal gathered outside the Assembly Hall but inside the chamber there was none of the vitriol and recrimination that has marked much of the broader debate.

For the Conservatives, who have opposed repeal, the deputy leader, Annabel Goldie, said the executive's decision to remove the clause and replace it with "unenforcable wacko" was unacceptable to Scottish Conservatives and to the majority of Scottish people.

Nicola Sturgeon, for the Scottish National Party, said they supported repeal but believed the executive had not done enough to assuage public concern. The SNP was proposing an amendment for the bill's second stage which would introduce guidelines on sex education enshrined in statute. Ms Sturgeon stressed, however, that the nationalists considered section 28 "despicable."

"The natural desire we all have to protect children must not become confused as support for a piece of legislation that legitimises intolerance," she said.

Last night, Tim Hopkins, of the gay rights group, the Equality Network, welcomed the vote but said their campaign was not over. "There is an important job still to be done which is to explain to people why Keep the Clause is wrong and the things they have been saying are misinformation."

fields.headline: Wounded soldiers to lose pension
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence is to make radical changes to war pensions in an attempt to free wounded servicemen from a dependency culture.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is to make radical changes to war pensions in an attempt to free wounded servicemen from a dependency culture.

Following a year long review, the government has decided to give servicemen and women suffering minor injures a one-off compensation payment, instead of a regular pension. Tariffs are likely to be set for different injuries.

War veteran groups are likely to claim the new scheme, due to be announced next month, will leave them worse off in the long term.

The changes come as the MoD faces a class action by 280 former soldiers who claim they have not been treated properly, or given proper prior warning of the risks of war. They are seeking compensation for post traumatic stress disorder and loss of earnings.

The compensation scheme will replace the current system which is administered by three government departments and left largely unchanged since the first world war.

Soldiers who suffer very serious injury and war widows will continue to receive a pension.

webTitle: Tobacco firm tries to fend off inquiry

fields.headline: Tobacco firm tries to fend off inquiry
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: British American Tobacco has hired two law firms in an attempt to avert court action and a government inquiry into evidence that it exploited smuggling.
fields.body:
British American Tobacco has hired two law firms in an attempt to avert court action and a government inquiry into evidence that it exploited smuggling.

The London-based corporation, the world's second biggest cigarette maker, yesterday disclosed it has taken the steps since internal documents were published detailing how BAT benefited from black marketeering.

City firm Allen & Overy has been asked by BAT to investigate its "current business practice" and US chain Crevath Swaine and Moore to fight any anti-racketeering charges.

The Guardian revealed earlier this year how BAT supplied huge numbers of cigarettes around the world knowing they would end up in the hands of smugglers. BAT fears Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, will use his powers under the companies act to order DTI inspectors to investigate the allegations.

The Commons health committee is planning to call for a DTI inquiry when it publishes a report next month expected to be highly critical of BAT.

The company's board hopes its actions will dissuade Mr Byers as well as preparing a defence against any possible legal action brought in the US.

Martin Broughton, BAT's chairman whose earnings jumped by a third last year to £1.36m, told yesterday's annual general meeting in London: "There is really no need for a DTI investigation."

But anti-smoking campaigners complained the Allen & Overy investigation would look only at the company's current operations. The internal documents published earlier this year showed how a series of euphemisms were used for cigarettes sold to wholesalers that ended up on black markets in South and North America and across Asia.

Clive Bates, director of Action on Smoking and Health, said directors needed to be questioned under oath. "A DTI inquiry is needed to get to the truth of what really went on."

Mr Broughton refused to allow Mr Bates to put specific questions about smuggling from the documents to Keith Dunt, BAT's finance director, at the meeting. Tory ex-chancellor and health secretary Kenneth Clarke, whose earnings as BAT's part-time deputy chairman jumped from £67,820 to £100,000 last year, also defended the company.

webTitle: Briton dies in fire at kibbutz

fields.headline: Briton dies in fire at kibbutz
fields.trailText: A Briton working as a volunteer on a kibbutz in Israel has been burned to death in an underground bomb shelter converted into an internet cafe.
fields.body:
A Briton working as a volunteer on a kibbutz in Israel has been burned to death in an underground bomb shelter converted into an internet cafe.

The Foreign Office confirmed yesterday that the 19-year-old, from Swindon, Wiltshire, was working on a computer when fire broke out on Wednesday.

It is understood the fire was caused by an electrical fault at the Kibbutz Metzer camp in central Israel. The dead man's family are due to travel to Israel. "We understand that the young man had only been at the site for a matter of weeks," a Foreign Office spokeswoman said.

An Israeli fire service spokesman said the man, who has not been named, had been prevented from escaping by smoke.

Each year hundreds of Britons visit Israel to work on kibbutzim - communal living projects - in exchange for living expenses and accommodation.

fields.headline: Freudian slip destroys art
fields.trailText: Two porters at Sotheby's auction house in central London were being blamed last night for the destruction of a painting by Lucian Freud, considered one of the most collectable of modern British artists.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, Arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Two porters at Sotheby's auction house in central London were being blamed last night for the destruction of a painting by Lucian Freud, considered one of the most collectable of modern British artists.

The picture, which was inside its wooden travelling packaging in a store room at Sotheby's Bond Street head quarters, was consigned to a crusher by workers who thought it was an empty crate. The contents have since probably found their way to a council tip or incinerator.

This is a further embarrassment for one of the world's leading auction houses, which has been going through a rocky period with a US Justice Department inquiry over allegations of commission fixing and several senior resignations.

A Sotheby's statement which claimed that the painting, a small early oil study of plants, was worth £100,000 raised eyebrows. Freud, now in his 70s, has become one of the most instantly recognisable and collectable of all living British artists, and many of his most startling prices have been achieved through Sotheby's sales. The record price was £3.5m for a large oil painting of an interior, paid in 1998 by a private collector at a Sotheby's auction in New York.

"I think most people interested in Freud would regard £100,000 as a bit of a snip," David Barrie, director of the independent art charity, the National Art Collections Fund, said. The NACF has helped several British public collections to acquire Freuds, including the Tate, with grants to match the huge prices offered by private buyers.

Collectors covet most the pitilessly bleak nude studies and his portraits, such as The Artist's Mother - one of 1,000 images which he made of his mother Lucie in the last decade of her life - sold for £2m last year.

However Edward King, director of the Abbot Hall gallery in Kendal, Cumbria, which mounted a major Freud retrospective, said: "Collectors really want anything he did - even very small early sketches are cherished as rarities."

The accident happened before Easter, when the painting had been delivered from the owner's home to the auction house store room in central London. It was securely packed in a wooden travelling crate, which was apparently placed in the wrong part of the store and mixed up with the piles of used packaging which are crushed before being taken away as rubbish.

Sotheby's denied reports that the porters involved were sacked immediately. "That is not correct, but this is an internal matter and we are not commenting any further," a spokesman said.

The picture,which is believed to date from the 1960s and to have been about two feet square, was owned by a private collector, and was to be auctioned at Sotheby's contemporary art sale in June. Experts from Sotheby's had given the picture an initial appraisal at his home, but it would have been studied in more detail and photographed for the catalogue at the auction house premises.

The company spokesman blamed "human error" and described the incident as "most unfortunate".

It was no surprise that there was no reaction yesterday from the notably reserved artist himself. His very aloofness swells his status: supermodel Naomi Campbell recently put him top of the list of people she wanted to meet in London "because he's so cool", and Jerry Hall posed nude for him while pregnant with her latest child.

However Mr King, who came to know him well while working on the Abbot Hall exhibition, said his reaction might be surprising.

"He might be terribly upset, but he might well think it hilarious; he might roar laughing," he said. "He is intensely engaged with his paintings while he is making them, and when they are shown in public he takes a very hands-on part in deciding where and how they should be hung. But once they are sold, he once told me, he feels they have moved out of his life.

"He is not one of those artists who regards everything he has ever painted almost as his children."

The artist had no direct financial interest in this sale, but could well have benefited if the painting had sold again in the next few years.

His lawyer, Diana Rawstrom, of the London firm of Goodman Derrick, studied reports of the incident yesterday. A spokesman for the firm said: "Mr Freud never comments on newspaper stories."

webTitle: Cancer may cause Giuliani to quit race

fields.headline: Cancer may cause Giuliani to quit race
fields.trailText: The most glamorous election in the US in decades could be over almost before it starts. Hillary Clinton's opponent in the race for one of New York's two seats in the US Senate revealed yesterday that he has prostate cancer.
fields.body:
The most glamorous election in the US in decades could be over almost before it starts. Hillary Clinton's opponent in the race for one of New York's two seats in the US Senate revealed yesterday that he has prostate cancer.

The mayor of New York, Rudy Giuliani, a national political celebrity, said that he would spend the next few weeks working out whether he could continue his senate bid.

"I hope I'll be able to run," said Mr Giuliani, 55. "Same answer to the senate race as to the course of treatment - I don't know. I'll figure out whether it makes sense to run this year or doesn't it, or whatever. In fairness to me, the senate race, the Republican party, all the parties and everyone else, you need some time to think about it."

In his seven years as mayor he has made as many enemies as friends through his robust approach to cutting crime and cleaning up New York. However, he has won two mayoral elections in a city where his party's members are outnumbered five to one by Democrats.

He had tests just over two weeks ago and a biopsy on Wednesday that proved positive. Prostate cancer is the second-highest killer of men in the US: more than 180,000 are expected to be diagnosed and nearly 32,000 to die of it this year alone.

Five years after diagnosis, 89% of sufferers are still alive and 63% survive for ten years. Mr Giuliani, whose father also had the disease and died at 73, said that his own cancer had been caught early and was treatable. "My physical health is terrific, other than this problem. Would I take time off from the job or running? Yeah, probably. Some forms of treatment would require taking some time off," he added.

Even the mayor's closest advisers were unaware of his condition until two hours before his announcement.

Only the night before George W Bush, the Republican candidate for president in November's election, said: "Come January, Vice-President Al Gore will have one last official duty - to swear in Senator Rudy Giuliani of New York."

Should the brash former prosecutor be forced to withdraw from the senate election, the Republicans' most likely replacement would be Rick Lazio, an amiable congressman from Long Island who had flirted with contesting the party's nomination until he was warned to back off.

Mr Lazio would change the whole nature of the election. The prospect of a contest between the president's wife and one of the Republican party's biggest stars had intrigued all of America. Mr Lazio vs Mrs Clinton is a much less high-powered contest.

Despite the contrasts in their manner, Mr Lazio is actually more conservative than the mayor, whose disregard for etiquette sometimes masks the fact that he and Mrs Clinton are united on many issues, such as tighter gun control and a liberal stance on gay and abortion rights.

They part company on taxes, education vouchers and how best to enforce law and order. Mr Giuliani takes every opportunity to remind people that New York is now the US's safest large city. But the methods employed, including routine shaking down of black and Hispanic citizens, have alienated ethnic communities.

Mrs Clinton says that officers need more and better training and that the city should not have to choose between lower crime and good police-community relations.

Recently Mrs Clinton has edged ahead in the polls for the first time in months after another unarmed black man was shot dead by the police. But with seven months to go before the senate race, Mr Giuliani had plenty of time to recover his position.

The mayor's approval ratings had also plunged 14 months ago when four officers shot dead a 23-year-old black street-trader, mistaking his wallet for a gun. Mr Giuliani was back in the lead by the summer, however.

Mrs Clinton said yesterday: "Like all New Yorkers, my prayers and best wishes are with Mr Giuliani."

In classic Giuliani style, the mayor littered his announcement with jokes and said that he would be taking advice from Joe Torre, manager of the New York Yankees baseball team, who suffered prostate cancer last year.

Then he got back to business as usual - defending the New York police department.

fields.headline: Anger over medicinal drug raids
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Lancashire police have been criticised for the heavy-handed treatment of a great-grandmother with severe arthritis who smokes cannabis to ease her pain.
fields.body:
Lancashire police have been criticised for the heavy-handed treatment of a great-grandmother with severe arthritis who smokes cannabis to ease her pain.

Jean Jackson, who runs an antiques shop in Lancaster, has been raided six times in the past six months since she began taking cannabis.

Police broke into her home last week after an anonymous tip-off.

Ms Jackson has given the police a key to her business to prevent them causing further damage to her shop door.

She said: "I used to take between 16 and 20 painkillers and now I only take three or four at night. I suffered more side effects from the painkiller than I do from the cannabis."

She said it was ridiculous that the police forced their way into her home. "There were about eight or 10 of them and they went right through the house with a fine-tooth comb - they even took the sewage pipes apart," she said.

Her partner, Jonathan Bye, 32, who uses the drug to combat the after-effects of a serious road accident, was arrested for possession of cannabis. He was fined £70 by Lancaster magistrates.

Colin Davies, who set up the Medical Marijuana Co-operative, said: "The police have been a bit heavy-handed by turning up in this jack-booted fashion to tread on ill people. It is bizarre the way they pick out people who are ill who are like sitting ducks and they do not actually check whether these people have reasons in the first place."

Chief Superintendent John Thompson, of Lancaster police, said: "A number of officers go to carry out searches of this kind and when searching for drugs, it is common practice to make a rapid entry. Possession of cannabis is an offence and if people are in possession of it they can expect to be prosecuted."

webTitle: 'When a man's got to go, he's got to go - but not quietly'

fields.headline: 'When a man's got to go, he's got to go - but not quietly'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Heseltine, scourge of miners, peace protesters and Lady Thatcher, announced yesterday that he was standing down from the Commons at the next election after 34 years as an MP.
fields.body:
Michael Heseltine, scourge of miners, peace protesters and Lady Thatcher, announced yesterday that he was standing down from the Commons at the next election after 34 years as an MP.

His party leader, William Hague, led the plaudits despite the snub of learning of the former deputy prime minister's decision from an interview on Radio 4's Today programme. Mr Heseltine had told his constituency party officials in Henley, Oxfordshire, but was worried that Mr Hague's office would leak it.

"When a man's got to go, he's got to go," Mr Heseltine told Today, one of his favourite platforms. "I know that I will never serve in another Conservative government and I'm just not that good at sitting around."

A few minutes later on the same programme, Mr Hague paid tribute to an "immensely distinguished politician".

"We have had a disagreement over Europe, but we haven't had many other disagreements. We have had very good personal relations and we have not let the disagreement over one matter create bad relations.

"He is a great character and we will miss him in the House of Commons, where he always makes a big contribution as a serious heavyweight politician."

Mr Heseltine, MP for Henley since February 1974, has been in the Commons since he won Tavistock, in Devon, for the Tories in 1966.

He felt "extraordinarily fortunate" to have been an MP during a period when his party had been in power for so long. But he said: "I'm really a rather very active sort of person and I'm not given to being a sort of backbench guy waiting for the whips' instructions.

"Now at 67 years of age, facing an election, there are things I want to do which are not compatible with just being lobby fodder in the House of Commons.

"It's not fair to my constituents to deceive them by pretending that I'm doing a full-time job for them when I'm not."

He will devote more time to the Haymarket publishing group, the company he founded and chairs, which, according to the Sunday Times rich list, helped to make him the 28th richest person in Britain with a fortune estimated at £230m.

His potentially explosive autobiography is out in September and he also has plans to write a book about a subject he is "a bit manic about" - the arboretum at Thenford House, his home near Banbury.

He promised to continue to speak out on Europe, the "overarching debate of our time" on which he has been openly at loggerheads with Mr Hague. "Me, be quiet? That has never been part of the plan."

His friend, the former chancellor Kenneth Clarke, who is standing for parliament again, hailed "one of the great political figures of the last two decades" and told the Guardian: "His enthusiasm for the Conservative party and for the European cause remains quite undiminished and I am sure that he has no intention whatever of becoming silent on political issues. I will continue to regard him as a close political ally."

But Labour said Mr Heseltine's departure was indicative of the Tories "lurch to the right". Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, claimed he was "one of a number of moderate Conservatives who will be replaced by increasingly extreme Tory candidates."

Mr Heseltine may not have the inclination or the influence to ensure the selection of a pro-European for his rock-solid Tory constituency. In 1997, he had a majority of 11,167 over the Lib Dems.

His constituency chairman, Howard Green, said: "Michael has served his people, his party and his country well and has brought great credit to the Henley constituency. We are all grateful for that and wish him well."

webTitle: Alas, Poor Frank, we knew him well

fields.headline: Alas, Poor Frank, we knew him well
fields.standfirst: In the latest of our series profiling the four main contenders we follow Labour's candidate, who will be looking for consolation on polling dayThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: It could only happen to him. At 8am yesterday Frank Dobson's helpers were standing outside Hornchurch station on the easternmost reaches of the District line.
fields.body:
It could only happen to him. At 8am yesterday Frank Dobson's helpers were standing outside Hornchurch station on the easternmost reaches of the District line.

It is one thing being in Hornchurch at eight in the morning if you live in Hornchurch, though - the way things are these days - most commuters apparently leave there by about half past six. It is decidedly inconvenient if, like Mr Dobson, you live in Holborn.

He was running late (signal failure, Mile End area), and there emerged from the station not a portly, bearded politician but a London Underground jobsworth of the sort who, all the mayoral candidates agree, are never around on stations when you need them.

"Have you got a letter of authorisation to leaflet outside the station? You're creating a litter problem. It's a fire hazard on the platform. I've got to ask you to move."

"It's a public right of way," said a Labour voice, rather wanly.

"No, it's not. All this is ours. I'll get the police on to you."

Then Frank appeared. And, alas, before the story could be written to fit the Guardian's exclusive headline (Dobson arrested in Yard swoop), he had disappeared again, back down the line for a similar exercise at East Ham. It was just another small mishap in a campaign which is not a chapter of accidents but the whole book.

Another stinker

Poor Frank. Everyone calls him Poor Frank. In keeping with Tony Blair's policy towards his political friends, he ought by now to be Sir Frank or Lord Dobson. He's just Poor Frank.

But there has been a change. The snappish, defensive Dobson who has become familiar over the past few weeks seems to have disappeared. He has acquired the serenity that comes to those who have finally given up hope. All political careers end in failure. And Frank Dobson now knows when and where that failure is going to come: at the count early next Friday.

There was yet another terrible poll yesterday, showing Ken Livingstone miles ahead, and Mr Dobson had to give the ritual TV interview saying he never took any notice of opinion polls and the only poll that mattered blah-blah-blah. The funny thing was that I think he was telling the truth. So far as I know, he had never even looked at the figures; he just knew it was yet another stinker.

With a few minutes left till the final whistle, he is 5-0 down. Since he watches West Ham, this is a situation with which he is not wholly unfamiliar. He has decided the only thing to do is to try to string a few passes together on the off-chance of scoring a consolation goal. There is no longer any point in getting shirty about it all.

Happy pills

Ask him a question that mentions the name Livingstone, and there is a pause, as though he is counting to 10 before saying anything. Mostly, though, he is rather jolly again.

As we strolled past some flowering cherries, we talked about Garry Sobers and Shakespeare. He laughed loudly and often. If he is clinically depressed, as Mr Livingstone has alleged, then the happy pills have now kicked in nicely. On the tube to East Ham, he could have worked the carriage. But that's a thankless task on a commuter tube. So he sat at one end, wearing a very Frankish expression: arms folded, head lolling back, half-reading the Sun held by the bloke in a jerkin with a death's head motif sitting next to him. He might have been a snooker player who has just gone in-off.

Mr Dobson could have looked up and read the adverts. But luckily I don't think he did. Almost every one had a message for him. There was one of those Underground poems, which began: Lying is an occupation/ Used by all who mean to rise./ Politicians owe their station/But to well-concerted lies. There was an ad for the Natural History Museum: Humpty Dumpty sat on the wall Humpty Dumpty had a great fall. And one for Guernsey: Go south. The Dobson campaign went south weeks ago.

After East Ham, he had to go south, to Eltham. Labour had quite a decent stunt lined up here. Mr Dobson and Jack Straw walked to the polling station with Katrina Walker, 17, who Labour believes is the youngest voter in British elections.

Small mercies

This is because of the new, confusing system that allows some early voting. Katrina will be 18 on Wednesday, the day before the official polling day, so she was allowed to cast her ballot yesterday.

Mr Dobson and Mr Straw shared what was billed as a soapbox meeting. The soapbox has acquired a mythic status in British politics because John Major used one in the 1992 election and then happened to win it. I think (and Mr Dobson agreed) that the one had nothing to do with the other. And this soapbox turned out to be an over-elaborate, very New Labour one: a plushly carpeted platform with a carefully constructed backdrop.

Mr Straw spoke interminably and was heckled something rotten.

Eltham is angry about almost everything, and pretty much convinced that when he saw the asylum-seekers hiding in the backs of lorries at Dover on Wednesday, Mr Straw handed them free bus passes on the spot.

The home secretary probably had better things to do, but the candidate next had to face sitting next to Mr Livingstone once more at yet another of this election's all-party hustings.

Through it all, Mr Dobson maintained his neo-Buddhist in-off pose. He now thanks heaven for small mercies. Like Steve Norris and Susan Kramer, he believes Mr Livingstone is winning, but not by as much as the polls suggest. "A few weeks ago, there were a lot of people shouting Vote for Ken, but it's more or less stopped. For what that's worth."

The implication was that it wasn't worth much, but that he was past caring. He is gaining solace from Shakespeare. He isn't Lear any more. He would like to play Falstaff, and he is doing his best. But really he is now Yorick. Alas, Poor Frank. He does not deserve this.

webTitle: Death of MP splits Ulster Unionists over byelection

fields.headline: Death of MP splits Ulster Unionists over byelection
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Ulster Unionists were at odds last night over a forthcoming parliamentary byelection in south Antrim following the sudden death yesterday of Clifford Forsythe, 70, an opponent of the Good Friday agreement.
fields.body:
Ulster Unionists were at odds last night over a forthcoming parliamentary byelection in south Antrim following the sudden death yesterday of Clifford Forsythe, 70, an opponent of the Good Friday agreement.

David Trimble, the party's leader, will want see one of his south Antrim assembly members, Duncan Shipley-Dalton or Jim Wilson, chosen as candidate. Opponents of the agreement will back either David Burnside, the London-based public relations guru, or John Hunter.

Depending on the choice, the Democratic Unionist Party will consider fielding a candidate against the agreement; it did not stand in 1997, enabling Mr Forsythe to achieve a 16,611 majority.

Mr Forsythe collapsed on Wednesday from a suspected brain haemorrhage, and died in hospital. A quiet and courteous man, he was described as a traditional unionist. He held the rare distinction of playing football for both Linfield, a Protestant club, and Derry City, a nationalist side. He attracted attention from Burnley and Celtic, which has mainly Catholic support. By trade a plumber, he became MP in 1983.

Downing Street announced yesterday that Tony Blair and Bertie Ahern, the Irish prime minister, would meet with Ulster Unionists, Sinn Fein and the SDLP in London on Tuesday.

fields.headline: Pony found strangled on tether
fields.trailText: A woman who bought a pony for her two children was banned from keeping horses for life yesterday after the animal was found strangled by its own tether.
fields.body:
A woman who bought a pony for her two children was banned from keeping horses for life yesterday after the animal was found strangled by its own tether.

Carolyn Charles, of Tremorfa, Cardiff, had kept the grey horse tied to a goalpost overnight on parkland near her home for six weeks before it was found dead by police, the city magistrates court heard.

Prosecutor Geraint Davies, representing the RSPCA Cymru, told the court how a policewoman had seen the horse a couple of times in the weeks before it died and had taught Charles, 40, how to correctly tie a halter.

A month later the same officer found the horse, which had been bought by Charles for £60, strangled by a rope tight around its neck, and still tied to the goalpost.

Trudy McBride, defending, said: "She didn't have the wherewithal to look after [the horse]. There is no suggestion she was deliberately cruel."

Charles, who admitted causing the pony unnecessary suffering, was fined £50, and ordered to pay £250 costs.

webTitle: Divided Labour head for defeat as poll gives Livingstone huge lead

fields.headline: Divided Labour head for defeat as poll gives Livingstone huge lead
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson, Labour's candidate in next week's London mayoral election, is struggling to hold on to third place, according to an opinion poll yesterday. The poll shows the frontrunner, Ken Livingstone, with an apparently unbeatable 34-point lead over Tory Steven Norris.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson, Labour's candidate in next week's London mayoral election, is struggling to hold on to third place, according to an opinion poll yesterday. The poll shows the frontrunner, Ken Livingstone, with an apparently unbeatable 34-point lead over Tory Steven Norris.

The poll findings, which point to a potential humiliation for the former health secretary, were published as differences emerged between Mr Dobson and Labour assembly candidates over Mr Livingstone's manifesto pledge to cut traffic by 15% in 10 years.

Yesterday's ICM poll for the Evening Standard put Mr Livingstone's support at 51% - up a couple of points on a fortnight ago and back where he was in February - with Mr Norris up one at 17%, Mr Dobson down one at 14% and the Liberal Democrat, Susan Kramer, holding steady at 12%.

But, more alarmingly for Tony Blair and the Dobson campaign, it shows Mr Dobson level-pegging with Ms Kramer at 12% when the results are restricted to the two-thirds of respondents who said they were certain or likely to vote next Thursday, with Mr Livingstone at 53%.

Mr Dobson insisted the findings bore no relation to his canvassing returns and that voters would think twice about Mr Livingstone's "hidden taxes". Labour posters claim Mr Livingstone will introduce a monthly congestion charge of £300 to achieve his traffic reduction target of 15% by 2010.

But at least five Labour candidates running in tandem with Mr Dobson for the assembly have signed up to the same target as part of a Friends of the Earth campaign, a spokesman for the environmental group said yesterday.

Labour's candidate for Haringey and Enfield, Nicky Gavron, last month signed a statement in support of introducing congestion charges in the capital by 2003, as part of a plan to tackle the traffic crisis backed by the boroughs .

Jeremy Fraser, Mr Dobson's campaign manager, said: "Assembly candidates may have signed up to the 15% cut, but Frank has a large degree of scepticism about what can be achieved and serious candidates shouldn't sign up to stuff they don't think can be achieved".

A Labour spokesman added that no one was opposed to the "principle of congestion charging or aspirational targets", but that Mr Livingstone had ruled out increasing car parking charges, as proposed by the boroughs, and would have to rely on congestion charges.

That is rejected by Mr Livingstone, whose manifesto promises to consult about a possible charge for "unnecessary car journeys in a small zone of central London" to begin around 2002, as part of a wider package of measures. His spokesman dismissed the £300 figure as preposterous.

Mr Dobson's running mate, Trevor Phillips, will today can vass drivers with leaflets highlighting Labour's claims about Mr Livingstone's 15% traffic reduction target which, a party statement said last night, "would mean the introduction of a zonal congestion charge policy".

webTitle: Jury rules on mooring rope death

fields.headline: Jury rules on mooring rope death
fields.trailText: A sailor in the Royal Fleet Auxiliary, the navy's civilian support wing, died when he was hit by a flying mooring rope, an inquest in Portsmouth heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A sailor in the Royal Fleet Auxiliary, the navy's civilian support wing, died when he was hit by a flying mooring rope, an inquest in Portsmouth heard yesterday.

Paul King, 23, of Plymouth, was killed on the Sea Centurion in Portsmouth navy base in May last year.

An inquest jury returned a verdict of accidental death after hearing that Mr King was flung across the ship and died on board after suffering multiple broken bones in his legs, ribs, jaw and pelvis.

Witnesses said the rope had become tangled in a tug's propeller. Mr King was hit as he tried to stop the flying rope.

A marine accident investigation branch inspector, Captain Paul Kavanagh, said the RFA's unberthing procedures had been changed since the death. Mr King had worked in the ship's engine room and had not helped with unberthing before.

After the inquest, Mr King's mother, Janet, said she had filed a damages claim against the Ministry of Defence.

fields.headline: Phoney medic not breaking law
fields.trailText: Police yesterday said they were powerless to stop a man caught posing as a paramedic at an Easter Monday motorcycle racing meeting.
fields.body:
Police yesterday said they were powerless to stop a man caught posing as a paramedic at an Easter Monday motorcycle racing meeting.

The man was spotted at the Oulton Park race circuit in Cheshire, kitted out in a fluorescent jacket emblazoned with the word "paramedic".

He was riding a motorcycle with "paramedic" displayed on its panniers and fitted with a flashing green and orange beacon.

After being reported by a member of staff from Mersey Regional Ambulance service, the 58-year-old from the Oulton Park area was spoken to by police, but he said he was only handing out donor cards.

Although inquiries are continuing, according to a Cheshire constabulary spokesman police cannot pursue the matter because impersonating a paramedic is not against the law.

Mersey Regional Ambulance spokesman Ray Clayton said members of the public needed to be aware of the problem but should not be alarmed.

"If anyone is in any way unsure, they should ask to see ID which is carried by all our staff," he added.

It emerged that genuine ambulance staff became concerned because the bogus paramedic was riding a motorcycle, and bikes are not employed by the service. When approached, he claimed to be an employee of Mersey Regional Ambulance but then left.

Mr Clayton said he had since heard further reports of a motorbike-riding paramedic in the Birkenhead area of the Wirral, on Merseyside.

The meeting was organised by the Cheshire Autocycle Union. A spokesman for Oulton Park said the man "did not go anywhere near the medical facilities".

webTitle: Cup anthem puts Belles on their toes

fields.headline: Cup anthem puts Belles on their toes
fields.trailText: The musically primitive world of the football chant discovered descants, harmonies and counterpoint yesterday with the launching of Britain's first women's cup final song.
fields.body:
The musically primitive world of the football chant discovered descants, harmonies and counterpoint yesterday with the launching of Britain's first women's cup final song.

Violins, organ and choir accompany 25 sopranos and contraltos in the specially commissioned anthem in D Minor for Doncaster Belles, who take on Croydon Ladies for the FA women's trophy on Monday.

Two "subtle and delicate" duets alternate with a chorus of the club's first team and reserve players, which the composer Mark Morris described as "very powerful when they all pile in".

The song, Northern Pride, also includes a prolonged rap section, working through the names of the players and their achievements.

Mr Morris, 42, a Doncaster club singer, decided that women's voices were the missing ingredient of football anthems.

The song, published on CD yesterday, was composed by Mr Morris in a period of inspiration after the Belles eliminated Arsenal women's team in the semi-final.

fields.headline: Worldwide version of WI nudes
fields.trailText: Members of a Women's Institute group who posed nude for a charity calendar yesterday launched a worldwide version in America.
fields.body:
Members of a Women's Institute group who posed nude for a charity calendar yesterday launched a worldwide version in America.

Eleven women from the Rylstone and District WI in North Yorkshire posed for the British calendar last year, wearing nothing but pearl necklaces, hats and strategically positioned floral displays.

The Alternative WI Calendar attracted massive publicity and has raised more than £330,000 for leukaemia research. The Leukaemia Research Fund received more than 70,000 emails from Americans wanting the calendar after it was featured in the US media.

Earlier this year the women, aged between 45 and 60, agreed a deal with American publishers Workman for publication of a 19-month version. The new calendar will now go on sale in the US, Canada, South Africa, New Zealand, Australia, and across Europe. It will be available in Britain in about two weeks.

The money raised from the new version will be split between leukaemia charities in the US and Britain.

Four of the WI members launched the calendar in New York and were due to fly to Los Angeles to carry out more interviews.

The 11 women who took part were inspired to produce the calendar after the death from cancer of John Baker, husband of Angela Baker, one of the members.

webTitle: US kidnap victim dead in swamp

fields.headline: US kidnap victim dead in swamp
fields.trailText: A Briton who was kidnapped by his girlfriend's jealous ex-lover in America has been found murdered in a swamp.
fields.body:
A Briton who was kidnapped by his girlfriend's jealous ex-lover in America has been found murdered in a swamp.

Paul Gale's body was discovered in a marshy area in New Jersey known as Devil's Hill, 10 days after he was lured from his hotel room in Florence, Kentucky, by Greg Marcinski, who was posing as an FBI agent.

Marcinski had driven 800 miles from his home in New Jersey in his grandmother's Buick to confront his rival at the Holiday Inn in Florence on April 17.

He claimed to be Special Agent Trimble, showed Mr Gale, 28, a fake FBI badge, and then frisked and handcuffed him before bundling him into the car.

The abduction was witnessed by staff at the hotel, who thought Marcinski was a genuine FBI agent.

Mr Gale's family, who live in Erdington, Birmingham, have been devastated by the murder. Elsie and Jeff Gale learned of their son's death in a phone call from another son, Mark, who had flown to the US to search for Paul.

They were being treated by their family doctor for shock yesterday.

Jeff Gale said yesterday: "Our worst fears have been confirmed. The family is devastated. We are now waiting for more details about Paul's death from the US."

Paul's twin brother, Peter, sister Rita and brother Mark had all flown to America earlier in the week to help in the search.

Elsie Gale had made a plea to the kidnapper to tell her what he had done to her son.

Paul's sister Julie said: "We have had some information that they have found Paul dead. He was found in New Jersey in a swamp. But that's all we know because of the time difference. We are all inconsolable."

Marcinski, 23, claims that the two men drove around for several hours and that Mr Gale was alive when he dropped him off near Cincinnati airport. It emerged that his mobile phone had been used in Ohio two hours after the kidnap.

The alarm was raised the following day when Mr Gale failed to keep work appointments and the FBI had no record of him being arrested.

Marcinski was tracked down after FBI investigators traced calls he had made to Mr Gale's computer firm asking for personal information about him.

Mr Gale's body was found less than a mile from Marcinski's home in Brick, New Jersey. Police wearing waders discovered the body in an area of muddy marshland known as Devil's Hill.

Marcinski admitted to police that he was angry after learning that his girlfriend, Darla Guidie, had formed a month-long relationship with Mr Gale, a computer consultant for a firm in New Jersey.

Ms Guidie had reportedly severed relations with Marcinski because she felt intimidated by him. She told investigators that Marcinski once showed her how he could make a fake FBI badge on his computer.

fields.headline: Keeping the colonial ties alive
fields.standfirst: Privilege and politics for the capital's economic eliteZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Privilege and politics for the capital's economic elite
fields.body:
At the Harare club there is plenty of wealth but no money. Cash, according to the mores of this exclusive establishment in Zimbabwe's capital, does not exchange hands between gentlemen. If you want a gin and tonic in the early evening or beef roulade for lunch, you sign for it and it goes on your bill.

This is the watering hole of Rhodesia's old political elite - who happen to remain Zimbabwe's economic elite too - a patriarchal bolthole that has done all it can to stay frozen in time, steeped in nostalgia.

The former head of Rhodesia, Ian Smith, is a regular. Yesterday, in the reading room, the president of the commercial farmers' union, which represents white farmers, addressed a crowd of around 100. On the walls are sketches of lords and colonels, stills of the original Salisbury club back in 1893 and a framed copy of the last bar tab before history caught up with it and it was forced to change its name.

White Zimbabweans take their colonial ties seriously. Many were born here and may have never been to Britain. But the few who don't have familial ties still have some kind of emotional attachment to the old country. You can see them on the ironed lawns of the bowling greens in Harare gardens, near Park Lane. You can see their influence in much of the architecture and some of the place names, like Queen Victoria museum. In the Miekles hotel, the English tea platter is served with jam and scones on three tiers of silver.

Their ties may not now be as strong as those of Mary Turner, the principal character in Doris Lessing's award-winning novel, The Grass is Singing. For her "the word 'home' spoken nostalgically, meant England, although both her parents were South Africans and had never been to England." But whether it is sport, religion or the arts, to them England remains the centre around which this post-colonial metropole revolves.

They are understandably, and rightly, keen to assert their Zimbabwean roots and heritage. But when violence flares many have also shown themselves equally keen to head for the British high commission to ensure that their papers are in order in case they must flee.

It is this colonial connection which lies at the heart of the issue of land reform. When a troop of mostly British settlers arrived here in 1890 they stuck their flag on a hill near a Harare and, ironically, called it Occupation Day. Now the black population want some of it back - a wish which President Mugabe is attempting to cynically exploit by encouraging his supporters to launch "occupations" of their own.

Back at the Harare club, lunch, for one group of white businessmen, is running long and the wine is flowing freely. The colour bar has long gone here and some influential black businessmen have joined. To become a member you must first be interviewed by all the members of the selection committee individually; to remain a patron you must remember the rules - no mobile phones, no business is to be conducted, women are allowed but only in the guests' dining room.

But the clientele remains overwhelmingly white. There are more elephants (75,000) than whites (70,000) in Zimbabwe, but you could not tell that from an afternoon at the Harare club, where all the waiters are black.

The club has always prided itself on being the home of the liberal wing of the white establishment. One cabinet minister had his membership revoked for being rude to the servants. Nonetheless, this community, which makes up less than 1% of the population still employs 65% of the nation's workers. Thanks to their land, they dominate the tobacco and cattle sectors from which they have made a lot of money; but you will not see them use it at the Harare club.

fields.headline: While Donald's away...
fields.standfirst:
The Scots will learn more about coalition

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Devolved government within the United Kingdom is a work in progress. All judgments are interim. All events, even such accidents as the discovery of Donald Dewar's heart problem, have the potential to teach both the citizens of Wales and Scotland and the rest of us something about the range and staying power of the new governing institutions.
fields.body:
Devolved government within the United Kingdom is a work in progress. All judgments are interim. All events, even such accidents as the discovery of Donald Dewar's heart problem, have the potential to teach both the citizens of Wales and Scotland and the rest of us something about the range and staying power of the new governing institutions.

At this early stage in its life the Scottish executive deserves some plaudits. Labour and the Liberal Democrats have forged a civilised partnership. Over student fees they made a workable compromise from which Westminster could learn. But the carping audible in Edinburgh has also been justified. Sir David Steel, presiding officer of the parliament, has taken upon himself responsibility for the cost overruns and delays in housing it in a new building, but he shares the charge with Donald Dewar's cabinet, which has been secretive in the worst traditions of London government.

Now the executive faces an unwonted test. Mr Dewar will have to undergo major surgery which will keep him out of the loop for months - and if his party and political friends have any regard for his health they will make sure he is indeed kept out while recuperating.

The first minister's mantle passes to Jim Wallace while Labour's leadership is taken by Henry McLeish. They have complementary political talents and this episode ought to provide good evidence of the longer-run durability of the coalition. As well as we wish Donald Dewar, he is inevitably a transitional figure. His political generation made devolution an imperative for the Blair government. It will be up to their successors to make the parliament as a governing institution.

Mr Dewar bequeaths one issue which has not been well handled - the capture of Clause 28 by Perthshire moralists in the shape of the Souter family. Brian of that ilk is organising a private plebiscite. Here is an opportunity for the Scottish cabinet to speak, as it is not yet done, with self-confident belief in their country's modernisation, for its emancipation from Knox and kailyard bigotry.

That will require Messrs McLeish and Wallace to forget their partisan obligations and muster their forces. Mr Dewar's (temporary) disappearance creates space for the epigones to get out there and campaign. The media, critical to date, likes a scrap. The executive has a chance to show its appetite - for reshaping Scotland as only legitimate national leaders can.

webTitle: 38 injured as Channel ferry hits dock

fields.headline: 38 injured as Channel ferry hits dock
fields.trailText: A cross-channel ferry hit a dock at Calais yesterday, injuring 38 people.
fields.body:
A cross-channel ferry hit a dock at Calais yesterday, injuring 38 people.

It was reported that passengers on the P&O Stena Line vessel, the Aquitaine, from Dover, were thrown over by the force of the collision with a concrete berth. A Stena spokeswoman confirmed that 38 people had minor injuries, including at least one member of staff, with one casualty suffering a broken arm.

"The investigation into the incident is continuing and the damage to the boat is still being assessed.

"All other services are continuing as normal."

The 8.15am sailing from Dover was carrying 1,241 passengers and 123 crew. The 28,838 tonne Aquitaine is P&O's largest ferry on the route and came into service last November.

Passenger John Duncombe, 41, a solicitor from Essex, said everyone had been standing ready to get off the ferry as they approached berth seven at Calais.

"The first thing I thought of was the boat sinking. There was a big thump, the lights went off and the engine went quiet. I saw someone fly about 10ft across the corridor.

"After realising my wife was okay I looked around and could see people lying on the floor hurt and screaming."

Mr Duncombe said he saw around 15 people carried off the boat on stretchers.

About a dozen ambulances and a helicopter were parked on the quayside next to the ferry. He said the ship's captain requested over the boat's intercom for any doctors and nurses to come forward.

Gerard Barron, head of communications at the Port of Calais, said a number of cars and lorries on board were damaged in the collision.

Around 15 people had been taken to hospital in the town.

Mr Barron said the ferry got into difficulties as it tried to dock at Calais.

"It seemed that the boat was unable to reverse its propeller to stop and crashed into the quay."
