webTitle: Information gap leads to illegal sentences

fields.headline: Information gap leads to illegal sentences
fields.standfirst: Watchdogs predict a flood of court challenges
fields.trailText: Judges are passing illegal sentences and prisoners are unlawfully held in jail because crucial information is not being passed between courts and prisons, the six chief inspectors who oversee the criminal justice system say today.
fields.body:
Judges are passing illegal sentences and prisoners are unlawfully held in jail because crucial information is not being passed between courts and prisons, the six chief inspectors who oversee the criminal justice system say today.

A joint report from the six inspectorates, covering prisons, police, crown prosecution service, probation, social services and magistrates courts, points to widespread communication failings which could lead to a flood of court challenges when the Human Rights Act comes into force next October.

The report, the first to survey the whole of the criminal justice system, says there are significant gaps in provision of information between agencies "which could compromise the achievement of the government's aims for the criminal justice system."

It says lack of information leads judges to impose illegal sentences on offenders who are released from prison on licence but commit further offences and are sent back to jail.

"Some judges prefer to specify the sentence length in days and, not having the information regarding the previous time spent in prison to hand, they estimate the sentence length.

"In many cases the sentences are illegal because they are too long."

The inspectors complain that courts are under no obligation to notify prisons when charges are dropped.

One prison is being sued by a former inmate because staff wrongly calculated the time he had to serve.

They failed to deduct days associated with a charge they were not told had been dropped.

"It was only when the prisoner mentioned that he thought he had been in prison too long - in fact 27 days too long - that his file was looked at more carefully."

Inspectors were "concerned" to find that prisons are not told when defendants brought to court in custody are released by the court on bail.

The prison has to rely on the prisoner escort report from the private contractor which takes inmates to court, with a note explaining why the prisoner was released.

"Without written documentation from the court, there is a risk that prisoners might be released in error.

"With no official confirmation of release, there is also a potential for collusion in escapes."

One busy prison which sent 60 or more inmates to court each day filled in the prisoner escort report form, which specifies whether the inmate is a risk for escape or violence, a few days in advance.

The practice contributed to an escape when a prisoner's escape risk assessment changed between completion of the form and departure for court.

Confiscation orders - court orders requiring offenders such as drug dealers to pay a sum of money or serve further time in jail - "sometimes simply disappear into the multitude of paperwork in prison files".

In one case, a drug dealer who had been ordered to pay £135,000 or serve an extra two years, was let out early even though none of the money was paid.

The order was missed by the two prisons where he was an inmate. He had to be rearrested to complete his sentence.

The report says: "Inspectors have the most serious concerns about the multiplicity and incompleteness of court warrants which give the prison service the legal authority to hold prisoners in custody.

"Not only does the prison need to know the legal status of prisoners (in order to accommodate them appropriately) but also further details of the sentence, and time spent in police custody, in order to calculate correctly the period to be served.

"The current system relies on prison staff in custody offices being prepared to pursue courts for the information, which is not always willingly given."

The inspectors criticise magistrates courts for delays in telling police about the outcomes of cases.

"These delays can cause serious problems for the police and victims: offenders may be disqualified from driving with the police being unaware; offenders may be released on conditional bail and police be unaware.

"In consequence, victims of crime may also be unaware that an offender has been released and may be caused alarm or distress by being confronted by their attacker."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Gangster death fuels gunfight
One policeman was killed and at least one other injured yesterday as gunfights exploded in Kingston, Jamaica, over the death of alleged gang leader, Sylvester Wint.
fields.body:
Gangster death fuels gunfight
One policeman was killed and at least one other injured yesterday as gunfights exploded in Kingston, Jamaica, over the death of alleged gang leader, Sylvester Wint.

Police who wanted to question him about an earlier shooting said Wint held up a baby as a shield and opened fire on them, but residents say police fired first and that Wint dropped the baby before he was shot.
AP, Kingston

Habash to bow out of PFLP
Radical Palestinian guerrilla leader George Habash plans to resign from the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a PFLP spokesman said yesterday.

Mr Habash, 73, has led the PFLP since he established it in 1968. PFLP sources said the group's deputy leader, Abu Ali Mustafa, was his most probable successor.
Reuters, Damascus

Burma arrests 40 activists
Burmese authorities arrested more than 40 youth members of the opposition National League for Democracy this month, party leader Aung San Suu Kyi said. In a videotaped interview smuggled out of Burma, Ms Suu Kyi said the detainees were involved in meetings on reorganising the NLD's youth wing. "This is a demonstration of the fact that this regime is not getting any better at all," Suu Kyi said. "The leopard certainly has not changed its spots."
AP Bangkok

More Iranian papers shut
Iran's hardline judiciary yesterday banned two more pro-reform newspapers, including a leading daily published by the brother of President Mohammed Khatami, the official news agency IRNA said.

The bans on the two largest reform papers follow the closure without trial earlier this week of more than a dozen pro-reform dailies and journals.
Reuters, Tehran

fields.headline: Hezza bows out
fields.standfirst:
He was a star. There are not many left

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Perhaps because cartoonists used to portray him as Tarzan in leopardskin, the phrase big beast of the jungle always suited Michael Heseltine, who yesterday announced his impending departure from the House of Commons.
fields.body:
Perhaps because cartoonists used to portray him as Tarzan in leopardskin, the phrase big beast of the jungle always suited Michael Heseltine, who yesterday announced his impending departure from the House of Commons.

He had style. His mane and his physical size marked him out in the political crowd. His performance skills wowed the blue-rinsed brigade at Tory conferences, but also the council tenants of Knowsley after the urban disturbances of 1981. Liverpool was a fine hour, not just for his policy innovations, but for the way a senior minister put himself squarely in the front line, eggs and all.

We can argue still about his urban development corporations, but the reason why both neutral civil servants and broadminded social democrats warmed to him was his Heathite conviction that when it came to the pinch, collective action could achieve great things. "It took a riot" - consigned to Thatcher's bottom drawer - remains a rare state paper written with passion.

He departs the scene a grandee. The advent of plebeian/classless William Hague banishes to a far past all that internecine Tory stuff about having to buy your own furniture. The toffs are still around, but the party belongs to them no more than to that liberal, Bow Group, corporatist, boardroom-minded, pro-European grouping personified by Heseltine, Kenneth Clarke and Ted Heath. Their failure to breed a successor generation is a large one.

Like an actor, Heseltine will be remembered for his great scenes: the episode with the mace in his bovver-boy youth, the walk out from Downing Street during the Westland affair, his stalking of Margaret Thatcher, the onset of illness in Venice. Politicians divide into the majority who, though competent public servants, fail to lodge in the public imagination, and the small number who achieve stardom. Democracy needs both. But public affection for representative government desperately needs the latter. He will be missed.

Like an actor, Heseltine will be remembered for his great scenes: the episode with the mace in his bovver-boy youth, the walk out from Downing Street during the Westland affair, his stalking of Margaret Thatcher, the onset of illness in Venice. Politicians divide into the majority who, though competent public servants, fail to lodge in the public imagination, and the small number who achieve stardom. Democracy needs both. But public affection for representative government desperately needs the latter. He will be missed.

webTitle: Republicans to block Clinton's arms initiatives

fields.headline: Republicans to block Clinton's arms initiatives
fields.trailText: The US Congress will refuse to ratify any arms agreement that is made between the United States and Russia for the remainder of the Clinton administration's term, senior Republican leaders have made clear.
fields.body:
The US Congress will refuse to ratify any arms agreement that is made between the United States and Russia for the remainder of the Clinton administration's term, senior Republican leaders have made clear.

"This administration's time for grand treaty initiatives is at an end," the Republican chairman of the Senate foreign relations committee, Senator Jesse Helms, said in a speech in Washington.

Mr Helms said he wanted to play no part in any "final photo op" for the administration.

His threat, which is seen as a real one, could affect any US-Russian agreement to amend the 1972 Anti-Ballistic-Missile (ABM) treaty to allow the development of missile defence systems, as well as any agreement on Start 3 arms cuts.

The pledge creates a major complication for President Clinton and his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, as they prepare for a US-Russian summit in Moscow in early June, at which Washington is hoping to secure Russian agreement to a limited US missile-defence system in return for another round of missile cuts.

US negotiators who met the Russian Foreign Minister, Igor Ivanov, in Washington for two days of talks this week believe that Moscow is willing to continue discussing the missile-defence issue and it has not ruled out the possibility of an agreement to amend the ABM treaty.

Meanwhile, the Republican presidential candidate, George W Bush, made it clear to the Russian government this week that a Republican administration would not feel bound by a limited agreement on missile defence signed with the Clinton administration.

Mr Bush would reserve the right to proceed to a much more extensive missile-defence programme than any that is currently under discussion in Washington.

Mr Bush also met Mr Ivanov in Washington on Tuesday at the Russian foreign minister's request.

It was the first high-level, face-to-face meeting between the Russian government and Mr Bush, who was accompanied in the talks by his senior foreign policy adviser Condoleezza Rice and his defence adviser Paul Wolfowitz.

The Republican presidential hopeful told the Russians that, if Russia would not amend the ABM treaty to allow the US to develop a missile-defence programme, a Bush administration would back out of the treaty.

"It's time to move to a new world, and the ABM treaty is a product of a different world," Ms Rice said in a speech in Washington yesterday.

The Republicans' readiness to turn the screw on the missile-defence issue at this time reflects their fear that Mr Clinton aims to make a more limited agreement with the Putin government over the issue in June.

At present, subject to the success of a still incomplete test programme, the US intends to establish what it describes as a "limited" national missile-defence system, which would have around a hundred interceptor missiles based in Alaska to destroy a small number of incoming warheads fired at the US by "rogue states" such as North Korea, Iraq or Iran.

Mr Clinton has said he will make a final decision on whether to deploy the system later this year, following the completion of the test programme.

A third test firing is due to take place in June, and governments around the world are assuming that the only uncertainty is when, rather than whether, Washington will decide to deploy the system.

Mr Helms and other Republican hawks want the missile-defence system to be much larger.

They favour including space-based interceptors in the programme as well as sea- or land-based anti-missile missiles designed to intercept hostile missiles during the "booster" stage of their launch, in order that the fall-out debris would fall over the missile's country of origin.

Many Republicans also wish to be able to extend the missile-defence shield to some of the US's allies, especially to Taiwan.

fields.headline: David Marks
fields.trailText: Status: Much lauded architect, along with his partner Julia Barfield, of the millennium wheel.
fields.body:
Status: Much lauded architect, along with his partner Julia Barfield, of the millennium wheel.

State: In a spin, going round in circles, wheely wheely annoyed.

Why, pray tell? Because the unique experience of seeing the city from a moving pod 443ft up might not stay unique for very long.

Don't tell me they're building another one beside it? The London Eye becomes the London Spectacles? Mercifully, no. But we might well see a Prague Eye. Or an Orlando Eye. Hell, why not an Ouagadougou Eye.

Sounds painful. Indeed - and particularly painful for Marks and Barfield. A company called World Wheel Group wants to build bootleg copies of the London wheel around the world, first in Prague and then - quelle surprise! - in Disney World.

But I thought the architects held the copyright? So did they. Marks and Barfield have already stymied an attempt by Disney to build an exact copy of their design. But it's all to do with specifications: diameter dimensions, pod quantities, rim distances, that sort of thing.

Sorry, dozed off there. You were saying? The WWG thinks by tinkering with the design it can get round the London wheel's copyright.

And can they? Marks thinks not: "Let them try." Which is exactly what WWG are going to do.

But surely one can't copyright a wheel? If you could, there would be one very rich caveman out there. George Washington Gale Ferris Jnr might agree. But then his first Ferris wheel, built for an exhibition in Chicago in 1893, was an attempt to copy the success of the Eiffel Tower four years earlier. So he might well think all's fair in love and large metropolitan landmarks.

Doesn't Marks take it as a compliment? Well he has spoken of "the natural human desire to want to view the earth from high places". What he's less keen on is the natural human desire to rip off any good idea that makes money.

Do say: "Nice to see London leading the world again in civic design."

Don't say: "Look, Marge, you can see Space Mountain from up here!"

webTitle: No miracles promised by hostage negotiator

fields.headline: No miracles promised by hostage negotiator
fields.trailText: A former Muslim rebel chief who is negotiating for the freedom of 21 hostages held by Islamic gunmen in the southern Philippines warned of tough bargaining ahead, saying the kidnappers would cling to the captives "tooth and nail".
fields.body:
A former Muslim rebel chief who is negotiating for the freedom of 21 hostages held by Islamic gunmen in the southern Philippines warned of tough bargaining ahead, saying the kidnappers would cling to the captives "tooth and nail".

The Philippine military said it was ready to swing into action yesterday to rescue the hostages, who were abducted on Sunday from a Malaysian diving resort on Sipadan island, from separate hideouts on Jolo island in the Sulu sea, 600 miles south of Manila.

The hostages, who have been split up to thwart a rescue attempt, comprise 10 Malaysians, three Germans, two French, two South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese and a Filipina.

The muslim regional governor and head negotiator, Nur Misuari, said two emissaries sent to the gunmen's stronghold had contacted the armed group and had seen most of the hostages, who were safe and well. "It will take a lot of persuasion... that's why I am not promising a miracle at all," Mr Misuari said. "We should be prepared for any eventuality."

The hostages are being held at a stronghold of the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas, who demanded Filipino reporters witness any negotiations and that the government curb all fishing in waters around the area.

 Reuters

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: BAE buys Lockheed unit
fields.body:
BAE buys Lockheed unit

BAE Systems has bought Lockheed Martin Control Systems for £323m to help it stay in the race to supply technologies for the next generation of aircraft.

Control Systems designs and makes digital fly-by-wire controls and engine systems for military and civil aircraft. BAE already operates in those areas but on a smaller scale.

Control Systems' business is predominately US-based, and the company has provided equipment for a range of planes including the F-18 fighter and the A-10 tankbuster.

Its technology should help BAE win contracts for the next generation of aircraft - including successors to the Eurofighter and the latest Airbus.

Last year, Control Systems - which also makes space launch vehicle control systems and vehicle power drives - earned a profit before tax and interest of $42m (£26.6m) on sales of $359m.

A BAE spokesman said: "The addition of the Control Systems' business will broaden BAE Systems' backbone control technology... and improve the group's engineering base, heightening its core competencies in the design and production of leading edge control systems."

Abbey claims a first

Abbey National sold 12% of all new mortgages in the first three months of the year, twice the amount of a year ago, it said yesterday.

At its annual general meeting, the bank also claimed it would be first in the world to offer interactive services on both the internet and digital television when it launches on Open, the digital station in June. Next month, it intends to roll out its e-banking service for retail customers and set a target for 1m customers in 12 months.

Doubts over C&W deal

Pacific Century CyberWorks' takeover of Cable & Wireless HK looked wobbly yesterday after reports that Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and Singapore Telecom were poised with a counter-bid.

A collapse in the share price of PCCW has made the all-share deal look cheap. News Corp committed $1bn (£625m) to Singapore Telecom's original bid which analysts said could play an important part in any counter-offer.

Bloomsbury profits up 66%

The popularity of boy wizard Harry Potter has helped increase profits at Bloomsbury Publishing by 66%. Sales rose 37% to £20.9m in 1999, while pre-tax profit climbed to £2.6m due to the success of the Harry Potter series and the Encarta World English Dictionary, a joint venture with Microsoft.

"The future trading prospects for Bloomsbury are excellent," said chief executive Nigel Newton. "The increased profile of the company on the back of its successes in the book division is attracting more talented new and established authors than ever."

fields.headline: No windfall for the public
fields.trailText: The Treasury yesterday fended off demands for higher public spending and insisted the £22.5bn windfall from the mobile phone auction would be used to pay off government debt.
fields.body:
The Treasury yesterday fended off demands for higher public spending and insisted the £22.5bn windfall from the mobile phone auction would be used to pay off government debt.

Amid calls from former defence minister Peter Kilfoyle for the cash to be used to rescue manufacturing from the ravages of the strong pound, the Treasury issued a statement saying: "The cash proceeds of the auction will be used to reduce government net debt and therefore debt interest costs, not for tax cuts or higher public spending."

Like everyone else, the Treasury has been staggered by the sum raised by the auction. Its original estimate was £3bn.

There is nothing to stop the chancellor using the proceeds to fund schools and hospitals but he has already been criticised by the International Monetary Fund and others about the alleged laxity of his recent Budget, in which the NHS was allocated an extra £35bn over the next five years.

Critics said that by injecting large sums of money into the economy at a time when it is already growing strongly risks higher interest rates.

Net government debt amounts to about £340bn, generating interest payments of £27.8bn in 2000/2001.

Economists say paying off debt is prudent but Vincent Cable, Liberal Democrat spokesman for trade and industry, said Mr Brown could purchase overseas government securities in an attempt to drive down sterling's value against the euro.

Mr Kilfoyle says the cash should be used to fund a New Deal for industry. The Liverpool Walton MP, who resigned as defence minister earlier this year warning that Labour was neglecting its core voters, argues in the New Statesman that Britain should follow the example of the German government in propping up its eastern region, and use some of the £22bn to support the industrial heartlands.

Calling for the money to be used to finance a "manufacturing renaissance", he writes: "Surely any modern government sees this strategic need for core manufacturing industries like car production, ship building and engineering. We cannot all work in the service and financial sectors."

He says such spending would also fit with the government's professed assault on unemployment and low skills.

fields.headline: Europe rethinks strategy
fields.trailText: The outcome of Britain's auction of third generation mobile phone licences has set alarm bells ringing across Europe. A number of countries are already planning how to allocate their own licences as expectations about the amount of money that might be raised soar in the light of the British experience.
fields.body:
The outcome of Britain's auction of third generation mobile phone licences has set alarm bells ringing across Europe. A number of countries are already planning how to allocate their own licences as expectations about the amount of money that might be raised soar in the light of the British experience.

One government likely to find itself uncomfortably in the spotlight is France. France has opted for a beauty contest rather than an auction.

Companies wanting a licence will have to submit a bid which will consist of an upfront payment coupled with a strategy designed to show how much money the company plans to invest and the economic benefits that will accrue. There are plans, too, for the government to charge a levy on revenues.

Though that would ensure a steady income stream it will not realise the billions raised in Britain. As one observer said: "The UK government got a lot of money. It may be that the French government is starting to feel a little uncomfortable because people may start asking why France has not raised as much money - which could have been spent on new schools or new hospitals."

Little wonder that Italy, which was going for the beauty contest approach, has rethought. In Germany, the exact number of licences on offer has not yet been decided though it is expected to be between four and six. But Germany is going for a UK-style auction and expectations about the cash to be raised are roaring ahead - with anything from DM50bn (£16bn) to DM100bn being talked about.

Expectations are being influenced by the perception that it is not a question of how much companies can afford, rather that they cannot afford to miss out.

webTitle: Now that the dust has settled, it is time to deliver

fields.headline: Now that the dust has settled, it is time to deliver
fields.trailText: The bidding has stopped. Now the race is on to deliver the first video-quality G3 phones - with permanent internet access - to the market place. The stakes are high because this could be one of the biggest market opportunities of all time.
fields.body:
The bidding has stopped. Now the race is on to deliver the first video-quality G3 phones - with permanent internet access - to the market place. The stakes are high because this could be one of the biggest market opportunities of all time.

It marries the two fastest growing technologies in town - mobile phones and worldwide web access. No big players can bear the prospect of being excluded. That is why the manoeuvres are not yet over.

NTL Mobile - a joint venture between France Telecom and Britain's NTL - may re-emerge as a bidder for Orange. Orange won the E licence but the company has to be divested by Vodafone (the winner of the B licence) on competition grounds. But there will be plenty of other suitors too, some of them more attractive to Orange than France Telecom.

Other winners may re-auction part of the spectrum they have won but don't need in order to defray the cost of the auction which works out at £1,000 per household even before the costs of building a wireless infrastructure around the country have been factored in.

In theory, as the Consumers' Association reminded us yesterday, this could turn out to be a back door tax on using new technology leading to higher prices. But in practice the fact that there are five firms in competition with each other could force prices down despite the huge capital investment expended.

It will be interesting to see what happens in France (and Finland and Spain) where licences are being virtually given away after a so-called "beauty parade" of applicants. France's has not been announced but no one will be surprised if the most prized spectrum goes to France Telecom. But then what?

If it works according to the textbooks, spectrum given away (apart from licence fees) could lead to much cheaper G3 phones in France and therefore much wider coverage particularly among poorer people because network operators will have more money to subsidise handsets. But if textbook competition doesn't work the big telephone companies may start wallowing in monopoly profits.

Vodafone, as the biggest mobile phone company in the world, will be delighted to get the biggest of the unrestricted licences, while BT can reassure itself that it does not need so much spectrum because of its vast land-based infrastructure and it will take quiet satisfaction from forcing its mobile rival Vodafone into paying nearly £2bn more for the B licence.

fields.headline: WPP confirms merger talks
fields.standfirst: Hostile bid for US rival thought unlikely
fields.trailText: WPP, the advertising group, yesterday confirmed weeks of merger speculation by admitting it was negotiating a possible "agreement" with its American rival, Young & Rubicam.
fields.body:
WPP, the advertising group, yesterday confirmed weeks of merger speculation by admitting it was negotiating a possible "agreement" with its American rival, Young & Rubicam.

A combination of the two companies would create the world's largest advertising corporation, with revenues of up to £3.2bn.

However, hopes of a deal slipped almost immediately, amid rumours that Young & Rubicam was exploring at least one other opportunity.

There were suggestions in the market that the American group was in negotiations with another bidder, French advertising agency Publicis.

Industry sources also said Young & Rubicam was considering a strategic deal with Andersen Consulting under which the two companies would give each other access to their client bases.

WPP's shares ended the day down 48p to 973p, valuing the company at £7.5bn.

WPP's chief executive, Sir Martin Sorrell, is keen on adding a third advertising agency to the group's existing arms, Ogilvy & Mather and J Walter Thompson.

He is thought to be keen on Young & Rubicam's strength in Asia - which would complement WPP's geographical spread - and on the US group's range of marketing and public relations brands.

Despite this analysts believe he is unlikely to launch a hostile bid. Alex de Groote, of CCF Charterhouse, said: "Sorrell's very shrewd - he's not going to overpay.

"They don't need to do a deal but if a competitor buys Young & Rubicam it would change the competitive environment."

Negotiations between the two companies faltered last month when it emerged that the US group's directors were entitled to payoffs of up to $60m in the event of a change of ownership.

WPP is understood to have made a fresh offer last week, including a proposal which would mitigate the cost of these "golden parachutes".

fields.headline: Exporters facing total shut-out
fields.standfirst: Worsening trade position prompts fresh warning over sterling
fields.trailText: Exporters face being squeezed out of overseas markets completely by sterling's strength, economists warned yesterday, as new figures showed Britain's global trade position worsening. Although the deficit on trade in goods narrowed slightly in February to £2.41bn from £2.75bn the previous month, analysts said the improvement masked an underlying deterioration.
fields.body:
Exporters face being squeezed out of overseas markets completely by sterling's strength, economists warned yesterday, as new figures showed Britain's global trade position worsening. Although the deficit on trade in goods narrowed slightly in February to £2.41bn from £2.75bn the previous month, analysts said the improvement masked an underlying deterioration.

The shortfall on trade in goods widened to £5.1bn in the three months to February, nearly £2bn higher than the deficit over the previous three months, according to figures published yesterday by the Office for National Statistics.

While manufacturers are struggling with the pound's strength, consumers are also becoming increasingly gloomy about the economy, according to separate data from the European Commission, which showed confidence at a 15 month low.

While ONS statisticians said the trend in the trade deficit is worsening, economists warned that Britain's global trading gap would not be closed while the pound stood at its current level.

"We know that the trade situation is bad and getting worse, and it is hard to see the situation improving with sterling as strong as it is," said Neil Parker, UK economist with the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Exporters are cutting their prices to offset the pound's surge against other world currencies, but analysts fear the reductions are not enough to keep British goods competitive in world markets. "The sterling price of exports to EU countries has fallen by 3.8% over the last year while the pound-euro exchange rate has appreciated by 12%," said Dharshini David from HSBC markets. "This points to a further deterioration of exports to these countries and exporters possibly being squeezed out of markets altogether."

Exports to Europe have been hardest hit, reflecting sterling's movement against the single currency. Export volumes have fallen 1.6% over the past three months, while import volumes have risen by 0.3%.

The only bright spot in yesterday's figures was the resilience of Britain's trade in services which ran a £1bn surplus for the second month in a row, pegging back the overall trade shortfall to £1.4bn.

Analysts warned that more up-to-date figures for March, available only for trade with non-EU countries, showed few signs of improvement. Although the headline deficit narrowed to £1.5bn from £1.8bn the previous month, it was entirely due to an improvement in trade in oil and erratic items.

"Excluding those, the balance widened from £1.4bn to £1.5bn," said Michael Dicks, of Lehman Brothers. "It would be wrong to suggest sterling's strength can be ignored - as we have repeatedly warned."

The chancellor's budget failed to reassure consumer confidence, either, which has been on the slide for the last four months, according to research carried out by market surveyors GfK on behalf of the European Commission.

fields.headline: Big fee, big disclaimer
fields.standfirst: I don't run Barclays, says Sir Anthony
fields.trailText: Silence of the Lambs and Barclays television advertisement star Sir Anthony Hopkins says he is just an actor and not a villain.
fields.body:
Silence of the Lambs and Barclays television advertisement star Sir Anthony Hopkins says he is just an actor and not a villain.

The Hollywood star was criticised after his appear ance in the Barclays commercial with the slogan "A Big World Needs a Big Bank" coincided with the announcement that the bank was this month closing 171 branches across England and Wales. Welsh assembly member for Neath, Gwenda Thomas, wrote to the Welsh-born actor as part of her campaign against the closures.

But she revealed yesterday that Sir Anthony had replied to her in a hand-written letter, saying that he feels he had been "made the villain of the piece".

"I just have to set the record straight by saying that I do not run Barclays Bank. So if I happen to be the chosen villain of the piece, so be it." The actor, who has taken US citizenship, also pointed out that the ad was made last June.

fields.headline: Standard Chartered snaps up Grindlays
fields.trailText: Standard Chartered yesterday pulled off the biggest acquisition in its history by buying Grindlays, once the banker to Britain's civil servants.
fields.body:
Standard Chartered yesterday pulled off the biggest acquisition in its history by buying Grindlays, once the banker to Britain's civil servants.

Through the £848m acquisition from Australia and New Zealand Bank (ANZ), Standard Chartered will become the biggest international bank in India, Pakistan and Bangladesh and the second largest in the UAE and Sri Lanka.

Shares in Standard Chartered, which is paying for the bank in cash, rose 3% to 865.5p when the deal was confirmed yesterday.

The transaction, which temporarily united John MacFarlane, the ANZ chief executive, with his former employer, will allow the combined bank to make annual cost savings of £70m and is expected to involve job cuts, particularly in India where most of Grindlay's customers are based.

To achieve the cost savings, Standard Chartered warned it would incur a bill of £101m in aggregate over the first three years of integration.

While Standard Chartered already has extensive operations in the Middle East and southern Asia, the bank does not intend to eradicate the Grindlays name yet.

Rana Talwar, chief executive of Standard Chartered, said the acquisition was in line with the bank's drive to become the world's biggest in the emerging markets and hinted that further acquisitions might be on the cards.

It comes after recent deals for Standard Chartered, including buying the international trade finance business of UBS and Nakornthon Bank in Thailand.

"We will continue to pursue opportunities to develop our unique franchise," Mr Talwar said.

He noted that the acquisition of Grindlays would give Standard Chartered increased access to India at a time when its middle class, obvious customers for bank accounts, was growing rapidly. "It will position us to take advantage as the region, with its rapidly growing middle class, opens up to e-commerce and new banking products," Mr Talwar said.

By selling Grindlays, which has had a colourful ownership - being bought by ANZ from Citigroup in the 1980s - ANZ is able to extract itself from the risk of emerging markets which it has cited for holding back its shares in Australia.

ANZ is expected to use its proceeds from the sale, which includes £475m of goodwill, to buy back its shares in what it believes will be one of the largest ever single transactions of its kind in Australia.

webTitle: Euro's slide could turn to rout

fields.headline: Euro's slide could turn to rout
fields.standfirst: Uncertainty - a desirable quality
fields.trailText: The European Central Bank was between a rock and hard place yesterday. With the euro hovering barely above its recent lows, whichever of the three available options it chose would have been likely to send the single currency staggering to fresh depths.
fields.body:
The European Central Bank was between a rock and hard place yesterday. With the euro hovering barely above its recent lows, whichever of the three available options it chose would have been likely to send the single currency staggering to fresh depths.

If the bank had chosen to leave European interest rates on hold - as at least some politicians wanted - that would simply have postponed the inevitable. The financial markets had already pencilled in another increase in rates and would have been disappointed - that is, they would have sold the euro - if the central bank had not delivered.

In the event, the bank opted to give the markets what they expected - a quarter-point rise. But with the increase already discounted there was no up side to the decision.

Unfortunately for the ECB the strength of data from the US economy, which make it ever more likely that the Federal Reserve will raise American interest rates next month, turned no up side into significant down side.

The third option - to raise rates by more than the market expected - was the most problematic but may come to be seen to have been the best.

The big risk was that if the ECB had surprised the financial markets it would have been seen to have acted out of panic. The markets may have concluded that the bank had suddenly decided that inflationary pressures were stronger than it previously judged. Hardly the sort of thing to boost a central bank's credibility.

But although there would have been a significant risk attached to a higher than expected rate rise, there was also an up side lacking with the other two options. Taking the markets by surprise might have prompted an initial fall in the euro, but as inflation numbers came in which did not support the "panic move" theory the markets would have been forced to reappraise their view of the ECB's strategy. A little uncertainty is a handy thing.

But would the ECB have been justified in taking a risk as opposed to pursuing the predicted course - which, although it may have seen the euro weaken a little more, has hardly brought the roof down. The answer is "yes".

Yesterday's slide may rank as "another day at the office" for the single currency but slide could yet turn to rout. There are some chunky holders of the single currency out there who have been hanging on in the hope of improvement. Unless the ECB manages to pull off a trick or two soon they may decide to cut their losses and quit.

Gilts conundrum

Mr Micawber was famously eloquent on the relative merits of income outstripping or undershooting expenditure. But then he did not have a bond market to run. The government's determination to use the £22.5bn proceeds from the mobile phone licence auction to repay debt represents a headache for the gilts market and the debt management office.

The market exists to trade government debt. The less the government needs to borrow, the less stock there is to trade. The market was already concerned that, given the healthy state of the nation's finances, the government would have a hard time issuing enough gilts to satisfy the market's appetite. Now it faces the prospect of even shorter commons.

Lack of supply, exacerbated by regulations which require pension funds to hold long dated gilts, was distorting the yield curve before the auction turned into such a blockbuster cash raiser. The authorities had already shown considerable ingenuity to be able to stick to the promise of issuing £12.2bn worth of gilts this year. The proceeds of the auction must put that under threat.

There are some uncertainties about when the cash will come in. The successful bidders have the option of paying all the cash up front or spreading half the payment over a number of years, although the interest rates charged on the outstanding amounts looks distinctly unattractive.

But the fact is that very large sums of money will be flowing into the government's coffers, and the Treasury and debt management office need to work out how to deal with it.

They could use some of the money to pay off the government's overdraft at the Bank of England, but the Bank would then want to use the cash to buy other quality assets - that is, gilts. They could recycle some cash to the sterling money markets, which is likely to be the source of some of the funding for the licences. They could increase purchases of foreign currency bonds. Finally they could retire some short term debt and replace that by longer term paper, for which demand is highest.

But whichever combination is chosen - and the debt management office is indicating it will have the answer within weeks - it is unlikely to provide a complete solution. The betting has to be that at least one of this year's gilt auctions will have to be cancelled - not the news the market wanted to hear.

fields.headline: Gordon's big bonanza
fields.standfirst:
There are plenty eager to spend it

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Before even considering what should be done about it, just wallow in the wonderment of it all. This government, formed by a party never famed in the past for its luck with the economy, is to pocket a windfall gain of £22.5bn as a result of the auction of radio spectrum for the next generation of all-singing, all-dancing mobile phones.
fields.body:
Before even considering what should be done about it, just wallow in the wonderment of it all. This government, formed by a party never famed in the past for its luck with the economy, is to pocket a windfall gain of £22.5bn as a result of the auction of radio spectrum for the next generation of all-singing, all-dancing mobile phones.

The Treasury expected £3bn at most, but has ended up with £22.5bn: the biggest windfall on record (twice the peak annual income from North Sea oil), the biggest privatisation, the biggest auction and the biggest practically everything else. It is equivalent to £1,000 for every household or a reduction in income tax of 11p for a year. And it comes on top of a budget surplus of up to £15bn, even before the mobile nuggets are counted.

And what does Lucky Gordon plan to spend it on? Nothing, absolutely nothing. This is the element that will understandably perplex the average voter. This could turn into a major political issue for Labour at a time when there is widespread dissatisfaction with the dreadful state of our railways and when, for all the generosity of the last budget, there are still huge needs for spending on hospitals and schools.

The Treasury argues that the transaction is economically neutral because the bidding companies will become more indebted and the government less indebted, thereby making no difference to a fiscal stance that is already regarded as too loose by the International Monetary Fund and by much City opinion. In this scenario Gordon Brown is pictured as someone imprisoned in Fort Knox with riches he is unable to spend. But the voter in the street will, understandably, see it differently - as a tax on companies, the proceeds from which now belong to us all, and part of which should be spent on improving social infrastructure. Interestingly, Italy, having watched the British experience closely, is about to raise by over 10 times the estimate of what it expects to get from its own licence awards. The windfall gains there will be poured into economic and education projects to stimulate technological progress.

The government regards the cheap issue of the previous round of licences as one of the reasons Vodafone has become so rich. It does not see it as the government's job to bankroll national champions. Some other European countries like France, Finland and Spain, are giving the licences away almost for nothing. It will be fascinating to see whether the result will be excess corporate profits or, as is argued in Finland, a much speedier and cheaper take up of the new phones that will consolidate its world lead in the use and manufacture of mobile phones.

Meanwhile, Gordon Brown should urgently find ways of spending part of the windfall gain on projects with the least inflationary consequences. Why is more spending by a private sector led consortium on the London Underground regarded as beneficial, yet extra public money on the same project is deemed inflationary? Surely the inflationary consequences of rejuvenating problem schools in regions of high unemployment or refurbishing the railways are minimal, especially if the spending is spread over a number of years.

Mr Brown would be envied by Stanley Baldwin, who when a Treasury minister dipped into his own pocket to augment the public finances. Brown is an innovative chancellor well-skilled in micro- as well as macroeconomics. He should start now to find innovative ways to spend some of this money. He might otherwise find the heartlands - and not just the Labour-occupied ones - very unforgiving.

fields.headline: Share options
fields.trailText: Companies that dish out share options to staff like so much confetti were reminded yesterday of the threats from the main accounting regulator to make them pay now rather than later.
fields.body:
Companies that dish out share options to staff like so much confetti were reminded yesterday of the threats from the main accounting regulator to make them pay now rather than later.

The Accounting Standards Board (ASB) issued a notice detailing how the tax on share options, in the form of national insurance contributions, should be dealt with in the profit and loss account.

Gordon Brown's decision to tax non-accredited share option schemes in the first place has already brought its own backlash. Employers pay the tax and dot.com companies believe it will act like a ball and chain as they attempt to compete with US hi-tech outfits unencumbered by similar rules.

The accounting rules that accompany the tax will make company chiefs even more unhappy. Government rules state that national insurance will be applied to the difference between the allocation price of an option and its redemption price. So for tax purposes, each year of the options life, the issuing company must calculate its liability.

Dot.com companies, the ASB believes, will be tempted to take an arbitrary share price that increases their liability in the first years of the option's life. If they can front load the cost of share options it will only add to their already inflated up-front costs, which everyone expects dot.com companies to incur.

In the later years the cost of the options will be minimal just when they hope to show some profit. The regulator has been on a mission to end all forms of creative accounting ever since the late 1980s when the likes of Robert Maxwell ran rings round the regulators.

To that end, the cost of option schemes will be determined by the price of the shares at the year end and the tax will be calculated on that basis, whatever the effect on fledgling dot.coms Harsh? Maybe. But the ASB believes it is the shareholders who count and they need to see their company's current liabilities and not an obscure set of figures gently massaged by the board.

The Accounting Standards Board (ASB) issued a notice detailing how the tax on share options, in the form of national insurance contributions, should be dealt with in the profit and loss account. Gordon Brown's decision to tax non-accredited share option schemes in the first place has already brought its own backlash. Employers pay the tax and dot.com companies believe it will act like a ball and chain as they attempt to compete with US hi-tech outfits unencumbered by similar rules. The accounting rules that accompany the tax will make company chiefs even more unhappy. Government rules state that national insurance will be applied to the difference between the allocation price of an option and its redemption price. So for tax purposes, each year of the options life, the issuing company must calculate its liability. Dot.com companies, the ASB believes, will be tempted to take an arbitrary share price that increases their liability in the first years of the option's life. If they can front load the cost of share options it will only add to their already inflated up-front costs, which everyone expects dot.com companies to incur. In the later years the cost of the options will be minimal just when they hope to show some profit. The regulator has been on a mission to end all forms of creative accounting ever since the late 1980s when the likes of Robert Maxwell ran rings round the regulators. To that end, the cost of option schemes will be determined by the price of the shares at the year end and the tax will be calculated on that basis, whatever the effect on fledgling dot.coms Harsh? Maybe. But the ASB believes it is the shareholders who count and they need to see their company's current liabilities and not an obscure set of figures gently massaged by the board.

webTitle: Prozac no relief for Bioglan depression

fields.headline: Prozac no relief for Bioglan depression
fields.trailText: Unhappy Britons have been able to buy cheaper pick-me-up pills since January, when the popular antidepressant Prozac lost its UK patent protection.
fields.body:
Unhappy Britons have been able to buy cheaper pick-me-up pills since January, when the popular antidepressant Prozac lost its UK patent protection.

A glut of companies leapt into the market with cut-price versions of the drug. Leading the way was Hertfordshire-based Bioglan Pharma, which got its version of Prozac into pharmacies within 24 hours of the liberalisation.

That produced a pleasing blip in Bioglan's annual sales, even though the company's financial year ended just two weeks later. However, the company came in for some flak in the City yesterday, when its full results were made public.

As well as selling generic drugs, Bioglan specialises in developing dermatology treatments - for problems such as acne, psoriasis and eczema. The company's pre-tax profits doubled to £7m but this included licensing income of £9m from a US group, Winston Laboratories. This was under the terms of a deal in December, when Bioglan raised £24m from shareholders to buy 19% of Winston.

It emerged yesterday that without the Winston transaction, Bioglan would have made a loss because of a largely unexplained slump in European sales of its skin drugs during the second half of the year.

John Savin, an analyst at Greig Middleton, said: "My suspicion is that they were having a major slowdown and the Winston deal was an opportunity to rescue profits."

Bioglan's shares, which have been riding high for most of the year, slumped 71p to 587p on the news. Chief executive Terry Sadler has responded to recent events by stepping up research and development spending - he has increased this year's budget from £6.7m to £10.6m. This means profits will suffer in the short-term but it should pay off with new products further ahead.

Bioglan is working on drug discovery technology - its expertise is in taking medicines which are difficult to dissolve and altering their chemical make-up to get them into creams. Using this technique, the group has been able to make easy-to-apply versions of many widely used skin treatments.

In the past, Bioglan has been a notable success story. Mr Sadler bought the business in 1984 for £176,000, raising part of the money by borrowing £30,000 on three gold credit cards. The group's market value is now £550m and Mr Sadler's 40% stake is worth nearly £200m.

Bioglan's house broker, HSBC Securities, believe profits will recover to £9m this year. But just a couple of months ago, Bioglan's shares were changing hands for more than 900p. It will take more than a few pills to push the price that high again.

webTitle: Unigate takeover nears as Dairy Crest raises offer to £235m

fields.headline: Unigate takeover nears as Dairy Crest raises offer to £235m
fields.trailText: A merged dairy foods group, bringing together Unigate and rival Dairy Crest, seemed certain last night after an improved £235m offer appeared to shut out an alternative bid from Scottish milk group Robert Wiseman. Should this prove the end of the auction, Unigate shareholders will end up £33m better off than they would otherwise have been.
fields.body:
A merged dairy foods group, bringing together Unigate and rival Dairy Crest, seemed certain last night after an improved £235m offer appeared to shut out an alternative bid from Scottish milk group Robert Wiseman. Should this prove the end of the auction, Unigate shareholders will end up £33m better off than they would otherwise have been.

Dairy Crest's original £202m agreed merger with Unigate was upset last week when Wiseman entered a surprise £225m counter-bid. Hours later, Dairy Crest was back with £235m. Unigate, which had urged shareholders to accept the first Dairy Crest bid, advised them to take no action and await developments. But last night it once more recommended acceptance of Dairy Crest's offer.

Wiseman, a bulk supplier of milk in Scotland run by brothers Alan and Robert Wiseman, said it was considering its response. Under the terms, Unigate can accept a higher offer if one emerges, but would need to pay Dairy Crest a "break fee" of £2.35 million.

Dairy Crest's range includes Country Life butter and Clover spread. Unigate has St Ivel, Shape and Vitalite. Should the deal go ahead, it will create a group that is number one or two in every sector of the British dairy business.

Wiseman has claimed its own plans would save jobs. The company said: "Both Unigate and Dairy Crest are strong in the south and their merger is based on cost savings, which means job cuts and closures. Wiseman, on the other hand, is strong in the north. It is a perfect geographical fit."

webTitle: Beijing retracts its war threat against Taiwan

fields.headline: Beijing retracts its war threat against Taiwan
fields.standfirst: Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: China threatened war against Taiwan yesterday - but then promptly insisted it had not meant to do so.
fields.body:
China threatened war against Taiwan yesterday - but then promptly insisted it had not meant to do so.

A bellicose dispatch from the state-run Xinhua news agency stepped up the pressure on the island by predicting armed conflict if Taiwan's president-elect, Chen Shui-bian, refused to accept Beijing's cherished one-China position, which he has already rejected. It quoted a senior mainland envoy, Tang Shubei, as warning at a Shenzhen forum to rally opposition to Taiwan's independence that, in the event of such a refusal, "the result will not be peace but war, not harmony but confrontation, not goodwill but enmity".

The sabre-rattling came amid rising tension across the Taiwan strait, with reports of a build-up of Chinese fighter planes and ground troops as well as signs of unusual naval activity. Taipei's ministry of national defence said it expected Beijing to stage war games in the run-up to the presidential inauguration on May 20.

But Mr Chen yesterday sought to play down the threat, insisting that Chinese military drills were common at this time of year. "We should not scare ourselves," he told a crowd of supporters. "When history is watching us, when the whole world is watching us, we must have confidence, love and hope. And we won't have any fear."

The threats and tension seemed unlikely to lead to war last night after Xinhua took the almost unprecedented step of claiming it had made a mistake; apparently, its initial report used the wrong phrase - Mr Tang had actually threatened "disaster" rather than "war", it said.

"It was a slip of the pen by the reporter," insisted an editor at the agency's Beijing headquarters.

However, there was no attempt to qualify or deny the other threats the agency re ported Mr Tang as uttering, which included a warning that China was ready to shed "lives and blood" in order to force Taiwan into line.

Yesterday's confusion about just what was being threatened highlighted the uncertainty in Chinese policy towards the island since last month's election of a pro-independence president.

Although Mr Chen has softened his separatist policies, his deputy, the vice-president-elect Annette Lu, has openly taunted Beijing by insisting that Taiwan had "independent sovereignty", prompting China to denounce her as "the scum of the nation".

Although most observers expect tensions to increase in coming weeks, Beijing has not yet given up on Mr Chen. Alongside the bellicose rhetoric, Mr Tang yesterday also dangled an olive branch. He said that talks could be conducted between Beijing and Taipei on the basis of "equal status" and the island might even be allowed a greater presence on the world stage. This would answer a common complaint by Taiwan, which is not allowed to join most international bodies and has lost diplomatic ties with much of the world due to strenuous pressure from Beijing.

But he made clear that the precondition for such concessions was Mr Chen's acceptance of the one-China principle. The president-elect has flatly rejected holding discussions on that basis. It is a move which would split his Democratic Progressive party, where pro-independence sentiment remains strong.

Most military analysts believe China's armed forces are still several years away from being strong enough to mount a successful invasion of Taiwan. But they already possess the capability to mount a naval blockade that would economically cripple the island. And amid the increasing signs of tension, few are prepared to discount such a possibility.

fields.headline: Cheap land for absent 'farmers'
fields.standfirst: Poor lose out as old farms go to people with connectionsZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Poor lose out as old farms go to people with connections
fields.body:
The majority of state-owned commercial farms leased out under Zimbabwe's land resettlement programme in the last three years have been given to well-connected individuals, most of whom are absentee landlords with no farming experience, according to a list obtained by the Guardian. Many of the new owners have been given leases for 98 years at advantageous prices, while others have yet to have their lease rates assessed.

The list was obtained in a parliamentary written answer in January by the opposition MP, Margaret Dongo, but it has received scant attention in the Zimbabwean press. It also includes land rented out under the tenant farm scheme since 1990. Only a handful of these, which range from very large farms to smallholdings, have been given to genuine farmers.

Mrs Dongo, the president of the Zimbabwe Union of Democrats and a founder member of the War Veterans' Association, has been trying to give the list a wider circulation with a message accusing the ruling Zanu-PF of "corruption and mismanagement".

She added: "I appeal to my fellow war veterans not to let your suffering be used by selfish and greedy politicians who caused your suffering. This will not benefit you at the end of the day. Comrades, you should stand up and be a watchdog of the government. If you do not, you will have fought for nothing."

The nine commercial farms, totalling about 500,000 acres, were voluntarily offered for sale by their owners in 1998 and divided into 253 separate units.

Among the leaseholders and tenants are a cabinet minister, two provincial governors, numerous civil servants, two judges, four members of the president's office and employees of large private and state corporations.

The Battlefields farm, for example, in the cotton-farming area of Kadoma south of Harare, has been divided into 27 parcels, some as large as 4,800 acres. Not one is occupied by its owner. Twenty four of the absentee lessees have no agricultural experience. Although they were given out at the beginning of last year, no lease rates have been assessed.

Of the 50 parcels from the Coburn farm, only nine are occupied by farmers; 22 lessees have no farming experience.

One provincial governor is paying under £1,000 a year for 2,800 acres.

Another governor whose five-year tenancy on 2,400 acres expires this September has still to have his rental assessed. The defence permanent secretary rented 780 acres during the 1990s for just over £1 a year.

These farms were supposed to be part of the government's ambitious scheme to resettle 150,000 families by 2003.

But after a donor conference in September 1998, when 24 countries refused to come up with the required financial support, the plan was scaled down to the resettlement of 77,000 families by 2001.

But the slow pace of reaching that more modest target has been caused by the government only providing about 15% of its planned contribution, according to Sam Moyo, who led the official land reform technical team. He said earlier this year that support from donors had only been enough to provide start-up money for the trial phase.

Zimbabwe's 4,500 white farmers own about 11m hectacres of prime land, about 30% of the total land mass, while 6m black Zimbabweans are crowded into barren communal areas representing some 41%.

fields.headline: French claim gene therapy breakthrough
fields.standfirst: Gene patenting: special report
fields.trailText: French scientists claim today to have successfully delivered "gene therapy" to two infants condemned to a life sealed off from all others.
fields.body:
French scientists claim today to have successfully delivered "gene therapy" to two infants condemned to a life sealed off from all others.

The babies, aged 8 and 11 months, were born with a rare condition called human severe combined immunodeficiency (Scid) XI. Such children are forced to live in a sterile "bubble" - because they have no immune systems and would be unable to resist any infection - while waiting for a bone marrow transplant.

Alain Fischer of the hospital Necker in Paris reports in the US journal Science that he and a colleague delivered a normal copy of the defective gene that caused Scid XI which proliferated in the patient's body. The new gene "unblocked" the development of the other immune cells, restoring the immune system to normal functioning.

The two children have so far been normal for 11 months, with no side effects. A third patient is doing well after similar treatment four months ago, according to the report.

There are around 4,000 diseases caused by defects in single genes. Scientists began dreaming almost a decade ago of treating illnesses such as cystic fibrosis by replacing genes. But the treatments proved difficult and success has been elusive. Some diseases were far more difficult to treat than researchers had imagined. The cystic fibrosis experiments were disappointing. There was alarm in the US this year at deaths in what may prove to be improperly conducted gene therapy trials. The Paris experiment is one of the first of this kind of treatment to succeed.

Dr Fischer and colleagues took bone marrow from the children, and filtered out blood stem cells. They bathed them in a growth factor and then infected the cells with a retrovirus which carried a good copy of the gene. They then put the infected cells back into the babies without giving any drug treatment at all.

The children now have immune cell counts similar to those of normal children. Both now live at home, without treatment, and are developing normally.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Food Court | The Inn At Lydda
fields.body:
The creation of the Food Standards Agency to inspect everything destined for our tables is the latest topic for John Humphrys and his Food Court (1.30pm, Radio 4). After the Ministry of Agriculture's record on E.coli and BSE, the new body can hardly do worse. But its remit runs from abattoir hygiene to the safety of genetically modified crops: can its relatively small staff really police them all? Professor Hugh Pennington, who investigated the Scottish food poisoning epidemic, is among those taking part.

John Wolfson's play The Inn At Lydda (9.0pm, Radio 4) is built around a brief reference in the New Testament Apocrypha. The first-century writer speculated about a meeting between Tiberius Caesar and Jesus. No such meeting ever happened, of course, and the very concept vanished into the mists of history. Wolfson argues, however, that the idea was well worth pursuing because the principles underpinning the potential dialogue remain relevant 2,000 years on.

fields.headline: Heart of darkness
fields.standfirst: In reconstructing the court case of Holocaust-denier David Irving, Channel 4 faced a dilemma. The inclusion of archive images of Nazi atrocities was vital, but how much horror can an audience be expected to take? By  Vikram Dodd
fields.trailText: In reconstructing the court case of Holocaust-denier David Irving, Channel 4 faced a dilemma. The inclusion of archive images of Nazi atrocities was vital, but how much horror can an audience be expected to take? By Vikram Dodd
fields.body:
This Saturday evening, Channel 4 is doing something rare in British television. It's taking a risk, and in prime time too. Saturday night is traditionally when television channels roll out their biggest entertainment guns to try and win one of the most hotly contested time slots in the schedules.

Channel 4 has cleared 90 minutes for a programme about the Holocaust, one of the darkest episodes in human history.

The peg for The Holocaust on Trial is the libel case brought by the Third Reich author David Irving, which ended just over a fortnight ago in his humiliating defeat. Irving sued the American academic Deborah Lipstadt and publisher Penguin Books Ltd over a book that branded him a Holocaust denier. The judge decided they were right and in his judgment excoriated Irving as an anti-Semite and bogus historian.

The scope of the programme is a rarity in television. It examines the evolution of the Holocaust, starting with Kristallnacht, mass shootings and the Final Solution which saw Hitler's murderous campaign intensified with gas chambers - industrialised mass murder to exterminate more Jews more rapidly.

The prime-time slot was chosen very consciously, according to Tim Kirby, commissioning editor for History at Channel 4: "In view of the high level of public interest in the Irving libel trial, we want The Holocaust on Trial to be seen by as wide an audience as possible - including younger viewers."

The programme is not purely a dramatic reconstruction of the trial, it is a hybrid, with extracts from the court case woven in with interviews with historians, archive footage and modern-day footage of death camps like Auschwitz.

The aim was to put issues raised in the trial into a broader context. "We felt that if you weren't able to step out of the court and provide the background, you'd be getting a narrow view of the subject," says Kirby.

For the courtroom scenes, Irving is played by John Castle. He had the task of representing on screen the bombastic performance of Irving as he denied the systematic genocide by the Nazis in the face of a mountain of evidence.

Writer/director Leslie Woodhead says: "We recreated the exact geography of the courtroom, the same colour of the furniture and how the players related to each other physically."

However, the dramatisation fails to accurately recreate the atmosphere in court. And, to be fair, it could never hope to. The proceedings were often turgid and dragged out. Richard Rampton QC (barrister for the defendants) and Irving engaged in convoluted arguments that revolved around semantics, involving German vocabulary and grammar. Castle also falls short of capturing the sheer ridiculousness of Irving, who represented himself during the trial.

Irving's denials of key parts of the Holocaust are used by Woodhead as a bridge to present the evidence that exposed the author as a fraud. "From the very inception onwards, the intention was to set what was going on in the courtroom in the wider context of the phenomenon of Holocaust denial, and a re-examination of the nuts and bolts of the Final Solution in the light of current scholarly knowledge."

If the challenge in the reconstruction was distilling thousands of pages of transcripts into short sections that remained comprehensible, choosing which footage of the death camps to air presented profound problems.

As Tim Kirby explains: "You're pulled two ways. The visual archive material is horrific and shocking; on the other hand you mustn't censor it - you'd be denying it, in a way doing what Irving does."

He believes the programme achieves the right balance, and avoids using archive images in the way that some other documentaries do. "I see Holocaust images being used as wallpaper, detaching the images from the reality of the event. It's important that the archive is used sensitively and accurately."

Woodhead chose to leave out shocking footage such as the dissection of babies. "In the end, the job is to represent what took place rather than paddle in it, exploit it in a disgusting fashion. We don't embark on a 90-minute film trying to get everyone to turn off, that would be a self-defeating exercise.

"You can't make a programme about the Holocaust without conveying some of the awful reality that took place, otherwise that's a meaningless sanitisation and evasion.

"Any audience watching a TV programme about the Holocaust is well versed about the nature of the material it might include. They are watching at 7.15pm on a Saturday evening and they shouldn't be dissuaded through the hell of dissected babies for no valid reason."

It examines the evolution of the Holocaust, starting with Kristallnacht, mass shootings and the Final Solution which saw Hitler's murderous campaign intensified with gas chambers - industrialised mass murder to exterminate more Jews more rapidly. The aim was to put issues raised in the trial into a broader context. "We felt that if you weren't able to step out of the court and provide the background, you'd be getting a narrow view of the subject," says Kirby. Richard Rampton QC (barrister for the defendants) and Irving engaged in convoluted arguments that revolved around semantics, involving German vocabulary and grammar. Castle also falls short of capturing the sheer ridiculousness of Irving, who represented himself during the trial. Irving's denials of key parts of the Holocaust are used by Woodhead as a bridge to present the evidence that exposed the author as a fraud. "I see Holocaust images being used as wallpaper, detaching the images from the reality of the event. It's important that the archive is used sensitively and accurately." fields.headline: Land and freedom
fields.trailText: Ben had a problem. People come in the night and steal his potatoes. He scoured the field with his binoculars, never once taking his eyes off the invisible enemy. "They move quickly," said Ben. "They wait until the coast is clear." A tactic normally associated with the fieldmouse.
fields.body:
Ben had a problem. People come in the night and steal his potatoes. He scoured the field with his binoculars, never once taking his eyes off the invisible enemy. "They move quickly," said Ben. "They wait until the coast is clear." A tactic normally associated with the fieldmouse.

Ben was a Dutchman trying to make it on Polish soil. He'd developed a curious hubris based on the principle that "the worst Dutch farmer is better than the best Polish farmer." He bought land when people said it was "insanity!", anticipating the heavens opening and EU cash raining down.

Nothing happened, so instead he sat at the edge of a field with his binoculars, a sublimated rage against Poles, Brussels and Poles, fixed on a central spot between his eyes. When asked who he thought the spud thieves might be, Ben calmly said he suspected the whole of Poland. EUtopia: Gambling on Europe (BBC2) made a subtle parallel between Ben with his potatoes and Austrian border guards, eyes peeled for capitalism. The guards catch the same people three times a week, pushing them back like a dog off a rat.

Ossers, eastern people keen to stick their head in the EU trough, could get a fair approximation of an average day in the west by watching Britain's Richest People 2000 (ITV). This banal and frightening programme was a glimpse into QVC-topia - a conveyor belt of gold water-fountains, plastic chandelier glitz, nestling in acres of loose, tanned flesh. David Del Boy Jason strolled round, mouthing "super-rich statistics": Gerrards Cross has 500 millionaires; fruit'n'veg stall-holders make an average £800 a week ("took me 40 years to make my first million"). Incidentally, Engelbert Humperdinck once wrote a song called Lesbian Seagull (he showed us the gold disc).

A kitchen-worktop mogul was so bored with his money, he bought 21-carat gold door hinges for the whole house. "See this room here. Take the piano: £60,000; mirror: £12,000; two paintings: £50,000. That's £250,000 to do a room like this." Ah, but is he happy? (Yes.)

Chris De Burgh, talking quietly like Hannibal Lecter, showed off his castle and helicopter ("I deserve them"). An endless parade of self-made millionaires droned on about how they'd had no formal education, called a spade a spade, etc, covering up for the fact that they were really just dull snobs with no imagination. Money had nothing to do with it. "All right, I might have the £6m yacht and the Lear Jet, but I'm not extravagant." No, just stupid.

Cheshire - which lies just behind Gerrards Cross in the super-rich league table - was the one witness that couldn't be called for Sally Clark in Dispatches (C4). Cheshire is a county, with its bland QVC wealth, which spreads a carpet of misery over its "super-rich" citizens. Just like Posh Spice, Sally Clark found herself catapulted from the fast lane to sitting alone in a Tudorbethan house, caring for a screaming baby.

Posh looks depressed and anorexic, but Sally Clark is now in prison - for the murder of her two sons. Born and died two years apart, it was a 73-million-to-one chance that her sons' deaths were accidental. That's it, a lottery. So Clark becomes the worst kind of murderess and, in that regional news cliche, "showed no emotion".

The truth is that the evidence, bar the lottery statistic, is very, very shaky. The reporter, David Jessel, deeply frustrated at the uselessness of his inquiries, sat in a car park and said that he really didn't know. "Do you think she murdered those children?" he asked Dr Rushton, a pathologist. "I have to say, from the evidence of... er, whether or not, certainly they were unnatural, but in these two cases, I'm still, er, I'm not certain." Well, places and situations can kill as cold-bloodedly as people, but I doubt you could prove it in court.

jam (C4) wrung dry what little goodwill remained on the part of Chris Morris fans. Like the is-he-isn't-he-racist? Ali G, Morris trades on ambiguity. In his case, somewhere between comedy and weirdness, which is handy. Because he does neither very convincingly. There was more of both in the opening titles of Always And Everyone (ITV). To jaunty music, Martin Shaw swings across frame on a hospital trolley, pummelling a cardiac patient in best costume-trauma tradition. Shaw runs a very British operation. No ER tricks here, thank you very much. "Does it hurt here, Trevor?" "URGHH!" That's a yes then.
