fields.headline: A very British paradox
fields.standfirst: How to judge the true state of the nation's economy
fields.trailText: And now, as the Two Ronnies may once have said, for the bad news. Britain owes the rest of the world about £100bn, and her workers are slacking off in a big way. Productivity growth since at least 1996 has been "abysmal".
fields.body:
And now, as the Two Ronnies may once have said, for the bad news. Britain owes the rest of the world about £100bn, and her workers are slacking off in a big way. Productivity growth since at least 1996 has been "abysmal".

So Gordon Brown has abolished boom and bust? Ha! The balance of payments is estimated at £12.8bn in the red for this year - against a 1982-91 average of £6.6bn - and is forecast to hit £18.5bn next year.

Just to add to the gloom, "services" - that futuristic, smokestack-free bundle of 21st century activities at which the UK is always said to excel - sees Britain at a disadvantage to those hidebound continental EU economies, with whom we run a service-sector trade deficit.

This stroll down the un-sunny side of the street comes courtesy of Roger Bootle, economic adviser to accountants Deloitte & Touche and an economist who has seen it all before - several times over. But these snippets from his review The World is Our Oyster, published today, are deeply misleading, because while not ducking the downside of Britain's current balmy economic climate, Professor Bootle believes the future is actually shaping up rather nicely.

Bank of Britain

Britain, he says, is not only no longer the workshop of the world (a century-old truism), but neither is it "a pure rentier country, drawing in goods and services from the rest of the world [paid] for with the income from its investments".

Instead: "It would be more accurate to think of her as a sort of giant investment bank."

Such an image has immediate attractions, conjuring up visions of Renaissance Italy and the Venetian and Florentine city states. But how does the "giant bank" role differ from that of the "rentier"?

To stay in business, a rentier nation would need to do two things: pay out little or no "rents" - interest, profits or dividends - to foreigners, and maintain a near-permanent creditor position in relation to the rest of the world.

Britain, writes Professor Bootle, fulfils neither criterion. It pays out "an unusually large amount" of "rent" to foreigners. "It could hardly be otherwise, since the UK welcomes huge volumes of foreign direct investment (FDI)... and, mainly through London, is a major player... in the global financial markets.

"This inevitably means that an awful lot of investment income goes out, as well as comes in."

A very dodgy number

This paradox of a huge debtor nation running a service-sector deficit with its near neighbours yet with a pivotal role as the world's banker is best unravelled by imagining Britain's financial accounts as less like a balance sheet and more like a wedding cake.

At the base is the "net external asset position", the figure left after the world's claims on the UK have been deducted from the UK's claims on the world.

On paper, this has dived from a flat position in 1995 to a huge £100bn deficit in 1998.

Professor Bootle is unfazed, first, because he believes collating such statistics, however conscientiously, will produce a "very, very dodgy number".

Second, as with high street banks, he says Britain is rather good at paying the world less in interest than it earns on its loans - and this makes up the second layer of the cake.

The top layer essentially represents fees earned by Britain from the investment of other people's money, a lucrative money-spinner dependent on technical skills and not on the size of the UK balance sheet or on the country's creditor status.

As for Britain's service deficit with the continental EU, this is due to one of life's great unalterables: the weather. Britons holidaying in France, Italy and Spain are to blame, a factor that will dwindle as higher incomes take tourists ever further afield.

And that productivity slump? Here, Professor Bootle is less certain. It could be that British productivity will imitate that in the US, which dawdled until very recently. Or perhaps not.

It is really the only red indicator that can't immediately be explained away.

But as all veterans of the British economy know too well, one can be all it takes.

webTitle: BBC 'tries to bury' inquiry on equality

fields.headline: BBC 'tries to bury' inquiry on equality
fields.standfirst:
World Service journalist passed over for promotion accuses corporation of race and sex discrimination and suppressing damaging evidence
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC is attempting to suppress details of a 16-month inquiry by the commission for racial equality which allegedly raises damaging suspicions of racism at the World Service.
fields.body:
The BBC is attempting to suppress details of a 16-month inquiry by the commission for racial equality which allegedly raises damaging suspicions of racism at the World Service.

Investigations by the commission uncovered evidence that staff from ethnic minorities were not promoted beyond junior grades, procedures to monitor ethnic minority representation were "wholly inadequate", and there was "widespread concern" among white and non-white staff about the situation, an employment tribunal heard yesterday.

The BBC is opposing an application to disclose correspondence about the inquiry to Sharan Sandhu, a World Service journalist who is claiming sex and race discrimination. She believes she has been passed over for promotion because of her race and gender.

Ms Sandhu's barrister, Shirley Bothroyd, told the tribunal in central London that she believed the correspondence contained a "wealth of statistical information and analysis" to support her client's case. "The BBC is desperate to prevent this coming into the public domain because its contents are extremely damaging," she said.

Ms Bothroyd read from a letter written by a National Union of Journalists official to Ms Sandhu which outlined the evidence uncovered by the commission. Ethnic minority staff stood in for colleagues at higher grades but were rarely promoted. There was a "bottleneck" of ethnic minority staff at low levels in the World Service newsroom at Bush House in London, the letter said.

Promotions which were not made through the BBC's board system always went to white candidates, and there was "widespread concern" among non-white and senior white staff about the poor representation of ethnic minorities. It alleged that monitoring processes were "wholly inadequate": for example, a white South African was allowed to class himself as "African", thereby "inflating the ethnic breakdown".

In a statement later, the BBC said it would not discuss Ms Sandhu's claims. But it added: "The BBC has been cooperating with the CRE in their preliminary inquiries into complaints made by a local NUJ chapel. During the course of these inquiries the BBC commissioned an independent investigation to look into the branch's allegations and concluded that they were without foundation. In fact, in World Service news programmes, 10.5% of the staff are from ethnic minorities. But we recognise that we can make improvements and are discussing with the CRE how we can make our equal opportunities policies more effective."

Ms Bothroyd told the tribunal that Ms Sandhu, who still works for the BBC, had been turned down for promotion on a number of occasions between 1994 and 1999. "She is the victim of continuing dis crimination every day, she is being discriminated against as we speak," the barrister said.

"Rigorous" shift patterns at the World Service newsroom also discriminated against women who chose to have children, the tribunal heard. Women's careers were compromised if they had children, and staff who fell into this category were placed next to each other in the newsroom. "They were put into what was loosely de scribed as a creche," Ms Bothroyd said. "One felt largely as if one's career stopped there."

Dawn Cooper, the BBC's barrister, opposed the release of personnel files of Ms Sandhu's fellow applicants for promotion. Such wide disclosure would allow Ms Sandhu to conduct a campaign against the BBC, rather than simply argue her own case, Ms Cooper argued.

The CRE conclusions were the result of nothing more than a preliminary inquiry, she said. "The CRE have done no more than indicate a suspicion." There was no suggestion that the commission would launch a formal investigation.

The CRE was called in by the National Union of Journalists, which is supporting Ms Sandhu's case. The commission has now asked the BBC for its comments, and has the power to launch a formal investigation.

Ms Sandhu, 49, from west London, could not discuss the case due to the conditions of her contract. But her union representative, Pierre Vicary, said she had no regrets about bringing the action, and did not fear the consequences. "She has not been promoted so far, so it doesn't really make much difference," he said.

The tribunal will rule later whether to order disclosure of the documents.

fields.headline: Hague shifts on life sentences
fields.standfirst:
U-turn pledge to end mandatory term for murder

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague was yesterday accused of softening Tory policy on crime when he indicated that he favoured abolishing the mandatory life sentence for murder.
fields.body:
William Hague was yesterday accused of softening Tory policy on crime when he indicated that he favoured abolishing the mandatory life sentence for murder.

In a fresh twist to Conservative attempts to capitalise on public concern over the Tony Martin case, the Tory leader said his party's manifesto would include a guarantee to drop opposition to any weakening of the principle that murder automatically attracts a life sentence, as part of a package to "rebalance" the law in favour of householders acting in self-defence.

The change would mean not only a u-turn for Mr Hague (who, as the Guardian revealed yesterday, voted against such a change in the law in 1991) but a reversal in long-established party policy.

A blanket change, which would leave Labour tougher on the issue than the Tories, would be certain to be opposed by Conservative law and order hardliners.

Mr Hague's acknowledgement on Radio 4's Today programme that, if asked to vote on mandatory life sentences today, he would change his 1991 stance, was immediately seized on by the home secretary, Jack Straw.

In a letter to the Conservative leader and the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, he wrote: "If this policy has any effect, it can only mean that murderers would receive shorter sentences. The public would be less protected."

Mr Hague's words were yesterday being played down rapidly by Central Office sources, who claimed the party's preferred option was to see defendants such as Martin, who shot a burglar in his home, charged with manslaughter rather than murder, allowing a more lenient sentence.

A spokesman said: "William made it clear he was talking about the options in the context of the review of the laws on self-defence which we are proposing.

"One option would be to say that a life sentence for murder would not be mandatory under very limited circumstances where the householder has mounted a plea of self-defence. But a better way of doing this might well be... that the charge in those circumstances would be manslaughter rather than murder."

The call for more flexibility in murder sentencing puts Mr Hague to the left of Mr Straw, who makes clear the government had "no plans" to change the law.

Despite Central Office backtracking, the move would win for Mr Hague the support of lawyers and the judiciary, which has long clamoured for more discretion and flexibility in sentencing.

It would allow judges to pass relatively short sentences on mercy killers, battered women who kill their violent spouses after years of abuse, and people who use excessive force in self-defence, while reserving life sentences for cases such as that of Myra Hindley or Peter Sutcliffe, the Yorkshire Ripper.

Lord Donaldson, former master of the rolls, said: "I and most of the judges in the Lords have been advocating this for years.

"But I'd be surprised if the present government was prepared to change it. It seems to be something which is inherent to politicians - they want to control the sentence."

Release of prisoners serving mandatory life sentences is in the final instance at the discretion of the home secretary.

Giving judges the flexibility to fit the punishment to the crime looks like the only one of Mr Hague's ideas for "rebalancing" the justice system in self-defence cases that stands up to scrutiny.

His suggestion that a subjective test should be introduced, so "a person might be able to use force if it seemed reasonable to him in the circumstances in which he thought himself to be", was established in case law in the 1980s.

webTitle: How can I help my daughter when she blames me for her depression?

fields.headline: How can I help my daughter when she blames me for her depression?
fields.trailText: My daughter, who is 32, has suffered from depression for the past seven years. She received counselling and is now on medication. Though happily married with a lovely home and a responsible job, she has low self-esteem which has brought her to the brink of suicide.
fields.body:
My daughter, who is 32, has suffered from depression for the past seven years. She received counselling and is now on medication. Though happily married with a lovely home and a responsible job, she has low self-esteem which has brought her to the brink of suicide.

Recently, she wrote to me blaming me for her illness, and accusing me of criticising her and favouring her sisters. She says every encounter with me leaves her distressed, and has decided she does not want to see me again. I was devastated by this and wrote back to her, but there has been no response.

My husband and I divorced when she was 17, and I am aware of the pain it caused, but we separated amicably. I want my daughter to have the help that will enable her to see her childhood in a more balanced way. Any suggestions?

Her view is as valid

As the divorced mother of a daughter a few years older than yours, I would be distraught to be told that she never wanted to see me again. However, as one who has suffered from depression, I find myself identifying with your daughter. I also felt undervalued by my mother, and she seemed to favour my siblings. When I went into therapy she said she would never accept that she was to blame for my problems. After struggling for many years, I finally took control of my life through counselling/psychotherapy.

Is it possible that your daughter has been enabled to come to terms with the past through counselling? Who is to say that counselling has not given her a balanced view of her childhood? Could not her perspective be at least as valid as yours?

Is there someone - friend, relative, minister - with whom you could talk this through? I hope that this, and the love you have for your daughter, will enable you to support her, whatever decisions she makes about her life.

Show her you love her

Three years ago, I was in a similar situation to your daughter. At the time, it all made perfect sense to me: my childhood was the cause of the horrible way I felt, and if I avoided my family, then I'd feel better. It sounds as if your daughter has found an explanation for her depression that makes sense to her but is causing pain to you.

Unfortunately, she is likely to find that her depression won't go away just by avoiding you. Part of my recovery has been to identify that the way I behave in social encounters has a large part to play in how those encounters develop.

You say that your daughter is "happily married with a lovely home and a responsible job", as if that should make a difference. It doesn't. Depression is a serious illness that is not related to, but can be exacerbated by, personal circumstances - part of the torture is guilt that you have "all this" and are still unhappy. I wonder if this is part of the reason for your daughter's letter. You might consider writing again to try to understand what it is about your relationship that she finds upsetting, as well as to express your obvious love for her.

If she doesn't write back, then I'd suggest that the best you can do for her at the moment is to accept her decision. I am confident that given time your daughter will reach a more balanced perspective.

Try to understand her

My sister has cut herself off from the rest of her family after suffering from depression and anxiety for many years. It is important for the family, and parents in particular, to know that however much it was not intended, they have some responsibility for her unhappiness now. Rather than trying to get her to see that she is mistaken, it is more helpful to try to understand her point of view.

Acknowledge that, as her parent, you have some responsibility in producing a daughter who has suffered from depression for so long. You are denying what she feels, which is painful. Listen to her version and try to understand what life was like for her as a child. If you cannot do this, she will indeed find every encounter with you distressing, as me and my sister do with our mother.

Next week

My husband and I are both atheists and, as such, see no use for our bodies once we are dead - nor do we wish for any funeral services. Consequently, we have donated our remains to medical research, as we believe that this will both serve a useful purpose and also mean that our family have no funeral arrangements to make or pay for.

We have discussed this with our children and find that they are prepared to respect our wishes in this matter and are, in fact, in agreement with them. But one daughter has expressed concern that, without a funeral to mark our passing, there will be no "ending" and no "goodbyes", without which she feels grieving cannot take place.

Naturally, we would not wish to cause our children any more distress than they will feel at our passing, but we feel that the usual ceremonies are so contrary to our beliefs that we really don't want them to take place - even though we would obviously not be present.

Can any of your readers suggest a way out of this dilemma whereby everyone concerned can be content with the arrangements?

 Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020 7239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
So will ITV have to bring back the News At Ten? The Independent Television Commission - the industry's watchdog, a form of police for those making commercial TV - has warned the nation's favourite button that it's worried about fewer people watching the national and regional ITV news bulletins in the year since the last bongs at 10pm were heard. What you may not know is that it was the ITC which allowed News At Ten to be scrapped in the first place.

Those living in the eight or so million households with cable and satellite TV will no doubt be wondering what all the fuss is about - Sky News and the BBC's News 24 are just two of the 24/7 news channels that they can dip into whenever they want, not to mention the raft of breaking news services now available on the internet.

The biggest lobbying group for the return of News At Ten is that precious group of "decision-makers", the politicians. Tony Blair wasn't in favour of shifting News At Ten in the first place - an opinion which suggests his spinmeister Alastair Campbell reckoned News At Ten was the best evening forum for circulating news of the day's political dealings. And the fact that the "bring back the bongs" lobby gets so much press attention suggests that the only other people who care about whether ITV news is on in that slim window between middle-class dinner at 9pm and schoolday sensible bedtime at 11pm are sad hacks like us. But the big question is: what is ITV going to do to satisfy its schoolmarmy regulator and keep the politicos and journos off its back?

Answer: not sure. A compromise solution - putting the news on at 10.30pm and ditching the desperate headlines at 10pm, which reveal just how slow a news day it is - seems likely. Meanwhile, rumours abound that the BBC will catch the changing tide and shift its news to a slot later in the evening. Will you care?

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Cheat's kitchen
fields.standfirst: Toffee banana splurge
fields.trailText: Toffee banana splurge
fields.body:
4 bananas
1 450g pot Merchant Gourmet Dulce de Leche (Banoffee Toffee)
4 hot cross buns
55g butter cream

1 Peel and fry bananas in butter until slightly soft.
2 Slice hot cross buns in half and toast on cut side only
3 Place toasted buns on four plates. Put a banana on each. (Slice bananas in half lengthways if you want to be fancy.)
4 Spoon as much Dulce de Leche over each as you think you can stand.
5 Pour a little cream over each. Serves 4.

Melanie Topham, Lincs.

 If you have any hints for Cheat's kitchen, please send them to The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

fields.headline: Call to outlaw medical ageism
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Doctors regularly issue "do not resuscitate" orders for patients without their or their families' knowledge, according to a professor of social medicine who is calling for ageism to be outlawed in the NHS.
fields.body:
Doctors regularly issue "do not resuscitate" orders for patients without their or their families' knowledge, according to a professor of social medicine who is calling for ageism to be outlawed in the NHS.

In the US, says Professor Shah Ebrahim from Bristol University, there is evidence that doctors allow their prejudices to interfere in the decision as to who should be resuscitated after a cardiopulmonary arrest.

Black people, alcohol misusers, non English speakers and those with HIV are more likely to get a DNR (do not resuscitate) order "suggesting that doctors have stereotypes of who is not worth saving", he writes in the British Medical Journal today.

"We don't know whether that obtains in this country - it certainly merits investigation," he said yesterday.

But there is evidence that older people are more likely to be the subject of an order than younger people, and research in Europe shows that in over two-thirds of cases, patients and their families had not been consulted.

The charity Age Concern recently confirmed the practice in the UK by issuing a dossier of 50 cases where patients had received a DNR order without their families knowing. One who died in hospital was found by her family to have NFR (not for resuscitation) written across her toes.

After making all the necessary adjustments for the severity of a disease, age and other factors, patients with a DNR notice are 30 times more likely to die than others, which suggests that "do not resuscitate orders may reduce quality of care", writes Prof Ebrahim.

Doctors may feel uncomfortable about discussing the matter, but they are wrong if they assume that families do not want to talk over the options for their relative, says Dr Ebrahim - on the contrary, they consider it part of good quality care.

"What we're dealing with here is doctors' problems, not patients' and families' problems," said Prof Ebrahim.

"One of the serious lessons for the medical profession and the nursing profession is that families don't mind it. They view it as important and necessary."

Prof Ebrahim also hits out at the entrenched ageism in the NHS. "Medical students still rejoice in their stereotypes of 'geriatric crumble' and 'GOMER' (get out of my emergency room) patients... Eradicating ageism in the NHS will almost certainly require legislation."

He suggests that the practice of writing DNR orders should be monitored as part of clinical governance, which requires hospital trusts to assess their doctors' performance on a regular basis.

webTitle: There is an alternative for us Tories

fields.headline: There is an alternative for us Tories
fields.standfirst: As Hezza bows out, Norris and Portillo offer us a kinder futureTories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: As Hezza bows out, Norris and Portillo offer us a kinder future
fields.body:
So farewell then, Michael Heseltine. The announcement that the former defence secretary and Thatcher assassin is to depart the Commons after the next election leads one to reflect not only on what might have been but also on what is to come for our party.

Many might say that the Tory party is losing one of its heavy hitters, that it will be a more lightweight and less balanced party after the next parliament. This is not entirely the case. Heseltine has had his day as an active politician, and he is man enough to admit it. He knows that he is a figure of enough stature to be able to make his point in the future whether he is in the Commons or not.

I am no Heseltine fan. For me, he was always too interventionist in the economic sphere and too pro-Europe. But he has always been a reflective and thoughtful politician, and not one given to the sort of crude posturing on social issues that is fast becoming the norm for our party. He would have made an interesting home secretary.

It is actually social policy, rather than the euro, that threatens to divide our party today. This week has seen extensive coverage of Steve Norris's reported views that he is disaffected with his party because of its racist and homophobic stance, and of William Hague's call to change the law to protect people who defend themselves against criminals.

Norris has been anxious throughout his campaign to present himself as tolerant and open to diversity. A campaign built around such tactics - opposition to section 28 and support for the Macpherson report - has led to real division within the London Conservative party. There is now a significant number of Conservative activists, including elected representatives, who will not vote for Norris, full stop. They will put their cross next to the Tory assembly candidate, and next to the Tory party for the top-up list, but they will not back Norris.

These activists are, by definition, part of "the core" of the Conservative party. They feel that Norris has gone beyond the pale, that, like Heseltine, he is no longer a Conservative and that he does not represent their views. If Norris feels detached, it turns out that for a significant minority of activists the feeling is mutual. It seems that what Norris gains from the swing voters, he will lose from the puritanical roundheads.

The tensions within the London Tory party, the dispute between Norris and Hague, the departure of Heseltine, are important because they encapsulate the crossroads at which the Tory party finds itself. Either we can decide to hunker down and appeal to our core vote, which appears to be the leadership's position. Or we can raise our game, broaden our horizon, recognise and embrace change, which is Norris's position.

And not just Norris, by all accounts. No one has watched the race for London mayor more closely than Michael Portillo, and not simply because he is a London MP. It is widely known that there are close links between the Norris and Portillo camps. Norris and Portillo share the same liberal outlook and approach on social issues. Thus many see Norris's campaign as a dry run for a possible future Conservative general election campaign.

Norris is seen to be extolling the "Portillo Lite" approach that we grew to know and love when our favourite former defence secretary was outside parliament, rediscovering himself in the wilderness. If Norris does well - by which I mean if he pushes Dobson into third place, or runs him very close indeed - it will be possible to argue that liberal Conservatism is a net vote winner. We may lose some hardcore diehards, the argument will run, but we will have begun to reach out to a new core of voters. It is a risky strategy, not least because the one-horse race that this election has become makes the experiment difficult to assess.

It is also difficult because the leadership of the Conservative party has decided to follow a strategy of leaping on bandwagons. If William Hague had maintained his early approach to compassionate Conservatism, the two strands of Tory thought might be closer together. The latest policies (or more accurately the way they are being spun) on detention centres and gun-wielding homeowners make us look little short of ludicrous. It is also somewhat misguided. The public likes its prejudices, but it actually does not particularly like politicians to pander to them.

Out of the two approaches, the Norris approach is closer to Conservatism and the spirit, if you like, of Britain. We want a government that interferes less, in both our economic and social lives. We do not want a government that legislates on outrage, be it dangerous dogs or dangerous homeowners.

It used to be said that general elections were determined by the London effect. It seems that the future of our party may be determined by how we react to the Norris effect.

 Ed Vaizey was a Conservative candidate at the last election

If Norris does well - by which I mean if he pushes Dobson into third place, or runs him very close indeed - it will be possible to argue that liberal Conservatism is a net vote winner. We may lose some hardcore diehards, the argument will run, but we will have begun to reach out to a new core of voters. It is a risky strategy, not least because the one-horse race that this election has become makes the experiment difficult to assess. It is also difficult because the leadership of the Conservative party has decided to follow a strategy of leaping on bandwagons. If William Hague had maintained his early approach to compassionate Conservatism, the two strands of Tory thought might be closer together. The latest policies (or more accurately the way they are being spun) on detention centres and gun-wielding homeowners make us look little short of ludicrous. It is also somewhat misguided. The public likes its prejudices, but it actually does not particularly like politicians to pander to them. Out of the two approaches, the Norris approach is closer to Conservatism and the spirit, if you like, of Britain. We want a government that interferes less, in both our economic and social lives. We do not want a government that legislates on outrage, be it dangerous dogs or dangerous homeowners. It used to be said that general elections were determined by the London effect. It seems that the future of our party may be determined by how we react to the Norris effect.  Ed Vaizey was a Conservative candidate at the last election

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Dark City | The Madness Of King George | Bad Lieutenant | Invasion Of The Body Snatchers
fields.body:
Dark City (Alex Proyas, 1998)
8pm, Sky MovieMax

Stylish collision of film noir and sci-fi which anticipated The Matrix's paranoid flights of fancy. John Murdoch (Rufus Sewell) is your typical noir hero, waking up terrified and amnesiac in a blood-stained bathroom. Trying to piece together his shattered memories is a job in itself, as is evading the attentions of The Strangers, mysterious pursuers straight out of a German Expressionist movie - led, unsurprisingly, by Richard O'Brien, Britain's answer to the Nosferatu.

The Madness Of King George (Nicholas Hytner, 1994)
8pm, FilmFour

A handsome historical drama about skulduggery at court - epitomised by Rupert Everett's foppish, scheming Prince of Wales - and a moving study of the man inside the ermine. Nigel Hawthorne's George is magnificent, lurching from nobility to wild-eyed tantrums to utter wretchedness. And counterpointing the affectations of courtly manners is his moving relationship with his Queen Charlotte, Helen Mirren.

Invasion Of The Body Snatchers (Don Siegel, 1956)
12midnight, Sci-Fi

Hysteria grips a small Californian town as people fear their loved ones are turning into complete strangers. Doc Kevin McCarthy, aided by the woman of his dreams, Dana Wynter, soon discovers the awful truth. Alien pods are replicating the townsfolk, and there's no way out. Fears of the red menace underpin Siegel's tense, fast-paced sci-fi tale which, despite excellent remakes by Kaufmann and Ferrara, remains the scariest.

Bad Lieutenant (Abel Ferrara, 1992)
12.05am, FilmFour

Harvey Keitel's detective isn't the guy you want to call when you've been burgled - he's up to his eyes in heroin, booze and gambling debts, and inclined towards sexually humiliating teenage girls. He's a walking composite of human degradation, wriggling in a septic, putrid New York. And then, rather astonishingly, the case of a raped nun offers a chance of redemption.

webTitle: Let's bring back politeness, urges Blunkett

fields.headline: Let's bring back politeness, urges Blunkett
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The education secretary, David Blunkett, yesterday urged parents and teachers to back a moral crusade to revive "the old-fashioned values of politeness and respect", and to refuse to tolerate foul language and abusive behaviour from children.
fields.body:
The education secretary, David Blunkett, yesterday urged parents and teachers to back a moral crusade to revive "the old-fashioned values of politeness and respect", and to refuse to tolerate foul language and abusive behaviour from children.

Mr Blunkett made his appeal amid protests from teachers that unruly children were making it impossible for them to do their job properly and were seriously disrupting lessons for other children.

Addressing delegates at the annual conference of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers in Llandudno, north Wales, Mr Blunkett made it clear that the main responsibility for children's behaviour lay with their parents.

But he said teachers should emphasise the difference between right and wrong, and schools should be a place "where good behaviour is encouraged and poor behaviour is dealt with effectively".

Mr Blunkett told delegates: "We need to work with you in trying to instil a bit of politeness and decency into the behaviour of the next generation. It may be in vain, but let's have a go at trying to eliminate foul and abusive language from our schools and our homes.

He went on: "Obscenity and foulness are a prerequisite of thuggishness and brutality. If we can reduce one, we can reduce the other."

At the same time, he was strongly critical of irresponsible parents who tolerated swearing at home, and of those who inexplicably seemed to resent "the civilising influence" that schools provided.

"We need to reassert the old-fashioned values of politeness and respect, of acceptable behaviour, and of intolerance of abusive and aggressive action," he said. "This will benefit the communities we live in, as well as our schools."

But the secretary of state could not resist a swipe at militant activists belonging to the larger National Union of Teachers, who last week walked out of a speech made by the school standards minister, Estelle Morris, at the union's conference in Harrogate, North Yorkshire. He said those who had "attacked" his colleague in this way had no right to complain about discipline and bad behaviour. As expected, Mr Blunkett announced a package of measures to improve discipline in schools, which will include increasing the number of learning support units within schools - or "sin bins" - to more than 1,000 over the next two years.

Around 60 of these will be set up to serve primary schools for the first time, in recognition of the need to tackle bad behaviour at an early age.

The NASUWT general secretary, Nigel de Gruchy, had said many children were arriving at nursery school and reception classes "completely out of control".

Mr Blunkett also confirmed that a proper timetable and longer teaching hours would be introduced into pupil referral units, which are generally away from school sites. This would ensure that disruptive pupils were not "rewarded for their bad behaviour by time out of school", but given a full education which would stop them roaming the streets.

He sought to reassure teachers worried by the government's target to cut the number of excluded pupils by a third by the year 2002 that "where children are violent and disruptive, heads have the power and the duty to exclude a child from school altogether".

But Mr de Gruchy told Mr Blunkett that the reduction in exclusions so far had been achieved "at the expense of teachers' health and other pupils' education. We seriously question whether you have the balance right between on-site and off-site units".

webTitle: Safer to go in the water

fields.headline: Safer to go in the water
fields.standfirst:
More beaches free of pollution

Good Beach Guide
fields.trailText: Britain's bathing beaches took a step nearer to regaining their picture postcard image yesterday as marine conservationists announced that a record number have cut back on pollution.
fields.body:
Britain's bathing beaches took a step nearer to regaining their picture postcard image yesterday as marine conservationists announced that a record number have cut back on pollution.

The Good Beach Guide 2000, published next month, reports that, although less than a third of British beaches meet recommended requirements, bathers now have more than ever to choose from.

Clean-up projects in pollution blackspots around northern England and Scotland have helped to raise standards. Of 249 beaches monitored, 215 now make the grade - 35 more than in 1999.

Kate Hutchinson, a coastal pollution officer with the Marine Conservation Society - which produces the annual report - said yesterday: "This year the Good Beach Guide results have shown that extensive clean up programmes are paying off, with fewer beaches failing the minimum water quality standard."

"Although the results are encouraging, we cannot afford to ease the pace of improvement now," Ms Hutchinson added.

"A case last year highlighted the need for all coastal discharges to be treated at least at secondary level."

Last summer Heather Preen, eight, from Rednal, Birmingham, died of E.coli poisoning, which could have been caught from sewage discharged into the sea near Dawlish Warren, Devon.

The beach on which she had been playing had been awarded the EU flag for cleanliness despite being affected by a raw sewage outlet - which, the MCS says, points to the inadequacy of current European directives.

Most of the beaches rec ommended lie in the south-west, with over a third of those in the region securing a place in the guide.

The Isle of Man gains no recommendations, with a quarter of its beaches failing to meet minimum standards due to raw sewage discharges.

The situation is better in Scotland and Wales, where the number of beaches failing to qualify has roughly halved.

fields.headline: High pollen count 'is heart killer'
fields.trailText: Days with a high pollen count may increase deaths for heart and lung diseases by as much as 5% to 10%, as well as spell misery for hay fever sufferers.
fields.body:
Days with a high pollen count may increase deaths for heart and lung diseases by as much as 5% to 10%, as well as spell misery for hay fever sufferers.

Researchers in the Netherlands found "a strong association between the day-to-day variation in pollen concentrations and that of deaths due to cardiovascular disease, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and pneumonia" they reported in the Lancet medical journal, published today.

Pollen has been largely disregarded in studies of air pollution and these diseases, write Bert Brunekreef and colleagues from Utrecht University, so they compared daily pollen counts with deaths for 1986-94.

"Pollen is a well-known trigger of allergies, especially hay fever and asthma.

"However, deaths related to these conditions are extremely rare, and cannot account for the associations seen in this study.

"The size of these associations is as large as that between air pollution and mortality, which typically shows a 5-10% increase in mortality on 'high pollution' days."

"Our findings suggest that high airborne pollen concentrations, which nowadays are mainly seen as triggers of allergic symptoms, may have far more serious effects than previously thought."

webTitle: Row over hit film leads to FBI sting

fields.headline: Row over hit film leads to FBI sting
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The former husband and the former boyfriend of the woman on whom the hit film Erin Brockovich was based have been arrested for trying to extort more than $300,000 (£190,400) from her. They had allegedly threatened to make false claims to the American   tabloids that Ms Brockovich, played by Julia Roberts in the film, had been a bad mother and had had an affair with her boss, the lawyer Ed Masry.
fields.body:
The former husband and the former boyfriend of the woman on whom the hit film Erin Brockovich was based have been arrested for trying to extort more than $300,000 (£190,400) from her. They had allegedly threatened to make false claims to the American tabloids that Ms Brockovich, played by Julia Roberts in the film, had been a bad mother and had had an affair with her boss, the lawyer Ed Masry.

The two men and a lawyer representing them were arrested in Thousand Oaks, California after a sting worthy of a movie itself. Shawn Brown, 38, Ms Brockovich's former husband and her ex-boyfriend Jorg Halaby, 46, who is portrayed sympathetically in the film, were allegedly unhappy that they had not profited substantially from the hit movie.

It is based on the true story of Ms Brockovich, 39, an unqualified legal worker who took on the utility company Pacific Gas & Electric and won a £211m settlement for 650 California residents affected by a poisoned water supply. She was given a £1.3m fee.

According to the charges, John Reiner, a lawyer representing the two, called Mr Masry earlier this month to say that Mr Brown would give interviews suggesting that Ms Brockovich had been a bad mother and had had a sexual relationship with Mr Masry; allegations denied by Ms Brockovich and Mr Masry.

The two men and their lawyer were then invited to a meeting with mother-of-three Ms Brockovich, Mr Masry and a lawyer, Cathleen Drury, who is representing Ms Brockovich in a child custody case. Ms Drury had already contacted the FBI and a hidden camera was installed in her office.

The cameras ran as the two men made their claims and signed a silence agreement in exchange for £19,000 for Mr Halaby and £178,000 for Mr Brown. The trio have been charged with extortion.

Ms Brockovich said Mr Halaby had already been paid by the film's makers, Universal, for being portrayed in the film. Mr Brown, who is not featured in the film, received nothing.

webTitle: God's own country fights off biblical swarms of locusts

fields.headline: God's own country fights off biblical swarms of locusts
fields.trailText: A plague of locusts of biblical proportions, estimated at 100 billion-strong, is on the move through the Australian outback threatening everything in its path from valuable vineyards to backyard washing.
fields.body:
A plague of locusts of biblical proportions, estimated at 100 billion-strong, is on the move through the Australian outback threatening everything in its path from valuable vineyards to backyard washing.

The infestation described as the worst for 20 years follows record rains and the greening of normally arid expanses. A change of wind direction is expected to blow it towards the food and wine growing area of the Riverina in southern New South Wales.

Locusts can swarm in densities of 15,000 per square metre. Four aeroplanes and five helicopters are currently spraying vast areas trying to arrest the migration.

"If it gets to the extreme they tend to attack anything that's green, including green clothes that are hanging on the clothesline," Geoff File of the New South Wales agriculture department said. "They've been known to eat the green out of clothes in a very severe plague, which we rarely get in Australia these days. They can create enormous damage."

The Australian plague locust commission said there were massive swarms on both sides of the continent. This was a particularly unusual event which has seen Western Australia's wheat belt, the rangelands of Queensland, as well as South Australia and New South Wales affected.

The eastern plague which has attacked cereal crops in South Australia is heading for the rich agricultural areas and could cause £100m-worth of damage, according to commission estimates. "They tend to fly on the same night, there are reports of locusts raining on rooftops," said the commission's director Dr Graeme Hamilton.

Rare and widespread flooding gave the locusts the damp soil they need to hatch new eggs and produced a swathe of green shoots to satisfy their insatiable appetites.

"We're spraying what we find. We're trying to do as much as we can, as fast as we can," said the commission's operations manager Walter Spratt. "Because conditions have been so good there have been multiple layings so there are still quite a lot of juveniles out there."

Brett Eglinton, a farmer whose property lies 30 miles south-east of Broken Hill, has witnessed a number of small hatchings in the past two months. "In the last few days they've started to fly and there are a lot of them in the air," he said. "They don't block out the sun but they're very thick."

In New South Wales the commission has identified 48 locust "targets" in the western districts and is spraying with pesticide. But their forecaster, Paul Wilson, said the problem is spreading across the state although the winter will slow it down temporarily.

"We have been doing quite a bit of control in the Tibooburra and White Cliffs areas. Basically there are locusts over a very, very wide area and wherever those adults were during the autumn, we can expect eggs to hatch next spring as well."

fields.headline: Lockerbie judge rejects delay call
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: Two Libyans go on trial next week for the Lockerbie bombing after a Scottish judge in the Netherlands yesterday threw out a prosecution request for a two month postponement.
fields.body:
Two Libyans go on trial next week for the Lockerbie bombing after a Scottish judge in the Netherlands yesterday threw out a prosecution request for a two month postponement.

Sitting at Camp Zeist, a converted US airbase, Lord Sutherland ruled that he saw no reason to delay further the start of proceedings against Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, who have been in custody for well over a year.

The Libyans, seated in the dock behind a bullet-proof glass screen and flanked by Scottish policemen, listened through headphones to an Arabic translation of the proceedings. They looked relieved as the three-hour hearing ended with a stern rebuke from the bench for both defence and prosecution.

It was "singularly unhelpful to indulge in attempts to blame each other over preparations for a case of unprecedented complexity," said Lord Sutherland, adding that the accused had been in custody for an unprecedented length of time. "I am not satisfied that postponement is necessary."

Colin Boyd QC, Scotland's lord advocate, had argued that the late release of a list of defence witnesses, just before the Easter holiday, meant that prosecutors could not make adequate preparations.

Starting next Wednesday, the court will call more than 1,000 prosecution witnesses, some disguised to protect their identity, and explore a mass of forensic evidence and conflicting theories about who carried out the worst act of mass murder in British history.

Two hundred and seventy people, including 190 Americans, died when Pan Am Flight 103, en route from London to New York, exploded over Lockerbie on December 21 1988.

The Libyans, said to be intelligence agents, surrendered last April after years of stalemate and diplomatic wrangling.

Jim Swire, whose daughter was killed in the bombing and who has worked tirelessly to secure a Scottish trial in the Netherlands, said after the hearing: "It is a relief beyond belief that this is going ahead."

Postponement would have caused grave logistical problems to relatives and witnesses, involving changes to long-booked flights and hotel accommodation in the vicinity of Camp Zeist, formally declared sovereign territory for the duration of the trial.

Scottish policemen armed with machine guns patrolled the court, emblazoned with the sign "High Court of Justiciary".

The accused, who looked fit and pleased to see half a dozen visiting relatives in the public gallery, were brought by van from the adjoining prison block.

Dr Swire said it was the first time that he had seen the two Libyans in the flesh. "I did not find it an emotional shock," he told reporters, "because I've seen so many video and mug shots of them."

Bill Taylor QC, representing Megrahi, indicated that his client would mount a "special defence" intended to incriminate others - members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, the subject of investigations in Germany.

Mr Boyd said he regretted seeking postponement by "an absolute minimum" of eight weeks. But he complained that only 31 of 124 witnesses named by the defence were previously known to the prosecution when they were received last Thursday.

Many of those were Libyans to whom, previous experience showed, access could be difficult. Other witnesses are also based in Malta, Sweden, Germany and the United States. "The Crown have been placed in an invidious position by the actions of the defence," he said.

Mr Taylor rebuffed the claims, accusing the Crown of failing to follow up leads and having been aware of many witnesses since 1990 or earlier.

Lord Sutherland said a major factor in his decision to reject the postponement request was the fact that the accused had already spent an unprecedented period in custody.

Crown evidence is expected to show that the bomb that downed the plane was hidden in a tape recorder, packed in a suitcase in Malta and placed aboard a plane bound for Frankfurt, London, and New York, using fake luggage tags.

Two hundred and seventy people, including 190 Americans, died when Pan Am Flight 103, en route from London to New York, exploded over Lockerbie on December 21 1988. The Libyans, said to be intelligence agents, surrendered last April after years of stalemate and diplomatic wrangling. Jim Swire, whose daughter was killed in the bombing and who has worked tirelessly to secure a Scottish trial in the Netherlands, said after the hearing: "It is a relief beyond belief that this is going ahead." Postponement would have caused grave logistical problems to relatives and witnesses, involving changes to long-booked flights and hotel accommodation in the vicinity of Camp Zeist, formally declared sovereign territory for the duration of the trial. Scottish policemen armed with machine guns patrolled the court, emblazoned with the sign "High Court of Justiciary". The accused, who looked fit and pleased to see half a dozen visiting relatives in the public gallery, were brought by van from the adjoining prison block. Dr Swire said it was the first time that he had seen the two Libyans in the flesh. "I did not find it an emotional shock," he told reporters, "because I've seen so many video and mug shots of them." Bill Taylor QC, representing Megrahi, indicated that his client would mount a "special defence" intended to incriminate others - members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, the subject of investigations in Germany. Mr Boyd said he regretted seeking postponement by "an absolute minimum" of eight weeks. But he complained that only 31 of 124 witnesses named by the defence were previously known to the prosecution when they were received last Thursday. Many of those were Libyans to whom, previous experience showed, access could be difficult. Other witnesses are also based in Malta, Sweden, Germany and the United States. "The Crown have been placed in an invidious position by the actions of the defence," he said. Mr Taylor rebuffed the claims, accusing the Crown of failing to follow up leads and having been aware of many witnesses since 1990 or earlier. Lord Sutherland said a major factor in his decision to reject the postponement request was the fact that the accused had already spent an unprecedented period in custody. Crown evidence is expected to show that the bomb that downed the plane was hidden in a tape recorder, packed in a suitcase in Malta and placed aboard a plane bound for Frankfurt, London, and New York, using fake luggage tags.

webTitle: Hot, dry summer spells ruin for midwest farms

fields.headline: Hot, dry summer spells ruin for midwest farms
fields.standfirst: From floods to famine, natural disasters across the globe seem to be pieces in the same ominous jigsaw
fields.trailText: The US agricultural heartland is in the grip of one of the worst droughts on record, as streams, rivers and lakes evaporate in the deep south and the midwest, threatening a disaster for farmers.
fields.body:
The US agricultural heartland is in the grip of one of the worst droughts on record, as streams, rivers and lakes evaporate in the deep south and the midwest, threatening a disaster for farmers.

For the first time, the national weather service issued a federal drought warning in spring, as the problems caused by last year's rainfall deficit were deepened by an unusually dry winter. Meteorologists warned that it could be the most arid period since the 1988-89 drought which caused losses of $54bn (£34bn) and is now considered the worst natural disaster in US history.

The worst-hit areas are southern Texas and southwestern Louisiana, which has had a little over a third of its normal rainfall so far this year. Even more worryingly, the drought extends over the main grain-producing states of the midwest: Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, Nebraska, Michigan and Indiana.

Most of these states have had 15 and 30cm less rain than normal since last summer, and there have been pockets where the situation has been worse. Kansas City, Missouri, for example, has had the driest April since records began.

"An unusual aspect is that this drought covers a very wide area of the midwest," said Michael Palecki, a climatologist at the Midwestern Regional Climate Centre in Illinois. "All the way from central Nebraska to southern Michigan - that's a very wide expanse for a drought."

As the spring drought warning was issued, the US secretary of commerce, William Daley, declared: "The news is not good. The drought of 1999 remains with us in the new century, and our data indicate drought conditions are proba bly going to get worse before they get better."

The drought is being blamed on the La Nina phenomenon, which has been distorting weather patterns across North America.

Extremely low winter snowfall has also affected the Great Lakes along the US-Canadian border, where water levels have dropped by a metre in three years, leaving lake beds exposed. If the summer is as dry as predicted, the lakes will reach their lowest levels since records began 120 years ago.

As the water level drops, the average temperature of the lakes rises, accelerating evaporation and completing a vicious circle that can only be broken by substantial rainfall. The drought has already had a serious impact on shipping, fishing and tourism, which are pillars of the local economy.

A series of thunderstorms last week moistened the topsoil in the midwest, tinting the prairies green, but any hope could prove illusory, said Douglas LeComte, a climate expert at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

"The storms have given the farmers some respite," he said, "But that doesn't change our concern about the amount of moisture in reserve for the next few months. When you dig below the surface there's very little moisture at all."

Mr Palecki, of the Midwestern Climate Centre, described conditions below the topsoil as a "ticking time bomb", explaining that last year's crops had tapped much of the sub-surface moisture, sucking it dry.

To replenish groundwater in the midwest, meteorologists estimate that states such as Missouri would need up to 25cm of rain spread out over several storms in the next few weeks. That would represent unusually heavy precipitation, which does not appear likely.

"The outlook is not too rosy for the next few months from May to July. That's why we're so worried," Mr LeComte said.

The summer is expected to be both dry and unusually hot. The past nine months are already the second warmest in over a century, according to the Midwestern centre.

The forecasts sound like death knells for midwestern farms. A University of Missouri study found that 17% of the state's farmers were at risk of going out of business because of the 1999 drought, and that another 32% could go under financially if the extraordinary arid spell continues for a few more months.

The potential economic damage is not restricted to arable farming. In Texas and the midwest, streams and water-holes are disappearing, threatening livestock. And even before the summer gets under way, the unusual conditions have triggered forest fires, especially in the Ozark forests in southern Missouri.

Doug Halliwell, a firefighting supervisor in the state's conservation department, said: "I've had at least 50,000 acres of timber burn since March 1. That's a conservative estimate."

webTitle: Walk for water grows longer as drought claims its first lives

fields.headline: Walk for water grows longer as drought claims its first lives
fields.trailText: The dusty wasteland stretching out from the village is brown and barren. "These are our fields," said Jay Salaya, a cattle farmer, pointing in despair. "This is where we usually grow our crops and that is for the cows and buffaloes."
fields.body:
The dusty wasteland stretching out from the village is brown and barren. "These are our fields," said Jay Salaya, a cattle farmer, pointing in despair. "This is where we usually grow our crops and that is for the cows and buffaloes."

There are no crops and no cattle. In the village of Bead, on the outskirts of Jamnagar in western Gujarat, the cakes of soil crumble in your hands and disappear into the burning wind.

On the other side of the village, women dressed in the brightest red, gold and green saris lower black plastic bags on ropes over a brick well to try to scoop up what is left of the water.

"That well is 100 years old," said Mr Salaya. "It is the only one for the village but now the water is no good. It is too dirty. We haven't had enough rain here for three years. The government started to build a water tank for us five years ago but it was never done."

Drought conditions, or prolonged periods of dryness leading to crop failure, are affecting close to 80m people in 11 states, the government said in a report published yesterday. The worst hit areas are here in Gujarat and in nearby Rajasthan, both on the border with Pakistan.

India's prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, has announced a 9.5bn rupee (£138m) relief package and asked for public donations to help. But he faces growing criticism over his government's failure to predict and prepare for the worsening crisis.

For the farmers the drought came as no surprise. They have been warning of impending water shortages in the worst affected areas for more than six months.

It has not rained in Rajasthan or in some areas of Gujarat for three years. As a result, the water table has gradually been drained, and only limited monsoon rains are forecast for mid-June.

For drinking water the villagers around Jamnagar rely on a government tanker which stops nearby two or three times a week and empties water into a trough. As dusk falls crowds of people walk towards the town to meet the tanker. Some carry tin pots on their heads, while others tie bags to their bicycles.

Farmers walk all day to find water for their cattle. The animals are thin, their hides stretched tight over their bones.

"We have to walk or go by bicycle to get our water," said Bindi, a 16-year-old girl living in another village nearby.

"Sometimes it takes one or two hours. What else can we do? The animals are dying. Many of the people are going to the city to look for water."

At least two people - a father and his seven-year-old daughter - have died of starvation, after collapsing near their village in Gujarat on Tuesday. Last week three farmers were shot dead by police near Jamnagar following protests over the water shortage.

Government officials have tried to play down the effects of the drought, which is bringing drastic economic and social dislocation to the lives of the millions of farmers, who have been forced to sell their cattle or watch them die in the heat.

Many of them are already heavily in debt and now face a lifetime of dependence on outside aid.

"It is all about economics. We are a backward class," said Gadvi Mega, a teacher from another village."We have one source for water and that is the rain. When it does not rain, we are without water. Now we have a big problem and people are very angry."

"Why don't the politicians come to visit our village?" he asked. "We are very worried."

There is a division of wealth in this drought. From the air it is clear that whole swaths of Gujarat's land have been baked brown. But there are sporadic pockets of green, signalling areas owned by private farmers wealthy enough to afford their own deep boreholes to keep their crops alive.

Gujarat is a vital agricultural supplier, producing a third of India's cotton and peanuts as well as grain, oilseed, maize, sunflowers and sugar cane.

So far the water shortage has not hurt the towns. Jamnagar is still crowded with traffic, its fruit and vegetable markets are still full of produce and the Apollo Circus is in town.

But the city's beautiful Ranmal lake, which surrounds the small Lakhota Palace, is dry. Teams of workers, using private and state funds, have been digging the lake deeper, hoping it will conserve more water when the rains return.

"If the monsoon rains do not come then there will be trouble for Jamnagar city as well," said Satesh, a shopkeeper.

fields.headline: 300,000 Afghans rely on UN food
fields.trailText: Wells are dry, camel carcasses rot in the sun and entire villages in southern Afghanistan are talking about leaving for neighbouring Pakistan, a World Food Programme official said yesterday.
fields.body:
Wells are dry, camel carcasses rot in the sun and entire villages in southern Afghanistan are talking about leaving for neighbouring Pakistan, a World Food Programme official said yesterday.

After four days of travelling from village to village in the drought-stricken Kandahar and Zabul provinces, Khalid Mansour, a WFP information officer in Pakistan, said the situation is desperate.

Afghanistan's nomads, called Koochis, have lost up to 80% of their cattle because of a severe water shortage, he said. Irrigation systems built to collect rainwater have dried up and apricot and almond trees have withered.

"In one village of Abu Kalar in Zabul province people were eating animal fodder," Mr Mansour said. "We saw a huge number of animal carcasses, camels were dying. When a camel dies from lack of water it is a drought."

The WFP has been feeding up to 300,000 people in the region since February. Mr Mansour said that next month it will add another 10,000 families to its feeding programme.

The UN wants to avoid an exodus and is offering people additional flour as an incentive if they stay in their villages. Mr Mansour said: "We think it is better to tell villagers to stay in their homes, dig deeper wells and clean up the irrigation canals," he said. "If they leave it could destroy the whole village structure."

fields.headline: Picture palace
fields.standfirst: Race against time to get Lowry complex ready for opening
fields.trailText: By the time the culture secretary, Chris Smith, arrives for today's opening of the £106m Lowry, the shimmering steel and glass culture palace on the banks of the Manchester ship canal, the vibrant purple paint in the foyer should be dry.
fields.body:
By the time the culture secretary, Chris Smith, arrives for today's opening of the £106m Lowry, the shimmering steel and glass culture palace on the banks of the Manchester ship canal, the vibrant purple paint in the foyer should be dry.

The foyer should have been painted earlier this week, but the wrong emulsion arrived so workmen were busy with rollers late into the night.

Yesterday more than 600 other workers raced against time to put the finishing touches to the complex named in honour of LS Lowry, the Salford artist sometimes derided by aesthetes but loved by people who do not profess to know much about art but know what they like.

The building, the national millennium landmark project for the arts, has been backed with £69m of lottery money and is widely seen as a northern, inner city answer to critics hostile to the complexity and cost of the refurbishment of the Royal Opera House.

Its managers expect to attract 770,000 visitors a year to its two auditoriums, chain of galleries, Lowry study centre, Artworks (where adults and children can unlock their creativity), bars, shop and restaurant.

Michael Wilford, the Lowry's architect, arrived to express elation and "a certain amount of depression" that the building was not as complete as he had hoped. Up in the galleries, staff were hanging some of Lowry's most famous pictures, including The Funeral, and The Fight, which features an angry man stuffing a bowler hat over the head of his opponent.

Almost 100 Lowry works will at first be on show out of the 55 paintings and 278 drawings in the Salford collection, the biggest in the world.

The Lowry exhibition will be introduced by a video, which features photographs taken at Lowry's home by retired Guardian photographer Denis Thorpe the day the artist died on February 23 1976. "I drove past his house out of homage, I suppose," he said yesterday. "I saw pictures being taken out and loaded into a Securicor van.

"There was police inspector and a couple of blokes in suits and I said to them, 'You are dismantling history'. I asked if I could take some photographs before anything else was taken out."

webTitle: Mozambique, India, Venezuela... millions pay a heavy price for a warmer world

fields.headline: Mozambique, India, Venezuela... millions pay a heavy price for a warmer world
fields.trailText: Floods are events of the moment. Droughts are disasters on a slow fuse. Both happen with or without global warming.
fields.body:
Floods are events of the moment. Droughts are disasters on a slow fuse. Both happen with or without global warming.

But the drought and famine in Ethiopia, the desiccation of Rajasthan, the arid cornland of the US west, and the towns in Mozambique and Venezuela swept by storms and floods, are beginning to look like pieces in the same ominous jigsaw.

"You can't ever say that a hurricane or a flood or a drought is because of global warming," said one disaster expert yesterday. "What you can say is that global warming makes any of these or all of them more likely."

One of the first predicted results of the greenhouse effect was that a warmer world would be accompanied by a greater frequency of "extreme" events. This is because more heat should mean more evaporation and more wind energy, and therefore more violence.

So far, events have matched predictions with an eerie precision. Islands usually hit by a cyclone once in a century have been pounded four times in a decade. Rivers that used to dry up once every few decades are now failing to reach the sea on 100 or more days a year. Seven of the hottest years ever recorded were in the 1990s and the three next hottest were in the 1980s - and during the last decade the cost of natural disasters added up to four times the bill of the 1980s.

The hottest year of the decade was 1998. It was also, according to the reinsurance giant Munich Re, one of the most expensive, with a total of 80 separate natural catastrophes attributed to the influence of El Nino, a cyclic blister of heat in the Pacific which periodically tips climate patterns upside down, sparking fires in tropical rainforests and floods on barren lands.

That year was marked by terrible floods in China, calamitous ice storms in the US, and a huge pall of smoke and flames over Indonesia. It also saw some of the most destructive hurricanes ever to hit central America, demolishing hillsides and sweeping away villages and cropland.

And Red Cross experts pointed out that the following year, 1999 - the fifth hottest recorded for the planet as a whole - was almost as bad, with floods and windstorms battering communities which were only just beginning to recover from the last wave.

Storms are reported by governments and the news media as single and separate events, but they are not. When winds die down and floodwaters ebb away, life does not return to normal. Victims will have lost their homes, their livestock and their savings, and they will face malnutrition and waterborne diseases.

And a year or two later, when the land is green again, they could also face plagues of locusts. For most of the time, locusts dwell in little groups in arid regions. But every few years, after rain has multiplied the vegetation, they suddenly swarm. One swarm in north Africa in 1988 was measured at 75 miles by 16 miles. It was estimated to contain 150bn insects consuming 300,000 tonnes of greenstuff a day.

"You don't see soil any more, you don't see plants," said one scientist. "It covers everything like a thick, natural fabric. All you hear is chewing."

Scientists working together have helped limit locust plagues around the Mediterranean, and meteorologists warn governments and each other about windstorms and floods, but drought is another matter.

Droughts tend to do their worst on land that is already arid, and where societies are on the margin. In a world where rain is rare, people can cope with a dry year or two, but then, quite quickly, the wells fail, and the livestock begins to die. The first sign of famine is usually a sudden series of grain price rises in local markets. Within weeks, gaunt figures begin to appear on the edges of towns.

Global warming will magnify all these problems. Rising sea levels will multiply storm surges and higher sea surface temperatures will guarantee more frequent hurricanes. But the real cost is likely to be imposed by the failure of rivers and the desiccation of the soil.

Everywhere in the northern hemisphere, glaciers are in retreat. Farmers in India and Pakistan who depend on spring floods face ruin in years to come. The Yellow River - which once flooded so often it was known as China's sorrow - failed to reach the sea on 226 days in 1997. Texas is losing irrigated land at 1% per year.

The problem is magnified even more by population growth. Each year, there are another 80m potential victims, most of them in the developing world.

And Red Cross experts pointed out that the following year, 1999 - the fifth hottest recorded for the planet as a whole - was almost as bad, with floods and windstorms battering communities which were only just beginning to recover from the last wave. Storms are reported by governments and the news media as single and separate events, but they are not. When winds die down and floodwaters ebb away, life does not return to normal. Victims will have lost their homes, their livestock and their savings, and they will face malnutrition and waterborne diseases. And a year or two later, when the land is green again, they could also face plagues of locusts. For most of the time, locusts dwell in little groups in arid regions. But every few years, after rain has multiplied the vegetation, they suddenly swarm. One swarm in north Africa in 1988 was measured at 75 miles by 16 miles. It was estimated to contain 150bn insects consuming 300,000 tonnes of greenstuff a day. "You don't see soil any more, you don't see plants," said one scientist. "It covers everything like a thick, natural fabric. All you hear is chewing." Scientists working together have helped limit locust plagues around the Mediterranean, and meteorologists warn governments and each other about windstorms and floods, but drought is another matter. Droughts tend to do their worst on land that is already arid, and where societies are on the margin. In a world where rain is rare, people can cope with a dry year or two, but then, quite quickly, the wells fail, and the livestock begins to die. The first sign of famine is usually a sudden series of grain price rises in local markets. Within weeks, gaunt figures begin to appear on the edges of towns. Global warming will magnify all these problems. Rising sea levels will multiply storm surges and higher sea surface temperatures will guarantee more frequent hurricanes. But the real cost is likely to be imposed by the failure of rivers and the desiccation of the soil. Everywhere in the northern hemisphere, glaciers are in retreat. Farmers in India and Pakistan who depend on spring floods face ruin in years to come. The Yellow River - which once flooded so often it was known as China's sorrow - failed to reach the sea on 226 days in 1997. Texas is losing irrigated land at 1% per year. The problem is magnified even more by population growth. Each year, there are another 80m potential victims, most of them in the developing world.

webTitle: IRA recruits 'sent to join British army for training'

fields.headline: IRA recruits 'sent to join British army for training'
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA had a policy of getting new recruits to join the British Army in the late 1950s so they could get military training, according to top secret military intelligence reports released yesterday.
fields.body:
The IRA had a policy of getting new recruits to join the British Army in the late 1950s so they could get military training, according to top secret military intelligence reports released yesterday.

The security files released at the Public Record Office also show that British intelligence knew IRA members were working in key British military installations in Northern Ireland, but failed to dismiss them to "save War Office embarrassment".

The monthly reports written by successive directors of military intelligence show that nothing was done about the flow of IRA recruits from southern Ireland joining the army until an IRA attack on the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers' main training camp at Blandford, Dorset, in February 1958.

Military intelligence believed that an IRA man stationed at the camp had acted as an informant and taken part in the attack. Six months later intelligence officers began to vet new army recruits who applied from southern Irish addresses, but a similar attempt to screen Northern Irish recruits for IRA members was blocked by the Stormont government.

Military intelligence was convinced that IRA men "often with their wives or women members of the organisation" visited Northern Ireland posing as tourists to log police movements and the deployment of military personnel and civil flights at Nutt's Corner airport, near Belfast. In April 1959, the IRA chief of staff ordered reconnaissance patrols into Northern Ireland to report on the security forces.

The monthly security reports, which were circulated to only the 20 most senior figures in Whitehall, including the cabinet's joint intelligence committee, put the strength of the IRA in the late 1950s at about 1,000 in Eire and about 100 men operating in Northern Ireland.

In May 1957 the director of military intelligence reported: "There are 14 known IRA members and active sympathisers employed in military installations in Northern Ireland... the RUC advised the dismissal of these employees on the logical grounds that their presence in military units would make these units more vulnerable to IRA attacks.

"However as they are civilian employees it has been decided that, rather than stir up trouble through their dismissal, the risk caused by their presence has to be accepted."

Again in October 1957 he complained of "20 cases" in the army. "This gives strength to the belief that members of the IRA sometimes join the British Army to gain military training and to be in a position to give information about camps and guards with a view to future attacks.

It was only after the attack on the REME training headquarters at Blandford that the army began to vet applications from potential recruits from Dublin.

A proposal to extend the circulation of the monthly security reports from 20 copies to 150 key people in Whitehall and Belfast was met with the threat from the RUC that if that happened, they would no longer share their intelligence.

"It would be extremely difficult to persuade the Ulster authorities that so wide a distribution can be made without considerable risk that some nationalist-minded person would come to see it," the head of MI5 (whose name is deleted from the file) told Brigadier C H Tarver, the deputy director of military intelligence.
