fields.headline: David Merrick
fields.standfirst: The New York producer, known as the 'abominable showman', whose populist taste brought joy to Broadway audiences
fields.trailText: Gentlemen don't produce great Broadway shows, but at least the "abominable showman", producer David Merrick, who has died in London aged 88, was often pleasant while being dictatorial.
fields.body:
Gentlemen don't produce great Broadway shows, but at least the "abominable showman", producer David Merrick, who has died in London aged 88, was often pleasant while being dictatorial. Ominously dressed in a Homberg hat, with a metal-tipped cane, dark moustache and eternal scowl, he could hire or fire, add or delete songs, but still inspire loyalty.

Even the Broadway actress and singer Patti LuPone couldn't speak ill of him, despite the constant threats to her big break in the musical The Baker's Wife. Her standout number, Meadowlark, arrived, departed and returned after Merrick insisted the song be cut and the composer, Stephen Schwarz, had to resort to legal measures to get it restored. According to LuPone, Merrick felt that the audience didn't want to listen to a seven-minute song at that point in the show. She went on to make Meadowlark one of her signature songs. "He might've been a shark but he was nice to everyone," she observed of Merrick. "I thought he was a cool guy."

Apparently, a small army of carpenters, electricians and songwriters felt the same way, since he often worked with the same people over his quarter-century heyday from 1955-80, during which he produced the bulk of his 80 shows. These ranged from Peter Brook's Marat/Sade to the Gian Carlo Menotti opera Maria Golovin, and also included Look Back In Anger, Jamaica, Beckett, Carnival, Oliver! Philadelphia Here I Come, I Do, I Do, Gypsy, Hello Dolly!, Promises Promises and 42nd Street. Merrick was best known for his populist, Broadway-centred touch, which often took the form of shows with titles ending in exclamation marks.

Merrick was full of unexpected flourishes, such as closing Hello Dolly! as a successful production starring Carol Channing and reopening it with an all-black cast starring Pearl Bailey. Most revealing, perhaps, are the musicals he didn't produce, or might have thought better of. In its pre-Broadway tour, he predicted that Gypsy, which signalled the beginning of smarter, more book-driven musicals, would flop. He also turned down a chance to invest in Cats.

Merrick offered a revealing critique of Stephen Sondheim's high-concept Follies, a musical about ageing showgirls in midlife crisis. He believed the public didn't want to see show folk having mundane problems. "It's simply a subject that doesn't interest anyone," he told Craig Zaden in the book Sondheim & Co. "When they got to all the razzle-dazzle at the end, the cheap stuff, I was interested."

With such singular views - and the success that they brought - he developed peculiar ways of getting things done. Again, the gestation of The Baker's Wife showed Merrick at his bossiest. According to one account, he had Meadowlark removed in a performance at Washington DC's Kennedy Center, but the cast, conductor and orchestra only discovered in mid-performance that all the orchestral parts were suddenly missing. Merrick never admitted to taking the disappearing pages, but according to press agent Josh Ellis he cryptically said, "Perhaps the FBI can find our meadowlark." By LuPone's account, the incident happened in Boston where Merrick was overheard saying at the local bar that he'd get rid of the song even "if I have to poison the birdseed". He apparently visited the orchestra pit before the show, helped himself to the music, locked it in a briefcase and returned to New York. Nice? Hardly. Expedient? Certainly. And, in his own way, full of honorable intentions. According to Ellis, Merrick adored the theatre.

Like many who personify New York, he came from elsewhere - St Louis, to be exact - and had so little regard for his birthplace he later said he refused to even fly over it. Raised by one of his sisters after his parents Samuel and Celia Margulois divorced when he was a child, he saw every touring show he could, and at Washington University in St Louis, won a playwriting contest ahead of Tennessee Williams. He also earned a law degree before changing his name from Margulois to Merrick and moving to New York in 1939.

Unlike many producers who get started with family money, Merrick slowly built up his resources with modest profits from show investments. By 1954, he not only had his first Broadway musical hit with Fanny, but his first battle with the critics.

He overrode negative reviews with publicity stunts. Many more were to follow, the most famous in conjunction with the musical Subways Are For Sleeping: he found several New Yorkers with the same names as the major critics and quoted their positive testimonies in his advertisements. He claimed to hate hype, but admitted that "if people can sell junk to the public that way, why can't I sell them a good play that way?"

By 1980, the year of 42nd Street - and the death of legendary director Gower Champion, which Merrick announced from the stage on opening night - the producer seemed to want to quit while he was so far ahead of all the others. If he had future plans, they were shattered by a stroke. There was talk and even legal measures taken to have him declared mentally incompetent; he responded by leaving the convalescent centre by himself in a wheelchair despite pouring rain. Unable to speak as a result of a stroke, he gave written instructions to strangers to have his lawyer fetch him. And though Merrick remained impaired, he had a number of helpers who could interpret his intentions from his monosyllabic exclamations; those included Natalie Lloyd, who became his sixth wife early this year.

Working in such fashion, he produced two more shows, George Gershwin's Oh, Kay! and a stage adaptation of the Rodgers & Hammerstein film, State Fair. When the Tony Award committee limited that show's eligibility in the spring of 1996, Merrick declared that he would start his own awards show, named after him, of course. It came to nothing, but at the time a spokesman said, "I'm a famous man and I believe my name should be carried into perpetuity." As if he needed to worry.

Merrick was married to Leonore Beck, Jeanne Gilbert, Etan Aronson (twice) and Karen Prunczik, and finally to his current wife Natalie, who survives him, as do his two daughters from his marriages to Gilbert and Aronson.

 David Merrick, producer, born November 27 1911; died April 25 2000

fields.headline: Gerald Thirst
fields.trailText: Gerald Thirst, who has died aged 84, was a legendary music man who stood at the helm of Norfolk's brass bands for a record-breaking 50 years. Although he worked with the Norwich Lads Club Band, Sprowston Band, and Taverham Bands, his main achievement was to re-establish the Stalham Brass Band, the oldest band in East Anglia, after the second world war.
fields.body:
Gerald Thirst, who has died aged 84, was a legendary music man who stood at the helm of Norfolk's brass bands for a record-breaking 50 years. Although he worked with the Norwich Lads Club Band, Sprowston Band, and Taverham Bands, his main achievement was to re-establish the Stalham Brass Band, the oldest band in East Anglia, after the second world war. With that band he notched up more than 1,000 performances, leading the players in charity concerts, Armistice day appearances, and Christmas carol tours.

Thirst devoted his life to music. As a schoolboy, he took up the cornet, but switched to the euphonium for the rest of his life.

Born in Stalham, Norfolk Thirst went to Paston Grammar School, and in 1932 became a clerk for the Midland and Great Northern railways - apart from the war years he spent his working life on the railways. During the second world war, Thirst served in the Royal Navy, rising to petty officer telegraphist, and serving on HMS Cold streamer, an escort for fast North Atlantic convoys.

Back in Stalham, he became a relief station master - which took him to every station in the region - and set about rebuilding the Stalham Brass Band as its players gradually returned from the war. He also provided entertainment in the area with his own dance band, the Skyliners. It was through their joint love of music that he met his wife Yvonne, when she joined the dance band.

In 1978, Thirst started working with the Stalham Middle School Brass Band, which I conduct, coming in each week on a voluntary basis. His reward was to see young musicians progress. Some of the young players even bestowed on him the title of honorary grandfather.

By the time of his retirement, he was head of the technical section at British Rail's Norwich base. In 1999, The Guinness Book of World Records acknowledged him as the longest serving musical conductor. He was made an MBE in this year's New Year's honours list for his services to music. His last engagement with the Stalham Brass Band was for a Hymns Of Praise CD.

He is survived by Yvonne and his son Tim, the present musical director of the Stalham Brass Band.

 Gerald Thirst, musician and conductor, born October 29 1915; died April 1 2000

fields.headline: Roger Pethybridge
fields.standfirst: Historian who explored the Russia of 'icons and cockroaches'
fields.trailText: The distinctive feature of the later work of Russian specialist Roger Pethybridge, who has died aged 65 following a stroke, was that, while other scholars were concentrating their research on Russia's capital cities, he gave due attention to the provinces - to what Leon Trotsky called "the Russia of icons and cockroaches" Other western specialists gradually followed his lead.
fields.body:
The distinctive feature of the later work of Russian specialist Roger Pethybridge, who has died aged 65 following a stroke, was that, while other scholars were concentrating their research on Russia's capital cities, he gave due attention to the provinces - to what Leon Trotsky called "the Russia of icons and cockroaches" Other western specialists gradually followed his lead.

Pethybridge was the author of A History Of Postwar Russia (1966), which was to remain in print for more than 30 years. His major work on Soviet "high politics" was A Key To Soviet Politics: The Crisis Of The Anti-Party Group, in 1962. It was in that year too that he edited Witnesses To The Russian Revolution, which heralded his shift towards the study of politics from below.

Pethybridge joined what was to become the University of Wales Swansea as a lecturer in 1963. He became director of the new Centre for Russian and East European Studies in 1972 and was awarded a personal chair in politics in 1975.

During those prolific years in Swansea his major published work included editing The Development Of The Communist Bloc (1965), and writing The Spread Of The Russian Revolution: Essays On 1917 (1972), which examined the role of transport and communications in disseminating the two revolutions of 1917. In The Social Prelude To Stalinism (1974), he dealt with the tensions between the Bolsheviks' large-scale theories and Russia's recalcitrant small-scale realities; and One Step Backwards, Two Steps Forward: Soviet Society And Politics Under The New Economic Policy (1990), looked at Smolensk, Tver and Kazakhstan in the 1920s.

Pethybridge was born in Skipton in Yorkshire and educated at Sedbergh School. He learned Russian on national service (1953-55). A gifted linguist, he won an open scholarship to read French and German at Worcester College Oxford, but initially read Italian (with distinction), Russian and Spanish before graduating with honours in modern history in 1958.

After an exchange course at Moscow University in 1958, he chose to go to Geneva as assistant to the Soviet director of the World Health Organisation in 1959. While in Geneva he completed a doctorate, in 1961, at the Graduate School of International Studies on the post-Stalin succession struggle, which became A Key To Soviet Politics. A Rockefeller Foundation fellowship at Columbia University in New York and at Harvard University followed. Then came Swansea.

In 1982-83, he held a Social Science Research Council research award when he was a visiting fellow at the Kennan Institute in Washington and at the Rockefeller Foundation Institute in Bellagio. In 1989 and 1992, he spent several months lecturing at the University of Otago, in Dunedin, New Zealand. His most influential academic work focused on the years from 1917-27.

Pethybridge was widely travelled. He spoke of writing a book about his philosophy of travel. His peregrinations sometimes put him at risk - as when a surface-to-air missile narrowly missed his plane as it flew out of Kabul in 1980. A lover of the fine arts, classical music and opera, he had special affection for the operas of Janacek. He also became seriously interested in mysticism and "the chain of being".

He was fond of sauna baths and swimming, until a skiing injury in his 50s led to hip problems. He refused on principle to have a hip replacement performed privately, and the ensuing wait had a visible effect on his health. But he made a strong recovery and regained his youthful looks and vigour.

His reserved and sometimes patrician demeanour masked innate modesty and kindness. Sensitive, a champion of those less fortunate than himself, he knew a wide circle of people in Swansea and around the world, and many enjoyed his sometimes lavish hospitality at the elegant house in which he spent his last 17 years and where croquet on the lawn sometimes continued by candlelight.

Soon after his elevation to an emeritus professorship last December, he was applauded at the university court of governors after his short but eloquent speech protesting against the continuing transfer of power from academic to executive bodies in universities.

In 1977, he was elected to the Atheneum club. He always took pride in his Yorkshire and Celtic origins. Roger was single, but for many years he had been particularly close to Carys Kneath.

 Roger William Pethybridge, historian, born March 28 1934; died March 27 2000

Sensitive, a champion of those less fortunate than himself, he knew a wide circle of people in Swansea and around the world, and many enjoyed his sometimes lavish hospitality at the elegant house in which he spent his last 17 years and where croquet on the lawn sometimes continued by candlelight. Soon after his elevation to an emeritus professorship last December, he was applauded at the university court of governors after his short but eloquent speech protesting against the continuing transfer of power from academic to executive bodies in universities. In 1977, he was elected to the Atheneum club. He always took pride in his Yorkshire and Celtic origins. Roger was single, but for many years he had been particularly close to Carys Kneath.  Roger William Pethybridge, historian, born March 28 1934; died March 27 2000

fields.headline: Clifford Forsythe
fields.standfirst: Hardline Unionist MP and critic of quangos
fields.trailText: Clifford Forsythe, who has died aged 70, was Ulster Unionist MP for South Antrim, and very much a traditional Unionist. Both his approach and demeanour, like those of the now ennobled Lord Molyneaux, seemed to belong to a different era. But Forsythe was also an exception in Northern Ireland politics, resolutely shunning publicity. As one pundit said: "He was the only MP who could abstain in person."
fields.body:
Clifford Forsythe, who has died aged 70, was Ulster Unionist MP for South Antrim, and very much a traditional Unionist. Both his approach and demeanour, like those of the now ennobled Lord Molyneaux, seemed to belong to a different era. But Forsythe was also an exception in Northern Ireland politics, resolutely shunning publicity. As one pundit said: "He was the only MP who could abstain in person."

He was opposed to the Good Friday Agreement and a staunch supporter of Union First, the hardline movement of Ulster Unionists responsible for many of current leader David Trimble's difficulties.

One of the ironies is that four years ago Forsythe was targeted in a failed deselection bid by the "baby barristers", now leading lights in Union First but then Trimble loyalists. In last month's challenge to Trimble, Forsythe voted for Rev Smyth, MP for south Belfast.

Forsyth was rarely agitated when disappointments hit him, or much excited by success. He was, however, unfailingly courteous, and took great pride in his dapper appearance. And he did have a hinterland. He had even been a fine, speedy winger who had played Irish League professional football in the postwar era for both Linfield, predominantly protestant, and Derry City, a catholic club, and won several medals. It illustrated, said his friends, Forsythe's practical approach to religious differences.

Forsythe was, as many were in the days of the old Stormont regime, virtually born into the Ulster Unionist Party and to the Orange Order, where he was to become assistant grand master to MP Martin Smyth nine years ago.

He built up a successful plumbing business, and was Jim Molyneaux's agent when he represented the old south Antrim constituency. After boundary reorganisation in 1983 created an extra seat, Forsythe succeeded the then UU leader as the party's standard-bearer in the new area after Molyneaux moved to the neighbouring Lagan Valley seat.

Forsythe was a mayor of Newtonabbey in 1983, and member of Newtonabbey borough council from 1981-85. He also sat on the Northern Ireland assembly from 1982-86.

His great love was the choir at the Church of Ireland in Templepatrick, and he was also said to be a star turn at Madam Speaker's Christmas function. His party colleagues would always wait for him to set the key at the end of Ulster Unionist Council meetings, when delegates joined him to sing the national anthem.

He had a reputation as an assiduous constituency MP, concentrating mainly on local issues, but he was nonetheless the only Northern Ireland MP to win a place on a select committee (overseeing environment, transport and regional affairs) in the current parliament, apart from the Northern Ireland select committee.

He was also seen as an expert on social services, having previously sat on that select committee, and took particular interest in local government. His own publication was Quangopus Government, a highly critical report on the quangos which flourished in Northern Ireland under direct rule.

Intensely private, he declined even to enter details of his family in Who's Who. He was twice married and had five children.

fields.headline: Letters
fields.body:
Bob Miller writes: Family And Kinship In East London by Peter Willmott (obituary April 19) and Michael Young was a work of art for a great many students in the 1960-70s, and one which brought a whole population to prominence. Willmott's "dislike of bullshit" referred to by Young would most certainly have been endorsed by his research in Bethnal Green and Dagenham, where it is de rigueur among the people, to speak as they see it.

As an "Old Dagonian", I well remember the book Evolution Of A Community, and how Dagenham was described as a "lovely place" in 1963. It fitted my experience as a youth growing up there during this period. The family and kinship never leaves us and on behalf of all who knew Peter Willmott or his works, thank you for a job well done, in touching so many lives.

Dr M M Winter writes: Your obituary of Prof W D McHardy (April 24), contained one small inaccuracy. His doctorate in 1943 was not about the Book of Ecclesiastes, but Ecclesiasticus. He prepared the first ever study for a critical edition of the Syriac translation of that book. Wartime conditions made it impossible for him to consult manuscripts outside the British Isles, or indeed to publish the work. However, 30 years later when I was engaged upon the same field of research - I was a lecturer in Syriac at University College London - he allowed me to consult his thesis. When the complete critical text of Ecclesiasticus in Syriac is published by the Peshitta Institute of the University of Leiden, McHardy's work will receive public recognition.

webTitle: Missing Briton buried in error by Italian family

fields.headline: Missing Briton buried in error by Italian family
fields.trailText: A British tourist who died of a heart attack while on holiday was mistakenly buried by an Italian family who thought he was their relative.
fields.body:
A British tourist who died of a heart attack while on holiday was mistakenly buried by an Italian family who thought he was their relative.

Benjamin Cooper, 63, from south west London, disappeared while on a day trip to Sicily from Malta on October 9 last year.

His wife Joan, 60, who had stayed in Britain because of her fear of flying, only found out her husband was dead five months later when the supposedly deceased Italian man turned up at his family's home alive and well.

The family had apparently been confused by Mr Cooper's dark skin and hair, and wrongly identified the body after it was found by police.

Mr Cooper, who suffered from angina, had split off from his tour group, then collapsed and died of a heart attack.

Mrs Cooper, who was distraught when the travel firm Thomson reported that her husband was missing, is fighting to overturn an Italian law banning exhumation for 22 months, so that she can re-bury her husband in Britain.

"He always looked like he was of foreign origin," she said. "He went very dark in the hot weather and had very dark hair."

A Foreign Office spokeswoman said: "The Italian man had been reported missing in Calabria and somehow the family managed to identify Mr Cooper's body as his.

"They immediately alerted the authorities when their relative walked in through the front door. It is not known where he had been.

"We have been in touch with Mr Cooper's family and the local magistrate to appoint an undertaker at this end and get Mr Cooper's papers ready.

"Our consulate in Naples is also trying to get an exemption on the burial rule."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Guardian stand wins support
fields.body:
Guardian stand wins support

The Commonwealth Press Union has joined the International Press Institute and the Society of Editors to express concern over the government's attempts to force the Guardian and the Observer to surrender material concerning former MI5 officer David Shayler.

The newspapers are challenging a judge's order to hand over any documents or emails relating to Mr Shayler, particularly his claim MI6 was involved in a plot to assassinate Libyan leader Colonel Gadafy.

Skaters get new honour

Ice skaters Jane Torvill and Christopher Dean returned to Buckingham Palace yesterday to collect OBEs to add to the MBEs they received almost 20 years ago.

The pair won gold at the Sarajevo Olympics in1984 for their interpretation of Ravel's Bolero.

Potter in line for prize

JK Rowling's third novel about her boy wizard, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, has been shortlisted for the Carnegie Medal, the UK's oldest children's book prize.

The novel won this year's Whitbread Children's Book of the Year and came a close second to Irish poet Seamus Heaney's Beowulf in the competition's overall book of the year category.

£5,000 for Xmas card

A 1966 Christmas card from John Lennon to Beatles' manager Brian Epstein fetched £5,405 at Christie's in London yesterday.

The hand-drawn card, saying Happy Christian Brian from John, was an ironic reference to Epstein's Jewish faith. Epstein's 18 carat gold watch went for £2,820 and three of his 1957 notebooks, giving a frank account of his homosexuality, made £3,290. But the bulk of an archive of diaries and notebooks failed to find buyers.

All in the mind

Hypnosis can reduce pain during surgery when patients are not given general anaesthetic, a study has found.

Researchers who studied 241 patients during minor operations found those who were hypnotised were more comfortable than those just comforted by nurses, according to the research led by Elvira Lang, of Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Centre, Boston, in the United States.

Ones that got away

Thieves drained 35,000 gallons of water from a fish pond in Hagley, Worcestershire, to steal 30 Japanese koi carp worth thousands of pounds, West Mercia police said yesterday.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman
fields.body:
 My old friend Jack Straw is in a shocking bate and demands corrections from several papers, this one included. "There have been a number of newspaper reports which describe my shaking hands with refugees and even climbing into the back of a lorry with them," said Jack yesterday while he was out canvassing for poor Dobbo, referring to his visit to Dover on Wednesday. "But you know what? It's all untrue... The articles were all made up. There were no photographs of me to corroborate the allegations." Corroborate the allegations... a lovely phrase to express his horror at the idea that a Labour home secretary with Jewish antecedents treated terrified people caught in the back of a lorry with as basic a gesture of human acknowledgement as a handshake. And it's hardly as if these immigrants had any genuine reason to seek sanctuary, such as fleeing some war-ravaged hell hole. They're Kosovans. While the corrections column considers how to make reparations, perhaps I might have the privilege of being the first to tell you, Jack, how thoroughly ashamed you make us feel.

 A reference on last week's Da Ali G Show continues to bemuse. After ruing the failure to get Mr Tony to appear, Ali said: "Get me the one who married that woman so people would think he was not batty." At Tory central office, press officer Andrew Scadding insists "it has nothing to do with us whatsoever", and quite right. What does concern Andrew and his colleagues is issuing press releases about the leader's movements, and one of these arrived yesterday. "Itineray for the Rt Hon Willaim Hague MP" it reads. Mm.

 In one of the craftiest stunts even New Labour has pulled, a "public consultation" about a highly contentious issue has been held in absolute secrecy. Not a soul has a clue, it seems, that the consultation about the Dome was held from April 8-24, an incredibly short time by any standards, let alone with the Easter break that came in the middle of it. If you didn't know better, you might almost imagine that the minister responsible, Chubby Falconer, wants the thing off his hands as quickly and quietly as possible... by flogging it on the cheap to a bidder such as Sportzone, for instance, a consortium including Sky TV. Might they expect a cheap new sports studio out of it? We shall see.

Sadly, there is no room today for news of www.ruthgledhill.com, the inaugural Website of the Month run by and for Times religion correspondent Ruth Gledhill and her husband and ballroom-dancing partner, Andrew. When we return to the matter next week, we will learn that the late actor Basil Rathbone was Ruth's cousin, and revisit her 16th birthday party... an event on no account to be missed.

On Nicky Campbell's Radio 5 show, Swindon MP Julia Drown brutally attacks Mr Tony. Asked if he should take time off for the baby, Julia expresses distaste for people who make personal matters public. Ouch. Mr T and Cherie have remorselessly publicised the issue, but when my colleague Kate Morris rings to congratulate Julia on her courage, she seems bemused. "But Tony's been forced to make these comments under pressure from the media." Now Julia, sledgehammer irony is a fine thing in its place, but it's hardly going to get you on the frontbench, is it? "Tony does try to keep his children and family private as much as he can..." No more, Julia, you're slaying us. Stop it!

 Let's hear it for Andorra! The tiny mountain state won the first international football match in its history on Wednesday night. Andorra, a "semi-feudal co-principality" according to the World Almanack, with a population of 57,000, and tobacco laundering as its main industry, astoundingly beat mighty Belarus (population: 10m) 2-0 in the Pyrenees.

webTitle: Unita's surprise offensive deepens refugee crisis revival threatens humanitarian crisis

fields.headline: Unita's surprise offensive deepens refugee crisis revival threatens humanitarian crisis
fields.trailText: Heavy fighting has erupted in eastern Angola just as the UN warns that the humanitarian situation in the country is alarming and threatens to deteriorate into crisis.
fields.body:
Heavy fighting has erupted in eastern Angola just as the UN warns that the humanitarian situation in the country is alarming and threatens to deteriorate into crisis.

Ten days ago Unita rebels, scattered after the taking of their headquarters late last year, regrouped and launched a counter-offensive on government troops in the east of Angola near the border with Zambia and Democratic Republic of Congo.

The intensity of the new offensive around the small town of Lumbala Nguimbo, which has changed hands already twice this year, took the Angolan military by surprise. It appears to confirm recent intelligence reports that Unita has recently received new military supplies despite the tightening of UN sanctions on the rebels last month.

In March a UN report into sanctions-breaking strongly criticised the leaders of Burkina Faso and Togo as the major conduits for the trade in arms for diamonds which keeps the Unita rebellion alive. This new resupply by night flights is presumed to involve stocks of arms for Unita still held in those countries and flown via Zambia into the most remote part of Angola.

Reports of the new military supplies will bring a major diplomatic row in the region. Togo is set to host the Organisation of African Unity annual summit in late June and will then become chairman for the next year, but countries in the regional organisation, SADCC, are already discussing a possible boycott of Togo because of President Gnasingbe Eyadema's support for Unita's leader, Jonas Savimbi.

After the fall of his headquarters in Andulo in the Central Highlands, Mr Savimbi designated Lumbala Nguimbo as his new headquarters, although Unita has been unable to consolidate its troops there because of government forces nearby. The area is bush and savannah, flooded during the rainy season and only accessible by canoe.

The eastern border is one of the many insecure areas the UN's humanitarian mission has not been able to reach in its recent research into the current level of malnutrition, sickness and deprivation. Thousands of refugees have fled from the area into Zambia in recent weeks, many in a very poor state.

The UN's new report, issued by the UN humanitarian office in Luanda, is the first to look at many places which have been inaccessible under Unita control. The report says aid shipments across Angola must quickly be increased and thousands of displaced people moved out of badly run temporary shelters where sanitary conditions are terrible.

Airstrips, roads and bridges need urgent repair for the agencies to be able to reach people.

The government estimates the fighting has uprooted some 3.8m people - about a third of the population. Many of them are living in makeshift camps and almost all rely on aid to survive.

Most at risk are children, widows, the handicapped and war-mutilated people. "These groups are on the edge of an abyss", the report said.

Among the worst affected areas are in Huambo province in the Central Highlands where Unita had control over large areas until late last year. Some families in Chipipa in the Central Highlands are surviving on larvae and grass, the UN says.

In Caala, Ukuma, Longonjo and Chipipa the condition of of the displaced was some of the worst encountered during the assessment. In Ukuma and Longonjo, both of which have become accessible only this month, people are clearly short of food and in Ukuma, child malnutrition can be seen. Sanitary conditions in the Caala transit centre are appalling. The 5,000 displaced persons living there should be immediately resettled.

The majority of displaced persons are completely dependent upon food assistance, unable to feed themselves because they have no agricultural land, seeds, tools, fertilisers and other resources.

Most people, whether newly arrived or long-term, do not own the essential items they need to survive, including plastic sheeting, blankets, soap, buckets and clothing.

Few non-food contingency stocks are available and almost none are pre-positioned in areas where further displacement is expected. More than half of the displaced persons living in camps have inadequate shelter.

The majority of displaced persons and other at-risk groups do not have access to safe drinking water.

None of the hospitals or health posts visited had sufficient essential medicines and many had no medicine at all, the UN reported. Children throughout the country have not been vaccinated against life-threatening diseases.

The UN this year is asking donors for an estimated £164m for Angola, more than double last year's £70m.

Sanitary conditions in the Caala transit centre are appalling. The 5,000 displaced persons living there should be immediately resettled. The majority of displaced persons are completely dependent upon food assistance, unable to feed themselves because they have no agricultural land, seeds, tools, fertilisers and other resources. Most people, whether newly arrived or long-term, do not own the essential items they need to survive, including plastic sheeting, blankets, soap, buckets and clothing. Few non-food contingency stocks are available and almost none are pre-positioned in areas where further displacement is expected. More than half of the displaced persons living in camps have inadequate shelter. The majority of displaced persons and other at-risk groups do not have access to safe drinking water. None of the hospitals or health posts visited had sufficient essential medicines and many had no medicine at all, the UN reported. Children throughout the country have not been vaccinated against life-threatening diseases. The UN this year is asking donors for an estimated £164m for Angola, more than double last year's £70m.

fields.headline: Nuclear accident claims new death
fields.trailText: A second worker exposed to dangerously high levels of radiation during Japan's worst nuclear accident last September died yesterday morning at a hospital in Tokyo.
fields.body:
A second worker exposed to dangerously high levels of radiation during Japan's worst nuclear accident last September died yesterday morning at a hospital in Tokyo.

Masato Shinohara, 40, died of multiple organ failure, doctors said. He had been connected to a respirator since February, after his condition worsened.

Mr Shinohara was one of two employees of the nuclear fuel company JCO exposed to massive levels of radiation during the accident on September 30 at the firm's uranium processing plant in Tokaimura, 80 miles north-east of Tokyo. Mr Shinohara and Hisashi Ouchi set off an uncontrolled chain reaction after mistakenly pouring too much uranium into a processing tank.

Mr Ouchi, 35, died last December, becoming the first fatality in Japan's civil nuclear power programme. A third worker, Yutaka Yokokawa, who was in an adjacent room when the accident occurred, was released from hospital the same month.

Yoshiro Mori, the prime minister, described Mr Shinohara's death as "extremely regrettable", and vowed to continue tightening up safety at Japan's nuclear power facilities. Hirofumi Nakasone, head of the science and technology agency, visited the hospital yesterday morning to offer the government's condolences to Mr Shinohara's family.

Doctors at Tokyo University Hospital, where Mr Shinohara had been treated since April 10, paid tribute to his courage. Kazuhiko Maekawa, head of the hospital's intensive care unit, said treating Mr Shinohara had made him aware of the limitations of medical science. "I was overwhelmed by a sense of helplessness in the face of something caused by human arrogance," he said.

At one point, Mr Shinohara's condition had shown signs of improvement. He received a blood transfusion in October, and on New Year's Day was well enough to venture into the garden at Tokyo University's institute of medical science in his wheelchair. In late February, however, doctors placed him on a respirator when pneumonia and radiation damage to his respiratory system brought on severe breathing difficulties.

Mr Shinohara, was married, with three children. He joined JCO's predecessor in 1984. Two years ago, he was placed in charge of processing nuclear fuel for the Joyo fast-breeder nuclear reactor not far from the Tokaimura plant.

webTitle: 55 more cult bodies found in Uganda

fields.headline: 55 more cult bodies found in Uganda
fields.trailText: Ugandan police exhumed 55 bodies from a grave yesterday in the grounds of a Kampala house used by a leader of the doomsday cult believed to have murdered more than 900 of its followers.
fields.body:
Ugandan police exhumed 55 bodies from a grave yesterday in the grounds of a Kampala house used by a leader of the doomsday cult believed to have murdered more than 900 of its followers.

Police spokesman Assuman Mugenyi said that the rows of black plastic bags laid outside the bungalow contained the bodies of 22 women, 15 men, 10 boys and eight girls. He said the bodies had been in the ground for more than a month but it was not clear how the victims were killed.

The house in Ggaba, just south of Kampala, had been rented by Dominic Kataribabo, a defrocked Roman Catholic priest in whose compound in the south-western village of Rugzai 155 bodies were exhumed on March 28 and 29. Those bodies were part of 394 exhumations found in and around the houses owned or rented by leaders of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God. The bodies were in addition to an estimated 530 believed to have burned during a March 17 fire in a church at the cult's headquarters in Kanungu.

Neighbours of the Ggaba house said yesterday that four women and two boys had been living in the small brick house until March 14. They said Kataribabo, who may have perished in the Kanungu fire, had been a regular visitor at the house and busloads of people would go there to pray.

fields.headline: No bar on fees, please
fields.trailText: It is good to see a newspaper trying to get beyond the lazy and inaccurate "fat cat" stereotype of barristers (Rough justice, G2, April 26). Barristers are a key public resource. The profession is a unique reservoir of skill in advocacy - the most important skill for justice alongside good judges. They are efficient and cheap.
fields.body:
It is good to see a newspaper trying to get beyond the lazy and inaccurate "fat cat" stereotype of barristers (Rough justice, G2, April 26). Barristers are a key public resource. The profession is a unique reservoir of skill in advocacy - the most important skill for justice alongside good judges. They are efficient and cheap.

The government must recognise these things when reforming legal aid. The bar council certainly has. We have spent our time and money developing transparent and economical fee systems - called graduated fees - which the government has accepted is the best structure for reforming legal aid. The government's job is to make sure that legally aided barristers are paid reasonably. We need to ensure the future of the independent bar, not watch these skilled people fade away or be captured by big organisations with financial targets to meet.
Stephen Irwin QC
Chairman, bar council remuneration committee

 Linda Grant tells us that barristers are suffering poverty and the bar itself is on the way out I first heard this in the sixties from a barrister friend. The bar had lost divorce and other markets and decline was a mathematical certainty. But my friend's maths turned out wrong: the bar went on to triple in numbers and its earnings rocketed up. I stayed in a company job, ending at £30,000 a year while he became a judge - regarded by the bar as the low-earnings option - a mere £90,000 a year, plus a huge safe pension.

Yes, when the Queen is sprinting down the Mall with her corgis followed by a raging mob, when London passes out of the ownership of the Duke of Westminster - then maybe the bar too will be under threat. But until then - poor, threatened barristers - puh-lease.
George Stern
London

fields.headline: A plague on that Hague
fields.trailText: As one of the few people who supported the Conservative party at the last general election, it is with a sense of disbelief that I now find myself unable to do so in the forthcoming local elections (Self-defence broadside backfires on Hague, April 27). The ill thought out reactionary statements which have followed the Tony Martin case, alongside the stance on asylum seekers, show the party and Mr Hague's leadership in an extremely bad light.
fields.body:
As one of the few people who supported the Conservative party at the last general election, it is with a sense of disbelief that I now find myself unable to do so in the forthcoming local elections (Self-defence broadside backfires on Hague, April 27). The ill thought out reactionary statements which have followed the Tony Martin case, alongside the stance on asylum seekers, show the party and Mr Hague's leadership in an extremely bad light. To win - or even perform respectably - in the general election, the party needs to gain some form of maturity. This will not occur whilst it indulges in reactionary student politics. If someone who has always voted Conservative now feels unable to do so, it begs the question - who will?
Jonathan Kirby
Sheffield

 If William Hague really thinks Norfolk farmers have the right to defend their homes by keeping a loaded gun in the house and shooting intruders, he should surely campaign to extend that right to everyone in the UK. After all, if you are burgled in London it is just as unlikely that the police will arrive in time to protect you. With every home in the realm containing a loaded weapon, I'm sure we'll all rest much easier. I notice that Hague used the same speech to demand that convicts serve their full sentences - so life should mean life for Tony Martin then? If anyone has found a plot lying around, please return it to Mr Hague.
Colin Williamson
London

 If there is no such thing as a society, then every man is for himself and he has to defend himself and his property - and that is what Mr Hague is promising he will allow us to do. We received our tax cuts and now we can spend it on our own security, education and health.
J Prajapati
London
prajapati@breathemail.net

 Let me think this through. The last government had the worst record in history on controlling rising crime. This means any Conservative authority represents a threat to the security of my home and family. Therefore, if I am doorstepped by a Conservative candidate in the run up to the local elections, I am entitled to shoot them.
Richard Lindley
Brighton
rllindley@brighton2.fsnet.co.uk

 Some years ago, driving to our apartment in Austin, Texas, I listened to a radio discussion about the fact that in the previous year 150,000 people had died of gunshot wounds in the US, and only six in the UK. Perhaps William Hague should undertake a fact-finding tour into how to shoot intruders dead, not to mention close relatives and fellow pupils. On his return he could organise training courses in how to shoot people in the back.
Robert Dyson
Kenilworth, Warks

 If a Gypsy caught two strangers roaming around his site at night, apparently intent on mischief, and shot them both in the back, one fatally, would Max Clifford, the Mail, the Sun and William Hague be so quick to leap to the defence of the killer?
Ray Woodcraft
Leeds

 Given William Hague's conversion to the cause of self-defence and the Tory party's horror at being labelled racist by the Steve Norris campaign (Tory core is racist says Norris team, April 26), can we now trust that he will join the call to free Satpal Ram? An Asian defending himself from racist thugs whilst eating in a restaurant is surely at least as worthy a cause as that of a bigoted vigilante?
Dr Keith Halfacree
Swansea
K.H.Halfacree@swansea.ac.uk

 Hague and his gang of populist bigots are renewing my faith in Labour almost daily.
Tom Freeman
Cambridge
tomafreeman@hotmail.com

fields.trailText: Some residents of Leeds LS29 were startled to read in the banner above the masthead on page 1 yesterday that theirs was the postcode with the most burglaries in Britain. We should have said, as we did in the inside story, Leeds LS2 9.
fields.body:
Some residents of Leeds LS29 were startled to read in the banner above the masthead on page 1 yesterday that theirs was the postcode with the most burglaries in Britain. We should have said, as we did in the inside story, Leeds LS2 9.

One of the climbers who died in a fall in Glencoe last weekend was wrongly named as Andrew MacKenzie, page 9, April 25.

He was Alexander MacKenzie. The wrong name was supplied by an agency. We took a few years off the age of rock drummer Roger Taylor when we said he was 40 on April 26 (Birthdays, page 24). He was born on July 26 1949.

The director of the film The Double Life of Veronique is Krzysztof Kieslowski. We attributed it to Andzrej Wyslocksi in a Travel piece, page 4, April 22.

Lou Donaldson appeared at the Jazz Cafe in London last week with Dr Lonnie Smith, who has played with him for many years, not Lonnie Liston Smith, as we said in a review, page 19, April 24.

The Idlewild album reviewed on April 21, page 16, G2 is called 100 Broken Windows, not 200 Broken Mirrors.

The author of the children's book Juggling With Gerbils is Brian Patten, not Pattern as he appeared in the book of the month review on page 15, G2, April 26.

We said in a story about school "sin bins" yesterday, page 11, that nearly 1,300 pupils are permanently excluded every year. The correct figure is nearly 13,000.

fields.headline: Pay scheme with poor performance
fields.trailText: James Mackenzie's clever anagram of performance-related pay for teachers ("mere end of year claptrap") should not be the last word (Letters, April 26). PRP is common in industry and is gradually being introduced into the public services. Research evidence offers six broad conclusions which should be helpful to those in charge of educational policymaking at all levels.
fields.body:
James Mackenzie's clever anagram of performance-related pay for teachers ("mere end of year claptrap") should not be the last word (Letters, April 26). PRP is common in industry and is gradually being introduced into the public services. Research evidence offers six broad conclusions which should be helpful to those in charge of educational policymaking at all levels.

First, given the inherent problem of measuring individual performance with objectivity, this weakens the search for a mutually acceptable link to pay. Second, though there is often employee enthusiasm for the principle of linking pay to performance, this soon fades given the perceived subjectivity of appraisers and the demotivation of those not awarded increases. Third, the growth of divisive attitudes can soon cancel out any early overall gains in performance. Fourth, even successful schemes find it difficult to sustain success over a long period. Fifth, given the above, there is a better case for rewarding group rather than individual performance. Sixth, appraisal interviews are often well-received but are much less so if linked to pay. Do Messrs Blair, Blunkett, Woodhead and their advisers know all this? If so, why are they forcing through PRP in schools?
Prof Brian Towers
Industrial Relations Journal
brian.towers@ntu.ac.uk

 David Blunkett and Estelle Morris clearly have a narrow conception of trade unionism. Those of us on the top of the main scale who feel a great need for a £2,000 rise but will not apply for the threshold and instead willingly strike to defeat it have the wider interests of education and our pupils at heart. Some of our colleagues may receive a pay lift in the next 12 months, but the consequences of performance-related pay will be bitterly divided staffrooms, more demoralised teachers and an even greater emphasis on "teaching to the test".
Patrick Murphy
Leeds

 I have been teaching for 20 years. I do not agree with PRP. If I apply and am successful in winning an extra £2,000, I intend to return it to my elected government. Will my union (NASUWT) back me?
Rich Dacosta
York

fields.headline: Surgeons try our patients
fields.trailText: I was appalled though not surprised to read Dr Dalrymple's patronising article (So, have you ever operated before? April 25). Late last year I survived (but only just) my first NHS treatment in nearly 40 years.
fields.body:
I was appalled though not surprised to read Dr Dalrymple's patronising article (So, have you ever operated before? April 25). Late last year I survived (but only just) my first NHS treatment in nearly 40 years. I suffered five cardiac arrests in 24 hours due to an "adverse drug reaction", or so I was informed after being rushed up to London after the first two. Three days later, when my life was still hanging by a thread and I was covered with wires in intensive care, the consultant reprimanded me for bad behaviour - he was accustomed to patients who said yes or no- he did not know how to respond to my questions. He then told me the arrests could have happened at any time, and were probably not caused by the drug. If doctors and consultants were more ready to level with their patients, we would be much less likely to embark on that hugely expensive and generally disastrous last resort, litigation.
Fay Godwin
Hastings

 As one of pensionable age, I just cannot wait until I have a minor medical condition, e.g. "coronary heart disease, stroke, dialysis", so that I can be treated in the virtual hospital of my own home proposed by Dera (Patients at home in virtual hospital, April 26). As I presumably shall not need washing, feeding or toileting, I can rot in my bed and, with a bit of luck, pass away unnoticed by my virtual consultant. What a boon and a blessing for the overstretched NHS and government funding thereof.
Chloe Baveystock
London

fields.headline: Well read
fields.trailText: One country has fulfilled all the pledges made at the 1990 World Education Forum. (Empty Assurances, April 26). In Cuba, according to Unesco last year, children enjoy the best education in Latin America.
fields.body:
One country has fulfilled all the pledges made at the 1990 World Education Forum. (Empty Assurances, April 26). In Cuba, according to Unesco last year, children enjoy the best education in Latin America. Next year is the 40th anniversary of the Cuban Literacy Campaign which eradicated illiteracy in less than 18 months. It was done by mobilising the entire country to the task under the slogan: Those who can't, learn! Those who can, teach!

Literacy brigades were organised to send groups of teachers out to the countryside in order to teach the peasantry. If the UN adopted the Cuban strategy worldwide, within a very short time the problem of illiteracy would be a thing of the past.
Enrico Signorelli
Cuba Solidarity Campaign

fields.headline: Knowing the score
fields.standfirst: An agent who represents both footballers and opera stars? It's not as far fetched as you might think
fields.trailText: An agent who represents both footballers and opera stars? It's not as far fetched as you might think.
fields.body:
Baffled by modern football, its prima-donna players and their tantrums? Think of opera, and it all makes sense. Of course, there's already a connection between them in the popular imagination, which may be summed up in two words: Nessun Dorma.

Everybody remembers the BBC coverage of the 1990 Italian World Cup, Pavarotti singing, the climax on the word vincero near the top of the tenor register. On the other hand, not everybody who thrilled to that special sound realised that it meant "I shall win", but that, as is so often the case with opera, hardly mattered. The message was clear: that football (like opera) was unashamedly emotional stuff, and that it somehow belonged (also like opera) to Italy.

With Athole Still, artist manager and promoter extraordinaire, the connection is much more than imaginary, because most of his clients do one or the other. It seems there's no real difference between placing a player at a football club or a singer at an opera house. "After all," he explains, "they're all performers, all capable of those moments of jaw-dropping skill."

Few are as well-placed to make this comparison: Athole, now in his 60s, has been both an international athlete (a swimmer) and an A-list lyric tenor in his time, so he has the professional trust of everyone on his books, from Bruce Ford (star of the recent Rossini Otello at the Royal Opera) to Gianluca Vialli.

The similarities between the two halves of Athole's business are reflected in the office space. Downstairs at his premises near Crystal Palace is an airy room with half a dozen desks: this is where the opera deals are done. In one corner is the football inner sanctum, where, one imagines, the really silly money can be made - 15% of it, anyway.

Upstairs in Athole's office, the symbiosis is total: incoming calls, which never stop, may be from La Scala or Old Trafford, and he is as likely to speak Italian as English. One conversation in particular sounds tantalising: "Look, all I can say at the moment is that Real Madrid, Arsenal and Chelsea are extremely interested." Notes are taken on the back of the intriguingly named Tactoboard, which looks like a child's drawing of a football pitch, photocopied and awaiting the stage directions of master strategists.

Athole wasn't surprised that the Three Tenors were such a hit at the World Cup. "Given the cultural climate of the time, something like it was bound to happen sooner or later." From New Laddism, in which watching football was nothing less than the exercise of aesthetic sensibility, it was a short step to more (shall we say) traditionally artistic forms. Since then, the beautiful game has had a makeover, mainly on account of satellite TV and its money, but with a certain post-Heysel, post-Bosman continental gloss.

Many would attribute this new gloss to the influence of Football Italia, now in its eighth season. There's no doubt Channel 4 packaged its coverage to appeal to commonly held ideas that all things Italian are stylish and expensive. What makes the Nessun Dorma phenomenon especially interesting, however, is that these ideas evolved from the fashion for Italian opera and singers, swooned over in this country as early as the 17th century. Enthusiasm for their exotic elegance reached fever pitch with the arrival in London - breaking all transfer records - of the great castrato, Farinelli. In the 1734-5 season, the new Italian up front was crucial to the triumph of the King's Theatre over its rivals at Covent Garden.

If the expensive imports Athole deals in (it was he who originally proposed Zola to Chelsea) have taken the place of the castrati, audiences' vacillation between worship and envy, and their harsh judgment of excess, remains. "In whatever discipline," Athole says, "talent is like a gene. You can't help it. Sometimes, the carrier of a talent finds it difficult to bear. That's where agents come in." Here, football has learnt from opera: "Singers have had their personal representatives for over 150 years. In Britain, it's only in the last five years or so that third parties have been officially permitted to negotiate on players' behalf."

But those players who do find the burden of their genius too much at times, and who do not benefit from the ministrations of an Athole Still, make the headlines every week. And perhaps what most brings football and opera together - separating them from the world of the merely rich and famous - is that they are both gladiatorial: superhuman talent, fleeting success, inevitable destruction. We watch our heroes keenly for signs of decay; Gascoigne no less than Callas felt the pressure of a public gaze unwilling to let the spectacle end at the final whistle or curtain. Both have suffered from consumption, as it were, like so many operatic heroines.

Juan from Barcelona phones. He has lost his Lohengrin for tomorrow night. This calls for the Tactoboard again: Alan Woodrow has just finished being Siegfried, so maybe he could step in. He'd be the very man to come off the bench and save the day - and he looks like Lohengrin, too: fresh-faced and Nordic. A Solskjaer for the stage, in fact.

 Dr Cormac Newark is research fellow in music at Trinity Hall, Cambridge.

fields.headline: Geezers with guns
fields.standfirst: British gangster movies have become havens for designer violence. Sam Delaney laments their demise
fields.trailText: British gangster movies have become havens for designer violence. Sam Delaney laments their demise
fields.body:
It is 1979. The depths of the London underworld. A flat-nosed fellow, built like an ape and dressed in a pinstriped suit, enters a bustling pub. He stands alone at one end of the bar wearing a menacing expression of barely controlled fury.

The other heavies in the pub recognise him as Harold Shand, terrifying crime overlord, and greet him with an appropriate mixture of reverence and fear. He smiles, knowing that he will soon have all of them hanging upside down from meat hooks in an abattoir.

Twenty-one years later and London's underworld is looking pretty much the same. Familiar-looking ruffians occupy an almost identically seedy pub. But one thing has changed. Bounding towards hard-nut HQ is a svelte, bronze-skinned young man with pretty, almost feline features. His hair is neatly gelled and he is wearing baggy jeans and a shiny tracksuit top that is undone to the midriff.

Surely this unsuspecting scamp has lost his way en route to the disco and will soon find himself unceremoniously redirected by the nasty types he is about to encounter in the pub? But wait... As he swaggers past the bomber-jacketed doormen, they greet him warmly with a nod of respect and the words: "Hello, Jude."

As it transpires, this Jude character is a distant successor to the late Harold Shand. He is, we are to discover, currently running the criminal activities of the capital with an iron rod. But it appears he has traded in the personal abattoir for some expensive home-tanning equipment. Has the London underworld really declined to such an extent over the last couple of decades?

If the cinema is to be believed, then yes. It was Bob Hoskins who portrayed Harold Shand in The Long Good Friday in the late 70s. His was a sinister, convincing performance in a complex and disturbing thriller. Its re-release next week will strike an unsympathetic contrast with the insufferable Brit-pack affair that is Love, Honour and Obey. In it, we are asked to suspend our disbelief while Jude Law portrays a scary villain, governing the sprawling mob of his even scarier Uncle Ray, played (naturally enough) by Ray Winstone.

It marks the trend - but probably not the end - of recent British movies that have sullied a tradition established by the likes of The Long Good Friday, by employing a new creative technique: the gangster flick by numbers. Forget real drama and characters you can believe in, these films have found that a moody soundtrack, sharp suits and a script laden with do-me-a-favour dialogue is enough to fill cinemas.

It is clear that, over the last couple of years, film companies have been falling over themselves to fund such ventures. Hence the current avalanche of films in which silly-billy cockneys call each other "slags" and make frequent threats to cut each others fingers orff. Hot on the heels of Love, Honour and Obey come Circus, with John Hannah, Essex Boys starring Sean Bean, Sexy Beast, with Ben Kingsley, and three of All Saints in Dave Stewart's Honest.

Who is to blame? Quite possibly Guy Ritchie, who, with the successful Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, reintroduced the gangster genre to the British film industry as a viable alternative to costume dramas. Apart from anything else, red-blooded British actors must have been desperate for roles with more potential for drama than a slap round the face with a handkerchief.

Lock, Stock brought some much needed action and adventure to British cinema: it had a twisted plot, a gag-per-minute-script and a lot of charismatic-looking blokes with quick-witted tongues.

But, other than its setting, it shared few similarities with the great British gangster films of the past. The Long Good Friday and Get Carter were bleak affairs that dealt with big, black themes of betrayal and paranoia. At their centre were complex characters who simmered with internal conflicts and eventually boiled over into dramatic violence.

In Get Carter, Michael Caine is trying to do what he believes is right by avenging the death of his brother. In the process, he sees himself do so much wrong that his calm exterior gradually crumbles, giving way to murderous rage.

In The Long Good Friday, Bob Hoskins endeavours to legitimise the activities of his corporation. But when a shadowy force begins to undermine his efforts, he finally gives in to the savagely violent instincts that made him king of the underworld in the first place.

Lock, Stock, on the other hand, depicts a man called Hatchet Harry, who, for a reason that is only thinly explained, beats a victim to death with a sex aid. There lies the key difference between gangster flicks new and old: they used to be fully rounded thrillers which, due to the nature of their setting, would inevitably involve elements of violence and black comedy. Nowadays, the plots are merely coat hangers for that violence and black comedy. It is as if film-makers have set out to devise a story that will conveniently accommodate some imaginative fighting techniques, cheeky cockney one-liners and very 60s design imagery.

As is so often the case, Quentin Tarantino is ultimately to blame. Before his rise, British gangster films were still trying to give honest accounts of a dark, fascinating world. The Krays was perhaps the last British gangster flick of the pre-Tarantino age. While it was guilty of excessive East End clichedom (Billie Whitelaw spent two-thirds of the proceedings scrubbing her doorstep and moaning about the war), it was a genuine attempt to dissect the strange inner workings of two legendary psychopaths.

What's refreshing about watching it now is that Gary and Martin Kemp's Kray twins are rather uncharismatic. The former new romantics were brooding and awe-inspiring but lacked the sparkling brashness possessed by Nick Moran in Lock, Stock or Jonny Lee Miller in Love, Honour and Obey. Deep down, one suspects that your average east end thug is far more likely to match the monosyllabic moodiness of the Kemps than the stand-up comic abilities of their gangster film successors.

It appears that screenwriters were seduced by the idea that Tarantino's wordy dialogue could be amusingly translated into cockney dialect. Knowing that the young male audiences they target like nothing more than to reel off choice lines to their mates in the pub, these film-makers kindly punctuate the de rigueur soundtrack CDs with quotations from their movies.

Tarantino started this trend with his Reservoir Dogs soundtrack. On it, we hear his clutch of talkative hoods analyse the meaning of Madonna's Like a Virgin. The words are as funny as they are implausible. In contrast, The Lock, Stock soundtrack separates tracks 12 and 14 with the voice of real-life hooligan Lenny McLean exclaiming simply: "Oh, you fackin' bastard."

The makers of Love, Honour and Obey were so enamoured of the marketability of a quote-friendly script that they emblazoned their promotional posters with a few of their favourite snatches of dialogue.

These snatches, as it happens, were largely stumbled upon by chance, thanks to the unconventional approach of co-directors Dominic Anciano and Ray Burdis. They issued their actors with the opening and closing lines of each scene and allowed them to ad lib the rest.

Unfortunately, most of their principal players were weedy theatrical types whose main points of reference are Primrose Hill gastro-pubs rather than rough-and-tumble south London boozers. Hence, the dialogue is more akin to an early episode of Grange Hill, with the likes of Sean Pertwee producing ill-conceived lines such as "Don't mac me off like a two-bob" in an unconvincing middle-class twang.

Of course, overestimating the wit and vocabulary of villains is not an entirely new feature of the gangster flick. When Hoskins's Harold Shand has his underworld rivals strung up in the sub-zero climes of his abattoir in The Long Good Friday, he makes it succinctly clear to them that, unless they give him the information he wants, they will be left there to freeze. "It's your decision," he tells them. "Verbals or frostbite!"

But while classics such as this and Get Carter are not short of funny moments, the characters invite you to laugh at them rather than with them. Michael Caine's Jack Carter is not what you might call a witty man but we laugh at his over-the-top attempts to be mysteriously cryptic.

"What's that gun doing in your room?" asks the landlady-cum-harlot he stays with in Newcastle.

"S'posing I called the police and told them that I had a man staying in my hotel who was planning to shoot somebody?"

"You wouldn't do that," Carter responds.

"How do you know I wouldn't?" she asks.

"Because I know you wear purple underwear," he smirks. "Think about it."

It's hard to imagine the current crop of gangster-impersonators delivering such lines with the same throwaway panache. In fact, such is the convoluted nature of their post-Tarantino scripts, most of them end up sounding more like Jim Davidson appearing in an episode of Blackadder. One can only dreadfully contemplate how Brad Pitt has handled such verbal manoeuvres in Ritchie's forthcoming Lock, Stock follow-up, Snatch.

It is likely that Snatch (scheduled for release in the autumn) will mark the temporary suspension of the British film industry's love affair with the underworld. This is good news for tired audiences but bad news for the likes of Jude Law, Sean Bean and Ray Winstone, who may soon be forced to exchange their gold chains and shooters for britches and handkerchiefs all over again.

 Circus and The Long Good Friday are released next Friday. Honest is out on May 26, and Gangster No 1 on June 16.

fields.headline: Deep and meaningless
fields.trailText: America's ill-fated and evil involvement with Vietnam came to its ignominious end a quarter-century ago this month. I remember my parents calling me inside to watch it happening live on television ("Instant history!" my dad shouted).
fields.body:
America's ill-fated and evil involvement with Vietnam came to its ignominious end a quarter-century ago this month. I remember my parents calling me inside to watch it happening live on television ("Instant history!" my dad shouted).

Saigon yielding to the NVA block by block, then suburb by suburb. Hysteria and raw panic inside the US embassy compound. Choppers rising from makeshift rooftop helipads with desperate Vietnamese hanging from the skids. And out at sea, groups of sailors pushing million-dollar jet-fighters and helicopters over the sides of overloaded aircraft-carriers.

Whenever I see that famous footage of a pilot ditching his Huey in the sea, and only just dodging the rotor blades as they carve up the water, I feel the same sickening lurch in the stomach I felt then. I didn't have much idea what had led to all this, but the images spoke eloquently enough of defeat, betrayal, dishonour and enormous waste (chucking airplanes away!).

You didn't have to understand: you saw the images - and you got the picture. I know now that it was the chickens coming home to roost, a whirlwind of iron and fire reaped tenfold, America's first military comeuppance, just one year short of its 200th birthday. Nice timing, if not quite as nice as the arrival of the bad news from Little Big Horn a century earlier. Word of that defeat arrived in Washington on July 4, 1876. Happy Birthday to us!

Those images burnt themselves into my memory forever, but during the anniversary last week it became apparent to me that the war has entirely slackened its hold on young Americans, who evidently think Vietnam is either the second planet beyond Neptune, or some dissident strain of the Feng Shui movement. History gets forgotten overnight here, and complex history doesn't stand a chance.

Vietnam now seems as remote and incomprehensible to the average 20-year-old as the War of Jenkins' Ear or Pickett's Charge. Perhaps this is why the second world war thriller U-571 was last week's most popular movie, and why the pro-military Rules of Engagement played to packed houses for three weeks in a row. At the dawn of the new millennium, Americans are more interested in the black and white moral certainties offered by the second world war, the Good War, than they are in whatever lessons might be drawn from America's first defeat.

This trend seems to have started with Saving Private Ryan, which was the second world war viewed through a scrim of Vietnam movies, and carried on with books like The Greatest Generation, written by the right-wing news anchorman Tom Brokaw, and movies like the upcoming Pearl Harbor. Is there a collective yearning for the good ol' days when Nazis were Nazis, commies were commies and all was right with the world, even if the world did happen to be in flames from pole to pole?

U-571 seems like evidence in support of that proposition. It's like Das Boot, but without the anti-war component - or the poop-deck drag queens, come to think of it. Writer-director Jonathan Mostow has taken a kernel of fact - the Royal Navy's discovery of an Enigma encryption machine on an abandoned U-Boat - and added an American cast, hot-looking Nazi uniforms, rivets popping at 300 metres under, depth-charge attacks and hellish claustrophobia.

It's firmly at the Where Eagles Dare end of the second world war movie spectrum, all guts, glory and derring-do on the high seas, a throwback to the uncomplicated days of Run Silent, Run Deep, The Enemy Below and The Cruel Sea.

And what's wrong with that? Mostow puts his cast into German uniforms so they can board a listing U-Boat, steal its encryptor, and then scuttle the sub and head for home. All fine and dandy, until a second U-Boat arrives on the scene and torpedoes the American vessel our heroes were planning to go home in, leaving them stranded on a shagged-out sub whose dials and instruments are all in German. The ensuing mayhem - including a toe-curling depth-charge offensive - makes the edge of one's seat carve a deep horizontal dent in one's bum.

It'll even make you forget about the weird cast. Matthew McConaughey, with his blonde buzz-cut, looks like the distillation of Ernst Rohm's dirtiest dreams of Aryan erotic perfection. Harvey Keitel gets to say the words, "I'm an old sea dog, me. I need my salt!" Jon Bon Jovi, of all people, makes an appearance, and so I'm told, does Confessions of a Driving Instructor star Robin Askwith (I couldn't spot him anywhere, though - he must have kept his trousers on). And low in the cast is someone going by the splendid name Jack Noseworthy.

Although it took Hollywood nearly 10 years to deal in a grown-up way with the war, Vietnam throbs like a demonic bassline beneath just about every movie made between Bonnie and Clyde and Raging Bull. It's quite stirring to see how un-black and white these movies look now, how complex and ambiguous, and when taken as a whole, how like a gigantic mural of history and politics.

In comparison U-571 is like a rollercoaster at Disneyland, designed to get you from A to B without doing any real thinking. It's unfair to compare it with, say, Who'll Stop the Rain or Cutter's Way - which are both about the poisonous aftermath of Vietnam - but watching the three of them in succession makes one yearn for some old-fashioned open-ended narrative, a dose of anti- heroism and a bucketful of doubt and ambiguity.

fields.headline: Angus MacFadyen
fields.trailText: What was the first film you saw at the cinema?
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw at the cinema?

Isadora, by Karel Reisz. I am still disturbed when Vanessa Redgrave is strangled as her scarf gets caught in the wheel of a Bugatti.

What's your favourite film?

Midnight Cowboy, a film about brotherhood between two of the strangest characters to have graced the screen.

When did you last walk out of the cinema and why?

I walk out often nowadays. Maybe I'm jaded but films aren't what they used to be. I walked out when Ben Stiller got his penis caught in his zipper in There's Something About Mary. That was enough for me.

What's the most erotic moment in a movie?

The feast in Babette's Feast.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

Staying because you paid.

When was the last time you snogged at the cinema?

Never. Films get my undivided attention. Until I walk.

Which actor would you most like to be?

I am what I am.

Which actress?

Liv Ullmann.

What's your favourite snatch of film dialogue?

The silence between the Tramp and the blind flower lady in City Lights, when she recognises his touch and says: "It's you." Chaplin smiles and nods with eyes lit up by tears.

When was the last time you cried in the movies?

There's Something About Mary.

When was the last time you hid under your seat?

Also There's Something About Mary.

What do you make of Greg Wise's success, seeing as he was in the same theatre club as you at university?

Not only Greg Wise, but also Hamish Clark. In fact, the three of us had a stand up routine called The Thunderbunnies back in the mid-80s, which we may resume in the near future.

 Angus McFadyen plays Orson Welles in Cradle Will Rock. Interview by Justina Hart.
